Kentucky]]\n[[Category:1968 establishments in Kentucky]]\n[[Category:Edmonton, Kentucky]]\n[[Category:Musical quartets]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Eric_Church","to":"Eric Church"}],"pages":{"4714852":{"pageid":4714852,"ns":0,"title":"Eric Church","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country singer-songwriter|bot=PearBOT 5}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Eric Church\n| image            = Eric Church 2012 Cropped.jpg\n| alt              = Photo of Eric Church performing live on stage\n| caption          = Church in 2012\n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = Kenneth Eric Church\n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1977|5|3}}\n| birth_place      = [[Granite Falls, North Carolina]], U.S.\n| origin           = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| instrument       = {{flatlist|\n* Vocals\n* guitar\n}}\n| genre            = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country music|Country]]<ref name=\"Spin\">{{cite journal|first=Jonathan|last=Bernstein|title=Review: Eric Church Retreats From the Dark Side on 'Mr. Misunderstood' |url=http://www.spin.com/2015/11/review-eric-church-mr-misunderstood/|journal=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|access-date=January 10, 2015|date=November 11, 2015}}</ref>\n* [[country rock]]\n* [[Southern rock]]\n}}\n| occupation       = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active     = 2005\u2013present\n| label            = {{flatlist|\n* [[Capitol Records Nashville|Capitol Nashville]]\n* [[Capitol Records Nashville|EMI Nashville]]\n* BigEC\n}}\n| website          = {{URL|ericchurch.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Kenneth Eric Church''' (born May 3, 1977) is an American [[country music]] singer-songwriter. He has released nine studio albums through [[Capitol Records Nashville|Capitol Nashville]] since 2005. His debut album, 2006's ''[[Sinners Like Me]]'', produced three singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts including the top 20 hits \"[[How 'Bout You]]\", \"[[Two Pink Lines]]\", and \"[[Guys Like Me]]\".\n\nHis second album, 2009's ''[[Carolina (Eric Church album)|Carolina]]'', produced three more singles: \"[[Smoke a Little Smoke]]\" and his first top 10 hits, \"[[Love Your Love the Most]]\" and \"[[Hell on the Heart]]\". 2011's ''[[Chief (album)|Chief]]'', his first No. 1 album, gave him his first two No. 1 singles, \"[[Drink in My Hand]]\" and \"[[Springsteen (song)|Springsteen]]\", and the hits \"[[Homeboy (Eric Church song)|Homeboy]]\", \"[[Creepin' (Eric Church song)|Creepin']]\", and \"[[Like Jesus Does]]\". His third No. 1 single was \"[[The Only Way I Know]]\", which he, [[Jason Aldean]], and [[Luke Bryan]] recorded for Aldean's album ''[[Night Train (Jason Aldean album)|Night Train]]''.\n\nA fourth album, ''[[The Outsiders (Eric Church album)|The Outsiders]]'', was released in February 2014. It produced five new singles between 2013 and 2015 with the [[The Outsiders (Eric Church song)|title track]], \"[[Give Me Back My Hometown]]\", \"[[Cold One]]\", \"[[Talladega (song)|Talladega]]\" and \"[[Like a Wrecking Ball]]\". \"Talladega\" and \"Give Me Back My Hometown\" each reached number one on the [[Country Airplay]] chart. Eric Church got his sixth No. 1 hit with [[Keith Urban]] in May 2015 with the single \"[[Raise 'Em Up]]\". His fifth studio album, ''[[Mr. Misunderstood]]'', was released in November 2015 and went on to produce two number one singles with \"[[Record Year]]\" and \"[[Round Here Buzz]]\". On July 13, 2018, Church released the first single and [[Desperate Man (song)|title track]] of his album ''[[Desperate Man (album)|Desperate Man]]'', which was released in October 2018. In April 2021, Church released the [[triple album]] set ''[[Heart & Soul (Eric Church album)|Heart & Soul]]''.\n\n==Early life==\nChurch was born on May 3, 1977, in [[Granite Falls, North Carolina]] (Dudley Shoals area), to Ken and Rita Church. Church worked with his father at Clayton Marcus, a furniture upholstery company where his father was president.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.furnituretoday.com/article/519425-pulaski-plans-eric-church-furniture-line|title=Pulaski plans Eric Church furniture line - Furniture Today|website=Furnituretoday.com|date=8 May 2015|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref> At 13, he bought a guitar and began writing songs of his own. By his senior year of high school, he had found a gig at a local bar, which occupied most of his time. He played many [[Jimmy Buffett]] cover songs and a few of his own original songs in some dive bars. Some of these places were so rough that he got into a few altercations from the stage. For a few years, the band played often in bars and restaurants throughout North Carolina.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} The band \"Mountain Boys\" consisted of his college roommate, brother, and a fellow guitarist.<ref name=\"allmusic\" />\n\nBefore moving to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], Eric graduated from [[South Caldwell High School]] and then [[Appalachian State University]] with a degree in [[marketing]].<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/301808/eric-church/biography |title=Eric Church biography\n|magazine=Billboard\n|access-date=2016-07-17 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820212033/http://www.billboard.com/artist/301808/eric-church/biography |archive-date=2016-08-20 }}</ref> Upon graduation, Church became engaged to a [[Spanish language|Spanish]] teacher in the town of [[Lenoir, North Carolina]]. The future bride's father attempted to persuade Church into a corporate career, which he rejected as an aspiring musician (and later referenced in his song \"What I Almost Was\" from his debut album). She broke the engagement and he headed to Nashville with his father's financial backing. His father also provided the opportunity to make contacts, and more importantly, time to focus on developing his songwriting ability.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}}\n\n==Music career==\n===2006\u20132010: ''Sinners Like Me'' and ''Carolina''===\nChurch co-wrote [[Terri Clark]]'s 2005 single \"The World Needs a Drink\",<ref name=\"allmusic\" /> and the track \"Whiskey Wings\" on [[Dean Miller]]'s 2005 album ''[[Platinum (Dean Miller album)|Platinum]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/platinum-mw0000208385|title=''Platinum'' review|last=Deming|first=Mark|work=Allmusic|access-date=29 August 2012}}</ref> He started recording with different producers. Capitol Nashville showed an interest and watched him perform but they were yet to be convinced enough to offer a recording contract.<ref name=\"hitquarters\">{{cite web |url=http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview/opar/intrview_AutumnH.html |title=Interview with Autumn House-Tallant |publisher=[[HitQuarters]] | date=3 Oct 2011 |access-date=6 October 2011}}</ref> Autumn House-Tallant told [[HitQuarters]] that they did not think his music was \"interesting\" enough.<ref name=\"hitquarters\" /> The record company's attitude changed after he started working with producer [[Jay Joyce]]. Doyle states, \"Eric scored a meeting with Nashville heavyweight Arthur Buenahora, a publisher at Sony Music who also signed [[Taylor Swift]] and [[Miranda Lambert]]. Church played him \"Lightning\", a ballad he wrote after watching the movie ''The Green Mile''\". (p. 5) The strong sound and direction the two forged together finally convinced Capitol Nashville that he was ready.<ref name=\"hitquarters\" /> His first single, \"[[How 'Bout You]]\" peaked at No. 14 on [[Hot Country Songs]] and led off his debut album ''[[Sinners Like Me]]''. In April 2006, he performed on the [[Grand Ole Opry]] for the first time.<ref name=\"cmtsinners\">{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1537741/eric-church-turns-heads-with-sinners-like-me.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607034411/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1537741/eric-church-turns-heads-with-sinners-like-me.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 7, 2011|title=Church Turns Heads With ''Sinners Like Me''|last=Morris|first=Edward|date=2006-08-02|work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]] | access-date=5 December 2009}}</ref>\n\nThe album's other two singles, \"[[Two Pink Lines]]\" and \"[[Guys Like Me]]\", both reached the Top 20 as well.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p816669/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Eric Church biography|last=Ruhlmann|first=William|work=[[Allmusic]] | access-date=2008-12-27}}</ref> The fourth single, the title track, peaked at No. 51. An additional track from the album, \"Lightning\", was made into a [[music video]] despite not being released as a single. Church wrote the song shortly after moving to Nashville, inspired by the movie ''[[The Green Mile (film)|The Green Mile]]''.<ref name=\"cmtsinners\" /> Following the album's success, Church toured with [[Brad Paisley]] and [[Rascal Flatts]].<ref name=\"cmtsinners\" /> Church was fired from opening for Rascal Flatts after repeatedly performing for longer than his allotted time, despite repeated warnings. He was replaced by Taylor Swift, who was just starting her career. Before Swift started the tour, Church and Swift spoke, where he told Swift that she would thrive on the tour and joked that she should give him her first gold record as a thanks. Swift later did give him her first gold record with an attached note that said \"Thanks for playing too long and too loud on the Flatts tour. I sincerely appreciate it. Taylor\".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/eric-church-rascal-flatts-tour-taylor-swift-secret-history/|title=How Eric Church's Rascal Flatts Feud Helped Launch Taylor Swift|first=Sterling WhitakerAnia|last=Hammar|website=Taste of Country|date=27 May 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/remember-when-taylor-swift-eric-church-gold-record/|title=Remember When Taylor Swift Gave Eric Church Her First Gold Record?|first=Billy|last=Dukes|website=Taste of Country|date=18 August 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tucson.com/entertainment/blogs/caliente-tuned-in/eric-church-s-taylor-swift-story/article_61cb6c52-5bd1-11e0-88bd-001cc4c002e0.html|title=Eric Church's Taylor Swift story|first=Cathalena E. Burch Arizona Daily|last=Star|website=Arizona Daily Star|date=31 March 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theboot.com/rascal-flatts-eric-church-fired-tour/|title=Rascal Flatts Comment on Firing Eric Church From Their Tour|first=Gayle|last=Thompson|website=The Boot|date=4 February 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theboot.com/eric-church-rascal-flatts-tour-secret-history-of-country-music/|title=Eric Church Deliberately Pushed Rascal Flatts' Buttons During 2006 Tour|first=Carena|last=Liptak|website=The Boot|date=27 May 2019 }}</ref>\n\nIn 2008, Church released a fifth single, \"His Kind of Money (My Kind of Love)\" to country radio. It debuted on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart at No. 55 in early 2008, and reached its peak of No. 46 in August. Originally slated as the lead single to an upcoming second album, \"His Kind of Money\" was instead included as a bonus track on albums sold at Best Buy. Following this song was \"[[Love Your Love the Most]]\", which debuted in early 2009 and was the first single from his second album ''[[Carolina (Eric Church album)|Carolina]]'', released in stores on March 24, 2009.<ref name=\"allmusic\" /> The night before the official release, Church and Capitol Records distributed copies of the album on the campus of Church's alma mater, Appalachian State University, during a \"release party\" concert.<ref name=\"goblueridge.net\">{{cite web | url = http://www.goblueridge.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5967&catid=1&Itemid=155 | title = Eric Church to Hold Album Release Party in Boone. | access-date = 2012-09-19 | url-status=dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130130075804/http://www.goblueridge.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5967&catid=1&Itemid=155 | archive-date = 2013-01-30 }}</ref> As with his debut album, ''Carolina'' was produced by Jay Joyce, and is entirely composed of songs that he co-wrote. \"Love Your Love the Most\" brought Church to the top 10 for the very first time, peaking at No. 10 in September 2009. The album's second single, \"[[Hell on the Heart]]\", debuted in October 2009 and would also hit the top 10 in May 2010. The third single from \"Carolina\" was \"[[Smoke a Little Smoke]]\". In June 2010, Church moved to Capitol Nashville's new imprint EMI Records Nashville, becoming their second artist. On January 14, 2011, he released a four-song EP entitled ''Caldwell County''.\n\n===2011\u20132015: ''Chief'' and ''The Outsiders''===\n[[File:Eric Church 2012 Cropped 2.jpg|thumb|alt=Photo of Eric Church on stage|Church performing live at GNA's Countryfest at the Times Union Center, Albany, New York, July 7, 2012]]\nChurch released \"[[Homeboy (Eric Church song)|Homeboy]]\" to country radio in early 2011. The album ''[[Chief (album)|Chief]]'', produced by Jay Joyce, was released July 26, 2011, debuting at No. 1 on both [[Top Country Albums]] and the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]].<ref name=\"Album source\">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/468392/eric-church-lands-first-no-1-album-amy-winehouse-continues-to-climb|title=Eric Church Lands First No. 1 Album, Amy Winehouse Climbs Into Top 5|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | access-date=August 3, 2011}}</ref><ref name=\":0\">{{Cite magazine|title = The Billboard Cover Story \u2013 The Gospel According to Eric Church: Thinking Global| magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |url = https://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/5812226/the-billboard-cover-story-the-gospel-according-to-eric-church-thinking|access-date = 2015-10-03}}</ref> The album sold 145,000 copies in its first week.<ref name=\"Album source\" /> On November 30, 2011, ''Chief'' was announced as a nominee for the 2012 Grammy Awards for Best Country Album. In January 2012 \"Drink in My Hand\" became his first No. 1 single. In February 2012, \"[[Springsteen (song)|Springsteen]]\" was released as the third single from ''Chief''. In an interview with [[American Songwriter]], Church stated that the song was about \"a love affair that takes place in an amphitheater between two people. It didn't happen with Springsteen, ironically, it happened with another artist.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2012/06/eric-church-springsteen/ |title=Eric Church, \"Springsteen\" |last=Giles |first=Jeff |date=11 June 2012 |publisher=American Songwriter |access-date=2012-06-11}}</ref> The song went on to become a No. 1 country hit, as well as his first Top 20 single on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. The album's fourth single, \"[[Creepin' (Eric Church song)|Creepin']]\", was released to country radio on July 16, 2012. Church lent his vocals for a song titled, \"[[The Only Way I Know]]\", with [[Jason Aldean]] along [[Luke Bryan]]. This song appears on Aldean's album ''[[Night Train (Jason Aldean album)|Night Train]]'', from which it was released as the second single. The fifth single from ''Chief'', \"[[Like Jesus Does]]\", was released in January 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/eric-church-like-jesus-does/ |title=Eric Church, 'Like Jesus Does' \u2013 Song Review |publisher=Taste of Country |access-date=February 13, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130302131929/http://tasteofcountry.com/eric-church-like-jesus-does/ |archive-date=March 2, 2013 |url-status=dead }}</ref> and peaked at number six on [[Country Airplay]] chart in June 2013.\n\nIn September 2012, Church announced that he planned to release his first live album in 2013, containing recordings of performances at the [[Tivoli Theatre (Chattanooga, Tennessee)|Tivoli Theatre]] in Chattanooga, Tennessee, on October 8 and 9, 2012.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.theboot.com/2012/09/04/eric-church-live-album/ | title=Eric Church Live Album to Hit Stores in 2013 | publisher=The Boot | date=September 4, 2012 | access-date=December 15, 2012}}</ref> On February 8, the live album's title was announced as ''Caught in the Act'', with a release date set for April 9.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/eric-church-caught-in-the-act-release-date/ |title=Eric Church Announces Release Date for First Live Album, 'Caught in the Act' |publisher=Taste of Country |date=February 8, 2013 |access-date=February 13, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130213083413/http://tasteofcountry.com/eric-church-caught-in-the-act-release-date/ |archive-date=February 13, 2013 |url-status=dead }}</ref>  Church has stated he plans to take some time off from music in 2013 to focus on his songwriting and musical direction.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.charlestoncitypaper.com/charleston/eric-church-rebels-against-the-music-city-machine/Content?oid=4246798 |title=Eric Church rebels against the Music City machine |publisher=Charleston City Paper |date=December 12, 2012 |access-date=December 15, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121215011233/http://www.charlestoncitypaper.com/charleston/eric-church-rebels-against-the-music-city-machine/Content?oid=4246798 |archive-date=December 15, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref> At the 2012 CMA Awards in November, Church's album ''[[Chief (album)|Chief]]'' won Album of the Year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/eric-church-album-of-the-year-2012-cma-awards/ |title=Eric Church Finally Finds His Niche, Wins Album of the Year Award at 2012 CMAs |publisher=Taste of Country |date=November 1, 2012 |access-date=December 15, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130109050200/http://tasteofcountry.com/eric-church-album-of-the-year-2012-cma-awards/ |archive-date=January 9, 2013 |url-status=dead }}</ref> In November it was announced that Church would co-headline [[Kenny Chesney]]'s No Shoes Nation Tour alongside Chesney, [[Zac Brown Band]], and [[Eli Young Band]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/kenny-chesney-2013-tour-no-shoes-nation/ |title=Kenny Chesney Announces 2013 No Shoes Nation Tour |publisher=Taste of Country |date=November 8, 2012 |access-date=December 15, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121115154253/http://tasteofcountry.com/kenny-chesney-2013-tour-no-shoes-nation/ |archive-date=November 15, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref> In December, Eric was honored as one of the CMT Artists of the Year Awards. His award was presented by [[Kid Rock]] and he received a video message of congratulations from [[Metallica]]'s [[James Hetfield]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1698588/2012-cmt-artists-year-revealed.jhtml |title=2012 CMT Artists of the Year Revealed |website=MTV.com |date=December 9, 2012 |access-date=December 15, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121212062555/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1698588/2012-cmt-artists-year-revealed.jhtml |archive-date=December 12, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nOn October 22, 2013, Church released a new single titled \"[[The Outsiders (Eric Church song)|The Outsiders]]\". His fourth studio album, also titled ''[[The Outsiders (Eric Church album)|The Outsiders]]'', was released on February 11, 2014.<ref>{{cite news|last=Talbott|first=Chris|title=Eric Church set to drop new album, 'The Outsiders,' blow minds at CMAs with metal moment|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/music/eric-church-set-to-drop-new-album-the-outsiders-blow-minds-at-cmas-with-metal-moment/2013/11/04/1bb43982-4554-11e3-95a9-3f15b5618ba8_story.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105034627/http://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/music/eric-church-set-to-drop-new-album-the-outsiders-blow-minds-at-cmas-with-metal-moment/2013/11/04/1bb43982-4554-11e3-95a9-3f15b5618ba8_story.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=November 5, 2013|access-date=November 5, 2013|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] | date=November 4, 2013}}</ref> This album, as with Church's previous three, was produced by Jay Joyce and released on the EMI Records Nashville label.<ref name=\":0\" /> It was followed in January 2014 by \"[[Give Me Back My Hometown]]\". This single reached number one on the [[Country Airplay]] chart, becoming his fourth overall. The third single, \"[[Cold One]]\", was released in June 2014, followed by \"[[Talladega (song)|Talladega]]\" in September. The latter reached number one on the Country Airplay chart in February 2015. The fifth single, \"[[Like a Wrecking Ball]]\", was released to country radio on March 9, 2015.\n\n===2015\u20132018: ''Mr. Misunderstood'' and ''Desperate Man''===\nOn November 3, 2015, Church's new surprise album, ''[[Mr. Misunderstood]]'', arrived in the mailboxes of his fan club members. The album became available to the public on iTunes the following day. The album was released as a surprise with no fanfare and no promotional advertisements. It was produced by Jay Joyce and executive producer Arturo Buenahora Jr. The first single, the [[Mr. Misunderstood (song)|title track]], was released to radio on November 9, 2015. The first live performance and debut of the track was at the 2015 CMA Awards. The song peaked at No. 15 on the airplay chart on February 6, 2016.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/301808/eric-church/chart?f%3D1244 |title=Eric Church - Chart history &#124; Billboard |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=2016-02-04 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160402033558/http://www.billboard.com/artist/301808/eric-church/chart?f=1244 |archive-date=2016-04-02}}</ref> \"[[Record Year (song)|Record Year]]\" is the album's second single. The album's final track, \"Three Year Old\", pays tribute to all the lessons Church has learned from his three-year-old son, who was also credited with naming Church's guitar \"ButterBean\". Church used \"ButterBean\" for the creation of the album.<ref>{{Cite magazine|title = Eric Church Releases Surprise Album 'Mr. Misunderstood'|url = https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/eric-church-releases-surprise-album-mr-misunderstood-20151104|magazine = Rolling Stone|date = 4 November 2015|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref> ''[[Mr. Misunderstood]]'' was nominated for Album of the Year at the 2016 [[ACM Awards]] and the [[Mr. Misunderstood (song)|title track]] was nominated for Video of the Year.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Eric Church leads the 2016 ACM Awards with 5 nominations \u2013 Eric Church|url = http://ericchurch.com/news/382683/eric-church-leads-the-2016-acm-awards-with-5-nomin|website = Eric Church|access-date = 2016-02-07|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160208011916/http://ericchurch.com/news/382683/eric-church-leads-the-2016-acm-awards-with-5-nomin|archive-date = 2016-02-08|url-status = dead}}</ref> ''[[Mr. Misunderstood]]'' features ten self-written and co-written tracks and features themes of independence, lessons learned, and loyalty. The album was recorded by Jason Hall at St. Charles in Nashville. In March 2016, \"Record Year\" was released to radio; it reached No. 1 on the Country Airplay in August 2016. The album's third single, \"[[Kill a Word]]\" released to country radio on August 29, 2016. Church was selected as one of 30 artists to perform on \"Forever Country\", a mash-up track of \"[[Take Me Home, Country Roads]]\", \"[[On the Road Again (Willie Nelson song)|On the Road Again]]\" and \"[[I Will Always Love You]]\" which celebrates 50 years of the [[CMA Awards]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/scenes-cmas-historic-music-video-featuring-30-country/story?id%3D42129062 |title=30 Country Music Stars Join Forces for Historic CMA Music Video, 'Forever Country' - ABC News |website=[[ABC News (United States)|ABC News]] |access-date=2016-09-17 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161115165209/http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/scenes-cmas-historic-music-video-featuring-30-country/story?id=42129062 |archive-date=2016-11-15 }}</ref>\n\nChurch played his biggest solo tour to date with his Holdin' My Own Tour that featured 62 shows in 61 cities from January through May 2017. The tour was capped off by two sold-out shows at Nashville's [[Bridgestone Arena]], with the Friday night show breaking the arena's capacity record before being one-upped by the Saturday night show which set of record of 19,020 attendees.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2017/05/28/eric-church-ends-tour-record-breaking-nashville-concert/347139001/ |title=Eric Church ends tour with record-breaking Nashville concert |website=[[The Tennessean]] |access-date=2018-07-14 }}</ref> On October 4, 2017, Church debuted a song he had written for Sonny Melton, who died in the [[2017 Las Vegas shooting|Las Vegas shooting]] tragedy. The song, called \"Why Not Me\", was performed at the Grand Ole Opry in Nashville.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kelley|first1=Caitlin|title=Eric Church Debuts New Song Dedicated to Las Vegas Shooting Victims at Grand Ole Opry|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/7989432/eric-church-new-song-las-vegas-shooting-victims-grand-ole-opry-show-video|access-date=11 October 2017|publisher=Billboard|date=5 October 2017}}</ref> In November 2017 Church released a limited run vinyl box set titled ''61 Days in Church'' that would be released in monthly stages through 2018.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/eric-church-releases-huge-61-days-in-church-live-set-w501112 |title=Eric Church Releases Huge '61 Days in Church' Live Set |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=2017-09-05 |access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1786110/eric-church-unveils-61-days-in-church/ |title=Eric Church Unveils 61 Days in Church |publisher=CMT |date=2017-01-09 |access-date=2017-11-14}}{{dead link|date=July 2024|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1786816/eric-churchs-new-61-days-in-church-release-covers-the-band-lynyrd-skynyrd-and-more/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170923005817/http://www.cmt.com/news/1786816/eric-churchs-new-61-days-in-church-release-covers-the-band-lynyrd-skynyrd-and-more/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 23, 2017 |title=Eric Church's New 61 Days in Church Release Covers The Band, Lynyrd Skynyrd and More |publisher=CMT |date=2017-09-22 |access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://theboot.com/eric-church-61-days-in-church-live-music/ |title=Eric Church Reveals '61 Days in Church' Live Collection |website=Theboot.com |date=September 2017 |access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref> The collection includes 124 tracks all of which were recorded live at the 61 shows of his 2017 Holdin' My Own Tour. The set includes two songs from each concert of the tour with the exception of the final two Nashville shows, which feature three songs from each night. He had already began releasing the album in stages for free on digital streaming services in September 2017. On July 12, 2018, Church announced via social media that he would release his sixth album, ''[[Desperate Man (album)|Desperate Man]]'', on October 5, 2018. He released the album's first single and [[Desperate Man (song)|title track]] the following day.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/ericchurch/status/1017397920142897152|title=Eric Church on Twitter|publisher=[[Twitter]]|access-date=5 October 2018}}</ref>\n\n===2020\u2013present: ''Heart & Soul''===\nOn November 11, 2020, Church won the Entertainer of the Year award at the [[54th Annual Country Music Association Awards]]. He performed \"[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]\" alongside [[Jazmine Sullivan]] at [[Super Bowl LV]]. On April 16, 2021, Church released the album ''[[Heart & Soul (Eric Church album)|Heart]]'', followed by the album ''[[Heart & Soul (Eric Church album)|&]]'', on April 20, and ''[[Heart & Soul (Eric Church album)|Soul]]'', on April 23. The triple-album release contains 24 songs in total, including the singles Heart On Fire and \"[[Hell of a View]]\".<ref>{{Cite magazine|first=Joseph|last=Hudak|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/eric-church-new-album-heart-and-soul-1117530/|title=Eric Church Is Releasing Three New Albums|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=January 21, 2021|access-date=March 4, 2021}}</ref> In October 2021, after two of his bandmates tested positive for [[COVID-19]], Church performed two solo concerts on his The Gather Again Tour. The solo shows were in Pittsburgh on October 8 and Philadelphia on October 9.<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Nicholson|first=Jessica|title=Eric Church Sets 2 Solo Shows After Bandmates Test Positive for COVID-19|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/9643045/eric-church-band-covid-solo-concerts/|date=October 8, 2021|access-date=October 10, 2021|magazine=Billboard}}</ref> On February 22, 2022, Church was announced to perform at the 57th [[Academy of Country Music Awards]] on March 7, 2022.<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Grein|first=Paul|title=Carrie Underwood, Eric Church & More Added to 2022 ACM Awards' Performance Roster|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/awards/2022-acm-awards-performers-roster-additions-1235034492/|date=February 22, 2022|access-date=February 23, 2022|magazine=Billboard}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nOn January 8, 2008, Church married music publisher Katherine Blasingame at West Glow Resort in [[Blowing Rock, North Carolina]]. At the wedding, Church performed \"You Make It Look So Easy\", a song he wrote for Blasingame. On October 3, 2011, their first son, Boone McCoy Church, was born;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2011/10/06/eric-church-welcomes-son-boone-mccoy/ |title=Eric Church Welcomes Son Boone McCoy \u2013 Moms & Babies \u2013 Celebrity Babies and Kids \u2013 Moms & Babies \u2013 People.com |website=Celebritybabies.people.com |date=2012-03-22 |access-date=2014-02-11 |archive-date=2014-02-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222051309/http://celebritybabies.people.com/2011/10/06/eric-church-welcomes-son-boone-mccoy/ |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theboot.com/2011/03/24/eric-church-wife-baby/ |title=Eric Church Baby News Brings 'Two Pink Lines' Full Circle |website=Theboot.com |date=2011-04-19 |access-date=2014-02-11}}</ref> he is the subject of Church's song \"Three Year Old\". On February 15, 2015, their second son, Tennessee Hawkins \"Hawk\" Church was born.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.etonline.com/music/159992_eric_church_welcomes_second_son_tennessee_hawkins |title=Eric Church Welcomes Second Son Tennessee Hawkins  |website=Etonline.com |date=2015-02-19 |access-date=2015-02-20}}</ref> Their home (along with Church's \"[[man cave]]\"), located in Nashville, was featured in an episode of [[Country Music Television|CMT]]'s ''Cribs''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1579702/eric-church-marries-in-north-carolina.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091223035514/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1579702/eric-church-marries-in-north-carolina.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 23, 2009|title=Eric Church Marries in North Carolina|date=January 15, 2008|access-date= February 27, 2010|publisher=CMT News}}</ref>\n\nThe Chief Cares Fund is a foundation organized by Eric and Katherine Church in 2013. The non-profit organization has been used to help underprivileged families in Tennessee, North Carolina, and even as far as helping orphans in Nepal receive clothing, proper bedding, and schooling. The foundation has also delivered Bibles to Haiti and helps fund Humane Society no-kill animal shelters. People can donate to the foundation on Eric Church's website by simply donating or by purchasing exclusive Chief Cares Platinum Tickets to his concerts where money from the tickets go to the Chief Cares Fund.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Chief Cares \u2013 Eric Church|url = http://ericchurch.com/chiefcares|website = Eric Church|access-date = 2016-02-07}}</ref>\n\nIn November 2022, North Carolina Governor [[Roy Cooper]] awarded Church the North Carolina Award, the state's highest civilian honor.<ref>{{Cite web |title=North Carolina Awards {{!}} NC DNCR |url=https://www.ncdcr.gov/about/special-programs/north-carolina-awards |access-date=2022-11-22 |website=Ncdcr.gov |language=en}}</ref>\n\nChurch wears his signature aviator sunglasses as a result of wearing contact lenses. When his career was getting started, he was forced to deal with the heat from the stage lights drying out his contacts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fwo51o6xsTA| archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211113/fwo51o6xsTA| archive-date=2021-11-13 | url-status=live|title=Eric Church talks sunglasses inside & Blake Shelton beef| website=[[YouTube]]}}{{cbignore}}</ref> As he began performing in larger venues, his aviators and [[Von Dutch]] denim trucker hat became his trademark.\n\nChurch has become an avid advocate for the use of [[cannabis]], reflected in songs such as \"[[Smoke a Little Smoke]]\"; at the time of that song's release, Church's record label urged him not to release the song, though it had minor success as a single.<ref>{{cite web|author=Eric Church / |url=http://ericchurch.com/forum/eric-church-blazes-his-own-path |title=Eric Church blazes his own path |access-date=2014-02-11 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105031439/http://ericchurch.com/forum/eric-church-blazes-his-own-path |archive-date=November 5, 2013 }}</ref> Church has also referenced marijuana use in other songs like \"The Joint\" and \"I'm Gettin' Stoned\", and has even been the subject of a marijuana joke at the 49th ACM Awards where [[Blake Shelton]] and [[Luke Bryan]] referred to Eric Church as the [[Willie Nelson]] for the new-country generation and compared Eric Church's dressing room to a cannabis dispensary.\n\nChurch opened Chief's, a bar, restaurant, and performance venue in downtown Nashville in April 2024.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/pamwindsor/2024/04/05/eric-church-on-chiefs-and-the-special-partnership-behind-his-new-nashville-bar--music-venue/|title=Eric Church & Developer Ben Weprin On The Partnership Behind \u2018Chief\u2019s\u2019 - Nashville\u2019s Newest Downtown Bar|first=Pam|last=Windsor|website=Forbes.com}}</ref>\n\n==Musical styles==\nChurch's style has been described as [[country rock]], [[outlaw country]], and [[southern rock]]. Church's influences include [[Hank Williams Jr.]], [[Merle Haggard]], [[Little Feat]], [[The Band]], [[Kris Kristofferson]], [[The Grateful Dead]], [[Ray Wylie Hubbard]] and [[Waylon Jennings]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/|title=MSN &#124; Outlook, Office, Skype, Bing, Breaking News, and Latest Videos|website=Msn.com}}</ref> Church has also said that many [[hard rock]] and [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]] bands influenced his music, including [[Metallica]] and [[AC/DC]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dhNQj96pLMo | archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211113/dhNQj96pLMo| archive-date=2021-11-13 | url-status=live|title=Eric Church \u2013 Musical Influences |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date=2012-01-30 |access-date=2014-02-11}}{{cbignore}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Eric Church discography}}\n'''Studio albums'''\n* ''[[Sinners Like Me]]'' (2006)\n* ''[[Carolina (Eric Church album)|Carolina]]'' (2009)\n* ''[[Chief (album)|Chief]]'' (2011)\n* ''[[The Outsiders (Eric Church album)|The Outsiders]]'' (2014)\n* ''[[Mr. Misunderstood]]'' (2015)\n* ''[[Desperate Man (album)|Desperate Man]]'' (2018)\n* ''[[Heart & Soul (Eric Church album)|Heart & Soul]]'' (2021)\n\n==Tours==\n;Headlining\n* J\u00e4germeister Country Tour (2010)<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/eric-church-to-headline-the-2010-jagermeister-country-music-tour-80798327.html|title=Eric Church To Headline The 2010 Jagermeister Country Music Tour \u2013 NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 6 /PRNewswire/|website=Prnewswire.com|access-date=2014-02-11}}</ref>{{better source needed|reason=PR Newsire is considered an unreliable source|date=April 2022}}\n* Blood, Sweat and Beers Tour (2012\u201313)\n* The Outsiders World Tour (2014\u201315)\n* [[Holdin' My Own Tour]] (2017)\n* Double Down Tour (2019)\n* Gather Again Tour (2021\u201322)<ref>{{Cite web|title=ERIC CHURCH SETS GATHER AGAIN TOUR DATES FOR FALL OF 2021|date=7 April 2021 |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/eric-church-2021-gather-again-tour-dates/|website=Tasteofcountry.com}}</ref>\n* Outsiders Revival Tour (2023)\n{{col-begin}}\n{{col-2}}\n;Supporting\n* Me and My Gang Tour (2006) with [[Rascal Flatts]]\n* Rowdy Friends Tours (2010) with [[Hank Williams Jr]]\n* CMT Revolution Tour (2010) with [[Miranda Lambert]]\n* Roadside Bars and Pink Guitars (2010) with Miranda Lambert\n* My Kinda Party Tour (2011) with [[Jason Aldean]]\n* Locked and Loaded Tour (2011) with [[Toby Keith]]\n* [[No Shoes Nation Tour]] (2013) with [[Kenny Chesney]]\n* Locked and Reloaded Tour (2013) with [[Dierks Bentley]] and Miranda Lambert\n{{col-end}}\n\n===Band members===\n'''Current members'''\n* Eric Church \u2013 lead vocals, rhythm guitar, acoustic guitar, banjo, piano\n* Driver Williams \u2013 lead guitar, rhythm guitar\n* [[Jeff Cease]] \u2013 rhythm guitar, lead guitar\n* Jeff Hyde \u2013 acoustic guitar, banjo, background vocals\n* Lee Hendricks \u2013 bass guitar\n* Craig Wright \u2013 drums\n* [[Jay Joyce]] \u2013 production\n\n'''Former members'''\n*[[Joanna Cotten]] - vocals (2013\u20132022)<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.savingcountrymusic.com/end-of-an-era-joanna-cotten-leaves-eric-churchs-band/ | title=End of an Era: Joanna Cotten Leaves Eric Church's Band|website=Savingcountrymusic.com | date=August 2022 }}</ref>\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Koe_Wetzel","to":"Koe Wetzel"}],"pages":{"68101377":{"pageid":68101377,"ns":0,"title":"Koe Wetzel","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Koe Wetzel\n| image             = Koe Wetzel in 2017.png\n| caption           = Wetzel in 2017\n| birth_name        = Ropyr Madison Koe Wetzel\n| birth_place       = [[Pittsburg, Texas]]\n| birth_date        = {{Birth date and age|1992|07|14}}\n| genre             = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country rock]]\n* [[alternative country]]\n* [[alternative rock]]\n* [[outlaw country]]\n* [[hard rock]]\n* [[grunge]]<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web|last=Stefano|first=Angela|date=2020-11-20|title=Interview: Koe Wetzel Sticks to His Guns on First Major-Label Album, 'Sellout'|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/koe-wetzel-sellout-album-interview-2020/|access-date=2021-07-01|website=Taste of Country|language=en}}</ref>\n* [[post-grunge]]}}\n| website           = {{URL|https://koewetzelmusic.com/}}\n| associated_acts   = Koe Wetzel and the Konvicts\n}}\n\n'''Ropyr Madison Koe Wetzel'''<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web|last=Durchholz|first=Daniel|title=Outlaw country artist Koe Wetzel has moved to a major label, but don't call him a sellout|url=https://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/music/outlaw-country-artist-koe-wetzel-has-moved-to-a-major-label-but-dont-call-him/article_42c37a67-cce1-5cd1-9387-024c5bcbd46d.html|access-date=2021-07-01|website=STLtoday.com|date=16 June 2021 |publisher=[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]|language=en}}</ref> (born July 14, 1992)<ref>{{Cite web|title=Koe's Black & Red Birthday Bash|url=https://dailytexascountry.com/posts/koes-black-&-red-birthday-bash|access-date=2021-07-01|website=dailytexascountry.com|language=en}}</ref><ref name=\":2\" /> is an American singer and songwriter. His music has been described variously as a \"blend of rock and country\",<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite web|last=Nicholson|first=Jessica|date=2021-06-22|title=Texas Artist Koe Wetzel Talks His First Major Label Album: \"We're Not Going To Change for Anybody\"|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1835312/texas-artist-koe-wetzel-talks-his-first-major-label-album-were-not-going-to-change-for-anybody/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210623010011/http://www.cmt.com/news/1835312/texas-artist-koe-wetzel-talks-his-first-major-label-album-were-not-going-to-change-for-anybody/|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 23, 2021|access-date=2021-07-01|website=CMT News}}</ref> [[outlaw country]],<ref>{{Cite web|last=Kent|first=Roy|date=2021-06-04|title=Country music artist Koe Wetzel to perform July 3 at Constellation Field in Sugar Land|url=https://www.houstonchronicle.com/neighborhood/sugarland/article/Country-music-artist-Koe-Wetzel-to-perform-July-3-16225144.php|access-date=2021-07-01|website=Houston Chronicle|language=en-US}}</ref> and \"fusing country and [[grunge]]\".<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web|last=Stefano|first=Angela|date=2020-11-20|title=Interview: Koe Wetzel Sticks to His Guns on First Major-Label Album, 'Sellout'|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/koe-wetzel-sellout-album-interview-2020/|access-date=2021-07-01|website=Taste of Country|language=en}}</ref>\n\n== Life and career ==\nWetzel was born in [[Pittsburg, Texas]], with one of his names being a reference to outlaw country singer-songwriter [[David Allan Coe]].<ref name=\":0\" /> His mother was a touring country singer, bringing the young Koe along and his father worked in construction. He would perform on stage for the first time at age six.<ref name=\":4\" /> Later, Wetzel was a [[linebacker]] at [[Tarleton State University]] in [[Stephenville, Texas]], where he decided to pursue a career as a musician instead.<ref name=\":0\" />\n\nWetzel formed \"Koe Wetzel and Konvicts\", and self-released an EP and one full-length album. His \"rowdy\" music and lyrics became popular among college students and young adults, and ''Noise Complaint,'' released in 2016, was considered to be his breakout album.<ref name=\":4\">{{Cite web|last=Deming|first=Mark|title=Koe Wetzel: Biography & History|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/koe-wetzel-mn0003724456/biography|access-date=2021-07-02|website=AllMusic|language=en}}</ref> Beginning with ''Noise Complaint'', the full name of the band was dropped, though Wetzel still performs with a bassist, one drummer, and two guitarists.<ref>{{Cite web|title=KOE WETZEL|url=https://www.chilifest.org/koe-wetzel/|access-date=2021-07-02|website=Chilifest 2020 Official Website|language=en-US}}</ref> The band signed with Red 11 Music in Austin, TX in early 2018 while being managed by 4-Tay Management out of Stephenville, TX until 2019 when the band signed a management deal with Floating Leaf Entertainment, establishing a joint venture between Wetzel and Jeb Hurt who had previously been the band's agent at Red 11 Music.\n\n''Harold Saul High'' was released in 2019 to mixed reviews,<ref>{{Cite web|last=Trigger|date=2019-06-24|title=Album Review \u2013 Koe Wetzel's \"Harold Saul High\"|url=https://www.savingcountrymusic.com/album-review-koe-wetzels-harold-saul-high/|access-date=2021-07-02|website=Saving Country Music|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Fox|first=Chris|date=2019-06-19|title=Koe Wetzel Earns High Marks in \"Harold Saul High\" {{!}}|url=http://texasmusicpickers.com/koe-wetzel-earns-high-marks-in-harold-saul-high/|access-date=2021-07-02|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Kephart|first=Zackary|date=2019-06-27|title=Album Review: Koe Wetzel \u2013 'Harold Saul High'|url=https://themusicaldivide.com/2019/06/27/album-review-koe-wetzel-harold-saul-high/|access-date=2021-07-02|website=The Musical Divide|language=en}}</ref> however sales were strong, and the album charted on the [[Billboard 200]].<ref name=\":3\" />\n\nIn 2020, Wetzel released ''Sellout'', named in reference to his signing with major label [[Columbia Records]].<ref name=\":5\">{{Cite web|date=2020-12-01|title=Koe Wetzel Reassures the Masses That He'll Never Change on 'Sellout'|url=https://americansongwriter.com/koe-wetzel-reassures-the-masses-that-hell-never-change-on-sellout/|access-date=2021-07-02|website=American Songwriter|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nIn 2023, Wetzel became<ref>{{Cite web|date=2023-01-19|title=Fort Worth hospitality vets partner with musician Koe Wetzel on new country venue|url=https://fortworth.culturemap.com/news/restaurants-bars/koe-wetzel-riot-room-emil-bragdon/|access-date=2024-05-08|website=CultureMap Fort Worth|language=en-US}}</ref> a partner in the opening of a highly successful restaurant-bar and live music review in Fort Worth, Texas called Koe Wetzel's Riot Room.\n\n== Musical style ==\nWetzel's music is usually described as fusing genres, especially rock and country while he has been rumored to personally refer to his blend of music as \"Hillbilly Punk-Rock\". In his youth, Wetzel was exposed to country, hip-hop, rap, and grunge including the music of [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]]. In an interview for ''[[American Songwriter]]'', Wetzel described his album ''Harold Saul High'' as \"...90s country meets early 2000s [[punk rock]] with early \u201990s [[grunge]] and [[Hip hop music|hip-hop]] music in the background.\"<ref name=\":5\" />\n\nHis lyrics often deal with mature subject matter, and are known for containing explicit language.<ref name=\":1\" /> One example is the song \"February 28, 2016\": a song about drunkenness, and a reference to his arrest for [[public intoxication]] in Stephenville on that day.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Langeler|first=Wes|date=2021-02-28|title=Happy February 28th, AKA Koe Wetzel Day|url=https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2021/02/28/happy-february-28th-aka-koe-wetzel-day/|access-date=2021-07-01|website=Whiskey Riff|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nIn 2019, Wetzel's performance at the [[Great Texas Balloon Race]] was the subject of some controversy, after some festival goers were offended at his refusal to make his songs more family friendly. Wetzel responded in a [[Tongue-in-cheek|tongue in cheek]] manner, taking credit for breaking attendance records.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2019-07-30|title=Koe Wetzel throws shade at Great Texas Balloon Race over apology|url=https://www.ketk.com/news/local-news/koe-wetzel-throws-shade-at-great-texas-balloon-race-over-apology/|access-date=2021-07-01|website=KETK.com {{!}} FOX51.com|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n\n=== Studio albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center\"\n|+ List of studio albums, with selected details and Gold<ref name=\"RIAA\" />\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Oklahoma Sun\"\n| \u2014 || \u2014 || 28\n|\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Sad Song\"\n| \u2014 || \u2014 || 34\n|\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Depression & Obsession\"\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2024\n| \u2014 || \u2014 || 36\n|\n| ''9 Lives''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Casamigos\"\n| \u2014{{efn|group=upper-alpha|\"Casamigos\" did not enter the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, but peaked at number 16 on the Bubbling Under Hot 100 chart.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/bubbling-under-hot-100-singles/2024-09-28/|title=Bubbling Under Hot 100: Week of September 28, 2024|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=September 24, 2024}}</ref>}} || 34 || \u2014\n|\n| {{Non-album single}}\n|}\n\n== Notes ==\n{{notelist-ua}}\n\n== References ==\n{{reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n* [https://koewetzelmusic.com/ Koe Wetzel's website]\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Wetzel, Koe}}\n[[Category:1992 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Texas]]\n[[Category:American rock songwriters]]\n[[Category:People from Pittsburg, Texas]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American alternative rock singers]]\n[[Category:American alternative country singers]]\n[[Category:Post-grunge musicians]]\n[[Category:Grunge musicians]]\n[[Category:American country rock singers]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Texas]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_Wolfe_Brothers","to":"The Wolfe Brothers"}],"pages":{"42980017":{"pageid":42980017,"ns":0,"title":"The Wolfe Brothers","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Australian country duo}}\n{{For|the street gang of the same name|Indian Posse}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=July 2014}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = The Wolfe Brothers\n| image           = Wolfe Brothers.jpg\n| alt             = \n| caption         = The Wolfe Brothers in 2016\n| origin          = [[Longley, Tasmania]], Australia\n| years_active    = 2010\u2013present\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[country rock]]}}\n| label           = [[Bertelsmann Music Group|BMG]]\n| current_members =\n* Tom Wolfe\n* Nick Wolfe\n| past_members    =\n* Casey Kostuik\n* Brodie Rainbird\n| website         = {{URL|http://www.thewolfebrothers.com}}\n}}\n'''The Wolfe Brothers''' are an Australian [[country music]] duo consisting of brothers Tom and Nick Wolfe. The group formerly included childhood friends Brodie Rainbird and Casey Kostiuk. The Wolfe Brothers rose to prominence after placing second in [[Australia's Got Talent (season 6)|season six]] of ''[[Australia's Got Talent]]''.\n\n==Career==\n===Early years to 2012: Formation and ''Australia's Got Talent''===\nTom and Nick Wolfe grew up on a small berry farm outside [[Hobart, Tasmania]]. Their father Malcolm and uncle Tony played in a band with their parents, called ''The Wolfe Family Orchestra''.<ref name=\"ABC Emily\">{{cite web|url= https://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-07-21/wolfe-brothers-berry-farming-country-music-in-a-days-work/8726552 |title= The Wolfe Brothers take on second family legacy to combine berry farming with country music|website=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=21 July 2017|access-date=23 February 2023 |author= Emilie Gramenz}}</ref>\n\nNick Wolfe says, \"We come from four generations of farmers and musicians.\" Their father guided Nick to the guitar and Tom to the piano, perhaps with \"the intention of starting a band with us\". Their mother filled the family home with music, exposing her children to 1990s country staples like [[Garth Brooks]] and [[Billy Ray Cyrus]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://musictasmania.org/connect/artists/wolfe-brothers |title= The Wolfe Brothers |website=Music Tasmania| access-date=23 February 2023}}</ref>\n\nThe Wolfe Brothers were formed by brothers Nick (guitar and vocals) and Tom Wolfe (bass and vocals), Brodie Rainbird (guitar) and Casey Kostiuk (drums).<ref>{{cite web|url= https://tinselandtapshoes.com/2017/05/08/thoughts-on-lee-kernaghan-25th-anniversary-tour/|title= THOUGHTS ON LEE KERNAGHAN \u2013 25TH ANNIVERSARY TOUR |website=Tinsel and Tap Shoes|date=May 2017|access-date=23 February 2023}}</ref><ref name=\"ABC Emily\"/> During their high school years all four played in different bands, covering songs by their glam rock and heavy metal music heroes. After leaving school they formed ''The Wolfe Brothers'', and for six years played covers in pubs and clubs across Tasmania.<ref name=\"ICCMM\">{{cite web|url=https://www.lccmm.com.au/the-wolfe-bros/|website=ICCMM| title=The Wolfe Bros.|date=19 November 2018|access-date=23 February 2023}}</ref>\n\nIn May 2010, The Wolfe Brothers self-released a self-titled debut EP.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/au/album/the-wolfe-brothers-ep/1440862650|title= The Wolfe Brothers EP|website=Apple Music|date=May 2010|access-date=18 April 2020}}</ref>\n\nIn 2012, The Wolfe Brothers auditioned for the [[Australia's Got Talent (season 6)|sixth season]] of [[Australia's Got Talent]], where they placed second behind [[Andrew De Silva]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kixcountry.com.au/hottest-country-news/44377-the-wolfe-brothers-perform-in-studio|title=The Wolfe Brothers dropped by the studios for a chat.|website=Kix Country|date=2013|access-date=23 February 2023}}</ref>\n\n===2013\u20132019: ''It's On'' to ''Country Heart''===\n[[File:The Wolfe Brothers with Big Stu & MJ.jpg|alt=The Wolfe Brothers pose for a photo with radio hosts Big Stu & MJ|thumb|The Wolfe Brothers posing for a photo with radio hosts [[Planet Country with Big Stu & MJ|Big Stu and MJ]] during the 2018 [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]].]]\n\nIn January 2013, The Wolfe Brothers released their debut studio album ''It's On'', which peaked at number 18 on the [[ARIA Charts]]. The album spawned three county top 10 singles, including their first #1 song and #1 video \"The Girl, The Bottle, The Memory\".<ref name=\"ICCMM\"/>\n\nThe Wolfe Brothers were special guests on [[Lee Kernaghan]]'s 2013\u20132014 ''Beautiful Noise Tour''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=James|title=Wolfe Brothers to support \"real gentleman\" Kernaghan for Bunbury gig|url=http://www.bunburymail.com.au/story/2266317/wolfe-brothers-to-support-real-gentleman-kernaghan-for-bunbury-gig/|access-date=6 June 2014|publisher=Bunbury Mail|date=7 May 2014}}</ref>\n\nAt the 2014 [[Country Music Awards of Australia]], The Wolfe Brothers were nominated for four awards and won the New Australian Artist of the Year at the [[CMC Music Awards]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Martain|first1=Tim|title=Tassie band Wolfe Brothers win major Country Music Channel award|url=http://www.themercury.com.au/news/tasmania/tassie-band-wolfe-brothers-win-major-country-music-channel-award/story-fnj4f7k1-1226855612710|access-date=6 June 2014|publisher=The Mercury|date=16 March 2014}}</ref><ref name=\"DM Mar14\"/>\n\nIn September 2014, The Wolfe Brothers released their second studio album, ''Nothin' But Trouble'', which peaked at number 13 on the ARIA Charts. The album spawned the single \"That Kinda Night\", which reached number 1 on the country singles chart.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://countrytrackschart.com.au/index.php?chartid=24|title=Country Songs Top 40 Australian Airplay Chart|website=countrytrackschart.com.au|access-date=15 July 2019}}</ref> The album's second and third singles, \"You Got to Me\" and \"Born and Bred\" became the group's third and fourth number 1 on the country charts and the CMC video chart.<ref name=\"ICCMM\"/>\n\nIn September 2015, a live album titled ''Live at CMC Rocks QLD 2015'' was released.<ref name=\"ICCMM\"/>\n\nThe group supported Kernaghan on his 2015 ''The Songs and the Stories Tour''. Tom Wolfe later saying, \"Touring with Lee has been a dream come true for us. He has taught us so much and it is still a little surreal to look across the stage and realise we are actually performing with one of our childhood heroes \u2013 the great Lee Kernaghan\".<ref name=\"ICCMM\"/>\n\nIn June 2016, the group released their third studio album, ''This Crazy Life'' album, which peaked at number 10 on the ARIA charts. The album was recorded in Nashville, USA over three months between November 2015 and February 2016 under the guidance of producer Luke Wooten.<ref name=\"ICCMM\"/>\n\nIn 2016, The Wolfe Brothers were nominated in three categories in the CMC Music Awards, winning the CMC Group of the Year Award; their second CMC Award.<ref name=\"ICCMM\"/><ref name=\"Knox\"/>\n\nLate in 2016, Nick and Tom's father, Malcolm died of cancer.<ref name=\"ABC Emily\"/>\n\nIn 2017 they recorded the single \"Damn Good Mates\" with Lee Kernaghan for Kernaghan's ''[[The 25th Anniversary Album (Lee Kernaghan album)|25th Anniversary Album]]''. In 2017 The Wolfe Brothers won Australian Group/Duo of the Year at the [[Planet Country with Big Stu & MJ|Planet Country's]] Music for a New Generation Awards.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.planetcountryradio.com.au/mfang-awards-2017|title=Planet Country Radio Show|website=Planet Country Radio Show|access-date=30 October 2018}}</ref>\n\nIn April 2018, the group released their fourth studio album ''Country Heart'', which peaked at number 9 on the ARIA Charts. The singles \"Ain't Seen It Yet\" and \"Country Heart\" both reaching number 1 on the country singles chart.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://countrytrackschart.com.au/index.php?chartid=208|title=Country Songs Top 40 Australian Airplay Chart|website=countrytrackschart.com.au|access-date=15 July 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://countrytrackschart.com.au/index.php?chartid=270|title=Country Songs Top 40 Australian Airplay Chart|website=countrytrackschart.com.au|access-date=15 July 2019}}</ref>\n\nAt the 2019 [[Country Music Awards of Australia]], the group won including Album of the Year, Contemporary Country Album of the Year, Group or Duo of the Year and  Song of the Year with \"Ain't Seen It Yet\".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/here-are-all-the-winners-from-the-2019-golden-guitar-awards|title=Here Are All The Winners From The 2019 Golden Guitar Awards {{!}} Country Music Channel on Foxtel|date=28 July 2019|website=Country Music Channel|language=en-AU|access-date=15 July 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2019-01-27/golden-guitars-wolfe-brothers-win-top-country-music-awards/10753724|title= Wolfe Brothers, Andrew Swift, Beccy Cole and Travis Collins win Golden Guitars|publisher=ABC|date=27 January 2019|access-date=27 January 2019 }}</ref>\n\n===2020\u2013present: ''Kids on Cassette'' to ''Livin' the Dream''===\nIn March 2020, Brodie Rainbird announced he is leaving the group as Casey Kostiuk had done some years earlier. However, both continue to play with the duo on tour.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/thewolfebrothers/videos/223840938754887/?t=1|title= Hey everyone, we have a bit of an announcement. Brodie has decided to step back as an official member of The Wolfe Brothers. |website=[[Facebook]]|date=2 March 2020| access-date=23 February 2023}}</ref>\n\nIn April 2020 the band worldwide deal with global independent label, BMG, in partnership with the [[BBR Music Group]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://themusicnetwork.com/the-wolfe-brothers-bmg/|title=Country rockers The Wolfe Brothers sign global record deal with BMG|date=2020-04-14|website=The Music Network|access-date=2020-04-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2020/04/bmg-signs-australian-duo-the-wolfe-brothers-to-global-label-deal/ |title =BMG Signs Australian Duo The Wolfe Brothers To Global Label Deal|website=Music Row|date=April 2020| access-date=23 February 2023}}</ref>\n\nOn 17 April 2020, the group released their first single on the label entitled \"No Breaks\".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/au/album/no-brakes-single/1502092204|title=No Brakes - single|website=Apple Music|access-date=18 April 2020}}</ref>\n\nThe Wolfe Brothers' fifth studio album, ''Kids on Cassette'' was released in July 2021, the same day they celebrated their 15th consecutive #1 single on the Country Airplay Charts with \"Startin' Something\"<ref>{{cite web|url= https://amnplify.com.au/the-wolfe-brothers-celebrate-their-15th-consecutive-country-1-single-on-the-day-they-release-their-fifth-studio-album/|title= THE WOLFE BROTHERS celebrate their 15th consecutive country #1 single on the day they release their fifth studio album|website= amnplify|date=July 2021|access-date=24 February 2023}}</ref> The album debuted at number 6 on the [[ARIA Charts]].\n\nIn November 2021, they joined Australian-born, Canadian country artist [[Gord Bamford]] for the Australian version of his single \"[[Drink Along Song]]\" in 2021.<ref>{{cite web|title=Drink Along Song by Gord Bamford and The Wolfe Brothers \u2013 Song of the Day|url=https://countrytown.com.au/reviews/drink-along-song-by-gord-bamford-and-the-wolfe-brothers-song-of-the-day/YP14cnV0d3Y/19-11-21|date=18 November 2021|first=Mallory|last=Arbour|work=Countrytown}}</ref>\n\nThe Wolfe Brothers were nominated for seven awards at the 2022 CMAAs, winning two.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://themusic.com.au/news/2021-golden-guitar-award-nominations/iSyRnZyfnoE/23-11-21 | title=Troy Cassar-Daley, The Wolfe Brothers Top Golden Guitar Award Nominations |website=[[The Music (magazine)|The Music]]|date= 23 November 2021|access-date=23 February 2023}}</ref>\n\nIn April 2022, the Wolfe Brothers commenced their ''Startin' Something'' tour across Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hotoffthepress.com.au/news/2022/04/the-wolfe-brothers-kick-off-their-startin-something-national-tour-with-two-wins-at-the-golden-guitars.html|website=hot off the press|title=The Wolfe Brothers Kick Off Their Startin' Something Tour|date=27 April 2022| access-date=23 February 2023}}</ref>\n\nThe Wolfe Brothers' sixth studio album ''Livin' the Dream'' was released on 14 April 2023.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jbhifi.com.au/products/cd-wolfe-brothers-the-livin-the-dream-cd|title=Livin' the Dream|website=[[JB Hi-Fi]]|access-date=21 February 2023}}</ref> The album was written during the pandemic over Zoom writing sessions with writers all over the world. Nick Wolfe produced the album with Rod McCormack and Matt Fell. Nick said \"Sonically, ''Livin' the Dream'' is a conscious decision by us to get back to our country roots. We explored a lot of pop and rock territory on our last record but we want to come out of the gate swinging country style and give everyone a taste of what's to come for the rest of this record that we're really proud of.\"\n\nThe Wolfe Brothers were nominated for six awards at the 2024 CMAAs.<ref name=\"CMAA23noms1\">{{cite web|url=https://www.tcmf.com.au/gga-nominees|title=Toyota 52nd Golden Guitar Awards|website=TCMF|date=20 November 2023|access-date=23 November 2023}}</ref><ref name=\"CMAA23noms2\">{{cite web|url=https://www.tcmf.com.au/nominees-announced-for-the-52nd-country-music-awards-of-australia-the-toyota-golden-guitar-awards#:~:text=Tamworth%20Regional%20Council%20will%20present,livestreamed%20via%20the%20Festival%20website.|title=Nominees Announced for the 52nd Country Music Awards |website=TCMF|date=20 November 2023|access-date=23 November 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n====Studio albums====\n{|class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n!rowspan=\"2\"| Title\n!rowspan=\"2\"| Details\n!colspan=\"1\"| Peak chart positions\n|-\n!style=\"width:3em;font-size:90%\"|[[ARIA Charts|AUS]]<br><ref>{{cite web|url=https://australian-charts.com/search.asp?search=The+Wolfe+brothers&cat=a|title=The Wolfe Brothers at Australian Charts|website=Australian Charts|access-date=18 April 2020}}</ref>\n|-\n! Title \n! Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"|''Live at CMC Rocks QLD 2015''\n|\n*Released: 18 September 2015<ref name=\"Live\">{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/au/album/live-at-cmc-rocks-qld-2015/1440862696|title=Live at CMC Rocks QLD 2015|website=Apple Music|access-date=18 April 2020}}</ref>\n*Label: The Wolfe Brothers/ ABC\n|}\n\n===Extended plays===\n{|class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n! Title \n! Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"|''The Wolfe Brothers''\n|\n*Released: May 2010<ref>{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/au/album/the-wolfe-brothers-ep/1440862650|title=The Wolfe Brothers (EP)|website=Apple Music|access-date=18 April 2020}}</ref>\n*Label: Wolfe Brothers\n|}\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n===AIR Awards===\nThe Australian Independent Record Awards (commonly known informally as [[AIR Awards]]) is an annual awards night to recognise, promote and celebrate the success of Australia's Independent Music sector.\n{{awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| [[AIR Awards of 2019|2019]]\n| ''Country Heart''\n| Best Independent Country Album\n| {{nom}}\n| <ref name=\"2019nom\">{{cite web|url=https://scenestr.com.au/music/2019-air-awards-nominees-20190328|title=2019 AIR Awards Nominees|date=28 March 2019 |access-date=20 August 2020}}</ref>\n|-\n| [[AIR Awards of 2022|2022]]\n| ''Kids on Cassette''\n| Best Independent Country Album or EP\n| {{nom}}\n| <ref>{{cite web|url=https://musicfeeds.com.au/news/nominees-announced-for-air-independent-music-awards-2022/|title=Nominees Announced For AIR Independent Music Awards 2022|website=musicfeeds|date=1 June 2022|access-date=1 June 2022}}</ref><ref name=\"AIRwins2022\">{{Cite web|url=https://musicfeeds.com.au/news/genesis-owusu-wins-big-at-the-2022-air-awards/|title=Genesis Owusu Wins Big At The 2022 AIR Awards|website=[[MusicFeeds]]|date=5 August 2022|access-date=6 August 2022|author=Tyler Jenke}}</ref>\n|-\n| [[AIR Awards of 2024|2024]]\n| ''Livin' the Dream''\n| Best Independent Country Album or EP\n| {{nom}}\n| <ref name=\"AIR 2024 noms\">{{cite web|url=https://themusic.com.au/industry/2024-air-awards-nominees-genesis-owusu-cub-sport-rvg-teen-jesus-more/3f1j8fDz8vU/14-05-24|title=2024 AIR Awards Nominees: Genesis Owusu, Cub Sport, RVG, Teen Jesus & More| website= [[The Music (magazine)|The Music]]|date=14 May 2024|access-date=16 May 2024}}</ref>\n{{end}}\n\n===APRA Awards===\nThe [[APRA Awards (Australia)|APRA Awards]] are presented annually from 1982 by the [[Australasian Performing Right Association]] (APRA), \"honouring composers and songwriters\". They commenced in 1982.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apra-amcos.com.au/APRAAwards/MusicAwards/History.aspx |title=APRA History |publisher=[[Australasian Performing Right Association]] (APRA) &#124; [[Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society]] (AMCOS) |access-date=25 April 2022 }}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Music Awards of 2014|2014]] \n| \"The Girl, the Bottle, the Memory\" (Nicholas Wolfe)\n| Country Work of the Year\n| {{nominated}}\n| <ref name=\"CWotYNom\">{{cite web | url = http://apraamcos.com.au/awards/2014-awards/apra-music-awards/country-work-of-the-year/ | title = Country Work of the Year | publisher = Australasian Performing Right Association (APRA) &#124; Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society (AMCOS) | year = 2014 | access-date = 2 January 2016 }}</ref>\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===ARIA Music Awards===\nThe [[ARIA Music Awards]] is an annual awards ceremony that recognises excellence, innovation, and achievement across all genres of [[Australian music]].The Wolfe Brothers have been nominated thrice.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.ariaawards.com.au/history/search/?text=Wolfe%20brothers|title = ARIA Awards Search Results \u2013 Wolfe Brothers|website =ARIA|access-date = 26 April 2020}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2016|2016]]\n| ''This Crazy Life''\n| [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]]\n| {{nom}}\n|\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2018|2018]]\n| ''Country Heart''\n| Best Country Album\n| {{nom}}\n|\n|-\n| [[2021 ARIA Music Awards|2021]]\n| ''Kids on Cassette''\n| Best Country Album\n| {{nom}}\n| <ref>{{cite web |url=https://themusicnetwork.com/2021-aria-awards-nominees/ |title=ARIA Awards nominees revealed: Amy Shark & Genesis Owusu lead the charge |work=[[The Music Network]] |date=20 October 2021 |access-date=24 October 2021 |author=Kelly, Vivienne |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211020000045/https://themusicnetwork.com/2021-aria-awards-nominees/ |archive-date=20 October 2021 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-11-24/aria-awards-winners-genesis-owusu-the-kid-laroi/100647266|title=You could dub this year's awards the Hip Hop and R'n'B ARIAs|publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|date=24 November 2021|first=Mawunyo|last=Gbogbo|access-date=25 November 2021}}</ref>\n|-\n| [[2023 ARIA Music Awards|2023]]\n| ''Livin' the Dream''\n| Best Country Album\n| {{nominated}}\n| <ref name=\"ARIA2023noms\">{{cite web|url=https://musicfeeds.com.au/news/nominees-announced-for-2023-aria-awards/|title= Nominees Announced for 2023 ARIA Awards|website=[[Music Feeds]]|date=21 September 2023|access-date=23 September 2023}}</ref>\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Country Music Awards of Australia===\nThe [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] (CMAA) (also known as the Golden Guitar Awards) is an annual awards night held in January during the Tamworth Country Music Festival, in [[Tamworth, New South Wales]], celebrating recording excellence in the Australian country music industry. The Wolfe Brothers have won nine awards.<ref name=\"CMAAwins\">{{cite web|url=https://www.country.com.au/awards/past-award-winners|title=Past Award Winners|website=Country|access-date=26 April 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"CMAA2014noms\">{{cite web|url=https://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/finalists-for-the-2014-cmaa-golden-guitars-announced|title=The finalists for the 42nd Annual CMAA Country Music Awards have been announced|website=CMC|date=2013 |access-date=26 April 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"CMAA2015noms\">{{cite web|url=https://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/kasey-chambers-and-luke-oshea-lead-the-2015-golden-guitar-nominations|title=Leading the list of nominees for the 2015 Golden Guitar Awards. |website=CMC|date= November 2014|access-date=26 April 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"CMAA2017noms\">{{cite web|url=https://www.workingbull.com.au/news/2017-golden-guitar-awards-nominees/|title=2017 Golden Guitar Awards; Finalists Announced|website=WorkbingBull|date=November 2017|access-date=26 April 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"CMAA2018noms\">{{cite Music Network|date=21 November 2017 |access-date=26 April 2020}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"4\"| 2014\n| ''It's On''\n| Top Selling Album of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"|
