Collaboration of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| The Wolfe Brothers\n| Group or Duo of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Country Music Association Awards===\nThe [[Country Music Association Awards]] (CMA) are and annual American awards show which honours country music artists and broadcasters and recognizes outstanding achievement in the country music industry. The Wolfe Brothers have one nomination.\n\n{{awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| [[56th Annual Country Music Association Awards|2022]]\n| The Wolfe Brothers\n| Global Country Artist Award\n| {{nom}}\n| <ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.billboard.com/music/awards/2022-cma-international-award-nominees-ashley-mcbryde-brothers-osborne-1235137577/ | title=Ashley McBryde & Brothers Osborne Among 2022 CMA International Awards Nominees | magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] }}</ref>\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===CMC Awards===\n[[CMC Music Awards|The CMC Awards]] are awarded annually by [[Country Music Channel]] Australia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2014/03/cmc-music-awards-winners.html|title=CMC Music Awards: winners|publisher=TV Tonight|date=15 March 2014|access-date=24 February 2023}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| 2014|| The Wolfe Brothers || New Australian Artist of the Year|| {{won}} || <ref name=\"DM Mar14\">{{cite news | url = https://www.dailymercury.com.au/news/morgan-evans-fans-choice-cmc-country-music-awards/2199901/ | title = Morgan Evans Is Fans' Choice in CMC Country Music Awards | work = [[Daily Mercury]] | publisher = News Corp Australia | date = 15 March 2014 | access-date = 23 February 2023 }}</ref>\n|-\n| 2016|| The Wolfe Brothers ||  CMC Group Of The Year || {{won}} || <ref name=\"Knox\">{{cite news | url = https://tvtonight.com.au/2016/03/cmc-music-awards-2016-winners.html | title = CMC Music Awards 2016: Winners | last = Knox | first = David | work = TV Tonight | date = 11 March 2016 | access-date = 23 February 2023 }}</ref>\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===National Live Music Awards===\nThe [[National Live Music Awards]] (NLMAs) are a broad recognition of Australia's diverse live industry, celebrating the success of the Australian live scene. The awards commenced in 2016.\n{{awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| [[National Live Music Awards of 2019|2019]]\n| The Wolfe Brothers\n| Live Country Act of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n| <ref name=\"2019noms\">{{cite web|url=https://www.nlmas.com.au/2019/10/22/here-are-your-2019-national-live-music-awards-nominees/|title=HERE ARE YOUR 2019 NATIONAL LIVE MUSIC AWARDS NOMINEES!|website=NLMA|date=22 October 2020|access-date=5 September 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"2019wins\">{{cite web|url=https://www.nlmas.com.au/2019/12/05/and-the-winners-of-the-2019-national-live-music-awards-are/|title=AND THE WINNERS OF THE 2019 NATIONAL LIVE MUSIC AWARDS ARE\u2026|website=NLMA|date=5 December 2020|access-date=5 September 2020}}</ref>\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n{{Australia's Got Talent}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Wolfe Brothers, The}}\n[[Category:2010 establishments in Australia]]\n[[Category:Australian country music groups]]\n[[Category:Australian country rock groups]]\n[[Category:Australian musical groups]]\n[[Category:Tasmanian musical groups]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Tasmania]]\n[[Category:Australia's Got Talent contestants]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Owen_Riegling","to":"Owen Riegling"}],"pages":{"75646581":{"pageid":75646581,"ns":0,"title":"Owen Riegling","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Canadian country singer-songwriter}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Owen Riegling\n| image           = Owen Riegling.jpg\n| caption         = Riegling performing in 2022\n| image_size      = \n| background      = solo_singer\n| birth_date      = {{birth year and age|1998}}\n| birth_name      = \n| birth_place     = \n| alias           = \n| origin          = [[Mildmay, Ontario]], Canada\n| instrument      = Guitar, vocals\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[country rock]]|[[Neotraditional country|traditional country]]}}\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 2019\u2013present\n| label           = [[Universal Music Canada]]\n| website         = {{official|https://www.owenriegling.com/}}\n}}\n'''Owen Michael Riegling''' is a Canadian [[country music]] singer and songwriter. He is currently signed to [[Universal Music Canada]], and has charted with the singles \"Love (The Sweater Song)\", \"[[Old Dirt Roads]]\", and \"Moonshines\".<ref name=\"Umusic\"/><ref name=\"Can Country\"/>\n\n==Early life==\nRiegling grew up on a 100-acre farm in [[Mildmay, Ontario]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cmaontario.ca/artist-of-the-month-owen-riegling-may-2022/|title=Artist of the Month: Owen Riegling|date=May 10, 2022|work=CMA Ontario|access-date=December 25, 2023}}</ref> He began playing the guitar at eleven years old, after receiving one as a Christmas gift.<ref name=\"FPM\">{{cite web|url=https://frontporchmusic.ca/owen-riegling-interview/|title=Owen Riegling Talks About Music and New Single|date=September 15, 2019|work=Front Porch Music|access-date=December 25, 2023}}</ref> He performed for the first time as part of his guitar teacher's band (Country Indie Artist Tattoos 'N Whiskey), before progressing to play covers of [[Eric Church]] songs at local venues.<ref name=\"FPM\"/> Riegling initially attended business school after high school, but realized he enjoyed playing music more. He elected to attend the [[Ontario Institute of Audio Recording Technology]] for music production, after he had won a free recording session in a contest.<ref name=\"FPM\"/>\n\n==Career==\nIn July 2019, Riegling independently released the song \"Smoke Man\".<ref name=\"FPM\"/> The song was included on his debut extended play ''Empty Room'', which was released on September 4, 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://frontporchmusic.ca/owen-riegling-ep-empty-room/|title=Owen Riegling's Debut EP ''Empty Room'' Drops Today|date=September 4, 2020|work=Front Porch Music|access-date=December 25, 2023}}</ref> In August 2022, Riegling won the [[Boots and Hearts]] Emerging Artist Showcase contest, securing him a single release with [[Universal Music Canada]], songwriting sessions, and a trip to [[Nashville]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://theranch100.com/mildmays-owen-riegling-wins-emerging-artist-showcase-at-boots-hearts/|title=Mildmay's Owen Riegling wins Emerging Artist Showcase at Boots & Hearts|work=100.1 FM The Ranch|date=August 8, 2022|access-date=December 25, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://frontporchmusic.ca/owen-riegling-wins-boots-hearts-emerging-artist/|title=Owen Riegling Wins The 2022 Boots & Hearts Emerging Artist Showcase|date=August 7, 2022|work=Front Porch Music|access-date=December 25, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.excal.on.ca/arts/2023/11/07/owen-riegling-small-town-country-music-star/|title=Owen Riegling: Small-town country music star|date=November 7, 2023|first=Kaila|last=Gallacher|work=Excalibur|access-date=December 25, 2023}}</ref>\n\nIn June 2023, Riegling signed a record deal with [[Universal Music Canada]] and released his debut radio single \"Love (The Sweater Song)\".<ref name=\"Umusic\">{{cite web|url=https://www.universalmusic.ca/press-releases/owen-riegling-signs-with-universal-music-canada-and-kicks-off-summer-with-new-single-love-the-sweater-song/|title=Owen Riegling Signs with Universal Music Canada and Kicks Off Summer with New Single \"Love (The Sweater Song)\"|date=June 23, 2023|work=[[Universal Music Canada]]|access-date=December 25, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://frontporchmusic.ca/owen-riegling-universal-music-deal-debut-single-love-the-sweater-song/|title=Owen Riegling Signs with Universal Music Canada and Releases Debut Single \"Love (The Sweater Song)\"|date=June 23, 2023|first=Logan|last=Miller|work=Front Porch Music|access-date=December 25, 2023}}</ref> He was also nominated for \"Rising Star\" at the CMA Ontario Awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pentictonherald.ca/spare_news/article_411cb3b8-4b60-509b-aad1-3c80087bc3c1.html|title=Mildmay's Owen Riegling nominated for CMAOntario Rising Star Award|first=Pauline|last=Kerr|date=June 2, 2023|work=[[Penticton Herald]]|access-date=December 25, 2023}}</ref> In August 2023, Riegling released the song \"[[Old Dirt Roads]]\", which later became his second single at Canadian country radio.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.universalmusic.ca/press-releases/owen-riegling-releases-second-single-old-dirt-roads-out-today/|title=Owen Riegling Releases Second Single \"Old Dirt Roads\" Out Today|date=August 10, 2023|work=[[Universal Music Canada]]|access-date=December 25, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://frontporchmusic.ca/old-dirt-roads-owen-riegling/|title=On \"Old Dirt Roads\" Owen Riegling Gets Down to Earth|first=Taylor|last=Preston|work=Front Porch Music|date=September 8, 2023|access-date=December 25, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rfdtv.com/rising-canadian-country-music-artist-owen-riegling-discusses-his-success-and-performs-his-latest-single|title=Rising Canadian country music artist Owen Riegling discusses his success and performs his latest single|date=November 10, 2023|first=Currey|last=McCullough|work=[[RFD-TV]]|access-date=December 25, 2023}}</ref> In October 2023, he was an opening act for American country artist [[Tyler Hubbard]] on his solo headlining tour in Canada.<ref name=\"Umusic\"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.country933.com/2023/08/08/one-to-watch-owen-riegling/|title=One to Watch: OWEN RIEGLING|first=Nicolina|last=Moscati|work=Country 93.3|date=August 8, 2023|access-date=December 25, 2023}}</ref> Later that fall, Riegling joined [[Robyn Ottolini]] as the opening act for the Canadian dates on her \"All My Friends Are Hot Tour\".<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.soundcheckentertainment.ca/robyn-ottolini-announces-the-all-my-friends-are-hot-north-american-tour/|title=Robyn Ottolini Announces the 'All My Friends Are Hot' North American Tour|date=September 12, 2023|first=Hendrik|last=Pape|work=Sound Check Entertainment|access-date=December 25, 2023}}</ref> In 2024, he joined [[Chase Rice]]'s \"Get Western Tour\" as an opening act for most of the Canadian dates.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2023/11/chase-rice-to-head-up-north-for-get-western-tour/|title=Chase Rice To Head Up North For 'Get Western Tour'|date=November 22, 2023|first=Lorie|last=Hollabaugh|work=Music Row|access-date=December 25, 2023}}</ref> On May 24, 2024, Riegling released the extended play ''Bruce County''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kx947.fm/index.php/melissa-s-country-news/4754-owen-riegling-announces-his-debut-ep|title=Owen Riegling Announces His Debut EP|work=KX 94.7 FM|access-date=May 20, 2024}}</ref> He was nominated in four categories at the [[2024 Canadian Country Music Awards]], and won Breakthrough Artist of the Year and Songwriter of the Year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ca.billboard.com/music/country/ccma-nominations-2024|title=Canadian Country Music Association Awards 2024 Nominations: Jade Eagleson, MacKenzie Porter Lead The Pack|first=Kerry|last=Doole|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] Canada|access-date=September 11, 2024|date=July 18, 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://ccma.org/2024-ccma-award-nominees/|title=2024 CCMA Award Nominees|access-date=September 11, 2024|work=[[Canadian Country Music Association]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://ccma.org/2024-ccma-award-winners/|title=2024 CCMA Award Winners|work=[[Canadian Country Music Association]]|access-date=September 15, 2024|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20240915175950/https://ccma.org/2024-ccma-award-winners/|archive-date=September 15, 2024}}</ref>\n\n==Tours==\n*''Old Dirt Road Trip'' (2024)\n\n==Discography==\n===Extended plays===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|+List of EPs, with selected details\n! scope=\"col\"| Title\n! scope=\"col\"| Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Uncle_Kracker","to":"Uncle Kracker"}],"pages":{"11060967":{"pageid":11060967,"ns":0,"title":"Uncle Kracker","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American musician (born 1974)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2022}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Uncle Kracker\n| image             = Uncle Kracker Las Vegas 2023.jpg\n| caption           = Uncle Kracker performing at [[Las Vegas Motor Speedway]] in 2023\n| birth_name        = Matthew Shafer\n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1974|6|6}}\n| birth_place       = [[Mount Clemens, Michigan]], U.S.\n| origin            = \n| instrument        = {{hlist|Vocals|turntables}}\n| genre             = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country rock]]<ref name=MT2015/>\n* [[pop rock]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/little-big-towns-uncle-kracker-the-showdown/ |title=Little Big Town vs. Uncle Kracker \u2013 The Showdown |last=Dukes |first=Billy |date=October 8, 2012  |publisher=Taste of Country |access-date= |quote=a man best known for his success in the pop-rock world.}}</ref>\n* [[rap rock]]<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n* [[country rap]]<ref name=MT2015>{{cite web |url=https://www.metrotimes.com/music/country-rap-pioneer-uncle-kracker-brings-his-pure-country-rock-shine-to-royal-oak-friday-nov-27-2383030 |title=Country-rap pioneer Uncle Kracker brings his pure country-rock shine to Royal Oak Friday, Nov. 27  |author=Staff |date=November 25, 2015 |publisher=Metro Times |access-date=2022-12-20}}</ref>\n}}\n| occupation        = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter|musician|rapper}}\n| years_active      = 1987\u2013present\n| label             = {{hlist|[[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]]|[[Lava Records|Lava]]|[[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill]]|Top Dog}}\n| website           = {{URL|unclekracker.com}}\n}}\n'''Matthew Shafer''' (born June 6, 1974), also known by his stage name '''Uncle Kracker''', is an American singer and musician. He was previously a turntablist for [[Kid Rock]]'s backing group [[Twisted Brown Trucker]]; since 1999, he has recorded as a solo artist. His singles \"[[Follow Me (Uncle Kracker song)|Follow Me]]\" and \"[[Drift Away#Uncle Kracker featuring Dobie Gray version|Drift Away]]\" were top 10 hits on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].\n\n== Early life ==\nShafer was born in [[Mount Clemens, Michigan]], on June 6, 1974.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/uncle-kracker-mn0000219428|title=Uncle Kracker biography|last=Wilson|first=Mackenzie|work=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=June 25, 2013}}</ref> With his brother Mike Shafer, he visited a [[nightclub]] in [[Clawson, Michigan]], where a [[turntablist|turntables]] competition was occurring. His older brother was competing against a then-unknown musician, Kid Rock. Shafer soon became friends with [[Kid Rock]]. In those times, he was mainly [[rap]]ping. He went to [[L'Anse Creuse High School]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://music.yahoo.com/read/news/12064066|title=Uncle Kracker On Eminem/ICP Gun Incident|publisher=YAHOO!|access-date=June 17, 2008}}</ref> In 1994, Kid Rock asked Shafer to play turntables for his band called Twisted Brown Trucker. Shafer knew nothing of using turntables, but since his brother was an experienced DJ, he agreed. He only performed at live shows at the time, until he began recording for Rock's album, ''[[Early Mornin' Stoned Pimp]]''; Shafer was a featured vocalist on some of the tracks. He then began working on a [[solo album]], but he continued being the DJ for Kid Rock. Upon the release of Rock's multi-platinum album, ''[[The History of Rock]]'', Shafer decided that it was time to release his first solo album, ''[[Double Wide (Uncle Kracker album)|Double Wide]],'' in 2000.\n\n== Career ==\n\n=== ''Double Wide'' ===\n''Double Wide'' was Uncle Kracker's first solo album. Released on June 30, 2000, it peaked at Number 7 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] album chart and is Shafer's most successful and highest-selling album. The album was produced by [[Kid Rock]], with mixing additional production by [[Michael Bradford]]. The first single taken off the album was \"[[Follow Me (Uncle Kracker song)|Follow Me]]\", which was co-written with Bradford, and peaked at Number 5 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] in June 2001. The album spent the next 10 months on the Billboard 200, and \"Follow Me\" also had a long chart run. His second single, \"Yeah, Yeah, Yeah\", failed to hit the Hot 100 chart; however, the song has been released one year earlier in the soundtrack of ''[[Shanghai Noon]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Shanghai Noon \u2013 Cast {{!}} IMDbPro|url=https://pro.imdb.com/title/tt0184894/|access-date=September 7, 2020|website=pro.imdb.com}}</ref> ''Double Wide'' was certified 2\u00d7 Multi-Platinum on November 29, 2001.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS&artist=Uncle%20Kracker&title=Double%20Wide&format=ALBUM&go=Search&perPage=50|title=RIAA \u2013 Gold & Platinum \u2013 November 21, 2010: ''Double Wide'' certified awards|publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]]|access-date=November 21, 2010}}</ref>\n\n=== ''No Stranger to Shame'' ===\nAfter a great deal of touring to promote the first album, he began to work on a follow-up album. Entitled ''[[No Stranger to Shame]]'', it was released on August 27, 2002. The album reached No.&nbsp;43 on the Billboard albums chart. A hit single was released, a cover version of [[Dobie Gray]]'s 1973 Top 5 hit, \"[[Drift Away]]\" \u2013 also including Gray as a guest vocalist. Kracker's version of this song peaked at No.&nbsp;9 on the [[Hot 100]] one week to the day after Gray's 63rd birthday, and it set a record for most weeks at No.&nbsp;1 on the Adult Contemporary chart, remaining atop this chart for 28 nonconsecutive weeks. Other singles released from ''No Stranger to Shame'' include \"In A Little While\", which peaked at No.&nbsp;59 on the Hot 100 and No.&nbsp;26 on the Adult Contemporary charts. A third single was released, \"Memphis Soul Song\", which charted on the [[Adult Top 40]] at No.&nbsp;35. A special remix of \"Memphis Soul Song\" was also released, featuring harmonies by legendary singing group [[The Jordanaires]], who had famously sung harmonies with [[Elvis Presley]]. The album was certified gold by the [[RIAA]] within a year of its release. Soon after this period, Kracker became good friends with country music star [[Kenny Chesney]] and the two began a successful touring partnership together, brought on by the success of Kenny's hit single \"[[When the Sun Goes Down (Kenny Chesney song)|When the Sun Goes Down]]\", featuring Uncle Kracker both on the single, and prominently in the video.\n\n=== ''Seventy Two and Sunny'' ===\nAfter touring, Shafer began working on a third album which he called ''[[Seventy Two and Sunny]]''. It was his first not to feature a [[parental advisory]] label as well as the first one to not feature any [[hip-hop]] songs, and moved onto a pure country sound. The album featured two singles: \"Rescue\", which only charted at No.&nbsp;20 on the Billboard Adult Contemporary singles chart but did not chart on any other charts, and \"Writing It Down,\" which did not chart at all. Shafer did have some success that year though when he was featured on Chesney's track, \"[[When the Sun Goes Down (Kenny Chesney and Uncle Kracker song)|When the Sun Goes Down]]\", which peaked at No.&nbsp;1 on the [[Hot Country Songs]] chart, and went on to achieve Gold status. ''Seventy Two and Sunny'' has sold about 200,000 copies. It peaked at No.&nbsp;39 on the Billboard 200.\n\n=== ''Happy Hour'' ===\nUncle Kracker's fourth studio album is entitled ''[[Happy Hour (Uncle Kracker album)|Happy Hour]]''.<ref name=\"HappyHourAlbumDelay\">{{cite web|url=http://new.music.yahoo.com/uncle-kracker/news/uncle-kracker-quotfrustratedquot-by-album-delay--51638611|title=Uncle Kracker \"frustrated\" by album delay|publisher=Yahoo! Music News|access-date=May 11, 2009}}</ref> The album was in the works for five years and was delayed due to [[Atlantic Records]]' decision to bring in [[Rob Cavallo]] to produce the album right as they were finishing their cut of the album in late 2007. An early promo version of the album contained the tracks \"Happy Hour\", \"Vegas Baby\", \"I'm Not Leaving\", \"The One That Got Away\", and \"That's What's Happenin\". \"[[Smile (Uncle Kracker song)|Smile]],\" the first single from the album, was released on July 13, 2009, and has peaked at No.&nbsp;31 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. The album was released on September 15, 2009. \"Smile\" also became his first solo entry on the [[Hot Country Songs]] chart, where it debuted at No.&nbsp;57 for the week of November 7, 2009, and peaked at No.&nbsp;6 in September 2010. A music video for the track \"My Girlfriend\" was released in November 2009, though there has been no official word whether it will be serviced as the album's second single. The album also features country singer [[Jesse Lee (singer)|Jesse Lee]] (also on Atlantic Records) in a duet they wrote called \"Me Again.\"\n\n==== ''Happy Hour: The South River Road Sessions'' ====\nA six-song EP, ''[[Happy Hour: The South River Road Sessions]]'', was released on June 22, 2010. The EP features country remakes of songs off the ''Happy Hour'' album. The singles released were a remake of \"Smile\" and \"[[Good to Be Me]]\", featuring Kid Rock.\n\n=== ''Midnight Special'' ===\n[[File:Uncle kracker.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Uncle Kracker performing in 2012]]\nOn November 16, 2012, Uncle Kracker released his fifth studio album, ''[[Midnight Special (Uncle Kracker album)|Midnight Special]]'', produced by [[Keith Stegall]]. [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]] and [[Vanguard Records]] released the album under parent company [[Welk Music Group]]. The album was a full-fledged country record. The first single to come off of the album was \"Nobody's Sad on a Saturday Night\", followed by \"Blue Skies\". Shafer performed songs from the album while on the road with Kid Rock for his $20 Best Night Ever Tour during 2013.\n\n=== New singles and ''Coffee & Beer'' (2018\u2013present) ===\nOn August 10, 2018, Kracker released his new single entitled \"Floatin'\", along with an accompanying music video.<ref>{{Citation |title=Uncle Kracker - Floatin' [Official Video] | date=August 10, 2018 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yvEvbUsS1Nw |access-date=2023-10-26 |language=en}}</ref>\n\nOn May 4, 2020, \"No Time to Be Sober\" premiered with a simple lockdown music video.<ref>{{Citation |title=Uncle Kracker - No Time to Be Sober [Official Video] | date=May 4, 2020 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YAvvup8Jf0E |access-date=2023-10-26 |language=en}}</ref> On December 21, 2020, \"Silver Bells\" released for Christmas.<ref>{{Citation |title=Uncle Kracker - Silver Bells | date=December 21, 2020 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2naN7iFdTa0 |access-date=2023-10-26 |language=en}}</ref>\n\nOn June 9, 2023, Uncle Kracker released the single \"Sweet 16\".<ref>{{Citation |title=Sweet 16 | date=June 8, 2023 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mo3_YJPUDqg&list=OLAK5uy_mZRUANEXFbPT47far85pfC5Na-ZadKpwc |access-date=2023-10-26 |language=en}}</ref>\n\nOn July 20, 2023, \"Reason to Drink\" was released.<ref>{{Citation |title=Reason To Drink | date=July 20, 2023 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O3lUA4DGQOA&list=OLAK5uy_m7oTorh9yOaBVFDZ3T32wZ9W3VS_m8Lh8 |access-date=2023-10-26 |language=en}}</ref>\n\nUncle Kracker toured with [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]] and [[ZZ Top]] on their Sharp Dressed Simple Man Tour, which commenced on July 21, 2023 in [[West Palm Beach]] and concluded on September 17 in [[Camden, New Jersey|Camden]].<ref>{{Citation |title=Uncle Kracker - Drift Away - Live - Sharp Dressed Simple Man Tour - 8/11/23 | date=August 12, 2023 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o3Kq9ldfcJc |access-date=2023-10-26 |language=en}}</ref>\n\nOn October 19, 2023, \"Cruising Altitude\" released after the finished tour.<ref>{{Citation |title=Cruising Altitude | date=October 19, 2023 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qxqw-ShjxSA&list=OLAK5uy_lAZdY4V3HKsDufrwZ-lVe98OMhs8e7JJ0 |access-date=2023-10-26 |language=en}}</ref>\n\n\"Beach Chair,\" Uncle's latest single with accompanying video directed by The Manning Brothers, was released on May 31, 2024.\n\nOn July 12, 2024, Uncle Kracker released his first album in a decade entitled ''Coffee & Beer''<ref>{{cite web | url=https://musicrow.com/2024/07/uncle-kracker-offers-a-needed-escape-on-new-lp-coffee-beer/ | title=Uncle Kracker Offers a Needed Escape on New LP 'Coffee & Beer' | date=July 12, 2024 }}</ref>.\n\n== Personal life ==\nShafer was married to Melanie Haas from 1998 to 2014. They had three children together. Shafer has two children with his second wife.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Uncle Kracker & Wife Welcome Baby Boy|url=https://countryrebel.com/uncle-kracker-wife-welcome-baby-boy/|access-date=April 24, 2021|website=Country Rebel|date=October 30, 2020 |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nIn 2007, Shafer was arrested for a second-degree sex offense charge and released on $75,000 bond.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1049821/uncle-kracker-arrested-on-sex-offense-charge|title=Uncle Kracker Arrested On Sex Offense Charge|magazine=Billboard}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.foxnews.com/story/uncle-kracker-arrested-on-second-degree-sex-offense-charge|title=Uncle Kracker Arrested on Second-Degree Sex Offense Charge|work=Fox News|date=March 25, 2015 }}</ref> He pleaded guilty to a lesser charge and was sentenced to a year of probation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wral.com/news/local/story/1872722/ |title=Singer Pleads Guilty; Gets Probation in Bar Incident |publisher=WRAL.com |date=September 2, 2007|access-date=May 31, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/people/2007-11-13-kracker_N.htm |title=Uncle Kracker not happy with guilty plea \u2013 USATODAY.com |publisher=Usatoday30.usatoday.com |date=November 1, 2007|access-date=May 31, 2013}}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n{{Main|Uncle Kracker discography}}\n* ''[[Double Wide (album)|Double Wide]]'' (2000)\n* ''[[No Stranger to Shame]]'' (2002)\n* ''[[Seventy Two and Sunny]]'' (2004)\n* ''[[Happy Hour (Uncle Kracker album)|Happy Hour]]'' (2009)\n* ''[[Midnight Special (Uncle Kracker album)|Midnight Special]]'' (2012)\n* ''Coffee & Beer'' (2024)\n\n== References ==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n{{commons category}}\n* [http://www.unclekracker.com/ Official website]\n* {{allMusic}}\n\n{{Uncle Kracker}}\n{{Kid Rock}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Kracker, Uncle}}\n[[Category:1974 births]]\n[[Category:20th-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American rappers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American country rock singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American hip hop DJs]]\n[[Category:American pop rock singers]]\n[[Category:American rap rock musicians]]\n[[Category:Atlantic Records artists]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Michigan]]\n[[Category:Country rap musicians]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Midwest hip hop musicians]]\n[[Category:People from Mount Clemens, Michigan]]\n[[Category:Rappers from Detroit]]\n[[Category:Rock DJs]]\n[[Category:Singers from Detroit]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Michigan]]\n[[Category:Lava Records artists]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Loggins_and_Messina","to":"Loggins and Messina"}],"pages":{"2379482":{"pageid":2379482,"ns":0,"title":"Loggins and Messina","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use American English|date=August 2024}}\n{{Short description|American music duo}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2024}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Loggins and Messina\n| image             = Loggins and Messina 1974.JPG\n| caption           = Loggins (left) and Messina (right) in 1972\n| image_size        = 240px\n| background        = group_or_band\n| origin            = United States\n| years_active      = {{hlist|1971\u20131976|2005|2009}}\n| genre             = {{hlist|[[Country rock]]|[[folk rock]]|[[pop rock]]|[[soft rock]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/loggins-messina-mn0000277351/biography|title=Loggins & Messina &#124; Biography & History|website=AllMusic|first=William|last=Ruhlmann}}</ref>}}\n| label             = [[Columbia Records|Columbia]]\n| website           = {{url|logginsandmessina.com}}\n| current_members   = \n| past_members      = *[[Kenny Loggins]]\n*[[Jim Messina (musician)|Jim Messina]]\n}}\n\n'''Loggins and Messina''' was an American [[pop rock]] duo consisting of [[Kenny Loggins]] and [[Jim Messina (musician)|Jim Messina]], who achieved major chart success during the early-mid 1970s. Among their well-known songs are \"[[Danny's Song]]\", \"[[House at Pooh Corner (song)|House at Pooh Corner]]\", and \"[[Your Mama Don't Dance]]\". After selling more than 16 million records and becoming one of the leading musical duos of the 1970s,<ref name=\"Thibodeaux\">\"Together again: Kenny Loggins and [[Jim Messina (musician)|Jim Messina]] bring their hits to Biloxi,\" by Ron Thibodeaux, The Times-Picayune (New Orleans), July 29, 2005.</ref> Loggins and Messina separated in 1976. Although Messina would find only limited popularity following the breakup, Loggins went on to achieve major chart success in the 1980s. In 2005 and again in 2009, Loggins and Messina reformed for tours in the United States.\n\n==History==\n===Initial career 1971\u20131976===\n[[Jim Messina (musician)|Jim Messina]], formerly of [[Buffalo Springfield]] and [[Poco (band)|Poco]], was working as an independent record producer for [[Columbia Records]] in 1970 when he met [[Kenny Loggins]], a little-known singer/songwriter and guitarist who was signed to [[ABC-Dunhill]] as a staff songwriter.<ref name=\"Larkin\">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Virgin Encyclopedia of Popular Music]]|editor-first=Colin|editor-last=Larkin|editor-link=Colin Larkin (writer)|publisher=[[Virgin Books]]|date=1997|edition=Concise|isbn=1-85227-745-9|page=766}}</ref>\n\nThe two recorded a number of Loggins' compositions in Messina's home living room. When Columbia signed Loggins to a six-album contract (with the assistance of Messina), recording began in earnest for Loggins' debut album, with Messina as producer. Messina originally intended to lend his name to the Loggins project only to help introduce the unknown Loggins to Messina's well-established Buffalo Springfield and Poco audiences. However, by the time the album was completed, Messina had contributed so much to the album \u2013 in terms of songwriting, arrangement, instrumentation, and vocals \u2013 that an \"accidental\" duo was born.\n\nTheir debut album was released November 1971 as ''Kenny Loggins with Jim Messina [[Sittin' In (Loggins and Messina album)|Sittin' In]]''. The album's first single release, the Caribbean-flavored \"[[Vahevala]]\" (or \"Vahevella\" or \"Vaheevella\"), found top 3 success on Chicago's [[WCFL (AM)|WCFL]] on May 18, 1972.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oldiesloon.com/ilc/wcfl051872.htm|title=WCFL - all hit music in the Midwest|publisher=Oldiesloon.com|date=May 18, 1972|access-date=January 5, 2013}}</ref> \"Vahevala\" and \"Nobody But You\" both reached the [[Hot 100]]. Although at first the album went unnoticed by radio upon release, it eventually gained traction by autumn 1972, particularly on college campuses, where the pair toured heavily. Loggins' and Messina's harmonies meshed so well that what was begun as a one-off album became an entity unto itself. Audiences regarded the pair as a genuine duo rather than as a solo act with a well-known producer. Instead of just continuing to produce Loggins as a sole performer, they decided to record as a duo: Loggins and Messina.<ref name=\"Larkin\"/>\n\nOn March 3, 1973, Loggins and Messina played Carnegie Hall. Ian Dove in the ''New York Times'' called it a \"near-perfect rock 'n' roll concert\".<ref>{{Cite news|date=March 3, 1973|title=LOGGINS AND MESSINA PLAY CARNEGIE ROCK (Published 1973)|language=en-US|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1973/03/03/archives/loggins-and-messina-play-carnegie-rock.html|access-date=March 13, 2021|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>\n\n\"When our first album, ''[[Sittin' In (Loggins and Messina album)|Sittin' In]]'', came out, we started receiving a lot of excitement about the music and good sales,\" Messina recalled in 2005. \"We had a choice. It was either I now go on and continue to produce him and we do the solo career or we stay together and let this work. For me, I did not desire to go back out on the road. I had had enough of that, and I wanted to produce records. But [[Clive Davis]] (then president of the record company) intervened and said, 'You know, I think you'd be making a mistake if you guys didn't take this opportunity. Things like this only happen once in a lifetime. It may merit you sleeping on it overnight and making a decision that will be in your best interest.' He was absolutely correct. Kenny made the decision as well. It delayed his solo career, but it gave him an opportunity, I think, to have one.\"<ref name=\"Thibodeaux\" />\n\nMessina assembled The Kenny Loggins Band by summoning old friends, bassist Larry Sims and drummer Merel Bregante, formerly of [[The Sunshine Company]], multireedist [[Jon Clarke (musician)|Jon Clarke]], and violinist/multireedist Al Garth. Famed [[Grammy]]-winning keyboardist, songwriter and record producer [[Michael Omartian]] played keyboards on the [[Sittin' In (Loggins and Messina album)|debut]], [[Loggins and Messina (album)|second]] and [[Full Sail (Loggins and Messina album)|third]] albums, but did not join them on tour. Los Angeles\u2013based session percussionist [[Milt Holland]] played on all of the duo's studio albums, but like Omartian, he did not tour with them.<ref>{{cite web|last=Flans |first=Robyn |url=http://www.mixonline.com/news/profiles/classic-tracks-loggins-messinas-vahevala/375146 |title=Classic Tracks: Loggins & Messina's 'Vahevala' |publisher=Mixonline |date=September 1, 2004 |access-date=August 26, 2015}}</ref>\n\nOver the next four years, from 1972 to 1976, they produced four more studio albums of original material, plus one album of [[Cover version|covers]] of other artists' material (''[[So Fine (Loggins and Messina album)|So Fine]]''), and two live albums. They sold 16 million records and were the most successful duo of the early 1970s, surpassed later in the decade only by [[Hall & Oates]].<ref name=\"Thibodeaux\" /> They charted three top 20 singles from the second and third albums: \"[[Your Mama Don't Dance]]\" (No. 4), \"[[Thinking of You (Loggins and Messina song)|Thinking of You]]\" (No. 18), and \"[[My Music (song)|My Music]]\" (No. 16). Their work was covered by other prominent artists, including [[Lynn Anderson]], who recorded \"[[Listen to a Country Song (song)|Listen to a Country Song]]\" in 1972 and reached No. 3 on the charts, and [[Anne Murray]], who reached the U.S. top ten with \"[[Danny's Song]]\" in early 1973 and the U.S. top twenty with \"[[A Love Song (Loggins and Messina song)|A Love Song]]\" in early 1974. The later studio albums, ''[[Mother Lode (album)|Mother Lode]]'' (1974), ''[[Native Sons (Loggins and Messina album)|Native Sons]]'' (1976), often found both Loggins and Messina more as two solo artists sharing the same record rather than as a genuine partnership. As both Loggins and Messina noted in 2005, their collaboration eventually became more a competition.\n\nNever really a team of true equals because of the initial teacher\u2013apprentice nature of their music experience levels, the pair had quietly, amicably parted in 1976. Their final studio album of original material, ''[[Native Sons (Loggins and Messina album)|Native Sons]]'', was released January 1976. Later that year the duo went on a final tour, <ref name=\"Larkin\"/> though prior to the start of the tour, Loggins accidentally cut his hand with a [[craft knife]] while practicing his wood-carving hobby at home which required surgery, thereby preventing him from playing guitar for most of that final tour. The final two concert dates of Loggins & Messina - as a duo - were in [[Honolulu]], Hawaii, at the [[Neil S. Blaisdell Center]], on September 24 and 25, 1976, upon which the duo then parted to embark on solo careers. Messina found solo success elusive, but Loggins went on to become one of the biggest hitmakers of the 1980s.\n\nA greatest-hits album, ''[[The Best of Friends (album)|The Best of Friends]]'', was released in November 1976, two months after the duo had ended.  In January 1977, a second live album (from concerts in 1975 and 1976), ''[[Finale (album)|Finale]]'', was released, more by record company decision than one intended by the artists.\n\n===Reformation===\nThe two reunited in 2005 to choose tracks for an expanded compilation album of singles and album cuts ''[[The Best: Sittin' In Again]]'', which proved successful enough for them to embark on tour together. Their successful \"Sittin' In Again\" tour was launched in mid-2005 and played-out the remainder of the year. They also released an album that year of the tour. \"Every couple of years we'd talk about it, but I was having too much fun as a solo artist,\" Loggins said that summer. \"It was very rewarding for me, and I wasn't ready to share the reins. I still had a lot of stuff to do on my own, to prove myself and to express myself, in a way that wouldn't have fit in with Loggins and Messina.\"<ref name=\"Thibodeaux\" />\n\nThe two were pleased enough to consider future Loggins and Messina projects and the two also toured in 2009. \"Like most relationships, we were a moment in time,\" Loggins said. \"It's just really fun to be able to go back and celebrate that and just sort of really honor each other as grown men, in a way we never really did back then. We were young and competitive and didn't realize that it wasn't necessarily all about getting your way, but you learn that if you grow up.\"<ref name=\"Thibodeaux\" />\n\nTheir backing band changed from album to album, with the core members listed below. Some albums featured backing members who later were well-known in their own right; [[John Townsend (artist)|John Townsend]] and [[Ed Sanford]], later of the [[Sanford-Townsend Band]] (\"[[Smoke from a Distant Fire]]\"), contributed vocals and songwriting to the ''Native Sons'', their final studio album.\n\n==Members==\n*[[Kenny Loggins]] &ndash; vocals, rhythm guitar, acoustic guitar, harmonica \n*[[Jim Messina (musician)|Jim Messina]] &ndash; vocals, lead guitar, acoustic guitar, [[mandolin]], [[Dobro]]\n\n;Supporting personnel\n*Al Garth &ndash; tenor saxophone, bass clarinet, alto saxophone, violin, [[recorder (musical instrument)|recorder]], viola, percussion, [[steel drum]] and backing vocals\n*Jon Clarke \u2013 [[baritone saxophone]], [[English horn]], flute, tenor saxophone, soprano saxophone, bass saxophone, bass clarinet, [[Recorder (musical instrument)|recorder]], bass flute, oboe, [[steel drum]] and percussion (died in 2005)\n*Larry Sims \u2013 bass and backing vocals (died in 2014)\n*Merel Bregante \u2013 drums, percussion, [[timbales]] and backing vocals\n*[[Milt Holland]] \u2013 percussion (died in 2005)\n*[[Michael Omartian]] \u2013 keyboards, percussion and [[concertina]]\n*Vince Denham \u2013 flute, bass clarinet, alto, soprano and tenor saxophone\n*Don Roberts \u2013 clarinet, alto flute, alto, baritone, soprano and tenor saxophone\n*Steve Forman \u2013 percussion, [[vibraphone|vibes]]\n*[[David Paich]] \u2013 keyboards\n*Dave Wallace \u2013 synthesizer\n*Chris Brooks \u2013 [[koto (instrument)|koto]]\n*[[Michel Rubini]] \u2013 keyboards\n*Richard Greene &ndash; violin, mandolin, [[mandocello]]\n*[[Rusty Young (musician)|Rusty Young]] \u2013 Dobro (died in 2021)\n*Vince Charles \u2013 steel drums (died in 2001)\n*[[Victor Feldman]] \u2013 percussion (died in 1987)\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! \n|-\n| colspan=\"7\" style=\"text-align:center; font-size:9pt;\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart.\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.logginsandmessina.com/ Official site]\n* [https://web.archive.org/web/20160621191501/http://www.popularsong.org/forgotten-gem.html Commentary on ''Return to Pooh Corner'']\n* {{Discogs artist|Loggins And Messina}}\n\n{{Loggins and Messina}}\n{{Kenny Loggins}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n[[Category:American pop music duos]]\n[[Category:American soft rock music groups]]\n[[Category:Folk rock groups from California]]\n[[Category:Musical groups from Los Angeles]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 1971]]\n[[Category:Musical groups disestablished in 1976]]\n[[Category:Musical groups reestablished in 2005]]\n[[Category:Folk rock duos]]\n[[Category:Soft rock duos]]\n[[Category:American rock music duos]]\n[[Category:American male musical duos]]\n[[Category:Columbia Records artists]]\n[[Category:Kenny Loggins]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jesse_Winchester","to":"Jesse Winchester"}],"pages":{"2484677":{"pageid":2484677,"ns":0,"title":"Jesse Winchester","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American-Canadian singer-songwriter and producer (1944\u20132014)}}\n{{For|the Canadian ice hockey player|Jesse Winchester (ice hockey)}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name                = Jesse Winchester\n| image               = Jesse Winchester Smile JazzFest 2011.jpg\n| alt                 =\n| caption             = Winchester in 2011\n| image_size          = 250\n| landscape           = yes\n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_name          = James Ridout Winchester Jr.\n| birth_date          = {{birth date|1944|05|17}}\n| birth_place         = [[Bossier City, Louisiana]], U.S.\n| origin              = [[Memphis, Tennessee]], U.S. \n| death_date          = {{death date and age|2014|04|11|1944|05|17}}\n| death_place         = [[Charlottesville, Virginia]], U.S.\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]], [[country rock]], [[folk music|folk]]\n| occupation          = Musician, songwriter, producer\n| instrument          = Vocals, guitar, keyboards\n| years_active        = Circa 1961 &ndash; 2014 (his death)\n| label               = [[Appleseed Recordings|Appleseed]], [[Bearsville Records|Bearsville]], [[Stony Plain Records|Stony Plain]], [[Ampex Records|Ampex]], [[RCA Records|Victor]], [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill]], Great Big Island, [[Wounded Bird Records|Wounded Bird]], Blue Plate, Warner Brothers\n| website             = {{URL|Jessewinchester.com}}\n}}\n\n'''James Ridout''' \"'''Jesse'''\" '''Winchester Jr.''' (May 17, 1944&nbsp;\u2013 April 11, 2014) was an [[American-Canadian]] musician and songwriter. He was born and raised in the southern United States. Opposed to the [[Vietnam War]], he moved to Canada in 1967 to [[Draft evasion|avoid being drafted into the US military while the US engaged in the Vietnam War]] and began his career as a solo artist. His highest-charting recordings were of his own songs, \"Yankee Lady\" in 1970 and \"Say What\" in 1981. He became a [[Canadian citizen]] in 1973, gained amnesty in the U.S. in 1977 and resettled in [[Memphis, Tennessee]] in 2002.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thespec.com/whatson/music/article/500966--jesse-winchester-still-doing-the-rhumba |title=Jesse Winchester: Still Doing the Rhumba |publisher=TheSpec.com |access-date=2012-08-24 |archive-date=2012-09-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120911100203/http://www.thespec.com/whatson/music/article/500966--jesse-winchester-still-doing-the-rhumba |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nWinchester was best known as a songwriter. His songs were recorded by many notable artists, including [[Patti Page]], [[Elvis Costello]], [[Jimmy Buffett]], [[Joan Baez]], [[Jerry Garcia]], [[Anne Murray]], [[The Weather Girls]], [[Reba McEntire]], the [[The Everly Brothers|Everly Brothers]], [[Lyle Lovett]], [[Emmylou Harris]], [[George Strait]], [[Gary Allan]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[Jennifer Warnes]], [[The Mavericks]] and [[Michael Stanley]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/jesse-winchester-emc|title=Jesse Winchester profile|publisher=[[The Canadian Encyclopedia]]|access-date=2012-08-24|archive-date=2017-07-05|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170705052148/http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/en/article/jesse-winchester-emc/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Pop_Encyclopedia/W/Winchester_Jesse.html|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120712205243/http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Pop_Encyclopedia/W/Winchester_Jesse.html|url-status=usurped|archive-date=July 12, 2012|title=CANOE \u2013 JAM! Music \u2013 Pop Encyclopedia \u2013 Winchester, Jesse |publisher=Jam.canoe.ca|access-date=2012-08-24}}</ref> A number of these recordings achieved positions on various charts.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ruhlmann |first=William|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/jesse-winchester-p5847/biography|title=Jesse Winchester profile|publisher=AllMusic|access-date=2012-08-24}}</ref>\n\n==Biography==\n===Early life===\nWinchester was born at [[Barksdale Air Force Base|Barksdale Army Air Field]], near [[Bossier City, Louisiana]], United States, and raised in northern [[Mississippi]] through age 12, when his family relocated to [[Memphis, Tennessee]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jessewinchester.com/PDFs/Interview%20-%20Crossroads%20to%20Freedom%202010.pdf|title=Crossroads to Freedom Interview : Rhodes College, Memphis, Tennessee|date=November 19, 2010|website=Jessewinchester.com|access-date=October 19, 2021}}</ref> Winchester was one of three children born to James Ridout Winchester Sr. (1917\u20131962) and Frances Ellyn Manire Winchester (1920\u20132010). In 1952, a heart attack left his father unable to farm.  Through his father's side, he is part of the [[Lee family]] of Virginia ([[Henry Lee II]] and [[Richard Henry Lee]] were two of his 4th-great-grandfathers).  He graduated from Christian Brothers High School in Memphis in 1962 as a merit finalist, a National Honor Society member and the salutatorian of his class. He graduated from [[Williams College]], in [[Williamstown, Massachusetts]], in 1966. Upon receiving his [[Conscription in the United States|draft notice]] the following year, Winchester moved to [[Montreal]], Quebec, Canada, to [[Draft evasion|avoid being drafted into the US military while the US was involved in a war with Vietnam]].<ref name=star>\"Jesse Winchester dies of cancer\". ''Toronto Star'', 14 April 2014, E2.</ref>  \"I was so offended by someone's coming up to me and presuming to tell me who I should kill and what my life was worth,\" he told ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine in 1977.<ref>[https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/jesse-winchester-dead-at-69-singer-songwriter-became-anti-war-icon-20140411#ixzz3PtlzcMjR Notice of death of Jesse Winchester] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150102135631/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/jesse-winchester-dead-at-69-singer-songwriter-became-anti-war-icon-20140411#ixzz3PtlzcMjR |date=2015-01-02 }}, rollingstone.com; accessed November 19, 2015.</ref>\n\nWinchester began playing guitar in bands while still in high school. He played in Germany during college study abroad and after graduation. Upon arriving in Quebec in 1967, he joined a local band, Les Astronautes. He also began writing songs, which he performed as a solo artist at the Montreal Folk Workshop and at coffeehouses throughout eastern Canada, adding impetus to a revival in folk music that was taking place across Canada. Under the auspices of the [[The Band|Band]]'s [[Robbie Robertson]], another Canadian, Winchester began his recording career in 1970 with a self-titled album released on the [[Ampex Records|Ampex]] label.<ref>[http://www.discogs.com/Jesse-Winchester-Jesse-Winchester/release/2455681 Profile], discogs.com; accessed November 19, 2015.</ref>\n\n===Career===\n{{quote box|quote=\"Winchester's first LP was [[apolitical]] on the surface and not without its [[conservative]] tendencies, but its brooding lyricism and barely contained ferment reflected the force of will it took for him to flee this country.\"|source=\u2014 ''[[Christgau's Record Guide: Rock Albums of the Seventies]]'' (1981)<ref name=\"CG\">{{cite book|last=Christgau|first=Robert|author-link=Robert Christgau|year=1981|title=Christgau's Record Guide: Rock Albums of the Seventies|publisher=[[Ticknor & Fields]]|isbn=089919026X|chapter=Consumer Guide '70s: W|chapter-url=https://www.robertchristgau.com/get_chap.php?k=W&bk=70|title-link=Christgau's Record Guide: Rock Albums of the Seventies|access-date=2021-12-24}}</ref>|width=23%|align=right|style=padding:8px;}}\n\nWinchester released several albums during the 1970s. Because of his status as a draft-evader, entailing that he was subject to arrest had he entered the country, he was unable to tour in the United States, and he became recognized primarily as a songwriter. His best-known songs include \"Yankee Lady\", \"The Brand New Tennessee Waltz\", \"Mississippi, You're on My Mind\", \"A Showman's Life\",\"Biloxi\", \"That's a Touch I Like\", and \"Every Word You Say\".<ref name=star/> These and others have been recorded by numerous artists.  His 1970 recording of his song \"Black Dog\" preceded the release of [[Black Dog (Led Zeppelin song)|Led Zeppelin's]] different song of the same name by a year.<ref>{{cite web| publisher=[[AllMusic]]| title=Jesse Winchester: ''Jesse Winchester''| url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/jesse-winchester-mw0000319466| accessdate=2021-12-24}}</ref>\n\nIn 1974, Winchester often performed at the Hotel Le Chatelet in [[Morin Heights|Morin Heights, Quebec]], run by several expatriate Tennesseans who had come to Canada in 1972. David \"Butch\" McDade and Jeff \"Stick\" Davis moved to Quebec to become part of Jesse Winchester and the Rhythm Aces. Winchester was the first to record the songs \"[[Third Rate Romance]]\" and \"The End Is Not in Sight\", both written by [[Russell Smith (singer)|Russell Smith]]. Smith traveled to Montreal to assist in the recording of the album ''Learn to Love It'' at Studio Six. Smith, Davis and McDade later were original members of the [[The Amazing Rhythm Aces|Amazing Rhythm Aces]].{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}\n\nUpon his election in 1976, President [[Jimmy Carter]] declared he would grant [[amnesty]] to draft evaders, except those who had deserted or had become citizens of another country. Winchester had by then become a Canadian citizen, but Barry Bozeman, his manager at the time, convinced Carter on Winchester's behalf to broaden the amnesty.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.burlingtonfreepress.com/story/life/2014/04/19/winchesters-imprint-hills-old-vermont/7879197/|title=Winchester's imprint 'in the hills of old Vermont'|last=Green|first=Susan|date=19 April 2014|website=Burlington Free Press|publisher=USA Today Network|access-date=2016-09-15}}</ref>\n\nWinchester's first appearance in the U.S. was a sold-out performance in [[Burlington, Vermont]], on April 21, 1977. On June 10 he appeared alongside [[Little Feat]], [[Emmylou Harris]] and [[Bonnie Raitt]]  on Burt Sugarman's ''[[The Midnight Special (TV series)|The Midnight Special]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0647429/fullcredits|title=\"The Midnight Special\" Episode #5.23 (TV Episode 1977)|access-date=27 November 2018|website=IMDb.com}}</ref>\n\nIn 1981, he had his first (and only) Top 40 U.S. hit single, \"Say What\". (No. 32 on the [[Billboard Hot 100]]). The single was from his Bearsville Records album release, \"Talk Memphis\".\n\n\"I'm Gonna Miss You, Girl\", written by Winchester, was recorded by American country music artist [[Michael Martin Murphey]] and released in October 1987, as the lead single from the album ''River of Time''. The song peaked at number 3 on the ''Billboard'' Hot Country Singles chart and at number 4 on the Canadian RPM Country Tracks chart. The version recorded by Murphy omits the somewhat sadder second part of the song. Winchester's version is on his album ''Love Filling Station''.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}\n\n===Later career===\nWinchester was nominated for the [[Juno Awards of 1990#Best Country Male Vocalist|Best Country Male Vocalist]] award at the [[Juno Award]]s of 1990. In 2002, he moved back to the United States,  settling in [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]] with his girlfriend, Cindy. That year, his song \"Step by Step\", from the album ''Let the Rough Side Drag'', was used as background music for the montage that ended the first season of the television program ''[[The Wire]]''.<ref>[http://gawker.com/366135/saying-goodbye-to-the-wire-over-and-over-again \"Saying goodbye to ''The Wire'' over and over again] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208123019/http://gawker.com/366135/saying-goodbye-to-the-wire-over-and-over-again |date=2015-12-08 }}, gawker.com; accessed November 29, 2015.</ref> He received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the [[American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers]] in 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://appleseedmusic.com/jessewinchester/ |title=Jesse Winchester |publisher=Appleseedmusic.com |access-date=2012-08-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811152911/http://appleseedmusic.com/jessewinchester/ |archive-date=2011-08-11 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Winchester continued to record and perform throughout the United States and Canada, releasing his tenth studio album, ''Love Filling Station'', in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Jesse-Winchester-Love-Filling-Station/release/5986303 |title=Jesse Winchester - Love Filling Station (CD, Album) |website=Discogs.com |date=2009-04-21 |access-date=2017-01-15}}</ref>\n\n[[File:Jesse Winchester cropped.PNG|thumb|200px|right|Winchester at the 2011 Blue Highways festival in Utrecht, the Netherlands]]\n\nIn 2011, Winchester was diagnosed with cancer of the esophagus and underwent treatment for the next couple of months. He was later given a clean bill of health from his doctor and resumed touring.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jessewinchester.com/index.html |title=Jesse Winchester's Studio |publisher=Jessewinchester.com |access-date=2014-04-11 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140601071440/http://www.jessewinchester.com/index.html |archive-date=2014-06-01 }}</ref> ''Quiet About It'', a tribute record to Winchester, was released in 2012, featuring [[James Taylor]], [[Lyle Lovett]], [[Lucinda Williams]], [[Rosanne Cash]] and [[Jimmy Buffett]], who spearheaded the project, among others.<ref>{{cite web|last=Deming|first=Mark|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/quiet-about-it-a-tribute-to-jesse-winchester-mw0002418862|title=Quiet About It: A Tribute To Jesse Winchester Review|publisher=AllMusic|access-date=2017-01-23}}</ref>\n\nIn April 2014, it was revealed that Winchester was gravely ill and receiving hospice care at his home, in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/2014/04/07/jesse-winchester-gravely-ill/7414733|title=Songwriter/performer Jesse Winchester is gravely ill|publisher=Usatoday.com|date=2014-04-07|access-date=2014-04-11}}</ref> He died there on the morning of April 11, 2014, aged 69, from [[bladder cancer]]. He is survived by his wife, Cindy and three children from a previous marriage: James, Alice and Marcus Lee.<ref name=singout>{{cite news|last=Tearson|first=Michael|title=Jesse Winchester Passes|url=http://singout.org/2014/04/11/jesse-winchester-passes/|newspaper=[[Sing Out!]]|date=April 11, 2014|access-date=April 11, 2014|archive-date=April 13, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413123927/http://singout.org/2014/04/11/jesse-winchester-passes/|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=commappeal>{{cite news|last=Mehr|first=Bob|title=Memphis-bred songwriter Jesse Winchester dies|url=http://www.commercialappeal.com/news/2014/apr/11/memphis-bred-songwriter-jesse-winchester-dies|newspaper=[[The Commercial Appeal]]|date=April 11, 2014|access-date=April 11, 2014}}</ref><ref>Browne, David (April 11) \"Jesse Winchester Dead at 69, Singer-Songwriter Became Anti-War Icon\" ''Rolling Stone'' (New York), April 11, 2014.</ref><ref>[https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/jesse-winchester-dead-at-69-singer-songwriter-became-anti-war-icon-20140411 Notice of death of Jesse Winchester] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150102135631/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/jesse-winchester-dead-at-69-singer-songwriter-became-anti-war-icon-20140411 |date=2015-01-02 }}, rollingstone.com; accessed November 19, 2015.</ref>\n\nWinchester's final CD, ''A Reasonable Amount of Trouble'', was released in September 2014, with liner notes by his friend [[Jimmy Buffett]]. It was nominated for two Grammy awards.''  Rolling Stone'' called it \"a gentle collection of playful songs about love, memory and gratitude that amounts to one of the most moving, triumphant albums of Winchester's 45 year career.\"<ref>[https://www.rollingstone.com/music/premieres/hear-the-late-jesse-winchesters-chilling-dissertation-on-dying-song-premiere-20140902#ixzz3PtoHBNxh \"Jesse Winchester's chilling dissertation on dying\"], rollingstone.com; accessed November 19, 2015.</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n!
