web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/zac-brown-band-castaway/|title=Zac Brown Band, 'Castaway' [Listen]|date=April 15, 2016|work=[[Taste of Country]]|access-date=September 19, 2019}}</ref>\n}}\n| years_active      = 2002\u2013present\n| label             = {{flatlist|\n* [[Bigger Picture Music Group|Bigger Picture]]\n* Southern Ground\n* [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]]\n* RPM\n* [[Big Machine Records|Big Machine]]\n* [[Republic Records|Republic]]\n* [[Elektra Records|Elektra]]\n* [[BMG Rights Management|BMG]]\n}}\n| spinoffs          = [[Sir Rosevelt]]\n| website           = {{URL|zacbrownband.com}}\n| current_members   = * [[Zac Brown]]\n* [[Coy Bowles]]\n* [[Clay Cook]]\n* [[Daniel de los Reyes]]\n* Matt Mangano\n* Jimmy De Martini\n* [[Chris Fryar]]\n* [[John Driskell Hopkins]]\n* [[Caroline Jones]]\n\n| past_members      = * Tim Ussery\n* Jacob Lawson\n* Marcus Petruska\n* Joel Williams<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charlestoncitypaper.com/charleston/visiting-act-zwnj-what-a-rush/Content?oid=1105874|title=VISITING ACT \u200c What a Rush Zac Brown knows it's all good on the Road Bus Tour|last=Lesemann|first=T. Ballard|date=July 26, 2006|work=Charleston City Paper|access-date=March 19, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://djournal.com/news/082406-page-3-zac-brown-band/|title=Zac Brown Band|last=Barnett|first=Sheena|date=August 24, 2006|work=DJournal.com|access-date=March 19, 2017|archive-date=March 20, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170320052022/http://djournal.com/news/082406-page-3-zac-brown-band/|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n}}\n\n'''Zac Brown Band''' is an  American [[country music]] band based in [[Atlanta, Georgia]]. The lineup consists of [[Zac Brown]] (lead vocals, guitar), Jimmy De Martini ([[fiddle]], vocals), [[John Driskell Hopkins]] (bass guitar, guitar, [[baritone guitar]], [[banjo]], [[ukulele]], [[Double bass|upright bass]], vocals<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1726309/zac-brown-band-reveals-tour-dates/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215150452/http://www.cmt.com/news/1726309/zac-brown-band-reveals-tour-dates/|url-status=dead|archive-date=February 15, 2015|title=Zac Brown Band Reveals Tour Dates|date=April 16, 2014|work=CMT|access-date=February 15, 2015}}</ref>), [[Coy Bowles]] (guitar, keyboards), [[Chris Fryar]] (drums), [[Clay Cook]] (guitar, keyboards, [[mandolin]], [[steel guitar]], vocals), Matt Mangano (bass guitar), [[Daniel de los Reyes]] (percussion), and [[Caroline Jones]] (guitar, keyboards, harmonica, vocals).\n\nThe band has released seven studio albums along with two live albums, one greatest-hits album, and two extended plays. They have also 16 singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] or Country Airplay chart, of which 13 have reached number 1. Their first album, ''[[The Foundation (Zac Brown Band album)|The Foundation]]'', is certified triple-platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]], while its follow-ups, ''[[You Get What You Give (album)|You Get What You Give]]'' and ''[[Uncaged]]'', are certified platinum. Artists with whom they have collaborated include [[Alan Jackson]], [[Angie Aparo]], [[Jimmy Buffett]], [[Kid Rock]], [[Jason Mraz]], [[Dave Grohl]], [[Chris Cornell]], [[Brandi Carlile]], [[Avicii]], [[Los Lonely Boys]], [[Sara Bareilles|Sara Barellies]] and [[John Fogerty]] of [[Creedence Clearwater Revival]].\n\n==History==\n===Formation===\n{{more citations needed section|date=January 2015}}\nIn 2002, Brown was traveling with a heavy tour schedule of approximately 200 dates a year. The initial Zac Brown Band lineup consisted of Brown, on acoustic guitar and lead vocals, backed by drummer Marcus Petruska and bass guitarist Jacob Lawson. In 2003, Brown started his own label, called Home Grown\u2014it was later renamed \"Southern Ground\".\n\nIn 2004, Brown opened a music club and restaurant with his father in the Lake Oconee area of Georgia, called \"Zac's Place\" where the fare was southern-style cooking. A developer bought the restaurant and, in turn, the Zac Brown Band bought a tour bus and began touring full-time, playing rock and country clubs, as well as folk and jam band festivals. The release of the Zac Brown Band's first independent album, ''Home Grown'', occurred during the same year.\n\nAlso in 2004, Brown added violinist/fiddler and tenor vocalist Jimmy De Martini to the lineup. According to an interview with De Martini, he explained that Wyatt Durrette, Brown's frequent songwriting collaborator, was working as a bartender at Sidelines Sports Bar in [[Kennesaw, Georgia]], at the time, where the Zac Brown Band frequently performed. Durette suggested De Martini to Brown, who was wanting a \"lead instrument\" in his band, as well as a harmony singer. After doing several performances with the band at the club, Brown asked De Martini to become a permanent member, to which De Martini gladly obliged.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://greenville.metromix.com/music/article/q-and-a-jimmy/1470971/content|title=Q&A: Jimmy DeMartini of Zac Brown Band|author=Matt Wake|publisher=Metromix Greenville|date=September 17, 2009|access-date=November 23, 2011}}</ref>\n\nBrown met [[John Driskell Hopkins]] in 1998 when Hopkins was hosting an open mic night at CJ's Landing in Buckhead, Georgia. Hopkins later recorded ''Home Grown'' in his music studio, Brighter Shade Studios. The two remained friends, and in 2005, Hopkins stepped in as bass guitarist while helping the group finish what became their number-one single \"Toes\". \"Toes\" was the second single from the band's major-label debut, ''[[The Foundation (Zac Brown Band album)|The Foundation]]'', which was partially recorded in Hopkins' studio. ''[[You Get What You Give (album)|You Get What You Give]]'' was also partially recorded in Brighter Shade Studios.\n\n[[Coy Bowles]] transferred to Atlanta's [[Georgia State University]] to study music. He subsequently became involved in Atlanta's various music scenes, and eventually formed Coy Bowles and the Fellowship in 2004. Two years later, Bowles decided to reconnect with Brown. Through mutual friends, he learned that the Zac Brown Band was scheduled to perform in Atlanta one evening. Bowles and Brown spent the afternoon prior to the performance reacquainting with each other, which ended with Brown inviting Bowles to sit in with his band at that night's performance. To return the favor, Bowles invited the band to attend his own gig with the Fellowship a couple of months later, which in turn resulted in Brown and his band sitting in at that gig.\n\nThis turn of events continued for eight months until Bowles concluded that it was too overwhelming to balance his time with Brown's band and his own band, in addition to other activities; he therefore made a decision to put the Fellowship on an indefinite hiatus, and became a permanent member of the Zac Brown Band.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.coybowles.com/music/about-zbb/|title=About ZBB|work=Coy Bowles|access-date=November 23, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.coybowles.com/coy/about/|title=About|work=Coy Bowles|access-date=November 23, 2011}}</ref>\n\nIn 2008, the Zac Brown Band signed to Live Nation Artists Records, in association with Brown's own Home Grown label, after Chris Fryar became an addition to the band. An [[Alabama]] native, Fryar attended the [[University of North Texas]] and the [[Mississippi University for Women]], and made a name for himself in the [[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]] music scene.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blog.al.com/mcolurso/2011/05/and_the_beat_goes_on_gardendal.html|title=The beat goes on: Gardendale drummer Chris Fryar earns fame, stays humble in Zac Brown Band (video)|author=Mary Colurso|newspaper=[[The Birmingham News]]|date=May 27, 2011|access-date=November 23, 2011}}</ref> According to Fryar, a mutual friend recommended him to Brown, who was in need of a new drummer for the band. Fryar, who in turn had just finished a stint with a previous band, subsequently auditioned and shortly afterward became the Zac Brown Band's newest member.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pandora.com/static/ads/landing_pages/4343_zacbrownband/4343_landing_page.html|title=Landshark Lager - Proud Sponsor of Zac Brown Band|website=Pandora.com|access-date=December 23, 2011}}</ref>\n\nIn 2014, with the addition of bass guitarist Matt Mangano to the line-up, Hopkins expanded from his own role as bass guitarist to add other instruments in his arsenal such as standard six-string guitar, seven-string guitar, baritone guitar, ukulele, double bass, and banjo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zacbrownband.com/john-driskell-hopkins.html |title=John Driskell Hopkins |publisher=Zac Brown Band |access-date=August 1, 2014}}</ref>\n\n===Commercial success===\n{{more citations needed section|date=January 2015}}\nThe Zac Brown Band's debut single, \"[[Chicken Fried]]\", was originally recorded in 2003 and included on the ''Home Grown'' album, but later re-recorded and released to country radio in 2008. This song was also recorded by [[The Lost Trailers]], whose 2006 recording was released as a single but withdrawn after Brown decided that he wanted to release it himself.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allbusiness.com/services/motion-pictures/4477828-1.html |title= BNA Forced To Swap Trailers' Single |access-date=June 19, 2008 |last=Tucker |first=Ken |date=March 15, 2006 |work=Radio Monitor}}</ref> Brown also co-wrote \"Simple Life\", a song recorded by The Lost Trailers on their 2006 [[The Lost Trailers (album)|self-titled album]].\n\nIn the third episode of HBO's music documentary series [[Foo Fighters: Sonic Highways|Sonic Highways]], Brown was a featured interviewee and explained why Lost Trailer's version of \"Chicken Fried\" was pulled from the radio. Brown stated that after six years of touring that he was broke and sleeping in his tour van. In 2005 the Lost Trailers contacted Brown and expressed interest in recording \"Chicken Fried\". Brown stated he agreed under the condition that the song would only be an album cut and not a single as he still had hopes of releasing the song as a radio single himself.\n\nBoth parties agreed and the Lost Trailers recorded the song. Some months later the Lost Trailers landed a deal with Sony Nashville, and when they submitted the tracks for their album, they included \"Chicken Fried\". [[Joe Galante]], then the Chairman of Sony Music Nashville, heard the tracks and chose \"Chicken Fried\" as the single that the label wanted to promote.\n\nBrown described hearing his song on the radio: \"The first time I hear 'Chicken Fried' on the radio and it wasn't us singing it. It was a nightmare.\" Brown then called his lawyer to have the song pulled from the radio immediately. Brown's lawyer warned him that because of Galante's power in the Nashville music scene that pulling the song could essentially have him blackballed in Nashville. Brown was insistent that his agreement with the Lost Trailers was violated, so his lawyer issued a [[cease and desist]] letter and the single was pulled from the radio.\n\nA few months later The Zac Brown Band was booked to perform at 3rd and Lindsley in Nashville and producer [[Keith Stegall]] came to watch their performance. Stegall and Brown had drinks later that night and Brown recalled Stegall stating, \"I just had to meet the kid that told Joe Galante to fuck off!\" Brown credits this incident and his meeting and collaboration with Stegall as the beginning of his success in the music business.\n\nIn October 2008, [[Atlantic Records]] acquired distribution of \"Chicken Fried\" after Live Nation Artists closed. The band's album ''[[The Foundation (Zac Brown Band album)|The Foundation]]'' was released under Atlantic Records' newly re-established country division in association with the Home Grown/Bigger Picture label on November 18 of that year.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1043645/zac-brown-band-signs-with-atlantic |title=Zac Brown Band Signs With Atlantic  |access-date=October 29, 2008 |last=Tucker |first=Ken |date=October 29, 2008 |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]}}</ref> \"Chicken Fried\" reached No.&nbsp;1 on the country charts that same month, making them the first country band to reach No.&nbsp;1 with a debut single since [[Heartland (country music band)|Heartland]] did so in 2006 with \"[[I Loved Her First (song)|I Loved Her First]]\".<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/content_display/charts/chart_alert/e3iac81cb9ace3320f8be5a577c0bd8f3ef |title=Beyonce's 'Fierce' Debut Leads Pre-Turkey Day Chart  |access-date=December 7, 2008|date=November 26, 2008 |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]}}</ref>\n\nIn July 2012, Zac Brown Band debuted their new CD, ''Uncaged'', which was well received. Billboard considered the album to be the best country album of 2012 as of its release.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/481828/zac-brown-band-uncaged-track-by-track-review|title=Zac Brown Band, 'Uncaged': Track-by-Track Review|last=Dauphin|first=Chuck|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=July 10, 2012|access-date=August 11, 2012}}</ref>\n\nOn January 7, 2013, Zac Brown Band performed the National Anthem at the [[2013 BCS National Championship Game]] between the Alabama Crimson Tide and the Notre Dame Fighting Irish at Sun Life Stadium in Miami. Just two weeks later on January 20, 2013, the band performed the National Anthem during the NFC Championship Game between the Seattle Seahawks and the San Francisco 49ers at the CenturyLink Field in Seattle.\n\nOn January 1, 2014, Zac Brown Band performed the National Anthem during the NHL's Winter Classic between the [[Detroit Red Wings]] & [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] at [[Michigan Stadium]] in Ann Arbor, Michigan, home of the [[Michigan Wolverines]] football team.\n\nThe Zac Brown Band announced on January 12, 2015, that it had finalized a four-way strategic partnership involving the Southern Ground Artists record label, Big Machine Label Group, Republic Records, and [[John Varvatos]] Records for the release of its fourth studio album. The terms of the deal state that the Zac Brown Band will work with Big Machine Label Group for marketing and distribution, while Southern Ground Artists will work on radio promotion, Republic will provide support in the area of non-country radio formats and international promotion, and Varvatos will oversee branding and styling.<ref name=\"Zac\">{{cite news|author=Nate Rau|title=Zac Brown Band aligns with Big Machine|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/money/industries/music/2015/01/12/zac-brown-band-aligns-big-machine/21649505/|newspaper=[[The Tennessean]]|access-date=January 17, 2015|date=January 12, 2015}}</ref> Brown stated in a press release:\n\n<blockquote>Southern Ground Artists together with John Varvatos Records, Big Machine Label Group, and Republic Records is the dream team for Zac Brown Band's evolution ... We're excited to reach new music fans worldwide.<ref name=\"Zac\" /></blockquote>\n\n===Addition of Clay Cook===\nIn January 2009, two months after \"Chicken Fried\" went to No.&nbsp;1, Atlanta native [[Clay Cook]] joined the Zac Brown Band as its multi-instrumentalist and high tenor vocalist. Cook had previously collaborated with [[John Mayer]] and [[Shawn Mullins]], and was also a member of the [[Marshall Tucker Band]] for two years prior to joining the Zac Brown Band.\n\nCook explains how he first met Brown:\n\n{{blockquote|We ran into each other (in) 2003 in a club scene in Atlanta, where my band opened up for his band ... ever since then, we've been friendly ... and I think he just thought I was a singer-songwriter for a long time; and then we were on a (music) cruise ship together ... and I was playing with the Marshall Tucker Band at the time, and (Brown)'s band (also participated in the cruise) ... and he actually got to see me play the guitar ... and then he realized, 'I need this guy in my band,' I guess.<ref name=\"youtube.com\">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gj69DZ-FHTE| archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211107/Gj69DZ-FHTE| archive-date=2021-11-07 | url-status=live|title=ExploreMusic chats with Clay Cook|publisher=[[YouTube]]|date=2010-12-10|access-date=2011-11-23}}{{cbignore}}</ref>}}\n\nBrown himself admitted his strong desire to add Cook to the lineup, for he believed Cook's musicianship would enhance the Zac Brown Band's overall musical style:\n\n{{blockquote|I'd been tryin' to get him in the band for three years, and you know, it's been a journey, but I always knew [he could make us better]. I'm a harmony fanatic. I love big harmonies and things, and we didn't have a high tenor, and Jimmy [De Martini], my fiddle player, sings a lot of the high stuff now, but havin' somebody that can actually sing on top of that, we've added a four-part harmony now that's searing, and the guy's a monster player, too.\"<ref name=gactv.com>{{cite web|url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/nw_headlines/article/0,,GAC_26063_5942665,00.html|title=Zac Brown Band Expands On ''The Foundation''|publisher=GAC News|date=2009-04-21|access-date=2011-11-23}}</ref>}}\n\nWith the new Zac Brown Band lineup completed, the band released its second single, \"[[Whatever It Is]]\", which went to No.&nbsp;2. In October 2009, a third single, \"[[Toes (Zac Brown Band song)|Toes]]\", became the band's second Number One. The album's fourth single, and third No.&nbsp;1, was \"[[Highway 20 Ride]]\". \"[[Free (Zac Brown Band song)|Free]]\" was the album's fifth single and on the week of August 21, 2010, it also peaked at Number One.\n\n===''Uncaged'' and ''The Grohl Sessions, Vol. 1''===\nOn April 25, 2012, it was announced via the Zac Brown Band's website that percussionist [[Daniel de los Reyes]] had joined the band on a permanent basis. De los Reyes had previously performed with the band as a touring musician and participated in the recording of their album ''[[Uncaged]]''. De los Reyes has also performed with artists and groups such as [[Earth, Wind and Fire]], [[Jennifer Lopez]] and [[Sting (musician)|Sting]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/music/zac-brown-talks-new-album-uncaged-out-july-10-new-band-member-and-search-for-that-pulse/2012/04/25/gIQA0wYKgT_story.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190113062655/https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/music/zac-brown-talks-new-album-uncaged-out-july-10-new-band-member-and-search-for-that-pulse/2012/04/25/gIQA0wYKgT_story.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 13, 2019|title=Zac Brown talks new album 'Uncaged,' out July 10, new band member and search for 'that pulse'|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|date=April 25, 2012|access-date=April 29, 2012}}</ref> \"[[Goodbye in Her Eyes]]\" reached Number One on the [[Country Airplay]] chart in 2013. The album's third single, \"[[Jump Right In]]\", was released to country radio on February 25, 2013. It peaked at number 2 on the Country Airplay chart in August 2013. The album's fourth single, \"[[Sweet Annie]]\", was released to country radio in August 2013, and rose to number 1 in January 2014. The music video for this track features footage of band member Coy Bowles\u2019 actual wedding.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://concerty.com/artist/507226f4-0842-4f43-950e-81a7017230ec |title=Zac Brown Band Biography |website=Concerty.com}}</ref> In December 2013, the band released a digital four-song EP titled ''[[The Grohl Sessions, Vol. 1]]'', produced by [[Dave Grohl]] of [[Foo Fighters]]. It was later given a physical release featuring a 45-minute DVD on the album's creation. \"[[All Alright]]\" was released as a single from the EP, charting at number 17 on [[Country Airplay]].\n\nIn April 2014, the band announced its summer tour schedule, which included [[Kacey Musgraves]] as an opening act, and the addition of Matt Mangano as an eighth member. Mangano previously performed live with Zac Brown Band when they performed \"Blackbird\" on the \"[[Pass the Jar: Zac Brown Band and Friends Live from the Fabulous Fox Theatre in Atlanta|Pass The Jar]]\" live album. Mangano assumed the role of [[bass guitar]]ist, while original bassist John Driskell Hopkins began adding other instruments including [[banjo]] and [[ukulele]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/zac-brown-band-great-american-road-trip-tour/ |title=Zac Brown Band Announce Summer Tour, Eighth Band Member |website=Tasteofcountry.com |date=April 15, 2014 |access-date=August 1, 2014}}</ref>\n\n===''Jekyll + Hyde''===\nThe band signed to [[Big Machine Records]] in 2015 and released its sixteenth single, \"[[Homegrown (song)|Homegrown]]\", in January. The song, co-produced by [[Jay Joyce]], was the lead single to an album, titled ''[[Jekyll + Hyde]]'', which was released on April 28, 2015. Despite being a country album, Jekyll + Hyde features prominent styles from other genres in several of its tracks including rock ([[Heavy Is the Head (Zac Brown Band song)|Heavy Is the Head]]),<ref name=\"NYT\">{{cite news |last1=Caramanica |first1=Jon |title=Review: Zac Brown Band's 'Jekyll + Hyde' |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/28/arts/music/review-zac-brown-bands-jekyll-hyde.html?_r=0 |access-date=4 January 2022 |work=The New York Times |date=27 April 2015}}</ref> EDM ([[Beautiful Drug ]]),<ref name=\"NYT\" /> celtic (Remedy),<ref name=\"RS\">{{cite magazine |last=Hermes |first=Will |date=28 April 2015 |title=Jekyll+Hyde |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/jekyll-hyde-99850/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]  |access-date=4 January 2022}}</ref> reggae ([[Castaway (Zac Brown Band song)|Castaway]])<ref name=\"RS\" /> and traditional pop/jazz (Mango Tree).<ref name=\"RS\" />\n\nOn Saturday, March 7, 2015, the band made their ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' debut, performing \"Homegrown\" and \"Heavy is the Head\".<ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Manning|first1=Erin|title=Watch Zac Brown Band and Chris Cornell on 'SNL'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/see-zac-brown-band-bring-homegrown-country-and-chris-cornell-to-snl-20150308|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=March 31, 2017|date=March 8, 2015}}</ref>\n\nThe band contributed vocals on the [[Avicii]] song \"[[Broken Arrows (song)|Broken Arrows]]\", released in September 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Avicii Explains Choosing Zac Brown for \"Broken Arrows\" Single|url=http://923amp.cbslocal.com/2016/02/19/avicii-explains-zac-brown-broken-arrows/|website=923amp.cbslocal.com|access-date=March 31, 2017}}</ref>\n\nJekyll + Hyde is the first album that ZBB recorded when they weren't on the road.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theboot.com/zac-brown-band-jekyll-and-hyde-album/?trackback=tsmclip |title=Everything We Know About Zac Brown Band's 'Jekyll + Hyde' |website=Theboot.com |date=March 25, 2015 |access-date=May 17, 2017}}</ref>\n\n===''Welcome Home''===\nOn January 30, 2017, the band previewed cover art for a new album titled ''Welcome Home'' produced by Dave Cobb, was released on May 12, 2017.<ref name=\"Welcome Home\">{{cite web|last1=Horton|first1=Carrie|title=Everything We Know About Zac Brown Band's 'Welcome Home'|url=http://theboot.com/zac-brown-band-welcome-home-new-album-2017-details/|website=Theboot.com|access-date=March 31, 2017}}</ref> The first single from the album, \"[[My Old Man (Zac Brown Band song)|My Old Man]]\", was released on February 3, 2017. Their latest song \"Roots\" was released on May 3, 2017. The band performed the song on ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon]]'' on March 29, 2017.<ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Gage|first1=Jeff|title=Watch Zac Brown Band's Powerful 'My Old Man' on 'Fallon'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/watch-zac-brown-bands-powerful-my-old-man-on-fallon-w474207|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=March 31, 2017|date=March 30, 2017}}</ref>\nIn September 2018, it was announced that Zac Brown Band would make their second appearance of ''[[CMT Crossroads]]'' along with [[Shawn Mendes]], which was televised on October 24, 2018.\n\n===''The Owl''===\nThe band released their sixth album ''The Owl'' on September 20, 2019. The album includes collaborations with [[Skrillex]], [[Max Martin]], [[Ryan Tedder]], [[Benny Blanco]], [[Andrew Watt (musician)|Andrew Watt]], [[Poo Bear|Jason \"Poo Bear\" Boyd]], and others. A digital single from the album, \"Leaving Love Behind\" was released on July 26, 2019. Brown describes some songs on the album as \"personal\" and \"pretty heavy.\"<ref name=\"The Owl\">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/8524009/zac-brown-band-new-album-the-owl-exclusive|title=Zac Brown Band Returning With New Album 'The Owl': Exclusive|magazine=Billboard|last=Newman|first=Melinda|date=July 26, 2019}}</ref> Concurrently, Brown released a solo album called ''Controversy'', accompanied by a new single called \"Swayze\".<ref>{{Cite magazine | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/zac-brown-solo-controversy-album-891670/ |title = Zac Brown, What Have You Done?|magazine = [[Rolling Stone]]|date = September 27, 2019}}</ref>\n\n===''The Comeback''===\nOn October 15, 2021, the band released their 7th album ''The Comeback.'' The first single from the album, \"Same Boat\", was released on June 11, 2021, by Homegrown Music and Waner Music Nashville.<ref>{{Citation|title=The Comeback by Zac Brown Band|date=2021-10-15|url=https://music.apple.com/us/album/the-comeback/1582050000|language=en-US|access-date=2022-01-14}}</ref> The song became the band's first number one single on the [[Country Airplay]] chart since 2016's \"[[Beautiful Drug]]\" and their fourteenth overall.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.billboard.com/music/chart-beat/zac-brown-band-same-boat-no-1-country-airplay-chart-1235003695/ | title=Zac Brown Band's 'Same Boat' Floats to No. 1 on Country Airplay Chart | magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] }}</ref> The album's second single \"[[Out in the Middle]]\" was released in January 2022 and reached number thirteen.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://tasteofcountry.com/zac-brown-band-out-in-the-middle/ | title=LISTEN: Zac Brown Band's 'Out in the Middle' Doubles Down on Their Roots | date=January 25, 2022 }}</ref> A deluxe edition of the album was released in September 2022 and features several tracks reimagined as duets featuring [[Blake Shelton]], [[Ingrid Andress]] and [[Jamey Johnson]], [[Cody Johnson]] and [[Jimmy Buffett]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://musicrow.com/2022/06/zac-brown-band-announce-plans-to-release-the-comeback-deluxe-album/ | title=Zac Brown Band Make Plans to Release 'The Comeback Deluxe Album' | date=June 13, 2022 }}</ref> On November 3, 2022, it was announced that [[Caroline Jones]] had joined the group as an official member after having opened for and toured with the band since 2017 becoming the band's first female member.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://tasteofcountry.com/zac-brown-band-caroline-jones-official-member/ | title=Zac Brown Band Welcomes Caroline Jones as Newest Member | date=November 3, 2022 }}</ref>\n\n==Awards==\nSince 2009, the Zac Brown Band has earned 55 award nominations from the [[Grammys]], [[Academy of Country Music]], [[American Music Awards]], [[Country Music Association]] and [[Country Music Television]], and has won 8.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://shorefire.com/index.php?a=bio&o=215 |title=Bio |publisher=Shore Fire |date=February 26, 1997|access-date=October 7, 2013}}</ref>\n\nThey have received four nominations for the 2009 CMA Awards: New Artist of the Year, Song of the Year, Single of the Year, and Music Video of the Year for their No.&nbsp;1 single, \"Chicken Fried\".<ref>{{cite news |title=Urban, Swift, Johnson & Zac Brown Band Lead BMI 2009 CMA Nominations |url=https://www.bmi.com/news/entry/urban_swift_johnson_zac_brown_band_lead_bmi_2009_cma_nominations |access-date=4 January 2022 |work=Broadcast Music, Inc. |date=10 September 2009}}</ref> That same year, they received three Grammy nominations for Best Country Album, Best Country Performance By a Duo or Group With Vocals and Best New Artist. On January 31, 2010, the band won the Grammy award for Best New Artist.\n\nThe Zac Brown Band was also nominated in 2009 for three ACM awards, \"Album of the Year\", \"Vocal Group of the Year\", and was one of eight contenders for \"Entertainer of the Year\".<ref>{{cite web |title=45th ACM Awards Nominees Announced |url=http://roughstock.com/news/2010/03/19868-45th-acm-awards-nominees-announced |website=RoughStock |access-date=4 January 2022 |date=2 March 2010}}</ref>\n\nThe Zac Brown Band led the nominees for the 46th annual Academy of Country Music Awards 2011, with a total of nine nominations including: Vocal Group of the Year, Album of the Year, Single Record of the Year, Song of the Year, Vocal Event of the Year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zacbrowninfo.com/zac-brown-band-news/621-acm-award-nominations.html |title=ACM award nominations - Zac Brown Band |website=www.zacbrowninfo.com |access-date=17 January 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718150554/http://www.zacbrowninfo.com/zac-brown-band-news/621-acm-award-nominations.html |archive-date=18 July 2011 |url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! \"Sweet Annie\"\n|{{nom}}\n|<ref>{{cite web |title=CMT Music Awards 2014: The Complete Winners List |url=https://www.thewrap.com/cmt-awards-2014-the-complete-winners-list/ |website=The Wrap |date=June 4, 2014 |access-date=5 January 2022}}</ref>\n|-\n|CMA Awards\n|Vocal Group of the Year\n|{{nom}}\n|<ref>{{cite news |last1=Wang |first1=Andrea |title=CMA Awards 2014: List of nominees and winners |url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-cma-awards-2014-list-nominees-winners-story.html |access-date=5 January 2022 |work=Los Angeles Times |date=6 November 2014}}</ref>\n|-\n|rowspan=\"5\"|2015\n|[[41st People's Choice Awards|People's Choice Awards]]\n|Favorite Country Group\n|{{nom}}\n|<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/peoples-choice-awards-winners-list-2015-1201395501/|title=People's Choice Awards 2015: Full Winners List|magazine=Variety|date=7 January 2015|access-date=5 January 2022}}</ref>\n|-\n|ACM Awards\n|Vocal Group of the Year\n|{{nom}}\n|<ref>{{cite news |title=ACM Awards 2015: The Complete List of Nominees |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/acm-awards-2015-complete-list-nominees/story?id=28605064 |access-date=5 January 2022 |work=ABC News |publisher=Walt Disney Television |language=en}}</ref>\n|-\n|CMT Awards\n|Group Video of the Year - \"Heavy is the Head\" (feat. \"Someone I Used to Know\"\n| {{won}}\n|<ref>{{cite web |last1=Tingle |first1=Lauren |title=2019 CMT Music Awards: The Winners |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1807252/2019-cmt-music-awards-the-winners/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190607162935/http://www.cmt.com/news/1807252/2019-cmt-music-awards-the-winners/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=June 7, 2019 |website=CMT News |access-date=5 January 2022}}</ref>\n|-\n|CMT Video of the Year - \"Someone I Used to Know\"\n| {{nom}}\n|<ref name=\"2019 CMT\">{{cite web |title=CMT Music Awards 2019: Complete list of winners |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/cma-music-festival/2019/06/05/cmt-music-awards-nominees-winners-2019/1359985001/ |website=The Tennessean |access-date=5 January 2022}}</ref>\n|-\n|CMT Performance of the Year - \"Keep Me In Mind (From CMT Crossroads) with [[Shawn Mendes]]\n| {{nom}}\n|<ref name=\"2019 CMT\" />\n|}\n\n===Grammy Awards===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Year\n! Nominee/work\n! Category\n! Result\n! class=\"unsortable\"| {{Abbr|Ref.|References}}\n|-\n|rowspan=\"3\"|[[52nd Annual Grammy Awards|2010]]\n|Zac Brown Band\n|[[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]]\n|{{won}}\n|<ref>{{cite news |title=Beyonce takes 5 Grammys; Kings of Leon win record - Yahoo! News |url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100201/ap_on_en_mu/us_grammys_50 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100204184820/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100201/ap_on_en_mu/us_grammys_50 |url-status=dead |archive-date=2010-02-04 |access-date=5 January 2022 |work=Yahoo! News |publisher=Yahoo! |date=4 February 2010}}</ref>\n|-\n| ''[[The Foundation (Zac Brown Band album)|The Foundation]]''\n| [[Grammy Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]]\n|{{nom}}\n|<ref name=\"2010 Grammys\">{{cite web |title=The 2010 Grammy Awards: Full List of Nominees |url=https://www.thehollywoodgossip.com/2009/12/the-2010-grammy-awards-full-list-of-nominees/ |website=The Hollywood Gossip |access-date=5 January 2022 |language=en |date=3 December 2009}}</ref>\n|-\n| \"[[Chicken Fried]]\"\n|rowspan=\"2\"|[[Grammy Award for Best Country Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocal|Best Country Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals]]\n|{{nom}}\n|<ref name=\"2010 Grammys\" />\n|-\n|rowspan=\"4\"|[[53rd Annual Grammy Awards|2011]]\n| rowspan=\"2\"|\"[[Free (Zac Brown Band song)|Free]]\"\n|{{nom}}\n|<ref name=\"2011 Grammys\">{{cite news |title=Grammy Awards 2011: Winners and nominees for 53rd Grammy Awards |url=https://www.latimes.com/la-et-env-grammys-nominees-2010-list-htmlstory.html |access-date=5 January 2022 |work=Los Angeles Times |date=12 March 2014}}</ref>\n|-\n|[[Grammy Award for Best Country Vocals|Best Country Collaboration with Vocals]]\n|{{won}}\n|<ref name=\"2011 Grammys\" />\n|-\n| ''[[You Get What You Give (album)|You Get What You Give]]''\n|rowspan=\"2\"| Best Country Album\n|{{nom}}\n|<ref name=\"2011 Grammys\" />\n|-\n|[[55th Annual Grammy Awards|2013]]\n| ''[[Uncaged]]''\n|{{won}}\n|<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://entertainment.time.com/2013/02/11/grammys-2013-the-complete-list-of-winners/|title=Grammys 2013: The Complete List of Winners|magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=11 February 2013|access-date=5 January 2022}}</ref>\n|-\n|[[2018 Grammy Awards|2018]]\n|\"My Old Man\"\n|Best Country Duo/Group Performance\n|{{nom}}\n|<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.instyle.com/news/2018-grammy-nominations|title=See All the 2018 Grammy Nominations and Winners Here|magazine=InStyle|date=29 January 2018|access-date=5 January 2022}}</ref>\n{{end}}\n\n==Collaborations and appearances==\nAlong with recent commercial success, the band has made appearances at The Hangout Music Festival, Hullabalou Music Festival and the [[Bonnaroo Music Festival]] in 2006, 2009, and 2010 along with an opening slot for the [[Dave Matthews Band]] during their 2010 Summer Tour. Also, after several years as perennial favorites on the annual [[The Rock Boat]] theme-cruise, the Zac Brown Band has been elevated to hosting their own theme-cruise, Sailing Southern Ground, in September 2010. In Fall of 2009, the band began offering fan-club members the ability to purchase tickets to VIP Eat & Greet experiences before the majority of their tour appearances. These events afford fans the opportunity to share a meal with band-members before the show, and have become an integral part of the overall Zac Brown Band live experience.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lNh_Hrzj30U | archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211107/lNh_Hrzj30U| archive-date=2021-11-07 | url-status=live|title=USA Today (2011). \"Eat and Greet with the Zac Brown Band\". USA Today |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date=January 19, 2011 |access-date=October 7, 2013}}{{cbignore}}</ref>\n\nIn 2011, the Zac Brown Band and [[Blackberry Smoke]] held a concert tour at venues and amphitheaters including Hollywood Bowl in Los Angeles, CA.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ocregister.com/entertainment/-300592--.html|work=The Orange County Register|first=Ben|last=Wener|title=Fans go wild for Zac Brown Band's Bowl debut|date=May 25, 2011 }}</ref>\n\nOn April 28, 2013, the Zac Brown Band headlined the 2013 [[Stagecoach Festival]] in Indio, California.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1706531/stagecoach-festival-scorching-heat-and-lots-of-george-jones-songs.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502113536/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1706531/stagecoach-festival-scorching-heat-and-lots-of-george-jones-songs.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=May 2, 2013|work=CMT.com|first=Chris|last=Willman|title=Stagecoach Festival: Scorching Heat and Lots of George Jones Songs|date=April 29, 2013 }}</ref>\n\nZac Brown Band completed a three-night, headlining stint at [[Red Rocks Amphitheatre]] on Wednesday, May 8, 2013, Thursday, May 9, 2013, and Friday, May 10, 2013. All three performances were sold out.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/zac-brown-band-red-rocks-pictures/|work=TasteOfCountry.com|title=Zac Brown Band Brave Cold and Rain to Entertain Fan at Red Rocks \u2013 Exclusive Pictures|date=May 9, 2013}}</ref>\n\nOn September 6, 2013, Zac Brown sat in with [[The String Cheese Incident]] and performed as the Zac Brown Incident during the inaugural Lockin' Festival in Arrington, VA.<ref>{{cite web|author=Curtis |url=http://www.panicstream.net/vault/zac-brown-incident-09062013-arrington-va/ |title=Zac Brown Incident - 09/06/2013 - Arrington, VA|website=PanicStream.net |date=September 6, 2013 |access-date=October 7, 2013}}</ref>\n\nOn November 6, 2013, Zac Brown Band performed at the 2013 CMA awards with [[Dave Grohl]] on drums, debuting their new song \"Day for the Dead\".<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://music-mix.ew.com/2013/11/06/cma-awards-dave-grohl-goes-country-with-zac-brown-band-video/|magazine=Entertainment Weekly|title=CMA Awards: Dave Grohl goes country with Zac Brown Band -- VIDEO|first=Katie|last=Atkinson|date=November 6, 2013}}</ref> On November 24, while being interviewed at the [[American Music Award]]s, Grohl revealed that he recently produced the band's new EP.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7vDaY4l4Eg0| archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211107/7vDaY4l4Eg0| archive-date=2021-11-07 | url-status=live|work=YouTube|title=Dave Grohl on producing Zac Brown Band at the 2013 AMA's red carpet|date=November 25, 2013}}{{cbignore}}</ref>\n\nOn January 21, 2014, Zac Brown Band released a live version of their 2010 #1 hit \"Free\" (transitioning into the [[Van Morrison]] classic \"Into the Mystic\"). The track features [[Clare Bowen]] and precedes their January 22 appearance on the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] TV show ''[[Nashville (2012 TV series)|Nashville]]''. The song(s) were recorded at the 2013 Southern Ground Music & Food Festival in [[Nashville]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zacbrownband.com/news.html?n_id=2083 |title=The latest Zac Brown Band news and information |publisher=Zac Brown Band |date=January 21, 2014 |access-date=August 1, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150604113313/http://www.zacbrownband.com/news.html?n_id=2083 |archive-date=June 4, 2015 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nIn 2016, Zac Brown formed a side-project, Sir Rosevelt,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/zac-brown-sir-rosevelt-new-songs-online/ |title=Zac Brown Side Project Sir Rosevelt Shares New Songs Online |website=Tasteofcountry.com |date=October 2016 |access-date=May 17, 2017}}</ref> that released several singles and announced an album that was released December 15, 2017.\n\nZac Brown Band re-recorded the song \"From Now On\" from ''[[The Greatest Showman]]'', as part of a compilation album, ''The Greatest Showman: Reimagined''. The album was released on November 16, 2018.\n\nBrown performed \"Colder Weather\" at the 2019 [[Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum]] Concert and Induction Ceremony.\n\n==Revenue==\nIn 2015, [[Forbes]] estimated that Zac Brown Band's annual income was $32 million.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/zac-brown-band/ |title=Zac Brown Band |work=[[Forbes]] |year=2015 |access-date=April 28, 2016 }}</ref>\n\n==Philanthropy==\nThe band has also supported [[Little Kids Rock]], a national nonprofit that works to restore and revitalize music education programs in disadvantaged U.S. public schools, by donating items for auction to raise money for the organization.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.littlekidsrock.org/friends/our-big-fans/zac-brown-band/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140115014556/http://www.littlekidsrock.org/friends/our-big-fans/zac-brown-band/|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 15, 2014|title=Zac Brown Band &#124; Little Kids Rock|date=January 15, 2014}}</ref> On January 16, 2013, Zac Brown, Clay Cook, and David Ryan Harris played a benefit with [[John Mayer]] for the firefighters and the residents of Pine Creek in [[Park County, Montana]], who fought a fire that swept through the area, and destroyed five homes.\n\n==Band members==\n\n===Current members===\n* [[Zac Brown]] \u2013 lead vocals, guitar, banjo, bass guitar <small>(2002\u2013present)</small><ref name=\"auto\">{{Cite AV media notes |title=Jekyll + Hyde |others=Zac Brown Band |year=2015 |type=CD booklet |publisher=John Varvatos/BMLG/Southern Ground/Republic |id=B0022962-02}}</ref>\n* Jimmy De Martini \u2013 harmony and backing vocals, fiddle, [[violin]], guitar, [[mandolin]], [[cello]] <small>(2004\u2013present)</small><ref name=\"auto\"/>\n* [[John Driskell Hopkins]] \u2013 harmony, backing and occasional lead vocals <small>(2005\u2013present)</small>; bass guitar, double bass <small>(2005\u20132014)</small>; guitar, [[baritone guitar]], ukulele, banjo<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1726309/zac-brown-band-reveals-tour-dates/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215150452/http://www.cmt.com/news/1726309/zac-brown-band-reveals-tour-dates/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 15, 2015 |title=Zac Brown Band Reveals Tour Dates |website=Cmt.com |date= April 16, 2014|access-date=December 27, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite AV media notes |title=The Grohl Sessions, Vol. 1 |others=Zac Brown Band |year=2014 |type=CD insert |publisher=Southern Ground |id=SGA022}}</ref> <small>(2013\u2013present)</small><ref name=\"auto\"/>\n* [[Coy Bowles]] \u2013 guitar, [[slide guitar]], Hammond organ, piano, Wurlitzer electric piano, [[resonator guitar]] <small>(2007\u2013present)</small><ref name=\"auto\"/>\n* [[Chris Fryar]] \u2013 drums, percussion <small>(2008\u2013present)</small><ref name=\"auto\"/>\n* [[Clay Cook]] \u2013 harmony, backing and occasional lead vocals, guitar, slide guitar, keyboards, Hammond organ, piano, Wurlitzer and Fender Rhodes electric pianos, [[Mellotron]], [[clavinet]], [[pedal steel guitar]], [[glockenspiel]], [[National String Instrument Corporation|National guitar]] <small>(2009\u2013present)</small><ref name=\"auto\"/>\n* [[Daniel de los Reyes]] \u2013 percussion <small>(2012\u2013present)</small><ref name=\"auto\"/>\n* Matt Mangano \u2013 bass guitar, guitar, double bass, backing vocals <!--acoustic bass guitar--><small>(2014\u2013present)</small><ref name=\"auto\"/>\n* [[Caroline Jones]] \u2013 vocals, guitar, banjo, mandolin, dobro, piano, steel guitar, autoharp, harmonica <small>(2022\u2013present)</small>\n\n===Former members===\n* Marcus Petruska \u2013 drums, percussion, backing vocals <small>(2003\u20132008)</small>\n* Jacob Lawson \u2013 bass guitar <small>(2003\u20132005)</small>\n* Tim Ussery \u2013 guitar, mandolin, bass guitar <small>(2003\u20132005)</small>\n* Joel Williams \u2013 guitar <small>(2005\u20132008)</small>\n\n====Timeline====\n{{#tag:timeline|\nImageSize  = width:800 height:auto barincrement:20\nPlotArea   = caption             = Everett in 2009\n| birth_name          = Jace Everett Beasley<ref>{{cite web | url=https://repertoire.bmi.com/Search/Catalog?num=SzAQdYLLevX63%252fLYIwx9AA%253d%253d&cae=Hsr9eK4E4AJDc%252bOwmMp%252fzw%253d%253d&partType=WriterList&search=%7B%22Main_Search_Text%22%3A%22bad%20things%22%2C%22Sub_Search_Text%22%3Anull%2C%22Main_Search%22%3A%22Title%22%2C%22Sub_Search%22%3Anull%2C%22Search_Type%22%3A%22all%22%2C%22View_Count%22%3A100%2C%22Page_Number%22%3A0%2C%22Part_Type%22%3Anull%2C%22Part_Id%22%3Anull%2C%22Part_Id_Sub%22%3Anull%2C%22Part_Name%22%3Anull%2C%22Part_Cae%22%3Anull%2C%22Original_Search%22%3Anull%2C%22DisclaimerViewed%22%3Anull%7D&resetPageNumber=True&partIdSub=YO0HedHMatLb45JzS23DVw%253d%253d | title=Results for Beasley, Jace Everett | publisher=[[Broadcast Music Incorporated]] | accessdate=June 30, 2022}}</ref>\n| birth_date          = {{Birth date and age|1972|5|27}}<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n| birth_place         = [[Evansville, Indiana]], United States\n| origin              = Evansville, Indiana\n| instrument          = Vocals, acoustic guitar, electric guitar, bass guitar\n| genre               = [[Country rock]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.digitaljournal.com/entertainment/country-rock-singer-jace-everett-returns-with-new-album/article/492542 |last=Peel|first= Adrian |date=May 13, 2017 |title=Country/rock singer Jace Everett returns with new album |publisher=Digital Journal |access-date=2023-01-05}}</ref>\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter, musician\n| years_active       = 2005\u2013present\n| label               = [[Epic Records|Epic]], Phantom, Weston Boys\n}}\n\n'''Jace Everett Beasley''' (born May 27, 1972) is an American singer-songwriter and musician. Signed to [[Epic Records]] in 2005, he released his debut single \"That's the Kind of Love I'm In\" in 2005, which peaked at No. 52 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, and was the first single from his self-titled debut album. He also co-wrote [[Josh Turner]]'s Number One single \"[[Your Man (Josh Turner song)|Your Man]]\".  His song \"[[Bad Things (Jace Everett song)|Bad Things]]\" is the theme for the [[Home Box Office|HBO]] series ''[[True Blood]]'' and peaked No. 2 in Norway in 2009. In the same year, he released his third album, ''Red Revelations'', under the Weston Boys label that peaked No. 12 in Norway.\n\n== Biography ==\nJace Everett was born in [[Evansville, Indiana]] in 1972. His father's jobs kept them on the move through [[Indianapolis]] and then [[St. Louis, MO]] before moving to [[Fort Worth, TX]] at the age of six. He started playing music in his church and in school concerts. He later moved to [[Nashville, TN]] to attend [[Belmont University]].<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p725883|pure_url=yes}} |title=Jace Everett biography |accessdate=July 17, 2008 |last=Monger |first=James Christopher |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>\n\nIn 2005, Everett was signed to [[Epic Records]]. He released his first single, \"That's The Kind of Love I'm In\", in June 2005. This song charted at No. 52 on the country charts, and was followed in early 2006 by the release of his self-titled debut album.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/><ref name=\"bmi\"/> Also in 2006, [[Josh Turner]] charted at Number One on the country charts with the song \"[[Your Man (Josh Turner song)|Your Man]]\", which Everett co-wrote, and for which Everett received a [[Broadcast Music Incorporated]] award.<ref name=\"bmi\">{{cite web |url=http://www.bmi.com/news/entry/334763 |title=Charts Stand By 'Your Man' |accessdate=June 4, 2010 |date=April 12, 2006 |work=[[Broadcast Music Incorporated]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1526605/ascap-bmi-honor-josh-turner-and-writers-of-your-man.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202021356/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1526605/ascap-bmi-honor-josh-turner-and-writers-of-your-man.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=December 2, 2008 |title=ASCAP, BMI Honor Josh Turner and Writers of \"Your Man\" |accessdate=June 4, 2010 |last=Morris |first=Edward |date=March 20, 2006 |work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]}}</ref> The album's other singles \u2014 \"Bad Things,\" \"Nowhere in the Neighborhood\" and \"Everything I Want\" \u2014 did not chart in the United States, although \"Bad Things\" reached No. 2 in Norway, No. 30 in Sweden and No. 49 in UK in 2009.<ref name=\"VG\"/><ref name=\"Sweden\"/><ref name=\"OCC\"/>\n\n\"Bad Things\" is used as the theme song for the [[Home Box Office|HBO]] TV series ''[[True Blood]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20222109,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080901234206/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20222109,00.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 1, 2008 |title=True Blood \u2013 TV Review|accessdate=October 22, 2008|date= September 7, 2008|last=Tucker |first=Ken |magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]}}</ref> Charlaine Harris pays homage to the song by including \"Bad Things\" playing at Merlotte's in the 2010 Sookie Stackhouse mystery ''[[Dead in the Family]]''. It won a 2009 [[Broadcast Music Incorporated]] award in the cable television category and was nominated for a 2009 [[Scream Award]] for \"Best Scream Song of the Year.\"<ref>[http://www.bmi.com/news/entry/538576 \"BMI Film & Television Awards Tout Composers of Year\u2019s Top Film, Television, & Cable Music\"] Retrieved on September 2, 2009.</ref><ref>[http://www.spike.com/event/scream2009/page/vote/category/33121 \"Best Scream Song of the Year, 2009\"] Spike.com Retrieved on September 2, 2009.</ref> His album, entitled ''Red Revelations'', was released in June 2009.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.trueblood-online.com/jace-everett/jace-everett-talks-about-his-new-cd-red-revelations| title=Jace Everett talks about his new CD \"Red Revelations\"| accessdate=July 17, 2009| work=True Blood Online| archive-date=September 3, 2009| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090903135917/http://www.trueblood-online.com/jace-everett/jace-everett-talks-about-his-new-cd-red-revelations| url-status=dead}}</ref> His duet Evil (Is Going On), a cover of the song written by Willie Dixon, with [[CC Adcock]] is part of the [[True Blood (season 2)|True Blood season 2]] soundtrack.<ref>[http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/37631/true-blood-listen-season-2-soundtrack-live-stream-watch-full-season-3-trailer True Blood: Listen to the Season 2 Soundtrack Live Stream; Watch the Full Season 3 Trailer]</ref> A new album, \"Mr. Good Times\" was released in 2011. His latest album, \"Terra Rosa\" was released digitally on July 23, 2013.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.jaceeverett.com/let-the-games-begin/ |title=\"JaceEverett.com: Let The Games Begin\" |access-date=October 27, 2013 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20131028004524/http://www.jaceeverett.com/let-the-games-begin/ |archive-date=October 28, 2013 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:16em;\"|Video\n! Director\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2005\n! scope=\"row\"| \"That's the Kind of Love I'm In\"\n| David McClister\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Bad Things\"\n| Kristin Barlowe\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2017\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Love's Not What We Do\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Woke Up in This Town\"\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist|2}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.jaceeverett.com Official website]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Everett, Jace}}\n[[Category:1972 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:American country rock singers]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Evansville, Indiana]]\n[[Category:Epic Records artists]]\n[[Category:Belmont University alumni]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Indiana]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Nate_Smith_(singer)","to":"Nate Smith (singer)"}],"pages":{"69387118":{"pageid":69387118,"ns":0,"title":"Nate Smith (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country music singer}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Nate Smith\n| birth_date        = {{Birth date and age|1985|09|19}}\n| birth_place       = [[Paradise, California]]\n| occupation        = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active      = 2018\u2013present\n| genre             = [[Country music|Country]], [[Country rock]]\n| instrument        = Vocals, guitar\n| label             = {{hlist|[[Word Records|Word]]|[[Arista Nashville]]|[[RCA Records|RCA Nashville]]}}\n| partner           = Vanessa  Sorensen  since  2024\n| website           = {{URL|natesmithofficial.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Nate Smith''' (born September 19, 1985) is an American [[country music]] singer signed to [[Sony Music Nashville]].<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-11-05|title=Sony Music Nashville Signs Nate Smith|url=https://musicrow.com/2021/11/sony-music-nashville-signs-nate-smith/|access-date=2022-01-24|website=MusicRow.com|language=en-US}}</ref> After his song \"Wildfire\" went viral on [[TikTok]] in 2020, he signed a publishing deal with [[Sony Music Publishing|Sony/ATV]]. He gained prominence on social media before landing his major label record deal. He was previously signed to [[Word Records]].<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-12-21|title=Sony Music Nashville C&I Country Roundup - C&I Magazine|url=https://www.cowboysindians.com/2021/12/sony-music-nashville-ci-country-roundup/|access-date=2022-01-24|website=Cowboys and Indians Magazine|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n== Early life and career ==\nBorn and raised in Paradise, California, Smith was introduced to performing music by his church youth leader and cites [[Garth Brooks]], [[Tom Petty]], and [[Fleetwood Mac]] as his early influences. After moving to Nashville at age 23, he signed a record deal with Word Records and a publishing deal with [[Centricity Music]]. During this time, he opened for artists including [[Brett Eldredge]], [[Eli Young Band]], and [[X Ambassadors]].<ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-10-16|title=Sony/ATV Nashville Signs Nate Smith To Worldwide Deal|url=https://musicrow.com/2020/10/sony-atv-nashville-signs-nate-smith-to-worldwide-deal/|access-date=2022-01-24|website=MusicRow.com|language=en-US}}</ref> Nate will be performing at \"Wild West Festival\" in Hays Kansas in summer of 2024.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2024-06-15|title=Wild West Festival|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240615233044/https://wildwestfestival.com/|access-date=2024-06-24|website=Wild West Festival|language=en-us}}</ref>\n\nAfter returning to Paradise, California, in 2018, Smith's home burned down in the [[Camp Fire (2018)|Butte County Camp Fire]].<ref>{{Cite news|last=Barber|first=Molly|title=One Of These Days, Our Interview with Nate Smith|work=Mountain Valley Living|url=https://www.mountainvalleyliving.com/2019/01/one-of-these-days-our-interview-with-nathaniel-smith/}}</ref> The tragedy inspired him to write his breakout song \"One of These Days\". News of the release was reported by local press and several national outlets including [[NPR]], which encouraged Smith to return to Nashville and continue pursuing music.<ref>{{Cite news|title=A Song Of Tribute To The Lost Town Of Paradise|language=en|work=NPR.org|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/12/13/676226073/a-song-of-tribute-to-the-lost-town-of-paradise|access-date=2022-01-24}}</ref>\n\nAfter relocating, Smith released his next single, \"Wildfire\". A clip of the performer singing his track went viral on the social media platform TikTok, gaining over 3 million views.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Natesmithcountry on TikTok|url=https://www.tiktok.com/@natesmithmusic/video/7007486587781123333?lang=en&is_copy_url=1&is_from_webapp=v1|access-date=2022-01-24|website=TikTok|language=en}}</ref> A few months later, in November 2021, Smith signed a record deal with Sony Music Nashville and dropped his major label debut, \"Raised Up\", which he co-wrote with hit songwriter Jonathan Smith. He soon followed it with \"I Don't Wanna Go to Heaven\".<ref>{{Cite web|last=Nicholson|first=Jessica|date=2021-11-19|title=First Country: Chris Stapleton, Adele, Cole Swindell, Lainey Wilson, Gabby Barrett|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/first-country-chris-stapleton-adele-cole-swindell-lainey-wilson-1234999428/|access-date=2022-01-24|website=Billboard|language=en-US}}</ref> The track helped land him on 2022 Artists to Watch lists by ''Country Now'', ''Country Lifestyle Network'' and ''PopWrapped''.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Liptak|first=Carena|date=2021-12-28|title=Country Next: 15 Artists to Watch in 2022|url=https://countrynow.com/country-next-15-artists-to-watch-in-2022/|access-date=2022-01-24|website=Country Now|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Rian|first=Lindsi|date=2022-01-10|title=Music Monday: One's to Watch in 2022|url=https://cowboylifestylenetwork.com/music-monday-ones-to-watch-in-2022/|access-date=2022-01-25|website=Cowboy Lifestyle Network|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Perkins|first=Trevor|title=31 Country Newcomers To Watch In 2022|url=https://popwrapped.com/31-country-newcomers-to-watch-in-2022/}}</ref>\n\nAfter Arista Nashville closed in March 2023, Smith was reassigned to [[RCA Records]]' Nashville division.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://variety.com/2023/music/news/sony-dissolves-arista-nashville-1235563003/ | title=Sony Music Dissolves Arista Nashville Label | publisher=Variety | date=March 23, 2023 | accessdate=March 27, 2023 | author=Jem Aswad}}</ref> The song \"Bulletproof\" was released on February 2, 2024 as the lead single from Smith's EP ''Through the Smoke''.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://backstagecountry.com/2024/02/09/nate-smith-delivers-new-single-announces-through-the-smoke-ep/ | title=Nate Smith Delivers New Single, Announces ''Through The Smoke'' EP | publisher=Backstage Country | date=February 9, 2024 | accessdate=May 15, 2024| author=Lauren Hoffman}}</ref> The song was subsequently re-recorded featuring [[Avril Lavigne]]. This version was released on May 16, 2024.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://newcountry1039fm.iheart.com/content/2024-05-15-nate-smith-texts-avril-lavigne-with-a-crazy-idea-see-the-conversation/ | title=Nate Smith Texts Avril Lavigne With A 'Crazy Idea' \u2014 See The Conversation | publisher=[[WZDA|New Country 103.9]] | date=May 15, 2024 | accessdate=May 15, 2024| author=Kelly Fisher}}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n=== Studio albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center\"\n|+ Studio album, with selected details and chart positions\n!
