This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Hardy_(singer)","to":"Hardy (singer)"}],"pages":{"60400726":{"pageid":60400726,"ns":0,"title":"Hardy (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country music singer (born 1990)}}\n{{redirect|Michael Hardy|the civil rights attorney|Michael Hardy (attorney)|the historian|Michael C. Hardy}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Hardy\n| image             = Hardy chilling on tour bus before concert in South Carolina.jpg\n| caption           = Hardy in 2020\n| birth_name        = Michael Wilson Hardy\n| alias             = \n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1990|09|13}}\n| birth_place       = [[Philadelphia, Mississippi]], U.S.\n| spouse            = {{marriage|Caleigh Ryan|2022}}\n| genre             = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country music|Country]]\n* [[country rock]]<ref>{{Cite magazine|date=July 6, 2020|title=Billboard Country Update - July 6, 2020|url=https://bulletins.billboard.com/country/country_update_0706.pdf|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=July 7, 2020|archive-date=June 10, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210610232148/https://bulletins.billboard.com/country/country_update_0706.pdf|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n* [[nu metal]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/music/story/2023-02-16/hardy-morgan-wallen-lainey-wilson-mockingbird-crow|title=Nashville's Nu Metal King|website=Losangelestimes|date=8 February 2023}}</ref>\n}}\n| occupations       = {{flatlist|\n* Singer\n* songwriter\n}}\n| instrument        = {{flatlist|\n* Vocals\n* guitar\n}}\n| years_active      = 2018\u2013present\n| label             = {{flatlist|\n* [[Big Loud]]\n* Big Loud Rock\n* Tree Vibez\n}}\n| website           = {{URL|hardyofficial.com}}\n}}\n'''Michael Wilson Hardy''' (born September 13, 1990), known professionally as '''HARDY''' (stylized in [[all caps]]), is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. He has written songs for [[Florida Georgia Line]], [[Chris Lane]], [[Blake Shelton]], [[Dallas Smith]], [[Thomas Rhett]], and [[Morgan Wallen]]. He released his debut album ''[[A Rock]]'' for [[Big Loud|Big Loud Records]], as well as the mixtape ''[[Hixtape, Vol. 1]].'' His singles \"[[Give Heaven Some Hell]]\", \"[[One Beer (Hardy song)|One Beer]]\", \"[[Wait in the Truck]]\" and \"[[Truck Bed (song)|Truck Bed]]\" charted in the US and Canada and he was featured on the Dallas Smith song \"[[Some Things Never Change (Dallas Smith song)|Some Things Never Change]]\". His album, ''[[The Mockingbird & the Crow]]'', topped the country music charts in early 2023.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/country-albums/2023-02-04/ | title=Top Country Albums | magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] }}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nMichael Wilson Hardy was born to Mike and Sarah Hardy, in [[Philadelphia, Mississippi]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hawkins |first=Scott |title=Hardy coming home to headline Fair |url=https://neshobademocrat.com/stories/hardy-coming-home-to-headline-fair,50937 |access-date=2022-03-29 |website=The Neshoba Democrat |date=21 July 2021 |language=en}}</ref> Growing up, Hardy often listened to music with his father, whom he has cited as the source of some of his earliest and fondest memories.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web |last=Ceneviva |first=Alex |date=2021-10-20 |title=The Untold Truth Of Hardy |url=https://www.nickiswift.com/638369/the-untold-truth-of-hardy/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=NickiSwift.com |language=en-US}}</ref> \n\nHe attended Neshoba Central High School in Philadelphia, Mississippi. It was during that time that he wrote his first song to \"impress a girl.\"<ref name=\":0\"/> Hardy then went on to attend [[Middle Tennessee State University]], where he got a degree in songwriting in the Recording Industry Management program.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2021-11-22 |title=Meet Country Singer Hardy: \"Nashville's most clever new redneck songwriter\" |url=https://www.countrythangdaily.com/hardy-country-singer/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nAfter graduating, Hardy took a trip to visit his sister, in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], which led to the start of his career. While there, he realized that it was possible to make [[country music]] into a career.<ref name=\":0\"/> Hardy met [[Florida Georgia Line]] in 2012 at a party where he was introduced to them by a mutual acquaintance.<ref name=\":03\">{{Cite web |last=Ceneviva |first=Alex |date=2021-10-20 |title=The Untold Truth Of HARDY |url=https://www.nickiswift.com/638369/the-untold-truth-of-hardy/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=NickiSwift.com |language=en-US}}</ref> He was eventually reconnected with the group years later.\n\nAfter moving to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], to pursue songwriting, he became a writing partner of the duo [[Florida Georgia Line]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://theboot.com/who-is-hardy/ | title=Who is Hardy? 5 things you need to know | work=The Boot | access-date=April 2, 2019}}</ref> Among the songs that Hardy wrote include \"[[Up Down (Morgan Wallen song)|Up Down]]\" by [[Morgan Wallen]]. Following the song's success and encouragement from record producer [[Joey Moi]], Hardy was signed to [[Big Loud|Big Loud Records]] in 2018.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://theboot.com/michael-hardy-songwriter-country-singer/ | title=Hardy talks going from songwriter to artist | work=The Boot | date=14 January 2019 | access-date=April 2, 2019}}</ref>\n\n== Career ==\nIn October 2018, he released an EP titled ''This Ole Boy'', which he promoted by joining Wallen's If I Know Me Tour.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://musicrow.com/2018/10/hardy-releases-debut-ep-today/ | title=Hardy releases debut EP today | work=[[MusicRow]] | date=19 October 2018 | access-date=April 2, 2019}}</ref> This was followed in 2019 by the single \"Rednecker\",<ref>{{cite web | url=https://tasteofcountry.com/who-is-hardy/ | title=5 things to know about Hardy, country's newest redneck | work=Taste of Country | date=18 January 2019 | access-date=April 2, 2019}}</ref> and a second EP titled ''Where to Find Me''. To support the EP, Hardy joined Florida Georgia Line on their [[Can't Say I Ain't Country Tour]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/hardy-wheretofindme-ep/ | title=Hardy to debut four new tracks on 'Where to Find Me' EP | work=Sounds Like Nashville | date=18 January 2019 | access-date=April 2, 2019}}</ref>\n\nHardy also co-wrote Florida Georgia Line's singles \"[[Simple (Florida Georgia Line song)|Simple]]\" and \"[[Talk You Out of It]]\", Blake Shelton's singles \"[[God's Country (Blake Shelton song)|God's Country]]\"<ref>{{cite web | url=https://tasteofcountry.com/hardy-interview-rednecker-florida-georgia-line/ | title=How Hardy is turning songwriting success into an artist's career | work=Taste of Country | date=March 2019 | access-date=April 2, 2019}}</ref> and \"[[Hell Right]]\", \"[[Drop (Dallas Smith song)|Drop]]\" by [[Dallas Smith]], [[Chris Lane]]'s single \"[[I Don't Know About You]]\", and [[Jameson Rodgers]]' debut single \"[[Some Girls (Jameson Rodgers song)|Some Girls]]\".<ref name=\"casey\">{{cite web | url=http://www.nashcountrydaily.com/2019/09/12/hardys-new-hixtape-vol-1-features-17-guest-artists-including-keith-urban-thomas-rhett-dustin-lynch-more/ | title=Hardy's New \"Hixtape Vol. 1\" Features 17 Guest Artists, Including Keith Urban, Thomas Rhett, Dustin Lynch & More | work=Nash Country Daily | date=September 12, 2019 | access-date=September 13, 2019 | last=Casey| first=Jim}}</ref>\n\nIn September 2019, Hardy released a collaborative mixtape titled ''Hixtape, Vol. 1'',<ref name=\"casey\"/> which featured a total of 17 artists including [[Thomas Rhett]], [[Keith Urban]], [[Tracy Lawrence]], [[Jake Owen]], [[Trace Adkins]], [[Joe Diffie]], [[Zakk Wylde]], [[Cole Swindell]], [[Dustin Lynch]], and [[Morgan Wallen]].\n\nHardy was set to be on tour with [[Thomas Rhett]] in 2020 for Rhett's [[Center Point Road Tour]], but the tour was postponed due to the [[COVID-19 pandemic]]. In September 2020, Hardy released his debut album ''[[A Rock]]'', which included his single \"[[One Beer (Hardy song)|One Beer]]\".<ref>{{cite magazine|title=How Hardy Became Nashville's Most Clever New Redneck Songwriter|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/hardy-new-album-a-rock-1031836/|first=Jon|last=Freeman|date=July 21, 2020|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=September 21, 2020}}</ref> He was also featured on [[Dallas Smith]]'s single \"[[Some Things Never Change (Dallas Smith song)|Some Things Never Change]]\".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mitz |first1=Roman |title=Dallas Smith \u2013 Country Music Awards Continue To 'Drop' |url=https://themusicexpress.ca/dallas-smith-country-music-awards-continue-to-drop/ |access-date=October 22, 2020 |work=The Music Express |date=September 28, 2020}}</ref> In June 2021, he was featured on the [[Brantley Gilbert]] single \"[[The Worst Country Song of All Time]]\". In July 2021, he was featured on [[Dierks Bentley]]'s single \"[[Beers on Me]]\", which he co-wrote.<ref>{{cite web|first=Chris|last=Parton|title=Brantley Gilbert, Toby Keith and Hardy Team For 'The Worst Country Song'|url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/music/brantley-gilbert-toby-keith-hardy-worst-country-song/|date=18 June 2021|work=Sounds Like Nashville}}</ref>\n[[File:Hardy at a concert in 2019.jpg|upright=0.85|thumb|Hardy performing in 2019]]\nHe later toured with Sean Stemaly in 2021 and created ''Hixtape, Vol. 2''. This album included artists such as [[Matt Stell]], [[Jon Pardi]], [[Jimmie Allen]], [[Colt Ford]], [[Randy Houser]], [[Rhett Akins]], and [[Lainey Wilson]]. In the fall of 2021, Hardy went on tour with [[Jason Aldean]], as well. The \"Back in the Saddle\" tour kicked off in August 2021, and included [[Lainey Wilson]], in addition to Hardy.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Bosch |first=Christina |date=2021-10-21 |title=Jason Aldean Announces Tour with Hardy & Lainey Wilson |url=https://www.thenashnews.com/2021/10/21/jason-aldean-announces-tour-with-hardy-lainey-wilson/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=The Nash News |language=en-US |archive-date=2022-02-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220217012146/https://www.thenashnews.com/2021/10/21/jason-aldean-announces-tour-with-hardy-lainey-wilson/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n[[Morgan Wallen]] announced his plans for his 2022 ''Dangerous'' tour, which included Hardy for almost all of the nearly 50 stops, including stops in Pennsylvania, South Carolina, Georgia, Louisiana, Oklahoma, and South Dakota.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Dukes |first=Billy|title=BREAKING: Morgan Wallen Announces the Dangerous Tour \u2014 See Dates! |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/morgan-wallen-the-dangerous-tour-dates-2022/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=Taste of Country |language=en}}</ref>\n\nIn October 2022, Hardy announced that his album, ''The Mockingbird & the Crow'', would be released on January 20, 2023, via Big Loud Records with guest vocals from fellow country singers [[Morgan Wallen]] and [[Lainey Wilson]] and [[A Day to Remember]] lead singer [[Jeremy McKinnon]].<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Nicholson|first=Jessica|title=HARDY Is Releasing a Half Country, Half Rock Album|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/hardy-announces-new-album-tracklist-morgan-wallen-feature-1235153334/|date=October 10, 2022|access-date=October 10, 2022|magazine=Billboard}}</ref> \n\nHardy released three songs from ''[[The Mockingbird & the Crow]]'' on October 9, 2022: \"Truck Bed\", \"Here Lies Country Music\", and \"The Mockingbird & the Crow\". The full album features half country and half rock music. The first half of the album is more traditional country music with all the song titles stylized in lower case. The song \"The Mockingbird & the Crow\" features a distinct shift halfway through the song to the rock genre, and the rest of the album continues as rock and hard rock, though still using country themes and imagery in the lyrics. The rock song titles are all stylized in uppercase.\n\nIn early 2024, Hardy announced a collaborative project titled ''[[Hixtape: Vol. 3: Difftape]]'', featuring him and other artists covering songs by [[Joe Diffie]] and honoring the fourth anniversary of his death in 2020. Unlike the previous two ''Hixtape'' installments, it is not credited solely as a Hardy album.<ref>https://musicrow.com/2024/03/hixtape-vol-3-difftape-reimagines-joe-diffie-classics-with-special-collaborations/</ref>\n\n== Awards ==\nIn 2019, Hardy received his first nomination for the [[Country Music Association]] awards. Held at the [[Bridgestone Arena]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], Hardy was nominated for Song of the Year for Blake Shelton's \"God's Country\", which Hardy co-wrote with [[Devin Dawson]] and [[Jordan Schmidt]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Whitaker |first=Sterling|title=Here's a Full List of the 2019 CMA Awards Nominees |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/2019-cma-awards-nominees/ |access-date=2022-04-21 |website=Taste of Country |date=13 November 2019 |language=en}}</ref> He was then again nominated in the [[55th Annual Country Music Association Awards|2021 CMA Awards]] as New Artist of the Year.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Freeman |first=Jon |date=2021-09-09 |title=2021 CMA Awards Nominations: Chris Stapleton, Eric Church Are Top Nominees |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/2021-cma-awards-nominees-nominations-1222399/ |access-date=2022-04-21 |magazine=Rolling Stone |language=en-US}}</ref> \n\nHardy was nominated for two awards in the 2020 [[Academy of Country Music]] Awards: Song of the Year, for [[Blake Shelton|Blake Shelton's]] \"Gods Country\" that Hardy co-wrote, and Songwriter of the Year. Following that, in 2021, he received three nominations: New Male Artist, Songwriter of the Year, and Music Event of the Year, for his song \"One Beer\" along with [[Lauren Alaina]] and [[Devin Dawson]]. Hardy was nominated for two awards in the 2022 [[Academy of Country Music Awards]], held at the [[Allegiant Stadium]] in Las Vegas. He did not win the award for New Male Artist, losing to Parker McCollum. He was, however, named the Academy of Country Music's 2022 Songwriter of the Year, making that his first ACM Award.  During the 2023 ACA Awards, Hardy was nominated for multiple awards, of which he ended up taking home three.  His colabration with Lainey Wilson won for \"Best Visual Media of the Year\" and \"Musical Event of the Year\".  In addition, he ended up winning the Artist-Songwriter of the Year\".<ref>{{Citation |title=Academy of Country Music Awards |date=2022-03-08 |url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Academy_of_Country_Music_Awards&oldid=1075984700 |work=Wikipedia |language=en |access-date=2022-03-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-03-08 |title=Country star Hardy reveals shocking win during ACM Awards red carpet |url=https://www.hellomagazine.com/celebrities/20220308134827/acm-awards-hardy-shocking-las-vegas-win/ |access-date=2022-03-11 |website=HELLO! |language=en}}</ref>\n\n== Personal life ==\nHardy proposed to his girlfriend Caleigh Ryan in August 2021 at The Lyric in [[Oxford, Mississippi]] which is where the couple met in 2017. The two married on October 29, 2022.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Fisher|first=Kelly|date=August 25, 2021|title=Hardy Tells The Sweet Story Of How He Proposed To wife Caleigh Ryan Hardy|url=https://www.iheart.com/content/2021-08-25-hardy-tells-the-sweet-story-of-how-he-proposed-to-now-fianc-caleigh-ryan/|access-date=February 17, 2021|website=iHeart|language=en}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Hardy discography}}\n\n'''Studio albums'''\n*''[[A Rock]]'' (2020)\n*''[[The Mockingbird & the Crow]]'' (2023)\n*''[[Quit!!]]'' (2024)\n\n==See also==\n{{See also category| Songs written by Hardy (singer)}}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{Hardy (singer)}}\n{{Authority control}}\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Hardy}}\n[[Category:1990 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Bro-country singers]]\n[[Category:American country rock singers]]\n[[Category:Big Loud artists]]\n[[Category:Country pop musicians]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Mississippi]]\n[[Category:People from Philadelphia, Mississippi]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Mississippi]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Little_Texas_(band)","to":"Little Texas (band)"}],"pages":{"1745443":{"pageid":1745443,"ns":0,"title":"Little Texas (band)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country music band}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See I meant on Lytle Texas comment on Little Texas Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name            = Little Texas\n| image           = Little Texas Live.jpg\n| caption         = Little Texas performing in 2007\n| image_size      = \n| background      = group_or_band\n| origin          = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| genre           = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country music|Country]]<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n* [[country rock]]<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n}}\n| years_active    = {{flatlist|\n* 1988\u20131997\n* 2004\u2013present\n}}\n| label           = {{flatlist|\n* [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros. Nashville]]\n* [[Montage Music Group]]\n* [[Cleopatra Records|Cleopatra]]\n}}\n| website         = {{URL|littletexasonline.com}}\n| spinoffs = {{flatlist|\n* [[Rushlow]]\n* Rushlow Harris\n* Hilljack\n* [[Hot Apple Pie]]\n* [[The Frontmen]]\n}}\n| current_members = \n* Del Gray\n* Porter Howell\n* Dwayne O'Brien\n* Duane Propes\n| past_members    = \n* [[Tim Rushlow]]\n* [[Brady Seals]]\n* Jeff Huskins\n* Steven Troy\n}}\n'''Little Texas''' is an American [[country music]] band started in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in 1988. Its founding members were [[Tim Rushlow]] (lead and background vocals, acoustic guitar), [[Brady Seals]] (lead and background vocals, keyboards), Del Gray (drums), Porter Howell (lead guitar, background vocals), Dwayne O'Brien (acoustic guitar, lead and background vocals), and Duane Propes (bass guitar, background vocals). Signed to [[Warner Bros. Records]] Nashville in 1991, Little Texas released its debut album ''[[First Time for Everything]]'' that year. The album's lead off single, \"[[Some Guys Have All the Love]]\", reached a peak of No.&nbsp;8 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] charts. Little Texas charted thirteen top-40 hits between then and 1995, including the number one \"[[My Love (Little Texas song)|My Love]]\" in 1994. Their debut album earned a gold certification from the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA), while 1993's ''[[Big Time (Little Texas album)|Big Time]]'' was certified double platinum and 1994's ''[[Kick a Little]]'' was certified platinum.\n\nSeals left the band in 1994 and was replaced by Jeff Huskins (keyboards, fiddle). After a [[Greatest Hits (Little Texas album)|''Greatest Hits'']] package and a [[Little Texas (album)|self-titled]] fourth studio album, the group disbanded in 1997. Seals went on to record three solo albums and one as the lead singer of [[Hot Apple Pie]], Rushlow recorded one solo album and one as the lead singer of [[Rushlow]], and Howell recorded one as a member of Hilljack. Gray, Howell, O'Brien, and Propes re-established Little Texas in 2004 with new lead singer Steven Troy; he left the band in 2006 and Howell took over lead vocals. Under the four-piece lineup, the band has recorded two albums for [[Montage Music Group]]: ''[[The Very Best of Little Texas: Live and Loud]]'' and ''[[Missing Years (album)|Missing Years]]''.\n\n== History ==\nLittle Texas was founded in 1988. Prior to the band's formation, [[Tim Rushlow]] and Dwayne O'Brien began playing together in [[Arlington, Texas]], in 1984. Porter Howell and Duane Propes got together while they were in high school in 1983 and moved to Nashville to attend [[Belmont University]]. [[Brady Seals]] and Del Gray played in the backup band of country music singer [[Josh Logan (country singer)|Josh Logan]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Rushlow, O'Brien, Propes, and Howell first started making music at [[Gaylord Opryland Resort & Convention Center|Opryland]] as a 1950s show band. With both Rushlow's first wife and Howell's wife, plus two other members, they took the show band on the road, naming their act \"The Varsities\".\n\nWhen two of the members left to pursue other interests, they contacted their old friends Gray and Seals, whom they had met while playing in [[Springfield, Massachusetts]], in hopes of forging a more country/Southern rock sound. All six members eventually moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], where they started playing together. The band played at venues across the United States (around 300 dates a year), eventually catching the attention of Nashville's division of [[Warner Bros. Records]].\n\n==Musical career==\n===1991-1993: ''First Time for Everything''===\n{{multiple image\n| width1 = 108\n| image1 = Tim Rushlow 2011.jpg\n| width2 = 120\n| image2 = Bradyseals.jpg\n| footer = [[Tim Rushlow]] (left) and [[Brady Seals]] (right) were both in the original lineup.\n}}\nWarner Bros. signed Little Texas in 1989, and two years later, the band released their debut single \"[[Some Guys Have All the Love]]\".<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/little-texas-mn0000266151/biography|title=Little Texas biography|last=Huey|first=Steve|author2=Sean Westergaard |website=AllMusic|accessdate=2009-04-09}}</ref> This song, which reached No.&nbsp;8 on the U.S. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country singles charts, was the first of five singles from their debut album ''[[First Time for Everything]]''. After the debut single came the album's title track at No.&nbsp;13, \"[[You and Forever and Me]]\" at No.&nbsp;5, \"[[What Were You Thinkin']]\" at No.&nbsp;17 and finally \"[[I'd Rather Miss You]]\" at No.&nbsp;16.<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> The album was certified gold by the [[RIAA]] for shipping 500,000 copies in the US.\n\n===1993-1994: ''Big Time''===\nLittle Texas' second album, ''[[Big Time (Little Texas album)|Big Time]]'', was issued in 1993. Their most successful album, it was certified 2\u00d7Platinum by the RIAA and gold by the [[Music Canada|CRIA]]. It also produced a minor crossover hit in leadoff single \"[[What Might Have Been]]\", a No.&nbsp;2 country hit that also reached No.&nbsp;74 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and No.&nbsp;16 on [[Hot Adult Contemporary Tracks]]. After it came \"[[God Blessed Texas]]\" and their only number 1 hit on ''Billboard'', \"[[My Love (Little Texas song)|My Love]]\", both of which were also minor Hot 100 entries. The latter also featured Seals on lead vocals.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Finishing off ''Big Time'' was the No.&nbsp;14 \"[[Stop on a Dime]]\". In late 1993, the band contributed a cover of the [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]]' \"[[Peaceful Easy Feeling]]\" to the multi-artist compilation album ''[[Common Thread: The Songs of the Eagles]]''. The rendition featured O'Brien on lead vocals, with Denny Dadmun-Bixby of [[Great Plains (Tennessee band)|Great Plains]] on bass guitar and no involvement from Seals.<ref>{{Cite AV media notes |title=Common Thread: The Songs of the Eagles |others=Various artists |year=1993 |type=CD insert |publisher=Giant Records |id=24531}}</ref> The rendition peaked at number 73 on the country charts.<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|date=2008|page=242|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref>\n\n===1994-1996: ''Kick a Little'' and ''Greatest Hits''===\n''[[Kick a Little]]'', the band's third album, was certified platinum by the RIAA. Leading off this album was its No.&nbsp;5 [[Kick a Little (song)|title track]], followed by the No.&nbsp;4 \"[[Amy's Back in Austin]]\" and No.&nbsp;27 \"[[Southern Grace]]\". After the album's release, however, Seals left for a solo career on [[Reprise Records]], and was replaced by multi-instrumentalist Jeff Huskins, a former backing musician for [[Clint Black]], for their tour to promote the album.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Huskins made his first appearance on \"[[Life Goes On (Little Texas song)|Life Goes On]]\" and \"Country Crazy\", two new tracks that the band recorded for their 1995 ''[[Greatest Hits (Little Texas album)|Greatest Hits]]''. Both of these songs were released as singles. The former became their final Top 40 hit with a peak of No.&nbsp;5, while \"Country Crazy\" stopped at No.&nbsp;44. Also in 1995, the band sang on the track \"Party All Night\", a musical track which featured snippets from a [[Jeff Foxworthy]] sketch and a sung chorus by the band. This song reached No.&nbsp;53, and later appeared on Foxworthy's 1996 album ''[[Crank It Up: The Music Album]]''.\n\n===1997-1998: ''Little Texas''===\nLittle Texas' fourth album was [[Little Texas (album)|self-titled]]. Lead-off single \"Bad for Us\" peaked at No.&nbsp;45, followed by their two lowest-charting singles, \"Your Mama Won't Let Me\" and \"The Call\" at No.&nbsp;64 and No.&nbsp;71 respectively. The band also charted that year with a cover of \"[[Kiss the Girl]]\", a song from the Disney film ''[[The Little Mermaid (1989 film)|The Little Mermaid]]'' which they recorded on ''[[The Best of Country Sing the Best of Disney]]''. Seals also charted his only Top 40 solo hit that year, the No.&nbsp;32 \"[[Another You, Another Me]]\". Seals would record a total of three albums between then and 2003. After ''Little Texas'', the band broke up.\n\n===Hiatus and status of former members===\n[[File:Little Texas 2011.jpg|thumb|Little Texas Live]]\nDuring the band's hiatus, Del Gray co-wrote [[Trace Adkins]]' 2000 single \"[[More (Trace Adkins song)|More]]\". Former frontman Tim Rushlow signed to [[Atlantic Records]] as a solo artist that same year, releasing a [[Tim Rushlow (album)|self-titled album]]. Although it accounted for four singles, including the No.&nbsp;8 \"[[She Misses Him]]\", Atlantic closed its country music division in 2001. Rushlow then founded a second band, [[Rushlow]], whose members included his cousin Doni Harris. Rushlow released two singles and one album (''[[Right Now (Rushlow album)|Right Now]]'') on [[Lyric Street Records]], but disbanded by 2004. Seals founded the band [[Hot Apple Pie]], which released a [[Hot Apple Pie (album)|self-titled album]] and three singles in 2005, while Rushlow and Harris founded the duo [[Rushlow Harris]] a year later. In addition, Howell recorded one album in the band Hilljack, which also included former solo artist [[Paul Jefferson]].<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0REEAAAAMBAJ | title=Dualtone gets Moore involved in promotion | author=Phyllis Stark | magazine=Billboard |date=November 1, 2003 | pages=36}}</ref>\n\n===Reunion===\nDuane Propes, Del Gray, Porter Howell, and Dwayne O'Brien decided to reunite Little Texas in 2004. When Little Texas reunited, Rushlow and Huskins made a legal attempt to keep their ex-bandmates from using the Little Texas name.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1470837/03282003/little_texas.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040307080243/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1470837/03282003/little_texas.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 7, 2004|title=CMT.com : Little Texas : HOT TALK: Little Texas in Court, Gilman in Transition|website=Cmt.com}}</ref> As the other four members felt uncomfortable singing lead vocals in Rushlow's and Seals's absence, they recruited Steven Troy as new lead vocalist.<ref name=\"erickson\">{{cite news | url=https://lacrossetribune.com/couleenews/lifestyles/big-time-fun-with-little-texas/article_03e1e8e1-2e8d-5956-b61a-3b1812bdf119.html | title=Big time fun with Little Texas | work=LaCrosse Tribune | date=August 15, 2007 | accessdate=November 3, 2020 | author=Randy Erickson}}</ref> However, O'Brien was critical of Troy's performance as lead singer, stating that it \"just didn't feel authentic\"; as a result, he exited the band in 2006.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/278365479/ | title=Little Texas finds way back to stage | work=The Tennessean | date=July 24, 2007 | accessdate=November 3, 2020 | author=Cindy Watts | pages=1D, 4D}}</ref> By the time the band had signed to [[Montage Music Group]] in 2007, producers for the label had suggested that Howell take over on lead vocals instead. Their first Montage Music release was the live album ''[[The Very Best of Little Texas: Live and Loud]]''. They promoted this album on the Triple Threat Tour that year, which included both [[Restless Heart]] and [[Blackhawk (band)|Blackhawk]]; touring guitarist Mark Sutton accompanied the band on both the tour and the live album.<ref name=\"erickson\"/> This was followed one month later by the studio album ''[[Missing Years (album)|Missing Years]]''. This album produced three singles, although only one \u2014 the title track \u2014 made the country charts, peaking at No.&nbsp;45.\n\nAnother studio album with Howell on lead vocals, ''Young for a Long Time'', followed in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/young-for-a-long-time-mw0002830145|title=Young for a Long Time - Little Texas {{pipe}} Songs, Reviews, Credits|website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref>\n[[File:Little Texas.jpg|thumb|500px]]\n\n=== 2004-present ===\nLittle Texas has continued to tour constantly averaging 65 shows a year.  In 2022, they are celebrating the 30th anniversary of the release of their debut album, ''First Time For Everything''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Little Texas Bio |url=https://www.littletexasonline.com/bio |website=Little Texas Online}}</ref> \n\n==Members==\n*Del Gray \u2013 drums (1988\u20131997, 2004\u2013present)\n*Porter Howell \u2013 lead guitar, background vocals (1988\u20131997, 2004\u20132006); lead vocals, lead guitar (2007\u2013present)\n*Dwayne O'Brien \u2013 rhythm guitar, lead and background vocals (1988\u20131997, 2004\u2013present)\n*Duane Propes \u2013 bass guitar, background vocals (1988\u20131997, 2004\u2013present)\n\n===Former members===\n*Jeff Huskins \u2013 background vocals, fiddle, keyboards (1994\u20131997)\n*[[Tim Rushlow]] \u2013 lead and background vocals, rhythm guitar (1988\u20131997)\n*[[Brady Seals]] \u2013 lead and background vocals, keyboards, rhythm guitar (1988\u20131994)\n*Steven Troy \u2013 lead vocals, rhythm guitar (2004\u20132006)\n\n== This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Rachele_Lynae","to":"Rachele Lynae"}],"pages":{"37385698":{"pageid":37385698,"ns":0,"title":"Rachele Lynae","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Rachele Lynae\n| image           = Rachele Lynae.jpg\n| image_size      =\n| landscape       =\n| alt             =\n| caption         = Rachele Lynae in 2014\n| birth_name      = Rachele Lynae Wurm\n| birth_date      = {{Birth date and age|1988|1|7}}\n| birth_place     = [[Yuba City, California]], US\n| origin          =\n| genre           = [[Country rock]]\n| occupation      = Singer\n| instrument      =\n| years_active    = 2012\u2013present\n| label           = Momentum Label Group\n| associated_acts = [[Jamie O'Neal]]\n| website         = {{URL|www.rachelelynae.com/}}\n}}\n'''Rachele Lynae Wurm-Creedon''' (born January 7, 1988), known professionally as just '''Rachele Lynae''' ({{IPAc-en|r|\u0259|\u02c8|\u0283|\u025b|l|_|l|\u1d7b|\u02c8|n|e\u026a}} {{respell|r\u0259|SHEL|_|lin|AY}}),<ref name=hotnew/> is an American [[country rock]] singer.<ref>{{cite news\n |title=Top 20 musicians to watch\n |author=Hammond, Valerie\n |url=http://www.nashvillelifestyles.com/entertainment/top-musicians-to-watch\n |newspaper=Nashville Lifestyles\n |date=January 3, 2012\n |accessdate=January 3, 2013}}</ref>\n\nLynae released her self-titled debut album on April 22, 2014, having released the new single \"Touch The Stars\" on February 18, 2014.<ref name=\"allaccess.com\">{{cite web |url=http://www.allaccess.com/nashville-iq/archive/18215/headline-of-the-day---january-23-2014 |title=Headline of the Day \u2013 January 23, 2014 by Neil Haislop {{!}} Nashville IQ {{!}} Top News & \u2026 |website=www.allaccess.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227232130/http://www.allaccess.com/nashville-iq/archive/18215/headline-of-the-day---january-23-2014 |archive-date=2014-02-27}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nBorn Rachele Lynae Wurm in 1988 to Robert Wurm, a commercial fisherman, and Alicia Wurm in [[Yuba City, California|Yuba City]], California,<ref>\n{{cite news\n |title=Party 'til the cows come home with Rachele Lynae\n |author=Wise, M. K.\n |url=http://www.fromtheguestroom.com/2012/04/party-til-cows-come-home-with-rachele.html\n |newspaper=From the Guestroom\n |date=April 16, 2012\n |format=Interview\n |accessdate=January 4, 2013\n |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130216022008/http://www.fromtheguestroom.com/2012/04/party-til-cows-come-home-with-rachele.html\n |archive-date=February 16, 2013\n |url-status=dead\n }}\n</ref> Lynae was raised in [[Kodiak, Alaska]], and [[Lynden, Washington]], where she attended [[Lynden Christian Schools]].<ref name=bikman>{{cite news\n |title        = Lynden Christian grad Rachele Lynae pursues singing career\n |author       = Bikman, Margaret\n |url          = http://www.bellinghamherald.com/2012/09/12/2684473/lynden-christian-grad-rachele.html\n |newspaper    = [[The Bellingham Herald]]\n |format       = Interview\n |date         = September 12, 2012\n |accessdate   = September 28, 2012\n |archive-url  = https://archive.today/20130118062701/http://www.bellinghamherald.com/2012/09/12/2684473/lynden-christian-grad-rachele.html\n |archive-date = 2013-01-18\n |url-status     = dead\n}}</ref> Her sister, Heather Cole, is also a singer.<ref name=bikman/><ref>{{cite AV media\n |people=Cole, Heather; Rachele Lynae\n |year=2012\n |title=Again and Again\n |location=YouTube\n |publisher=Murfalot Productions\n |medium=Video\n |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2HZTWXkbSFM\n |accessdate=January 4, 2013\n}}</ref> Rachele attended [[Belmont University]].\n\nLynae began singing in church choir at the age of five. She began writing songs at age 12.<ref name=bio>\n{{cite news\n |title=Rachele Lynae biography\n |url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,GAC_26071_6053111,00.html\n |newspaper=[[Great American Country]]\n |accessdate=September 28, 2012\n |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120813052107/http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,GAC_26071_6053111,00.html\n |archive-date=August 13, 2012\n |url-status=dead\n |df=mdy-all\n }}\n</ref> Early musical influences include [[LeAnn Rimes]], [[Reba McEntire]] and [[Shania Twain]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.kykx.com/Rachele-Lynae-Answers-10-Random-Questions-/11221103?pid=329988 |title = KYKX 105.7 \u2013 Rachele Lynae Answers 10 Random Questions! |archive-url=https://archive.today/20140225230024/http://www.kykx.com/Rachele-Lynae-Answers-10-Random-Questions-/11221103?pid=329988 |archive-date=25 February 2014 |url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nLynae is married to drummer Tim Creedon.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/rachele-lynae-engaged/|title=Rachele Lynae Engaged|date=8 October 2015 }}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nIn 2012 Rachele Lynae signed with Momentum Label Group of [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], Tennessee. At the end of her senior year at Belmont University, Rachele Lynae recorded a five-song [[extended play|EP]]. After sharing the EP with now-manager Jimmy Murphy, Lynae was introduced to [[Jamie O'Neal]], Murphy's daughter.<ref name=bikman/>\n\nWorking with Jamie O'Neal, [[Stephanie Bentley]], and producer Jimmy Murphy, Rachele co-wrote and recorded \"Party 'Til the Cows Come Home\", a country party anthem.<ref>{{cite AV media\n |people=Lynae, Rachele; Jamie O'Neal, Jimmy Murphy, and Stephanie Bentley\n |year=2012\n |title=Party 'Til the Cows Come Home\n |location=YouTube\n |publisher=Momentum Label Group\n |medium=Video\n |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m-F2vI7XIsg\n |accessdate=January 4, 2013\n}}</ref> The music video was directed by multi award-winning director [[Trey Fanjoy]].<ref name=hotnew>{{cite news\n |title        = Hot new country artist Rachele Lynae and ''Country Weekly'' are giving fans 7 free songs!\n |url          = http://www.todayscountrymag.com/830rachelelynae.htm\n |newspaper    = Today's Country\n |date         = August 31, 2012\n |accessdate   = September 28, 2012\n |archive-url  = https://archive.today/20130204100206/http://www.todayscountrymag.com/830rachelelynae.htm\n |archive-date = 2013-02-04\n |url-status     = dead\n}}</ref><ref>{{cite AV media\n |people=Lynae, Rachele; Jamie O'Neal, Jimmy Murphy, and Stephanie Bentley\n |year=2012\n |title=Party 'Til the Cows Come Home\n |location=Country Music Television\n |publisher=Momentum Label Group\n |medium=Video\n |url=http://www.cmt.com/videos/rachele-lynae/816810/party-til-the-cows-come-home.jhtml\n |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130724100839/http://www.cmt.com/videos/rachele-lynae/816810/party-til-the-cows-come-home.jhtml\n |url-status=dead\n |archive-date=July 24, 2013\n |accessdate=September 28, 2012\n}}</ref>\n\nIn 2012, Lynae and [[Jamie O'Neal]] released a duet of \"[[Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas]]\" as a holiday single and video, which was subsequently featured in [[People (magazine)|People Magazine]]'s Country Special Issue's Holiday Playlist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gotcountryonline.com/2013/11/16/rising-country-star-rachele-lynae-featured-in-the-new-issue-of-people-country/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140301221842/http://www.gotcountryonline.com/2013/11/16/rising-country-star-rachele-lynae-featured-in-the-new-issue-of-people-country/|archive-date=March 1, 2014|website=gotcountryonline.com|date=November 16, 2013|title=Rising Country Star Rachele Lynae Featured In The New Issue Of PEOPLE Country}}</ref> She was also listed in Nashville Lifestyles' Top 20 Musicians to Watch.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.nashvillelifestyles.com/bestof/top-musicians-to-watch |title=Top 20 Musicians to Watch \u2013 Nashville Lifestyles |access-date=2014-02-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140303084645/http://www.nashvillelifestyles.com/bestof/top-musicians-to-watch |archive-date=2014-03-03 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nLynae's 2013 single, \"Fishin' For Something\" was very well received at country radio, and topped the Renegade Radio/Nashville.com Chart in August.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nashville.com/music/2013/08/rachele-lynae-tops-the-renegade-radionashville-com-chart/ |title=Rachele Lynae Tops the Renegade Radio/Nashville.com Chart \u00ab Nashville.com |accessdate=2014-02-25 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131011225012/http://www.nashville.com/music/2013/08/rachele-lynae-tops-the-renegade-radionashville-com-chart/ |archivedate=2013-10-11 }}</ref> Earlier that same year, Lynae was invited to become an honorary \"Friends and Family\" member of the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.gotcountryonline.com/2013/02/19/newcomer-rachele-lynae-becomes-honorary-friends-and-family-member-of-the-country-music-hall-of-fame-and-museum/ |title=Newcomer Rachele Lynae Becomes Honorary Friends and Family Member Of The Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|date=February 19, 2013 |access-date=2014-02-25 |archive-date=2014-03-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302042331/http://www.gotcountryonline.com/2013/02/19/newcomer-rachele-lynae-becomes-honorary-friends-and-family-member-of-the-country-music-hall-of-fame-and-museum/ |url-status=dead |website = gotcountryonline.com}}</ref> \"Touch The Stars,\" released on February 18, 2014, was Lynae's third single release<ref name=\"allaccess.com\"/> and received airplay at [[Sirius XM Radio]]'s country channel, [[The Highway (Sirius XM)|The Highway]].\n\nLynae's self-titled debut album, which was released on April 22, 2014, was produced by Jamie O'Neal and included her first three singles: \"Party 'Til the Cows Come Home,\" \"Fishin' for Something,\" and \"Touch the Stars.\"\n\nLynae has opened for such legendary artists as [[Wynonna Judd]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ticketweb.com/t3/sale/SaleEventDetail?dispatch=loadSelectionData&eventId=3599494|title=Ticket Purchase Page for Sierra View Music Fest|website=ticketweb.com|access-date=2014-02-25|archive-date=2016-03-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304032252/http://www.ticketweb.com/t3/sale/SaleEventDetail?dispatch=loadSelectionData&eventId=3599494|url-status=dead}}</ref> and [[Leon Russell]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.gtrnews.com/greater-tulsa-reporter/11842/country-newcomer-opens-for-leon-russell |title=GTR Newspapers &#124; Find Local Tulsa, Bixby, Broken Arrow, Jenks, Union, and Owasso News, Sports, and Entertainment:Country Newcomer Opens for Leon Russell |access-date=2014-02-25 |archive-date=2015-04-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418031423/http://www.gtrnews.com/greater-tulsa-reporter/11842/country-newcomer-opens-for-leon-russell |url-status=dead }}</ref> She has played at famed Nashville's local bar [[Tootsie's Orchid Lounge]] and made five appearances at Nashville's 2012 [[Country Music Association Awards|Country Music Awards]] events, including one acoustic performance and several autograph signings.<ref name=bio/>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_Ranch_(band)","to":"The Ranch (band)"}],"pages":{"7674800":{"pageid":7674800,"ns":0,"title":"The Ranch (band)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Country music trio}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = The Ranch\n| image           = \n| image_size      = \n| landscape       = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank -->\n| alt             = \n| caption         = \n| background      = group_or_band\n| origin          = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[country rock]]\n| years_active    = {{start date|1997}}\u2013{{end date|1998}}\n| label           = [[Capitol Records Nashville|Capitol]]\n| past_members    =\n* Peter Clarke\n* Jerry Flowers\n* [[Keith Urban]]\n}}\n\n'''The Ranch''' was an Australian-American [[country music]] trio, which formed in 1997 by [[Keith Urban]] (guitar, keyboards and vocals), Jerry Flowers (bass guitar and background vocals) and Peter Clarke (drums and vocals).<ref name=\"NLA 1\">{{Citation | author1 = The Ranch | author2=Urban, Keith | authorlink2 = Keith Urban | author3 = Rust, Vernon | title = The Ranch | publication-date = 1997 | publisher = Capitol: Manufactured and distributed by WEA. [[National Library of Australia]] | location = [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville, Tenn]] | url = http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/8867792 | access-date = 17 August 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SAEC&p_theme=saec&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAFE7FAD5D99D77&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=\"Funktry\", Chesney & Willie |access-date=2008-09-05 |last=Alexander |first=Wiley |date=1997-10-10 |work=San Antonio Express-News}}</ref><ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|date=2008|page=338|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref> Most of the group's material was co-written by Urban and Vernon Rust.<ref name=\"NLA 1\"/><ref name=\"Ruhlmann\"/>\n\nThey issued a [[The Ranch (album)|self-titled album]] on [[Capitol Records]] in that year, and two related singles, \"Walkin' the Country\" and \"Just Some Love\", which appeared on the country charts before the group disbanded in 1998.<ref name=\"Ruhlmann\">{{cite web | url = http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-ranch-mw0000325776 | title = ''The Ranch'' \u2013 Keith Urban | publisher = [[AllMusic]] | author = Ruhlmann, William | access-date=17 August 2014 }}</ref> Besides its two singles, ''The Ranch'' included \"[[Some Days You Gotta Dance]]\", which was issued in 2001 as a single by the [[Dixie Chicks]], and also had Urban on guitar.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20040405190312/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/urban_keith/bio.jhtml Keith Urban Biography]</ref> After disbanding The Ranch, Urban resumed his solo career.<ref name=\"Ruhlmann\"/> Due to his solo success, The Ranch's album was re-issued in February 2004 on Capitol/[[EMI Records|EMI]] as ''Keith Urban in The Ranch'' with two bonus tracks: \"Billy\" and \"[[Stuck in the Middle with You]]\", the latter is a cover version of a single by the 1970s band [[Stealers Wheel]].<ref name=\"Ruhlmann 1\">{{cite web | url = http://www.allmusic.com/album/release/in-the-ranch-mr0001212200 | title = ''In the Ranch'' \u2013 Keith Urban | author = Ruhlmann, William | publisher = [[AllMusic]] | access-date = 17 August 2014 }}</ref> It also featured two music videos, \"Walkin' the Country\" and \"Clutterbilly\".<ref name=\"Ruhlmann 1\"/>\n\nAfter The Ranch disbanded, Urban began a solo career. Many of his solo efforts have included Flowers.\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|+ List of albums, with selected details and chart positions\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\"| Title\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\"| Album details\n! scope=\"col\" colspan=\"2\"| Peak positions\n|-\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:3em; font-size:90%\"| [[ARIA Charts|AUS]]<br /><ref>{{cite Ryan|page=229}}</ref>\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:3em; font-size:90%\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[The Ranch (album)|The Ranch]]''\n| \n* Release date: September 1997\n* Label: [[EastWest Records|EastWest]], [[Capitol Records Nashville|Capitol Nashville]]\n* Format: [[Compact disc|CD]], [[Cassette tape|cassette]]\n| 82 || 34<sup>A</sup>\n|}\n*<sup>A</sup>Chart position of 2004 re-release as ''Keith Urban in The Ranch''.\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! colspan=\"2\"| Peak chart<br />positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]<br /><ref name=\"whitburn\"/>\n! width=\"45\"| [[RPM (magazine)|CAN Country]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Walkin' the Country\"\n| 1997\n| 50\n| 65\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''The Ranch''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Just Some Love\"\n| 1998\n| 61\n| 92\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! Year\n! Director\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Walkin' the Country\"\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1997\n| rowspan=\"2\"| Roger Pistole\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Clutterbilly\"\n|}\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n===ARIA Music Awards===\nThe [[ARIA Music Awards]] are a set of annual ceremonies presented by [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA), which recognise excellence, innovation, and achievement across all genres of the [[music of Australia]]. They commenced in 1987. \n\n{{awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 1997|1997]] || ''The Ranch'' || [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]] || {{nom}} || <ref>ARIA Award previous winners. {{cite web|url=http://www.ariaawards.com.au/history/award/Best-Country-Album|title=ARIA Awards Best Country Album|publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA)|access-date=9 April 2022}}</ref>\n{{end}}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n{{Keith Urban}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Ranch, The}}\n[[Category:Country music groups from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Capitol Records artists]]\n[[Category:American musical trios]]\n[[Category:Keith Urban]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 1997]]\n[[Category:Musical groups disestablished in 1998]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Cory_Marks","to":"Cory Marks"}],"pages":{"64947614":{"pageid":64947614,"ns":0,"title":"Cory Marks","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Canadian country singer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Cory Marks\n| image           = Cory Marks.jpg\n| caption         = Marks performing in 2023\n| image_size      =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1989|10|11}}\n| birth_name      =\n| birth_place     = [[North Bay, Ontario]], Canada\n| alias           = Lion Man, Sunshine\n| origin          =\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar, drums\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[country rock]]|[[outlaw country]]|[[hard rock]]}}\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 2011\u2013present\n| label           = {{hlist|[[Better Noise Music|Better Noise]]|Big Star}}\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{URL|corymarks.com/}}\n}}\n'''Cory Gerald Joseph Marquardt''' (born October 11, 1989<ref name=\"Nugget\">{{cite news|title=Marquardt signs record deal|url=https://www.nugget.ca/entertainment/music/marquardt-signs-record-deal |work=[[North Bay Nugget]]|publisher=[[Postmedia Network]]|date=September 26, 2018}}</ref>) is a Canadian [[country rock]] singer-songwriter better known by his stage name '''Cory Marks'''. He is signed to [[Better Noise Music]].<ref name=\"Invictus\">{{cite news|title=Cory Marks - Biography|url=http://www.iegroup.ca/artists/cory-marks/|work=Invictus Entertainment Group|accessdate=August 14, 2020}}</ref> He has released two albums, ''[[This Man (album)|This Man]]'' in 2015 under Big Star Recordings, and most recently ''[[Who I Am (Cory Marks album)|Who I Am]]'' in 2020 under Better Noise. Since the release, the album has accumulated over 260 million global streams with his debut single \"[[Outlaws & Outsiders]]\" being certified Platinum in Canada, Gold in the US and reaching top 10 at US rock radio and #3 in Germany, making Marks the first to ever do so as a Canadian country act.\n\n==Early life==\nMarks was raised in [[North Bay, Ontario]], the younger brother of professional hockey player [[Matt Marquardt]], and learned how to skate at three years old.<ref>{{cite web|title= Cory Marks rise to stardom|url=https://www.mainstreet-nashville.com/opinion/cory-marks-rise-to-stardom/article_aca7ec08-f430-11ea-a269-d7e44b38b3ff.html|first=Bethany|last=Bowman|date=September 11, 2020}}</ref> He cites [[Merle Haggard]], [[Waylon Jennings]], [[Bryan Adams]], [[Ozzy Osbourne]], and [[Rush (band)|Rush]] as early musical influences.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cory Marks - Bio|url=http://www.corymarks.com/bio|work=CoryMarks.com|accessdate=August 15, 2020}}</ref> Marks played university hockey at the [[Royal Military College of Canada]] where he also pursued dreams of becoming a fighter pilot.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cory Marks hits a live wire with \"Outlaws and Outsiders\"|url= https://www.mynorthbaynow.com/49948/cory-marks-hits-a-live-wire-with-outlaws-and-outsiders/|first=Kortney|last=Kenney|work=My North Bay Now|date=November 20, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=INTERVIEW: CORY MARKS \u2013 Ontario, CA; 2020|url=https://www.musicalypse.net/cory-marks-ontario-ca-2020/|work=Musicalypse|date=March 12, 2020}}</ref> He had never performed music publicly until his friends encouraged him to do so while at a bar in college.<ref>{{cite news|title=Interview~ Mixing country music with the hard-hitting stomp of rock & roll, Cory Marks|url=https://ignitemusicmag.com/2020/03/31/interview-mixing-country-music-with-the-hard-hitting-stomp-of-rock-roll-cory-marks/|first=Bryan Joe|last=Corder|work=Ignite Music Magazine|date=March 31, 2020}}</ref> He has performed using the name \"Cory Marks\" since the release of his debut album.<ref name=\"Nugget\"/> Marks achieved his private pilot license in 2021.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cory Marks' single certified Gold|url=https://www.nugget.ca/news/cory-marks-single-certified-gold |work=[[North Bay Nugget]]|first=Michael|last=Lee|publisher=[[Postmedia Network]]|date=April 29, 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\n===2014\u20132015: ''This Man''===\nIn July 2014, he released his first single to Canadian country radio, \"Smartphone\".<ref name=\"Smartphone\"/> His second single, \"21\", was released in April 2015.<ref name=\"TwentyOne\"/> His first album, ''[[This Man (album)|This Man]]'' was released on May 26, 2015 through Big Star Recordings.<ref name=\"ThisMan\">{{cite web|title=Cory Marquardt releases his first album \"This Man\"|url=https://www.kissnorthbay.com/2015/05/26/cory-marquardts-releases-his-first-album-this-man/|work=Kiss 100.5 North Bay|date=May 26, 2016}}</ref><ref name=\"BayT\">{{cite news|last=Dawson|first=Chris|title=Marquardt releases first album today|url= https://www.baytoday.ca/local-news/marquardt-releases-first-album-today-18775|work=BayToday.ca|date=May 26, 2015}}</ref> The album included his first two singles, as well as two further singles, \"This Man\",<ref name=\"TM\">{{cite web|title= INTRODUCING, THIS MAN, CORY MARQUARDT|url= https://www.soundcheckentertainment.ca/introducing-this-man-cory-marquardt/|work=Sound Check Entertainment|date= July 26, 2015|accessdate=August 14, 2020}}</ref> and \"Nowhere With You\".<ref name=\"NWY\">{{cite web|title=New video released by Cory Marquardt|url= https://canadianbeats.ca/2016/01/06/new-video-released-by-cory-marquardt-3/|work=Canadian Beats Media|first=Jenna|last=Melanson|date=January 6, 2016}}</ref>\n\n=== 2016\u20132020: ''Who I Am'' ===\nIn 2016, Marks signed a deal to work with award-winning producer [[Kevin Churko]], known for work with [[Ozzy Osbourne]], [[Shania Twain]], and [[Five Finger Death Punch]].<ref>{{cite web|title=More good news for local artist Cory Marquardt|url=https://www.baytoday.ca/local-news/more-good-news-for-local-artist-cory-marquardt-305484|work=BayToday.ca|first=Chris|last=Dawson|date=May 27, 2016}}</ref> In 2018, he signed a record deal with [[Eleven Seven Label Group|Eleven Seven Music]] (later rebranded as [[Better Noise Music]]) as their flagship country artist.<ref name=\"Nugget\"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Cory Marks Signs Record Deal with Eleven Seven Music|url=http://www.iegroup.ca/news/cory-marks-signs-record-deal-eleven-seven-music/|work=Invictus Entertainment Group|date=September 26, 2018}}</ref>\n\nIn November 2019, Marks released his first single on Better Noise, \"[[Outlaws & Outsiders]]\", featuring [[Ivan Moody (vocalist)|Ivan Moody]], [[Travis Tritt]], and [[Mick Mars]],<ref>{{cite web|title=North Bay's Cory Marks' new song is number one on iTunes Canada|url= https://northernontario.ctvnews.ca/north-bay-s-cory-marks-new-song-is-number-one-on-itunes-canada-1.4703034|first=Jessica|last=Gosselin|work=[[CTV News]] Northern Ontario|date=November 26, 2019}}</ref> which debuted at #1 on [[iTunes]] in Canada as well as #1 on the [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] [[Rock Digital Songs]] and [[Rock Digital Songs|Hard Rock Digital Songs]] charts and #7 on the [[Country Digital Song Sales|Country Digital Songs]] charts.<ref>{{cite web|title= Cory Marks Throws Down in Single \"Outlaws & Outsiders\" ft. Travis Tritt, Ivan Moody & Mick Mars|url= http://frontporchmusic.ca/music/cory-marks-outlaws-outsiders/|work=Front Porch Music|date=January 26, 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"Billboard\"/> The song would later peak inside the top 10 on US [[Mainstream Rock (chart)|Mainstream Rock]] radio, top 5 on German rock radio, and peaked at #12 on [[Canada Rock]] radio.<ref>{{cite web|title=Big day for North Bay's Cory Marks|url=https://www.baytoday.ca/local-news/big-day-for-north-bays-cory-marks-2617951|work=BayToday.ca|date=August 7, 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"CanRock\"/> It was also certified Gold by [[Music Canada]].<ref>{{cite web|first=Chris|last=Dawson|title=Cory Marks is golden|url=https://www.timminstoday.com/local-news/cory-marks-is-golden-3681473|work=Timmins Today|date=May 1, 2021}}</ref>\n\nIn June 2020, Marks released \"[[Drive (Cory Marks song)|Drive]]\",<ref name=\"Drive\"/><ref name=\"Drive2\"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://themusicuniverse.com/cory-marks-announces-who-i-am/|title= CORY MARKS ANNOUNCES 'WHO I AM'|work=The Music Universe|first=Buddy|last=Iahn|date=June 5, 2020}}</ref> and announced it as the second single to country radio off his second album, ''[[Who I Am (Cory Marks album)|Who I Am]]'', which was released on August 7, 2020 through Better Noise.<ref name=\"WhoIAm\"/><ref name=\"CountryNote\">{{cite news|title=Cory Marks, The Critically Acclaimed Next Generation of Country Rock, Releases Debut Album, WHO I AM|url=https://www.thecountrynote.com/in-the-news/cory-marks-the-critically-acclaimed-next-generation-of-country-rock-releases-debut-album-who-i-am/|date=August 7, 2020|work=The Country Note}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://themusicuniverse.com/cory-marks-who-i-am-debuts-worldwide/|title= CORY MARKS 'WHO I AM' DEBUTS WORLDWIDE|work=The Music Universe|first=Buddy|last=Iahn|date=August 11, 2020}}</ref> In October 2020, \"[[Blame It on the Double]]\" was released as the second single to rock radio in Germany and the United Kingdom.<ref name=\"BOD\">{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/corymarksmusic/status/1313249605916733440|title=Cory Marks on Twitter: \"Very excited to announce that my single #BlameItOnTheDouble is now at UK & [German] rock radio!! \ud83e\udd43\ud83e\udd43 @BetterNoise \ud83c\uddec\ud83c\udde7\ud83c\udde8\ud83c\udde6\"|via=Twitter|accessdate=October 5, 2020}}</ref> Marks also released his first Christmas single \"Jingle My Bells\", a cover of a song by [[The Tractors]], that month.<ref name=\"JMB\"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://themusicuniverse.com/cory-marks-releasing-jingle-my-bells/|title=CORY MARKS RELEASING 'JINGLE MY BELLS'|work=The Music Universe|first=Buddy|last=Iahn|date=October 8, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Cory Marks has a new Christmas tune and it's catchy!|url=https://www.baytoday.ca/local-news/cory-marks-has-a-new-christmas-tune-and-its-catchy-3142123|work=BayToday.ca|first=Chris|last=Dawson|date=December 1, 2020}}</ref> In April 2021, Marks released a new version of \"Blame It on the Double\" featuring Tyler Connolly of [[Theory of a Deadman]] and [[Jason Hook]].<ref>{{cite news|title=CORY MARKS PUTS THE HAMMER DOWN FOR 'BLAME IT ON THE DOUBLE' COLLAB|first=Chris|last=Parton|url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/music/cory-marks-blame-it-on-the-double-collab/|work=Sounds Like Nashville|date=April 30, 2021|accessdate=May 4, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|title=Cory Marks Drops Single With Jason Hook & Theory of a Deadman's Tyler Connolly|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/rock/cory-marks-blame-it-double-single-video-9565706/|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|first=Dave|last=Brooks|date=April 30, 2021}}</ref>\n\n=== 2021\u2013present: ''Sorry for Nothing'' and extended plays ===\nOn June 18, 2021, Marks released the extended play ''Nashville Mornings''. It included a cover of [[Blaze Foley]]'s \"If I Could Only Fly\", as well as a \"Country Mix\" of \"[[Blame It on the Double]]\" featuring Tyler Connolly, which was sent to Canadian country radio.<ref name=\"NM\">{{cite web|title=CORY MARKS' NEW 'NASHVILLE MORNINGS' EP OFFERS REFRESHED APPROACH TO THE COUNTRY-ROCKER'S CATALOGUE|url=https://rocknloadmag.com/news/cory-marks-new-nashville-mornings-ep-offers-refreshed-approach-to-the-country-rockers-catalogue/|website=Rock N' Load Magazine|date=June 17, 2021|access-date=June 18, 2021|archive-date=June 18, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210618113122/https://rocknloadmag.com/news/cory-marks-new-nashville-mornings-ep-offers-refreshed-approach-to-the-country-rockers-catalogue/|url-status=dead}}</ref> He followed that up with the extended play ''Nashville Nights'' on August 20, 2021, which included a new track \"In Me I Trust\",<ref>{{cite web|title=Cory Marks - In Me I Trust \n|url=https://newcountrysongs.com/cory-marks/in-me-i-trust/|work=New Country Songs|accessdate=August 31, 2021}}</ref> the solo version of \"[[Outlaws & Outsiders]]\", and live versions of \"[[Drive (Cory Marks song)|Drive]]\" and \"Blame It on the Double\".<ref name=\"Nights\">{{cite web|url=https://tuonelamagazine.com/review-cory-marks-ep-nashville-nights/|title=REVIEW: Cory Marks \u2013 EP: Nashville Nights|work=Tuonela Magazine|date=August 13, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://canadianbeats.ca/2021/08/31/cory-marks-leaps-into-the-world-of-rock-heavy-with-the-release-of-his-latest-ep-nashville-nights-and-announces-his-fall-tour-dates/|title=Cory Marks leaps into the world of rock-heavy with the release of his latest EP, Nashville Nights and announces his fall tour dates|first=Nanci|last=Dagg|date=August 31, 2021|work=Canadian Beats Media}}</ref>\n\nIn November 2022, Marks released the extended play ''I Rise'', which included the singles \"Burn It Up\" and \"Flying\".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.music-news.com/news/Underground/153522/Cory-Marks-releases-new-EP-I-Rise|title=Cory Marks releases new EP 'I Rise'|date=November 11, 2022|access-date=November 18, 2022|work=Music-News.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Jenna|last=Melanson|title=Cory Marks unveils new EP, I Rise (Interview)|url=https://canadianbeats.ca/2022/11/16/cory-marks-unveils-new-ep-i-rise-interview|work=Canadian Beats Media|date=November 16, 2022|access-date=November 22, 2022}}</ref> He supported [[Five Finger Death Punch]] on their headlining tour in the United States in the fall and winter of 2022 alongside [[Brantley Gilbert]].<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/pro/cory-marks-major-tour-pandemic-delayed-live-music/|title=Cory Marks Ready to Support a Major Tour, After 3-Year Pandemic Delay|date=November 4, 2022|access-date=November 18, 2022|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|first=Dave|last=Brooks|url-access=subscription}}</ref> \n\nIn June 2024, Marks released two songs, \"Guilty\u201d, which featured [[Bad Wolves]]'s lead singer DL, and \"Drunk When I'm High\", which was serviced to Australian country radio.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.rock101.net/2024/06/28/cory-marks-premieres-new-song-guilty-featuring-bad-wolves-dl/|title=Cory Marks premieres new song, \"Guilty,\" featuring Bad Wolves' DL|work=Rock 101.1|date=June 28, 2024|first=Josh|last=Johnson|location=[[Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan]]|access-date=July 29, 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mnprmagazine.com/news/cory-marks-guilty-drunk-when-im-high/|title= \nCory Marks Releases Two Tracks \u2013 'Guilty' feat. DL of Bad Wolves and 'Drunk When I'm High'|date=June 28, 2024|work=MNPR Magazine|first=Richard|last=Bolwell|access-date=July 29, 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.baytoday.ca/local-news/marks-enjoys-homecoming-while-releasing-new-tunes-9152530|title=Marks enjoys homecoming while releasing new tunes|first=Chris|last=Dawson|work=BayToday|date=June 30, 2024|access-date=July 29, 2024}}</ref> On October 11, 2024, Marks will release his third studio album ''Sorry for Nothing''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nugget.ca/entertainment/cory-marks-getting-some-big-name-salutes-for-one-of-his-singles|title=Cory Marks getting some big name salutes for one of his singles|work=[[North Bay Nugget]]|first=Greg|last=Estabrook|date=December 6, 2023|access-date=December 10, 2023}}</ref><ref name=\"SFN\"/> He released the song \"(Make My) Country Rock\" featuring [[Sully Erna]], [[Travis Tritt]], and [[Mick Mars]], concurrently with the announcement of the forthcoming album.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.1057thepoint.com/music-news/sully-erna-mick-mars-guest-on-new-cory-marks-song-make-my-country-rock/|title=Sully Erna, Mick Mars guest on new Cory Marks song, \"(Make My) Country Rock\"|work=105.7 The Point|date=July 26, 2024|access-date=August 22, 2024}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! 16, 2023}}</ref>\n|\n|-\n|}\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|+\n!Year\n!Association\n!Category\n!Nominated Work\n!Result\n!Ref\n|-\n| [[2021 Canadian Country Music entertainer of the year|work=[[Global News]]|date=November 30, 2021}}</ref>\n|-\n\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2022\n| rowspan=\"2\"| Country Music Association of Ontario\n|Fans' Choice\n|{{n/a}}\n| {{nom}}\n| stats|nhl=|elite=61000|espn=|euro=|hr=|hockeydb=110995|legendsm=|legends=|legendstype=|tsn=}}\n\n{{Cory Marks}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Marks, Cory}}\n[[Category:1989 North Bay, Ontario]]\n[[Category:21st-century Canadian male singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century Canadian singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century Canadian singer-songwriters]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Lee_Kernaghan","to":"Lee Kernaghan"}],"pages":{"2193612":{"pageid":2193612,"ns":0,"title":"Lee Kernaghan","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2021}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name                = Lee Kernaghan\n| image               = Lee Kernaghan (cropped2).jpg\n| alt                 = Man in black hat sitting on ground\n| caption             = \n| birth_name          = Lee Raymond Kernaghan\n| alias               =\n| birth_date          = {{Birth date and age|1964|4|15|df=yes}}\n| birth_place         = [[Corryong]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Australia\n| instrument          = Vocals, guitar\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]], [[Country Rock]], [[Rock music|Rock]], [[Pop music|Pop]], [[Country Pop]]\n| occupation          = Singer, songwriter, musician\n| years_active        = 1977\u2013present\n| label               = [[ABC Music]]\n| associated_acts     = {{hlist|The Blue Devils|Fiona Kernaghan|[[Ray Kernaghan]]|[[Tania Kernaghan]]}}\n| website             = {{URL|leekernaghan.com.au}}\n}}\n'''Lee Kernaghan''' [[Order of Australia|OAM]] (born 15 April 1964) is an Australian [[country music]] singer, songwriter and guitarist. Kernaghan has won four [[ARIA Awards]] and three [[APRA Awards (Australia)|APRA Awards]], and has sold over two million albums, and as of 2021,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jbhifi.com.au/products/cd-kernaghan-lee-backroad-nation-cd?queryID=1f79a7cabae927384ce0134b82f8b8e6&objectID=379435|title=Backroad Nation|website=[[JB HiFi]]|access-date=30 December 2021}}</ref> has won 38 [[Golden Guitar]]s at the Country Music Awards of Australia (second to [[Slim Dusty]]).\n\nHe was the 2008 [[Australian of the Year]], in recognition of his support for rural and regional Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.cs-ma-ANL%3AMA~Converted-ruth-5|title=Kernaghan. Lee|work=Music Australia|publisher=National Library of Australia|access-date=16 October 2009}}</ref><ref name=\"aoty\"/> Kernaghan was the recipient of the Outstanding Achievement Award at the 2015 ARIA Awards, for ''Spirit of the Anzacs''.<ref name=\":3\" />\n\n== Biography ==\n===1965\u20131990: Early years===\nLee Kernaghan was born on 15 April 1964 in [[Corryong]], Victoria and is the son of country music singer and truck driver [[Ray Kernaghan]]. Lee spent his formative years growing up in Albury [[New South Wales]]. His grandfather was a third generation drover of sheep and cattle.<ref name=\"abcbio\">{{cite web|url=https://www.abcmusic.com.au/lee-kernaghan|title=Lee Kernaghan|website=ABC Music|access-date=30 December 2021}}</ref>\n\nIn 1986, Kernaghan traveled to the United States to represent Australia at the [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] 'Fan Fair' country music festival.\n\n===1990s ===\nIn 1992, Kernaghan released \"Boys from the Bush\" which became his first number one on the country chart.<ref name=\"abcbio\"/> Kernaghan said \"When Garth (Porter) and I first wrote 'Boys from the Bush' I had no idea it would ever be a hit. It was just a song about me and my mates, working on the land, going to the pub and tearing around in utes. I didn't think anyone would be that interested in us... we were just kids from the bush but Garth said 'this record (''The Outback Club'') has to be about your life and where you come from so we wrote that song and several others and before long I had a band and we were out on the road performing them live.\"<ref name=\"abcbio\"/>\n\nIn May 1992, Kernaghan released ''[[The Outback Club]]''. The album debuted at number 94 on the [[ARIA Charts]].<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/> At the 1993 Country Music Awards of Australia (CMAA), the album won Album of the Year the [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album]].<ref name=\"CMAA\"/> The album re-entered the chart later peaking at number 58 in May 1994.<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/>\n\nIn August 1993, Kernaghan released his second studio album, ''[[Three Chain Road]]''. The album again won the CMAA Album of the Year and the ARIA Award for Best Country Album.<ref name=\"CMAA\"/>\n\nIn July 1995, Kernaghan released his third studio album, ''[[1959 (album)|1959]]'', which peaked at number 9 on the ARIA Chart, becoming Kernaghan's first top ten album.<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/> The album won Kernaghan his third Album of the Year at the CMAA of 1996.<ref name=\"CMAA\"/>\n\nIn February 1998, Kernaghan released his fourth studio album, ''[[Hat Town]]''. The album peaked at number 7 on the ARIA Chart<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/> and won his fourth Album of the Year at the CMAA of 1999.<ref name=\"CMAA\"/>\n\nKernaghan's fifth studio album was ''[[The Christmas Album (Lee Kernaghan album)|The Christmas Album]]'' in November 1998. The album peaked at number 31 on the ARIA chart.<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/>\n\n===2000s ===\nIn January 2000, Kernaghan released his sixth studio album, ''[[Rules of the Road (Lee Kernaghan album)|Rules of the Road]]''. This was followed by ''[[Electric Rodeo (Lee Kernaghan album)|Electric Rodeo]]'' in July 2002 which won Album of the Year and Top Selling Album of the Year at the 2003 CMAA.<ref name=\"CMAA\"/> ''Electric Rodeo'' peaked at number 5 on the ARIA chart.<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/>\n\nKernaghan was part of ''[[The Man from Snowy River: Arena Spectacular]]'' in 2002.\n\nIn October 2004, Kernaghan released his first greatest hits collection titled, ''[[The Big Ones: Greatest Hits Vol. 1]]''. The album peaked at number 16 on the ARIA charts and was certified platinum.<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/>\n\nIn April 2006, Kernaghan released his eighth studio album, ''[[The New Bush]]''. The album peaked at number 6 on the ARIA Charts and won Album of the Year and Top Selling Album of the Year at the 2007 CMAA.<ref name=\"CMAA\"/>\n\nIn July 2007, Kernaghan released his ninth studio album, ''[[Spirit of the Bush]]''. The album's title track peaked at number 11 on the ARIA singles chart, becoming Kernaghan's highest charting single. The song won three awards at the 2008 CMAA.<ref name=\"CMAA\"/>\n\nIn November 2009, Kernaghan released his tenth studio album, ''[[Planet Country]]''.\n\nIn 2009 Kernaghan was named the biggest hit-maker of the last twenty years on the Australian Country Tracks chart, beating musical greats from Australia and international.<ref name=\"abcbio\"/>\n\n===2010s ===\nIn September 2011, Kernaghan released his second greatest hits collection, ''[[Ultimate Hits (Lee Kernaghan album)|Ultimate Hits]]''. The album peaked at number 8 on the ARIA chart.<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/>\n\nIn October 2012, Kernaghan released his eleventh studio album, ''[[Beautiful Noise (Lee Kernaghan album)|Beautiful Noise]]''. The album peaked at number 9 on the ARIA chart.<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/>\n\nDuring a visit to the [[Australian War Memorial]] (AWM) in 2013, Kernaghan's friend and AWM Director [[Brendan Nelson|Dr. Brendan Nelson]] introduced Kernaghan to letters that were written by [[Australian Defence Force|Australian service men and women]] during various wars dating back to the landing at [[Gallipoli Campaign|Gallipoli]] during the [[World War I|First World War]]. These letters were held in the vaults at the AWM.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Lee Kernaghan \u2013 \"Outstanding Achievement Award\" for Spirit of the Anzacs {{!}} Australian War Memorial|url = https://www.awm.gov.au/blog/2015/12/10/lee-kernaghan-Spirit-of-the-Anzacs/|website = www.awm.gov.au|access-date = 14 December 2015}}</ref> The power of the letters affected Kernaghan deeply and the experience at the Australian War Memorial that day was the catalyst that saw these letters put to music in what would become the ''[[Spirit of the Anzacs (album)]]'' in March 2015. Upon release, the album peaked at number 1 on the ARIA charts, becoming Kernaghan's first chart topper. It was the highest selling Australian artist album for 2015.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web|title = ARIAs: Lee Kernaghan wins achievement award|url = http://www.skynews.com.au/culture/showbiz/music/2015/11/26/arias--lee-kernaghan-wins-achievement-award.html|website = www.skynews.com.au|access-date =14 December 2015}}</ref>\n\n2015 also saw the release of Kernaghan's first book, ''The Boy from the Bush, These Are My Songs, These Are My Stories''.\n\nIn March 2017, Kernaghan released his fourteenth studio album, ''[[The 25th Anniversary Album (Lee Kernaghan album)|The 25th Anniversary Album]]''. The album peaked at number 2 on the ARIA chart.<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/>\n\nIn 2019 Kernaghan released his fifteenth studio album, ''[[Backroad Nation]]'' with the title track staying four weeks at #1 on the country singles charts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://countrytrackschart.com.au/index.php?chartid=273|title=Country Songs Top 40 Australian Airplay Chart|website=countrytrackschart.com.au|access-date=7 August 2019}}</ref>\n\n===2020s ===\nIn 2022 Kernaghan is set to celebrate his 30th anniversary as an artist. In January 2022, he released a 3-CD greatest hits collection titled ''[[The Very Best of Lee Kernaghan: Three Decades of Hits]]'' on 14 January 2022 which peaked at number 17 on the ARIA charts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jbhifi.com.au/products/cd-kernaghan-lee-very-best-of-lee-kernaghan-three-decades-of-hits-3cd?queryID=4099785a3b5dbca5b478be730a34c990&objectID=540243|title=Very Best Of Lee Kernaghan: Three Decades Of Hits|website=[[JB Hi-Fi]]|date=30 December 2021}}</ref>\n\n== Personal life ==\nDuring July 2015, Kernaghan's music was played at anti-Islam rallies in Australia, without his permission.<ref name=\"the Music\">{{cite news | url = http://themusic.com.au/news/all/2015/07/24/lee-kernaghan-sits-on-fence-over-reclaim-australia-use-of-song/ | title = Lee Kernaghan Sits on Fence Over Reclaim Australia Use of Song | last = (staff writer) | work = themusic.com.au | date = 24 July 2015 | access-date = 2 July 2016 }}</ref><ref name=\"Reclaim\">{{cite news | url = http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/as-midnight-oil-demands-reclaim-australia-stop-playing-songs-lee-kernaghan-refuses-20150724-gijkuu.html | title = As Midnight Oil Demands Reclaim Australia Stop Playing Songs, Lee Kernaghan Refuses | last = Vincent | first = Peter | work = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | date = 24 July 2015 | access-date = 2 July 2016 }}</ref> He responded that the use of his work should be \"consistent with \u2013 and respectful of, the memory of ... [soldiers who] laid down their lives for the freedoms we have today.\"<ref name=\"Reclaim\" /> Fellow local artists, [[Jimmy Barnes]], [[John Farnham]] and [[Mark Seymour]], objected to the use of their material at those rallies.\n\nKernaghan married musician Robyn McKelvie in 1999. They have two sons, Jet and Rock.<ref name=smh2013>{{cite web|url= https://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/what-i-know-about-women-20130528-2n9aw.html |title=What I know about women - Lee Kernaghan |website=Sydney Morning Herald |date=2 June 2013 |access-date=28 January 2023 }}</ref>\n\n=== Business ventures ===\nFor several years, Kernaghan owned the historic Great Western Hotel in [[Rockhampton, Queensland]], after buying the pub in 2003 when it was placed into receivership after a downturn in trade and public liability concerns.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/site-archive/rural/qld/stories/s828257.htm Kernaghan buys Great Western pub], Chris Lawson, ''[[The Country Hour|Queensland Country Hour]]'', [[ABC Rural]], 9 April 2003. Retrieved 23 March 2017.</ref><ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/site-archive/rural/news/stories/s828277.htm Boy from the bush buys QLD pub], ''National Rural News'', [[ABC Rural]], 9 April 2003. Retrieved 23 March 2017.</ref> Kernaghan has described the time during which he owned the Great Western Hotel as one of the greatest periods of his life.<ref>[https://www.themorningbulletin.com.au/news/lee-kernaghan-returns-to-second-home-country-music/2631007 Country music legend Lee Kernaghan returns to 'second home'], Michelle Gately, ''[[The Morning Bulletin]]'', 7 May 2015. Retrieved 23 March 2017.</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n=== Studio albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\" border=\"1\"\n|-\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:17em;\"| Title\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n! scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\"| Peak chart positions\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\"| [[List of music recording certifications|Certifications]]\n|-\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:3.7em;font-size:90%;\"| [[ARIA Charts|AUS]]<br /><ref name=\"AUS-Albums\">Peak chart positions in Australia:\n*Top 50 peaks: {{cite web|url=http://australian-charts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Lee+Kernaghan|title=australian-charts.com \u2013 Discography Lee Kernaghan|publisher=Hung Medien|access-date=25 August 2021}}\n*Top 100 peaks to December 2010: {{cite book|last=Ryan|first=Gavin|title=Australia's Music Charts 1988\u20132010|year=2011|publisher=Moonlight Publishing|location=Mt.
