Montana"}],"pages":{"55287046":{"pageid":55287046,"ns":0,"title":"Tim Montana","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Singer songwriter}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2023}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Tim Montana\n| image             = Tim Montana.jpg\n| image_size        = 230px\n| caption           = Tim Montana\n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1985|01|5}}\n| birth_place       = [[Kalispell, Montana]], U.S.\n| genre             = {{Hlist|[[Country rock]]<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/tim-montana-mostly-stoned-video-charlie-sheen-905334/ |title=Tim Montana's 'Mostly Stoned' Video Is Weird AF |last=Hudak |first=Joseph |date=October 29, 2019 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |access-date=2023-07-18 |quote=Charlie Sheen directed the clip, which finds the country-rocker being chauffeured in a ghost convertible}}</ref>|[[Southern rock]]<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/country-rocker-tim-montana-salutes-the-worker-in-american-thread-video-789354/ |title=Country-Rocker Tim Montana Salutes the Worker in 'American Thread' Video |last=Hudak |first=Joseph |date=February 3, 2019 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=2023-07-19|quote=Southern rock and country artist Tim Montana has released a new video for his single \u201cAmerican Thread.\u201d }}</ref>}}\n| occupation        = {{flatlist|\n* Musician\n* singer\n* songwriter\n* guitarist\n}}\n| instrument        = {{flatlist|\n* Vocals\n* guitar\n}}\n| years_active      = 2003\u2013present\n| label             = {{flatlist|\n* CD Baby\n* [[RED Distribution]]\n*BBR/Knox Records\n}}\n| associated_acts   = {{flatlist|\n* [[ZZ Top]]\n* [[Kid Rock]]\n}}\n| website           = {{URL|http://www.timmontana.com/}}\n}}\n\n'''Tim Montana''' (born January 5, 1985) is an American singer, songwriter and guitarist signed to Music Knox Records/BBR Music Group part of BMG Rights Management.<ref>{{Cite web |title= Music Knox Records/BBR Music Group Sign Tim Montana |url=https://www.bbrmusicgroup.com/music-knox-recordsbbr-music-group-signs-tim-montana/ |access-date=2023-04-28 |website=bbrmusicgroup.com}}</ref>\n\n== Early life ==\nTim Montana was born on January 5, 1985, in [[Kalispell, Montana]] and raised in [[Butte, Montana]].<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite news |url=http://billingsgazette.com/news/state-and-regional/montana/song-about-butte-gets-radio-play/article_66b8c947-84c9-5116-82f8-5c001c6d1745.html |title=Song about Butte gets radio play |first=Leslie |last=McCartney |work=The Billings Gazette |access-date=2017-09-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201041601/http://billingsgazette.com/news/state-and-regional/montana/song-about-butte-gets-radio-play/article_66b8c947-84c9-5116-82f8-5c001c6d1745.html |archive-date=2017-12-01 |url-status=live}}</ref> Tim was given his first guitar at the age of six.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://mtstandard.com/news/local/on-stage-tonight-butte-native-performing-his-way-through-nashville/article_fca2296e-ea45-5c6a-94b1-2dc49a5c9c60.html |title=On stage tonight: Butte native performing his way through Nashville |author=Leslie McCartney |work=Montana Standard |access-date=2017-09-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201033247/http://mtstandard.com/news/local/on-stage-tonight-butte-native-performing-his-way-through-nashville/article_fca2296e-ea45-5c6a-94b1-2dc49a5c9c60.html |archive-date=2017-12-01 |url-status=live}}</ref> Since his family's trailer had no electricity, Tim taught himself to play by candlelight.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://therustic.com/event/tim-montana-the-shrednecks/ |title=Tim Montana \u2013 The Rustic {{!}} Kitchen. Backyard. Bar. Live Music. {{!}} Dallas, TX|work=The Rustic {{!}} Kitchen. Backyard. Bar. Live Music. {{!}} Dallas, TX|access-date=2017-09-01}}</ref> He later performed in school talent shows. After graduating from Butte High School in 2003, he moved to Los Angeles to study music.<ref name=\":0\" />\n\n== Musical career ==\nIt was while living in Los Angeles where Tim met guitarist and producer [[Johnny Hiland]] and with Hiland's encouragement moved to Nashville and began playing country and southern rock. His debut album, ''Iron Horse,'' was produced by Hiland (who also played guitar and sang backup) and released on the [[CD Baby]] label on August 21, 2007.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cduniverse.com/productinfo.asp?pid=7515470 |title=Tim Montana \u2013 Iron Horse CD Album |website=cduniverse.com |access-date=2017-09-01}}</ref>\n\nEarlier that same year, late-night talk show host [[David Letterman]] met Montana prior to Montana's Independence Day concert in [[Choteau, Montana]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://mtstandard.com/news/local/butte-native-on-late-show-oct/article_7dc9d61f-e0df-56af-acfa-27a194416b92.html |title=Butte native on 'Late Show' Oct. 17 |date=September 25, 2008 |work=Montana Standard |access-date=2017-09-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201035658/http://mtstandard.com/news/local/butte-native-on-late-show-oct/article_7dc9d61f-e0df-56af-acfa-27a194416b92.html |archive-date=2017-12-01 |url-status=live}}</ref> Months later, Letterman personally invited Montana to appear on ''[[Late Show with David Letterman|The Late Show with David Letterman]].'' Montana performed his song \"Butte, America\" on the October 17, 2008, program broadcast.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://helenair.com/news/state-and-regional/butte-native-to-appear-on-letterman-today/article_69e49197-85a0-586e-a5fa-b9b174b9ac9d.html |title=Butte native to appear on Letterman today |date=2008-10-17 |work=Helena Independent Record |access-date=2017-09-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201030428/http://helenair.com/news/state-and-regional/butte-native-to-appear-on-letterman-today/article_69e49197-85a0-586e-a5fa-b9b174b9ac9d.html |archive-date=2017-12-01 |url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nIn 2013, Montana recruited guitarist Kyle Rife, drummer Brian Wolff, and bassist Bryce Paul to perform as Tim Montana and the Shrednecks. During a studio session on September 11, 2013, Montana was introduced to [[ZZ Top]] founder [[Billy Gibbons]].<ref>{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/premieres/hear-zz-tops-billy-gibbons-weed-anthem-with-nashville-protege-20150211 |title=Hear ZZ Top's Billy Gibbons' Weed Anthem With Tim Montana |magazine=Rolling Stone |access-date=2017-09-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180227030816/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/premieres/hear-zz-tops-billy-gibbons-weed-anthem-with-nashville-protege-20150211 |archive-date=2018-02-27 |url-status=live}}</ref> Their meeting resulted in an impromptu songwriting collaboration, during which the two co-wrote and recorded the single \"This Beard Came Here to Party.\" The [[Boston Red Sox]] (known at the time for beards they'd grown during the playoffs) adopted the song as their anthem during the lead-up to the [[2013 World Series]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://mtstandard.com/news/local/butte-native-reaches-new-heights-with-new-single-release-kid/article_766c9ce7-0714-5529-a5ad-5ab205726ed6.html |title=Butte Native Reaches New Heights with New Single Release |access-date=2017-10-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171030005955/http://mtstandard.com/news/local/butte-native-reaches-new-heights-with-new-single-release-kid/article_766c9ce7-0714-5529-a5ad-5ab205726ed6.html |archive-date=2017-10-30 |url-status=live}}</ref> The Shrednecks and Gibbons recorded a custom version for the post-season (with lyrics referencing Red Sox highlights and Boston landmarks).<ref name=\"NESN.com\">{{Cite news |date=October 24, 2013 |title=Tim Montana Remakes 'These Beards Came Here to Party' Featuring Lyrics About Boston, Red Sox Highlights (Video) |work=NESN.com |url=https://nesn.com/2013/10/tim-montana-remakes-these-beards-came-here-to-party-featuring-lyrics-about-boston-red-sox-highlights-video/ |url-status=live |access-date=2017-09-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171020033845/https://nesn.com/2013/10/tim-montana-remakes-these-beards-came-here-to-party-featuring-lyrics-about-boston-red-sox-highlights-video/ |archive-date=2017-10-20}}</ref> Montana and the band later returned to sing [[The Star-Spangled Banner]] at [[Fenway Park]] at a May 28, 2013, ceremony honoring the winning [[2004 World Series]] Red Sox team.<ref name=\"boston.cbslocal.com\">{{Cite web |title=Tim Montana and the Shrednecks Sing National Anthem at Fenway Park, Then on Flight Home |url=http://boston.cbslocal.com/2014/06/03/tim-montana-and-the-shrednecks-sing-national-anthem-at-fenway-park-then-on-flight-home/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171020032828/http://boston.cbslocal.com/2014/06/03/tim-montana-and-the-shrednecks-sing-national-anthem-at-fenway-park-then-on-flight-home/ |archive-date=2017-10-20 |access-date=2017-09-01}}</ref>\n\nMontana and Gibbons would go on to share credits on three other songs: \"Fifty Fifty,\" \"Weed and Whiskey,\" and \"Rust and Red.\" The last of these received its broadcast debut during the Fox News show [[The Five (TV program)|The Five]] during an interview with [[Navy SEAL Team 6]] member [[Robert J. O'Neill (U.S. Navy SEAL)|Robert J. O'Neill]], subject of the [[Fox News]] documentary ''The Man Who Killed Osama bin Laden.''<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.robertjoneill.com/2014-11-18_Rob-ONeill-Tim-Montana-Rust-And-Red.html |title=Rob O'Neill and Tim Montana on The Five |date=November 18, 2014 |access-date=2017-09-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170521092946/http://www.robertjoneill.com/2014-11-18_Rob-ONeill-Tim-Montana-Rust-And-Red.html |archive-date=2017-05-21 |url-status=live}}</ref> O\u2019Neill, a fellow native of Butte, had previously become acquainted with Montana through O\u2019Neill's brother Tom, a radio DJ and early supporter of Montana's music.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://roughstock.com/news/2014/11/30727-tim-montana-shrednecks-sign-deal-red-music |title=Tim Montana and the Shrednecks Sign Deal With RED Music {{!}} RoughStock|work=RoughStock|access-date=2017-09-01|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201030332/http://roughstock.com/news/2014/11/30727-tim-montana-shrednecks-sign-deal-red-music|archive-date=2017-12-01|url-status=live}}</ref> Robert J. O'Neill later featured prominently in the 2017 music video for Montana's single \"Hillbilly Rich\".<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.outdoorhub.com/news/2017/09/20/must-see-music-video-country-artist-tim-montana-joined-robert-oneill-navy-seal-shot-osama-bin-laden/ |title=Must-See Music Video: Country Artist Tim Montana is Joined by Robert O'Neill \u2013 the Navy SEAL Who Shot Osama bin Laden |access-date=2017-10-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170929025540/https://www.outdoorhub.com/news/2017/09/20/must-see-music-video-country-artist-tim-montana-joined-robert-oneill-navy-seal-shot-osama-bin-laden/ |archive-date=2017-09-29 |url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nFollowing the release of \"This Beard Came Here to Party,\" Gibbons invited Tim Montana to open for ZZ Top on tour. Tim Montana and the Shrednecks have continued to appear with ZZ Top and opened for [[Kid Rock]] on various tour dates during the summer of 2016.<ref>{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/10-new-country-artists-you-need-to-know-july-2016-20160701/tim-montana-the-shrednecks-20160630 |title=10 New Country Artists You Need to Know: July 2016 |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=July 2016 |access-date=2017-09-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180312080240/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/10-new-country-artists-you-need-to-know-july-2016-20160701/tim-montana-the-shrednecks-20160630 |archive-date=2018-03-12 |url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nOn February 24, 2016, Tim Montana released the album ''Tim Montana and the Shrednecks,'' featuring Gibbons on four tracks.\n\nTim Montana released the single \"Hillbilly Rich\" on September 8, 2017. He released a video for the song on September 19 which features friend Robert J. O'Neill and \"Streetbike\" Tommy Passemante from MTV's Nitro Circus. In their review of the video, ''Rolling Stone'' wrote that its \"aspirational swagger is perfectly on message for Montana's eclectic musical influences\".[15] Actor Charlie Sheen took an interest in the video stating on Twitter \"this is a stone-cold masterpiece! my man is flat out Killin the Game\" to his millions of followers.[16] Shortly after Tim met Charlie in person, Charlie went on to write and direct Tim's music video \"Mostly Stoned\" which created a press storm that ultimately led to Tim signing with Music Knox Records/BBR Music Group which is part of the BMG Rights Management family.<ref>{{Cite magazine |title= Tim Montana Mostly Stoned|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=October 29, 2019 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/tim-montana-mostly-stoned-video-charlie-sheen-905334/}}</ref>\n\nAs a songwriter Montana co-wrote \"Tennessee Mountain Top\" and \"Greatest Show on Earth\" for Kid Rock's 2017 \"Sweet Southern Sugar\" album. \u00a0Both of which went on to chart in the top 40. \u00a0He also co-wrote Travis Tritt's \"Smoke in a Bar\",<ref>{{Cite web |last=Churilla |first=Ken |date=March 4, 2021 |title=Travis Tritt Releases Single \"Smoke in A Bar\"; First New Music in 13 Years |url=https://americansongwriter.com/travis-tritt-releases-single-smoke-in-a-bar-first-new-music-in-13-years/ |access-date=2023-04-28 |website=American Songwriter |language=en-US}}</ref> Billy F Gibbons \"I was a Highway\" and Michael Ray's \"Higher Education\" which featured Montana, Billy F Gibbons, Lee Brice and Kid Rock.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Holthouse |first=Jerry |date=November 3, 2021 |title=Watch: Michael Ray's \"Higher Education\" |url=https://www.nashville.com/watch-michael-rays-higher-education/ |access-date=2023-04-28 |website=Nashville.com |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n== Personal life ==\nMontana is a vocal supporter of U.S. military veterans. After watching the film ''[[American Sniper]]'' (which tells the story of the late U.S. Navy SEAL [[Chris Kyle]]), Montana became involved in the welfare of veterans suffering from [[Posttraumatic stress disorder]]. He approached [[Gibson guitars]] to create a custom Chris Kyle guitar, decorated with Kyle's skull-and-crosshairs logo. The guitar was auctioned off, raising $117,500 for the Guardians of Heroes Foundation, helping wounded U.S. soldiers.<ref>{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/tim-montana-talks-chris-kyle-legacy-american-sniper-guitar-20160601 |title=Tim Montana Talks Chris Kyle Legacy, American Sniper Guitar |magazine=Rolling Stone |access-date=2017-09-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202104329/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/tim-montana-talks-chris-kyle-legacy-american-sniper-guitar-20160601 |archive-date=2017-02-02 |url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nMontana and his wife Danielle are the parents of four children and currently reside in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].\n\n== Discography ==\n=== Studio albums ===\n* ''Iron Horse'' (2008)\n* ''Tim Montana and the Shrednecks'' (2016)\n* ''American Thread'' (2020)\n* ''Reno'' (2022)\n* ''Long Shots'' (2022)\n* ''Savage'' (2024)\n\n=== Singles ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:8em;\"| Title\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! scope=\"col\" colspan=\"3\"| Peak chart positions\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|-\n!style=\"width:4em;font-size:75%\"|[[Hot Hard Rock Songs|US<br>Hard Rock]]<br>\n!style=\"width:4em;font-size:75%\"|[[Mainstream Rock (chart)|US<br>Main.]]<br><ref>Peaks on the Mainstream Rock chart:\n*\"Devil You Know\": {{cite magazine |title=Mainstream Rock Songs: Week of February 10, 2024 |url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/hot-mainstream-rock-tracks/2024-02/10 |magazine=Billboard |access-date=January 6, 2024}}\n*\"Savage\": {{cite magazine |title=Mainstream Rock Songs: Week of September 28, 2024 |url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/hot-mainstream-rock-tracks/2024-09-28|magazine=Billboard |access-date=August 27, 2024}}</ref>\n!style=\"width:4em;font-size:75%\"|[[Hot Rock & Alternative Songs|US<br>Hot<br>Rock<br>&<br>Alt.]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Amarula Sun\" {{small|(with Mac McAnally)}}\n| 2017\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| {{Non-album single}}\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Mostly Stoned\"\n| 2019\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"4\" | ''American Thread''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Hillbilly Rich\"\n| rowspan=\"4\"| 2020\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"American Thread\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Bury Me By the Bonfire\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Quarantine\" {{small|(with Mat Best)}}\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| {{Non-album single}}\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Be A Cowboy\"\n| 2021\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| ''Long Shots''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Devil You Know\"\n| 2023\n| 16\n| 5\n| 12\n| rowspan=\"4\"| ''Savage''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Savage\"\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 2024\n| \u2014\n| 7\n| 19\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Die Today\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Shut Me Out\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|}\n\n=== Music videos ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|+ List of music videos, showing year released and directors\n! scope=\"col\" | Title\n! scope=\"col\" | Year\n! scope=\"col\" | Director(s)\n|-\n| \"Butte, America\"\n| 2008\n| rowspan=\"4\" {{Unknown}}\n|-\n| \"Too Far Gone\"\n| 2012\n|-\n| \"This Beard Came Here to Party\"\n| 2013\n|-\n| \"Glass and Chicken Wire\"\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2017\n|-\n| \"Hillbilly Rich\"\n| Brad Rea\n|-\n| \"American Thread\"\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2019\n| Spidey Smith\n|-\n| \"Mostly Stoned\"\n| Charlie Sheen\n|-\n| \"Bury Me By the Bonfire\"\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2020\n| Michael Monaco\n|-\n| \"Do It Fast\"\n| rowspan=\"7\" {{Unknown}}\n|-\n| \"Be a Cowboy\"\n| 2021\n|-\n| \"American Dream\"\n| 2022\n|-\n| \"Devil You Know\"\n| 2023\n|-\n| \"Savage\"\n| rowspan=\"4\"| 2024\n|-\n| \"Get You Some\"\n|-\n| \"Death Row\"\n|}\n\n== References ==\n{{reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n* [http://www.timmontana.com/ Official Website]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Montana, Tim}}\n[[Category:1985 births]]\n[[Category:American country rock singers]]\n[[Category:American male guitarists]]\n[[Category:American rock guitarists]]\n[[Category:American Southern rock musicians]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Singers from Montana]]\n[[Category:21st-century American male singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American guitarists]]\n[[Category:Butte High School (Butte, Montana) alumni]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Tucker_Beathard","to":"Tucker Beathard"}],"pages":{"50197482":{"pageid":50197482,"ns":0,"title":"Tucker Beathard","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country musician}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2021}}\n{{Use American English|date=July 2016}}\n{{Infobox person\n| name               = Tucker Beathard\n| image              = Tucker Beathard live in concert June 2018.jpg\n| caption            = Beathard performing live in June 2018\n| birth_name         = Tucker Russell Beathard<ref>https://www.facebook.com/tucker.beathard {{User-generated source|certain=yes|date=October 2022}}</ref>\n| birth_date         = {{birth date and age|1995|1|24}}<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2012|publisher=Record Research, Inc|date=2012|page=40|isbn=978-0-89820-203-8}}</ref>\n| birth_place        = [[Franklin, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| occupation         = {{hlist|Singer|musician|songwriter|producer|composer}}\n| years_active       = 2014\u2013present\n| children           = 1<ref>{{cite web | url=https://people.com/parents/tucker-beathard-has-daughter-sage-birthday-tribute-photos/ | title=Country Singer Tucker Beathard Reveals He Has a 2-Year-Old Daughter Named Sage }}</ref>\n| parents          = {{plainlist|\n*[[Casey Beathard]] (father)\n}}\n| relatives = {{plainlist|\n*[[Bobby Beathard]] (grandfather)\n*[[C. J. Beathard]] (brother)\n}}\n| module             = {{Infobox musical artist|embed=yes\n| genre               = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[Country rock]]|[[Alternative rock]]|[[Grunge]]}}<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.redlightmanagement.com/artists/tucker-beathard/ | title=Tucker Beathard \u2022 Red Light Management }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/matthewleimkuehler/2019/01/28/tucker-beathard-nobodys-everything-interview-new-album-label/?sh=51d96946450e | title=Tucker Beathard Goes His Own Way on Debut Album: 'I'm Not Gonna Just Sell Out' | website=[[Forbes]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.npr.org/sections/therecord/2017/11/03/561150174/tucker-beathard-is-more-than-country-musics-latest-punk | title=Tucker Beathard is More Than Country Music's Latest Punk | website=NPR | date=November 3, 2017 | last1=Hight | first1=Jewly }}</ref>\n| instrument          = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar|drums}}\n| label               = {{hlist|[[Dot Records|Dot]]|[[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Nashville]]}}\n}}\n}}\n\n'''Tucker Russell Beathard''' ({{IPAc-en||'|b|\u025b|\u03b8||\u0259|r|d}} {{Respell|BETH|\u0259rd}};<ref>[https://www.mercurynews.com/2017/08/20/49ers-analysis-how-rookie-c-j-beathard-showed-another-glimpse-of-better-days-ahead/ Brown, Daniel. \"49ers Analysis: How rookie C.J. Beathard showed promise of better days ahead,\" ''The Mercury News'' (San Jose, CA), Sunday, August 20, 2017.] Retrieved November 27, 2020</ref> born January 24, 1995) is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. A son of songwriter [[Casey Beathard]], Beathard was signed to [[Dot Records|Dot]] Records, a subsidiary of [[Big Machine Records]] in 2015 where he released his debut single titled \"[[Rock On (Tucker Beathard song)|Rock On]]\" and released an EP titled ''[[Fight Like Hell]]'' in 2016. Since then, Beathard has departed Big Machine, releasing his debut album titled ''[[Nobody's Everything]]'' independently on November 30, 2018, and later signed to [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Music Nashville]] in early 2019.<ref name=\"auto\">{{cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2019/01/tucker-beathard-signs-with-warner-music-nashville/|title=Tucker Beathard Signs With Warner Music Nashville|date=January 15, 2019}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nTucker Beathard was born January 24, 1995, in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref name=\"whitburn\"/> He is the son of country music songwriter, [[Casey Beathard]], brother of [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] quarterback [[C. J. Beathard]] and grandson of [[NFL]] Hall of Famer [[Bobby Beathard]]. As a child, he played [[drum kit|drums]] in a band that also included his brothers,<ref name=\"amg\">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/tucker-beathard-mn0003424305/biography|title=Tucker Beathard biography|last=Monger|first=Timothy|work=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=16 April 2016}}</ref> but later moved to playing guitar instead.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1755687/newcomer-tucker-beathard-has-songwriting-in-his-blood/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150627030746/http://www.cmt.com/news/1755687/newcomer-tucker-beathard-has-songwriting-in-his-blood/|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 27, 2015|title=Newcomer Tucker Beathard Has Songwriting in His Blood|last=Bonaguro|first=Alison|date=June 25, 2015|work=[[Country Music Television]]|access-date=16 April 2016}}</ref> After graduating from [[Battle Ground Academy]] in 2014, he intended to play Division I baseball at [[Middle Tennessee State University]]. After tearing his shoulder, he chose to focus on music instead.<ref name=\"ew\">{{cite magazine|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/02/15/tucker-beathard-rock-on|title=Nashville newcomer Tucker Beathard details new single, 'Rock On'|last=Vain|first=Madison|date=February 15, 2016|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|access-date=16 April 2016}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nHaving grown up around his father award-winning songwriter [[Casey Beathard]], Beathard spent most of his teenage years playing scattered shows with his father. There are YouTube videos that show Tucker performing originals with his dad as early as June 2013 when they played one of Tucker's earliest songs \"Load The Bullets, Cock The Gun.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XEI9ZuFabI4|title=Tucker|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref>\n\nHeavily considering pursuing a career in the music industry Beathard began playing small shows scattered across the southeastern United States in late 2014.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/hear-tucker-beathards-homegrown-five-song-ep-201484/|title=Hear Tucker Beathard's Homegrown Five-Song EP|first1=Joseph|last1=Hudak|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=October 16, 2015}}</ref> In the second half of 2015 things began heating up for Beathard as he released demos of his recordings to YouTube, the tracks \"Ride On\", God and My Guitar and most notably \"Faithful\" sparked attracted fans and eventually allowed him to tour with the likes of [[Maddie and Tae]] and [[Dierks Bentley]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/tucker-beathard-faithful-video/|title=Tucker Beathard Longs for Love in 'Faithful' Video|first=Billy|last=Dukes|website=Taste of Country|date=December 7, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2015/09/tucker-beathard-joins-maddie-tae-tour/|title=Tucker Beathard Joins Maddie & Tae Tour|date=September 24, 2015}}</ref>\nOn September 18, 2015, it was announced Beathard was signed to [[Dot Records|Dot]] Records, a subsidiary of [[Big Machine Records|Big Machine]] Records where he would release an EP titled \"[[The Demos Vol. 1]]\" on October 15, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2015/09/tucker-beathard-lands-dot-records-big-machine-music-deals/|title=Tucker Beathard Lands Dot Records, Big Machine Music Deals|date=September 18, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2015/10/tucker-beathard-releases-demos-to-spotify/|title=Tucker Beathard Releases Demos to Spotify|date=October 16, 2015}}</ref> In January 2016 it was announced Beathard would open for [[Dierks Bentley]] throughout his [[Somewhere on a Beach Tour]] summer tour.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thecountrynote.com/in-the-news/tucker-beathard-wraps-tour-with-dierks-bentley-preps-for-headlining-dates/|title=Tucker Beathard Wraps Tour with Dierks Bentley and Preps For Headlining Dates|first=Press|last=Release|date=September 30, 2016}}</ref> On March 7, 2016, Beathard released his new single titled \"[[Rock On (Tucker Beathard song)|Rock On]]\" the song made its way up the charts all summer, eventually peaking at number 2 on the US Country charts.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/tucker-beathard|title=Tucker Beathard Rock On Chart History|magazine=Billboard}}</ref> \"Rock On\" was the lead single to Beathard's six-song EP \"[[Fight Like Hell]] which was released, October 7, 2016. The EP spawned one more single titled \"Momma and Jesus\" but failed to be a chart success like \"Rock On\" was. The EP's title track \"Fight Like Hell\" gained a cult-like following amongst listeners, leading to multiple fans to start a trend of getting the lyrics \"Fight Like Hell\" tattooed onto their bodies, leading Beathard to do the same.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/tucker-beathard-gets-crazy-in-new-momma-and-jesus-music-video-watch/|title=Watch Tucker Beathard's New 'Momma and Jesus' Music Video|first=Mike|last=Thiel|website=Taste of Country|date=January 30, 2017 }}</ref><ref name=\"auto1\">{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/tucker-beathard-fight-like-hell-ep/|title=Tucker Beathard to Release 'Fight Like Hell' EP|first=Annie|last=Reuter|website=Taste of Country|date=September 6, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mixcloud.com/offtherecordwithchuckwicks/off-the-record-with-tucker-beathard-talking-tattoos-sheep-music-and-more/?play=fb|title=Off The Record with Tucker Beathard!... Talking Tattoo's, Sheep, Music and More!|first=Off the Record with Chuck|last=Wick|website=Mixcloud}}</ref>\n\nIt was announced in December 2016 that Beathard would open up for [[Brantley Gilbert]] and [[Luke Combs]] on Gilbert's 2017 Devil Don't Sleep arena tour.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/tucker-beathard-brantley-gilbert-2017-devil-dont-sleep-tour-pictures/|title=Tucker Beathard Hits Evansville With Brantley Gilbert|first=Cillea|last=Houghton|website=Taste of Country|date=March 7, 2017 }}</ref>\n\nOn November 3, 2017, Beathard announced that his debut album titled \"Dear Someone\" would be released on November 17, 2017, and would contain thirteen tracks. Beathard released the first track titled \"The Boys That Make The Most Noise\", via SoundCloud the night of the announcement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://goncc.com/tucker-beathard-set-to-release-debut-studio-album-dear-someone-november-17/|title=Tucker Beathard Set To Release Debut Studio Album 'Dear Someone' November 17|first=Mariah|last=Crom}}</ref>\n\nOn November 16, 2017, the night before his debut album for Dot Records was supposed to be released Beathard abruptly announced that the album had been postponed citing creative differences with his label Dot Records.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bobbybones.iheart.com/featured/bobby-bones/content/2017-11-17-tucker-beathard-stops-by-talks-delay-of-new-album-performs-for-us/|title=Tucker Beathard Stops By, Talks Delay Of New Album + Performs For Us &#124; Bobby Bones &#124; The Bobby Bones Show|website=Bobby Bones}}</ref>\n\nAfter his debut album was delayed in November 2017, Beathard began leaking demos of his recordings to YouTube so fans could still hear new music from him. The first demo being released in early December 2017 titled \"Chasing You With Whiskey\", this has since become a fan favorite that he gets many requests for at concerts.<ref name=\"auto2\">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7Jb1hDtZr_U|title=chasing you with whiskey|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref>\n\nBeathard was released from his contract with Dot Records after a mutual agreement in January 2018.\n\nOver the course of the continuing months, Beathard was in a legal battle to maintain his songs he wrote and recorded while signed to Dot Records, however over the winter, spring and summer of 2018 Beathard leaked multiple demos of tracks to YouTube so fans could keep up where he was going with his debut record. The demo tracks he leaked were titled \"Goodbye Amy\", \"New Me\", \"I Don't Miss You Now\", \"Perfect Imperfections\", \"Same Kinda Different\", \"This Life\", \"Ride On\", Caught Me On A Good Night\", \"He Was\", \"Kiss Me With A Lie\", \"Hall of Fame\", \"Nobody's Everything\", \"New Used Oldsmobile\", \"She Ain't Right\", \"Over\", \"Nobody's Everything\", \"You Would Think Of Me\", \"The Closest Thing\",\"Time These Days\", \"Your Dreams\", \"It'd Hurt Me More If You Kept Hanging Around\", \"Smokin' Things\" and \"Better Than Me\".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w6MyS-wexs0|title=over|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c6CczJ0X_sc|title=he was (demo)|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Fu8lY7e9qE|title=you would think of me|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4Hn8K6a1Z1Y|title=your dreams (demo)|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wW30HOkXpKw|title=it'd hurt me more if u kept hanging round|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WXBzvHnMQIA|title=kiss me with a lie (demo)|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref>\n\nOn November 26, 2018, it was announced via ''Rolling Stone'' that Beathard had settled the year-long legal battle with former label Dot Records and announced that he would be releasing his debut album independently; the album titled ''Nobody's Everything'' contained nine tracks and was released November 30, 2018. It served as the first part of a two-part album, with part two containing nine more tracks intended to be released in 2019. Beathard got the name ''Nobody's Everything'' from one of the demos he wrote and leaked to YouTube during the summer of 2018.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/tucker-beathard-new-album-nobodys-everything-759768/|title='Rock On' Singer Tucker Beathard Readies Debut Album 'Nobody's Everything'|first1=Joseph|last1=Hudak|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=November 26, 2018}}</ref>\n\n''Nobody's Everything'' spawned the single \"Ride On\", which resulted in Beathard's 2019 Ride On Tour.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/tucker-beathard-2019-ride-on-tour-dates/|title=Tucker Beathard Books 2019 Ride on Tour to Play New Music|first=Annie|last=Reuter|website=Taste of Country|date=January 17, 2019 }}</ref>\n\nOn January 15, 2019, it was announced that Beathard had signed to Warner Music Nashville and would release part two of his debut album through their label.<ref name=\"auto\"/>\n\nOn February 22, 2019, the day Beathard's ride on tour kicked off at Coyote Joes in Charlotte, North Carolina Beathard released the first single to part two of his debut album, the single titled \"Better Than Me\" was released for purchase on February 22, and released to radio May 6, 2019. The second single to part 2 of Beathard's debut album titled \"Find Me Here\" was released digitally to purchase June 3, 2019.<ref>{{cite web|author=Robert Crawford |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/tucker-beathard-better-than-me-new-album-nobodys-everything-798658/ |title=Hear Tucker Beathard's New Song 'Better Than Me' \u2013 Rolling Stone |publisher=Rollingstone.com |date=2019-02-22 |access-date=2019-09-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://countrymusicrocks.net/2019/04/tucker-beathard-releases-better-than-me-to-country-radio.html/|title=Tucker Beathard Releases \"Better Than Me\" To Country Radio|date=April 17, 2019|website=Country Music Rocks}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.entertainment-focus.com/music-section/ef-country/tucker-beathard-shares-honest-new-track-find-me-here/|title=Tucker Beathard shares honest new track Find Me Here|date=June 6, 2019}}</ref>\n\nIn September 2019 Beathard announced he would be headlining the Monster Energy Outbreak Tour in the fall of 2019, wrapping up this year with a tour to support before his new album comes out.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.monsterenergy.com/news/monster-energy-outbreak-tour-tucker-beathard-4874|title=Monster Energy Outbreak Tour: Tucker Beathard|website=Monsterenergy.com}}</ref>\n\nBeathard released his next single \"You Would Think\" on February 21, 2020. The song is allegedly the lead radio single for part 2 of his debut album which is expected later this year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://newcountrysongs.com/tucker-beathard-you-would-think/|title=Tucker Beathard - You Would Think|website=Newcountrysongs.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://americansongwriter.com/tucker-beathard-you-would-think-new-song-brooks-dunn/jim-beviglia/|title=Tucker Beathard Premieres \"You Would Think\" \u00ab American Songwriter|date=February 21, 2020}}</ref>\n\nOn February 22, 2020, while performing at the [[Grand Ole Opry]], Beathard debuted a new song titled \"I Ain't Without You\", about his late brother who had died in December 2019.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KxMrDXok-8o&feature=youtu.be |title=Tucker Beathard - I Ain't Without You - YouTube |website=www.youtube.com |access-date=13 January 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201102122836/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KxMrDXok-8o&feature=youtu.be |archive-date=2 November 2020 |url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nOn August 21, 2020, Beathard released his second studio album ''[[King (Tucker Beathard album)|King]]'', which included previously released singles \"Better Than Me\", \"Find Me Here\", \"Can't Stay Here\", and \"You Would Think\". This album was the second half to the double album concept that Beathard talked about doing after releasing his first studio album, ''Nobody's Everything''.<ref name=\"warnermusicnashville.com\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.warnermusicnashville.com/news/tucker-beathard-finds-his-voice-new-album-king-available-august-21-4326#:~:text=Warner%20Music%20Nashville%20recording%20artist%20and%20%E2%80%9Ca%20singer%2Fsongwriter%20with,to%20pre%2Dorder%20now%20HERE.|title = Tucker Beathard Finds His Voice with New Album ''King'' \u2013 Available August 21 - Warner Music Nashville Official News| date=August 1970 }}</ref>\n\nBeathard released the single titled \"Prayin' for You\" on December 10, 2021.\n\nIn late October 2022 it was announced Beathard would release his new single \"One Of Those\" on November 4, 2022.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.enigmaonline.com/2022/11/04/tucker-beathard-releases-new-track-one-of-those/ | title=Tucker Beathard Releases New Track \"One of Those\" \u2013 Enigma Online | date=November 4, 2022 }}</ref>\n\nIn early 2023 Tucker teased multiple new songs via his official social media pages, sharing acoustic and demo versions of new songs titled \"Good One to End On\", \"I Owe You One\" and \"Good News\". On February 4, 2023, Tucker Beathard announced he will be releasing his next new single \"Who I Am With You\" on February 10, 2023, a song Beathard previously announced and shared a stripped down acoustic version of on January 19, 2021, via his official Instagram and Facebook pages.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.instagram.com/p/CoNNWjJg1LW/ | title=Tucker Beathard on Instagram: \"excited to be putting out a new song. \"who I am with you\" is out next Friday. Pre save it at the link in my bio\" }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://genius.com/Tucker-beathard-who-i-am-with-you-lyrics | title=Tucker Beathard \u2013 Who I Am with You }}</ref>\n\n== Personal life ==\nIn December 2019, a few days before [[Christmas]] Beathard's younger brother Clay Beathard was stabbed and killed alongside his friend Paul Trapeni<ref>{{cite web |date=December 29, 2019 |title=Funerals held for stabbing victims Clay Beathard, Paul Trapeni |url=https://www.wcbi.com/funerals-held-for-stabbing-victims-clay-beathard-paul-trapeni/}}</ref> outside of a bar in [[Nashville]] while protecting a girl who was being assaulted by the assailant Michael Mosley.<ref>{{cite web |date=March 31, 2022 |title=Mosley found guilty in fatal 2019 double stabbing |url=https://www.williamsonherald.com/news/local_news/mosley-found-guilty-in-fatal-2019-double-stabbing/article_9fa27e60-b167-11ec-855b-834aa0be5ae9.html}}</ref> At Clay's funeral, Beathard alongside his brother, [[C. J. Beathard]],<ref>{{cite web |date=December 29, 2019 |title=Watch 49ers QB C.J. Beathard's emotional eulogy at brother's funeral |url=https://www.nbcsports.com/bayarea/49ers/watch-49ers-qb-cj-beathards-emotional-eulogy-brothers-funeral}}</ref> and parents gave their eulogies which was streamed live on local news stations and via social media.<ref>{{cite web |date=December 28, 2019 |title=Funerals held for Nashville stabbing victims Clayton Beathard and Paul Trapeni III |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/49ers-quarterback-brother-funeral-clayton-beathard-brother-of-c-j-beathard-and-paul-trapeni-iii-funeral-services-held/ |website=[[CBS News]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |date=December 28, 2019 |title=Beathard and Trapeni: College students stabbed to death laid to rest |url=https://www.newschannel5.com/news/the-funeral-arrangements-for-the-two-college-students-stabbed-to-death-have-been-made}}</ref>\n\nOn July 13, 2020, in a very personal announcement, Beathard revealed to fans that he had become a father via his social media pages.<ref>{{cite web |date=July 14, 2020 |title=Country singer Tucker Beathard reveals he's a dad: 'The greatest blessing I could possibly ask for' |url=https://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/country-singer-tucker-beathard-reveals-dad |website=[[Fox News]]}}</ref> His daughter, named \"Sage\" was born in July 2018.<ref>{{cite web |date=July 14, 2020 |title=Tucker Beathard Reveals He's a Father, Wishes His Daughter a Happy 2nd Birthday |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/tucker-beathard-daughter//}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[King (Tucker Beathard album)|King]]''\n|\n* Release date: August 21, 2020<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.warnermusicnashville.com/news/tucker-beathard-finds-his-voice-new-album-king-available-august-21-4326#:~:text=Warner%20Music%20Nashville%20recording%20artist%20and%20%E2%80%9Ca%20singer%2Fsongwriter%20with,to%20pre%2Dorder%20now%20HERE.|title=Tucker Beathard fins his voice on new album King|website=[[warnermusicgroup]]|date=August 1970 |access-date=September 30, 2020}}</ref>\n* Label: Mother Tucker, Warner Nashville\n|}\n\n===Extended plays===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Corey_Kent","to":"Corey Kent"}],"pages":{"71437833":{"pageid":71437833,"ns":0,"title":"Corey Kent","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Infobox musical artist\n| background        = person\n| name              = \n| image             = \n| alt               = \n| birth_name        = Corey Kent White\n| alias             = \n| birth_date        = {{Birth date and age|1994|06|21}}\n| birth_place       = [[Bixby, Oklahoma]], U.S.\n| origin            = [[Frisco, Texas]], U.S.\n| genre             = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country music|Country]]\n* [[country rock]]\n}}\n| occupation        = Singer\n| instrument        = {{flatlist|\n* Vocals\n* guitar\n}}\n| years_active      = 2015\u2013present\n| label             = [[RCA Records Nashville|RCA Nashville]]\n}}\n\n'''Corey Kent White''' (born June 21, 1994) is an American [[country music]] singer from [[Frisco, Texas]] signed to [[RCA Records Nashville|RCA Nashville]].\n\n== Biography ==\nCorey Kent White was born in [[Bixby, Oklahoma]]. Kent grew up listening to [[country music]], taking influence from artists such as fellow Oklahoma native [[Garth Brooks]]. Learning the road life early, Kent was just 11 when he joined a touring Western Swing group, traveling the country at the front of a \u201cworking class\u201d band brothers for five years before they finally dissolved.<ref>{{Cite web |title=In Focus: Corey Kent {{!}} Holler |url=https://holler.country/feature/in-focus-corey-kent |access-date=2023-06-23 |website=holler.country |language=en}}</ref> Still in high school and unsure of what came next, he nearly quit entirely \u2013 but after a chance encounter of being pulled out of the audience and joining Willie Nelson on stage, he was inspired to start writing songs, a new path emerged. At age 17, he moved to Tennessee, hit the pavement and scored a publishing deal. And then the bottom dropped out.  He lost his publishing deal, decided to move back to Texas and then epidemic happened<ref>{{Cite web |last=O'Connell |first=Madeleine |date=2023-06-02 |title=Corey Kent's Major Label Debut, 'Blacktop,' Signals A New Sense Of Appreciation For His Life And Career |url=https://countrynow.com/corey-kents-major-label-debut-blacktop-signals-a-new-sense-of-appreciation-for-his-life-and-career/ |access-date=2023-06-23 |website=Country Now |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nAs the world started opening up, Corey began touring in Texas and Oklahoma<ref>{{Cite web |title=Country Star Corey Kent Coming in Concert to Sarasota, has hit, Wild as Her {{!}} 92.1 CTQ |url=https://ctqcountry.iheart.com/featured/maverick-mornings/content/2023-02-17-country-star-corey-kent-coming-in-concert-to-sarasota-has-hit-wild-as-her/ |access-date=2023-06-23 |website=Maverick |language=en}}</ref> playing in night clubs and opening for bands like [[Randy Rogers Band|Randy Rogers]], [[Parker McCollum]], [[Kolby Cooper]] and [[Cody Johnson]]. Corey then emerged on to the ''Billboard'' charts in 2022 with \"[[Wild as Her]]\". Due to popularity on streaming services, the song charted in late 2022. The song is a follow-up to Kent's second studio album, ''21''.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1842984/corey-kent-talks-chart-topping-single-wild-as-her-and-how-willie-nelson-took-a-chance-on-him/ | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220528191617/http://www.cmt.com/news/1842984/corey-kent-talks-chart-topping-single-wild-as-her-and-how-willie-nelson-took-a-chance-on-him/ | url-status=dead | archive-date=May 28, 2022 | title=Corey Kent Talks Chart-Topping Single \"Wild As Her\" And How Willie Nelson Took A Chance On Him | publisher=[[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] | date=March 24, 2022 | accessdate=August 2, 2022}}</ref> Because of this song's initial charting success, ''Billboard'' reported that many Nashville labels were in a [[bidding war]] to sign Kent.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.billboard.com/pro/corey-kent-wild-as-her-label-deal-inside-track/ | title=Inside Track: 'Wild as Her' Singer Corey Kent at Center of Nashville Bidding War | publisher=Billboard | date=April 26, 2022 | accessdate=August 2, 2022 | author=Jessica Nicholson}}</ref> [[RCA Records Nashville]] signed Kent in August 2022 and began promoting \"Wild as Her\" to country radio.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://countrynow.com/corey-kent-reflects-on-life-changing-success-of-wild-as-her-its-pretty-crazy/ | title=Corey Kent Reflects On Life-Changing Success Of 'Wild As Her:' 'It's Pretty Crazy' | publisher=Country Now | date=August 8, 2022 | accessdate=August 16, 2022}}</ref> \"Wild as Her\" amassed over 300 million streams in its first year, reached [https://musicrow.com/2023/05/corey-kent-lands-first-chart-topper-with-wild-as-her/ platinum] status in March 2023 and reached the [https://musicrow.com/2023/05/corey-kent-lands-first-chart-topper-with-wild-as-her/ top spot at Country Radio] in May of the same year.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hollabaugh |first=Lorie |date=2023-05-15 |title=Corey Kent Lands First Chart-Topper With 'Wild As Her' |url=https://musicrow.com/2023/05/corey-kent-lands-first-chart-topper-with-wild-as-her/ |access-date=2023-06-23 |website=MusicRow.com |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nKent's major label debut and third studio album, ''[[Blacktop (album)|Blacktop]]'', was released on June 2, 2023 via RCA Nashville. \"Something's Gonna Kill Me\" was released on July 10, 2023 as the second single.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allaccess.com/country/future-releases | title=Future Releases for Country Radio Stations &#124; New Music Artist Free Song }}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n=== Albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\" border=\"1\"\n|+ List of albums, with selected chart positions, showing other magazine=Billboard |access-date=September 17, 2024}}</ref>\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[To Make You Feel My Love]]\"\n| 2015\n| 44\n|rowspan=\"3\" {{Non-album singles}}\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Why (Jason Aldean song)|Why]]\"\n| rowspan=2|2016\n| 49\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[When I See You Smile]]\"\n| 38\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Now or Never\"<br />{{small|(featuring [[Lauren Alaina]])}}\n| 2024\n| 50\n| ''Black Bandana''\n|}\n\n== Notes ==\n{{notelist-ua}}\n\n== References ==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n{{The Voice (U.S.)}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Kent, Corey}}\n[[Category:American country singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American male singers]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Oklahoma]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:People from Bixby, Oklahoma]]\n[[Category:RCA Records Nashville artists]]\n[[Category:The Voice (franchise) contestants]]\n[[Category:1994 births]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Chris_LeDoux","to":"Chris LeDoux"}],"pages":{"1589105":{"pageid":1589105,"ns":0,"title":"Chris LeDoux","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country singer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2015}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Chris LeDoux\n| image            = Chris LeDoux promo photo.png\n| caption          = LeDoux in May 1999\n| birth_name       = Christopher Lee LeDoux<ref>{{cite web | url=https://repertoire.bmi.com/Search/Catalog?num=Ik7dfDtu1Xp6b%252bdT%252bHRDSQ%253d%253d&cae=EXUbCKDA%252br169YV0FkVmbw%253d%253d&partType=WriterList&search=%7B%22Main_Search_Text%22%3A%22lean%20mean%20and%20hungry%22%2C%22Sub_Search_Text%22%3Anull%2C%22Main_Search%22%3A%22Title%22%2C%22Sub_Search%22%3Anull%2C%22Search_Type%22%3A%22all%22%2C%22View_Count%22%3A100%2C%22Page_Number%22%3A0%2C%22Part_Type%22%3Anull%2C%22Part_Id%22%3Anull%2C%22Part_Id_Sub%22%3Anull%2C%22Part_Name%22%3Anull%2C%22Part_Cae%22%3Anull%2C%22Original_Search%22%3Anull%2C%22DisclaimerViewed%22%3Anull%7D&resetPageNumber=True&partIdSub=YO0HedHMatLb45JzS23DVw%253d%253d | title=Search results for LeDoux, Christopher Lee | publisher=BMI | accessdate=September 13, 2024}}</ref>\n| birth_date       = {{Birth date|1948|10|2}}\n| birth_place      = [[Biloxi, Mississippi]], U.S.\n| origin           = [[Cheyenne, Wyoming]], U.S.\n| death_date       = {{death date and age|2005|3|9|1948|10|2}}\n| death_place      = [[Casper, Wyoming]], U.S.\n| genre            = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[country rock]]|[[Western music (North America)|Western music]]}}\n| occupation       = {{hlist|Musician|singer-songwriter|[[rodeo]] competitor}}\n| instrument       = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar|harmonica}}\n| years_active     = 1971\u20132005\n| label            = {{hlist|[[Liberty Records|Liberty]]|[[Capitol Records|Capitol]]|American Cowboy Songs}}\n| associated_acts  = \n}}\n\n'''Christopher Lee LeDoux''' (October 2, 1948 \u2013 March 9, 2005) was an American [[country music]] singer-songwriter, [[Bronze sculpture|bronze sculptor]], and hall of fame [[rodeo]] champion. During his career, LeDoux recorded 36 albums (many self-released), which have sold more than six million units in the United States as of January 2007. He was awarded two gold and one platinum album certifications from the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA), was nominated for a [[Grammy Award]], and was honored with the [[Academy of Country Music]] Cliffie Stone Pioneer Award. LeDoux is also the only person to participate and also perform at the [[Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo]].\n\n==Biography==\n\n===Early years===\nLeDoux was born in [[Biloxi, Mississippi]], on October 2, 1948. He was of [[French people|French]] descent on his father's side. His father was in the [[US Air Force]] and was stationed at Keesler Air Force Base at the time of his birth. The family moved often when he was a child, due to his father's Air Force career. He learned to ride horses while visiting his grandparents on their [[Wyoming]] farm.<ref name=\"cmt\"/> At age 13, LeDoux participated in his first rodeo, and before long was winning junior rodeo competitions.<ref name=\"huey\">{{cite web |last= Huey |first= Steve |title= Chris LeDoux |publisher= [[Allmusic]] |year= 2005 |url ={{BillboardURLbyName |artist=chris ledoux |bio=true}} |access-date= 2007-03-16}}</ref>\n\nLeDoux continued to compete in rodeo events and played football through his high-school years. When his family moved to [[Cheyenne, Wyoming]], he attended [[Cheyenne Central High School]].  After twice winning the Wyoming State Rodeo Championship bareback riding title during high school, LeDoux earned a rodeo scholarship to [[Casper College]] in [[Casper, Wyoming|Casper]]. During his junior year at [[Eastern New Mexico University]], LeDoux won the Intercollegiate National [[saddle bronc and bareback riding|bareback riding]] championship.<ref name=\"cmt\">{{cite web |title= Chris LeDoux Biography |publisher= [[Country Music Television]] |year= 2005 |url= http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/ledoux_chris/bio.jhtml |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20111107135707/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/ledoux_chris/bio.jhtml |archive-date= November 7, 2011 |access-date= 2007-03-16 |url-status= dead}}</ref>\n\nLeDoux married Peggy Rhoads on January 4, 1972. They had five children: Clay, [[Ned LeDoux|Ned]], Will, Beau, and Cindy.<ref name=\"dillon\">{{cite web |last= Dillon |first= Jenni |title= Cowboy, Singer LeDoux dies in Casper |newspaper=[[Casper Star-Tribune]] |date= March 10, 2005 |url =https://trib.com/news/cowboy-singer-ledoux-dies-in-casper/article_4f7cb8ee-196b-56a0-bb2a-ca2b7355c248.html | access-date= March 16, 2007}}</ref>\n\n===Rodeo success and music beginnings===\nIn 1970, LeDoux became a professional rodeo cowboy on the national circuit.<ref name=\"huey\"/>  To help pay his expenses while traveling the country, he began composing songs describing his lifestyle.<ref name=\"cmt\"/>  Within two years, he had written enough songs to make up an album, and soon established a recording company, American Cowboy Songs, with his father.  After recording his songs in a friend's basement, LeDoux \"began selling his tapes at rodeo events out of the back of his pickup truck\".<ref>{{cite web |title=Chris LeDoux - LeDoux Country - Discography |url=https://www.ledouxcountry.com/discography/ |website=www.ledouxcountry.com |access-date=April 11, 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"huey\"/>\n\nIn 1976, LeDoux won the world bareback riding championship at the [[National Finals Rodeo]] in [[Oklahoma City]].<ref name=\"huey\"/> Winning the championship gave LeDoux more credibility with music audiences, as he now had proof that the cowboy songs he wrote were authentic.<ref name=\"coon\">{{cite web |last= Coon |first= Chuck |title= Chris LeDoux: Missing Chris |publisher= ChrisLedoux.com |year= 2005 |url =http://www.chrisledoux.com/bio3.htm |access-date= 2007-03-16 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070309150925/http://chrisledoux.com/bio3.htm |archive-date= March 9, 2007}}</ref> LeDoux continued competing for the next four years. He retired in 1980.<ref name=\"huey\"/>\n\n===Music career===\nWith his rodeo career at an end, LeDoux and his family settled on a ranch in [[Kaycee, Wyoming]]. LeDoux continued to write and record his songs, and began playing concerts.<ref name=\"huey\"/> His concerts were very popular, and often featured a [[mechanical bull]] (which he rode between songs) and fireworks.<ref name=\"coon\"/> By 1982, he had sold more than 250,000 copies of his albums, with little or no marketing.  By the end of the decade, he had self-released 22 albums.<ref name=\"huey\"/>\n\nDespite offers from various record labels, LeDoux refused to sign a recording contract, instead choosing to retain his independence and control over his work while enjoying his regional following.  In 1989, however, he shot to national prominence when he was mentioned in [[Garth Brooks]]' top-10 country hit \"[[Much Too Young (To Feel This Damn Old)]]\". Capitalizing on the sudden attention, LeDoux signed a contract with [[Capitol Records]] subsidiary Liberty Records and released his first national album, ''[[Western Underground]]'', in 1991. His follow-up album, ''[[Whatcha Gonna Do with a Cowboy]]'', was certified gold and reached the top 10. The [[Whatcha Gonna Do with a Cowboy (song)|title track]], a duet with Brooks, became LeDoux's first and only top-10 country single, reaching number seven in 1992.<ref name=\"huey\"/> In concert, he ended the song by saying, \"Thanks, Garth!\"\n\nFor the 35th annual Grammy Awards in 1992, the single track \"Whatcha Gonna Do with a Cowboy\" was nominated for Best Country Vocal Collaboration.<ref>{{cite web |title=Chris LeDoux |url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/chris-ledoux |website=grammy.com |access-date=24 August 2017 |date=14 May 2017}}</ref> LeDoux and Brooks also received nominations from the [[Academy of Country Music]] for Vocal Duo of the Year and from the TNN/Music City News Country Awards for Vocal Collaboration of the Year.\n\nFor the next decade, LeDoux continued to record for Liberty. He released six additional records, including ''[[One Road Man]]'', which made the country top 40 in 1998.<ref name=\"huey\"/> Toward the end of his career, LeDoux began recording material written by other artists, which he attributed to the challenge of composing new lyrics.<ref name=\"coon\"/> With his 2000 release, ''Cowboy,'' he returned to his roots, re-recording many of his earliest songwriting creations.<ref name=\"huey\"/>\n\nThe RIAA certified two gold and one platinum recordings for LeDoux. On February 22, 1993, the single \"Whatcha Gonna Do with a Cowboy\" went gold. On June 2, 1997, the album ''The Best of Chris LeDoux'' went gold. And on October 5, 2005, the album ''20 Greatest Hits'' went platinum.<ref>{{cite web |title=Gold & Platinum - Chris LeDoux |url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/?tab_active=default-award&se=chris+ledoux#search_section |website=RIAA |publisher=Recording Association of America}}</ref><ref name=\"remaster\" />\n\n===Illness and death===\nIn August 2000, LeDoux was diagnosed with [[primary sclerosing cholangitis]], which required him to receive a [[liver]] transplant. [[Garth Brooks]] volunteered to donate part of his liver, but it was incompatible. An alternative donor was located, and LeDoux received a transplant on October 7, 2000.<ref name=\"gardner\">{{cite web |last= Gardner |first= Tom |title= Chris LeDoux Back After Transplant |publisher= PlanetGarth.Com |date= June 20, 2001 |url =http://www.planetgarth.com/news/article.php?cid=00547 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924073947/http://www.planetgarth.com/news/article.php?cid=00547 |archive-date=September 24, 2015 |access-date= March 16, 2007}}</ref> After his recovery, he released two additional albums. In November 2004, LeDoux was diagnosed with [[cholangiocarcinoma]], for which he underwent radiation treatment until his death.<ref name=\"huey\"/>\n\nLeDoux died of cancer on March 9, 2005, at age 56. His funeral was held on March 11.\n[[File:Chris Ledoux Monument.jpg|thumb|\"Good Ride Cowboy\" Sculpture in Kaycee, Wyoming.]]\n\n==Tributes==\nShortly after his death, LeDoux was named as one of six former rodeo cowboys to be inducted into the [[ProRodeo Hall of Fame]] in [[Colorado Springs, Colorado]], in 2005.  He was the first person to be inducted in two categories, for his bareback riding and in the \"notables\" category \"for his contributions to the sport through his music\".<ref name=\"prorodeo\">{{cite web |title= LeDoux Named to ProRodeo Hall of Fame |publisher= [[Country Music Television]] |date= April 22, 2005 |url= http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1500641/04222005/ledoux_chris.jhtml |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070930035937/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1500641/04222005/ledoux_chris.jhtml |archive-date= September 30, 2007 |access-date= March 16, 2007 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nIn 2004, the [[Academy of Country Music]] awarded LeDoux their Cliffie Stone Pioneer Award during ceremonies.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cliffiestone.com/Cliffie/cliffie_c_awardlist.htm |title=The Cliffie Stone Pioneer Award |website=www.cliffiestone.com |access-date=May 9, 2017}}</ref> In 2005, Garth Brooks accepted the award on behalf of LeDoux's family.<ref name=\"pioneer\">{{cite web |title= Brooks to Accept LeDoux's Pioneer Award |publisher= [[Country Music Television]] |date=April 27, 2005 |url= http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1500885/04272005/ledoux_chris.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930014409/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1500885/04272005/ledoux_chris.jhtml |archive-date=September 30, 2007 |access-date=March 16, 2007 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nIn late 2005, Brooks briefly emerged from retirement to record \"[[Good Ride Cowboy]]\" as a tribute to LeDoux. Brooks remarked:<ref name=\"smith\">{{cite web |last= Smith |first= Hazel |title= A Conversation with Garth Brooks Country Music Television |date= November 1, 2005 |url= http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1512744/11012005/ledoux_chris.jhtml |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070930041246/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1512744/11012005/ledoux_chris.jhtml |archive-date= September 30, 2007 |access-date= March 16, 2007 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n::\"I knew if I ever recorded any kind of tribute to Chris, it would have to be up-tempo, happy ... a song like him ... not some slow, mournful song. He wasn't like that. Chris was exactly as our heroes are supposed to be. He was a man's man. A good friend.\"\n\nGarth Brooks performed the song on the ''39th Annual CMA Awards'' on November 15, 2005, live from Times Square in New York City.  Later that evening, LeDoux was honored with the CMA Chairman's Award of Merit, presented by [[Kix Brooks]] of [[Brooks & Dunn]], to LeDoux's family.\n\nFriends have also collaborated to produce an annual rodeo, art show, and concert in Casper, Wyoming to honor LeDoux's memory. The art show features sculpture and sketches that LeDoux completed for friends; none of his works were ever officially exhibited before his death.<ref name=\"graves\">{{cite web |last= Stoelzle Graves |first= Deirdre |title= Losing, and finding, Chris LeDoux |newspaper=[[Casper Star-Tribune]] |date= October 30, 2006 |url =http://www.casperstartribune.net/articles/2006/10/30/news/casper/64ec836ff5a9d8988725721600211708.txt | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170818045511/http://trib.com/news/local/losing-and-finding-chris-ledoux/article_397d93d8-9897-5f57-947d-3ea686df5df6.html | archive-date=August 18, 2017 | access-date= March 16, 2007}}</ref> However, LeDoux did have two pieces of sculpture that won awards while he was alive; it was more than just a hobby.<ref name=\"Cackett\">{{cite web |title=Chris LeDoux Biography |url=https://alancackett.com/chris-ledoux-biography |website=Alan Cackett |access-date=January 15, 2019}}</ref><ref name=\"NationalCowboy\">{{cite web |title=Chris LeDoux, A True American Cowboy |url=https://nationalcowboymuseum.org/explore/chris-ledoux-a-true-american-cowboy/ |website=National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum |access-date=January 15, 2019}}</ref>\n\nTo mark the second anniversary of LeDoux's death, in April 2007, Capitol Records released six CDs featuring remastered versions of 12 of the albums he recorded between 1974 and 1993.<ref name=\"remaster\">{{cite web |title= Chris LeDoux's Catalog Gems Remastered by Capitol Nashville / EMI |publisher= [[Capitol Records]] |date= January 22, 2007 |url =http://www.chrisledoux.com/news3.htm |access-date= March 16, 2007 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070205113333/http://chrisledoux.com/news3.htm |archive-date= February 5, 2007}}</ref>\n\nArtist and sculptor D. Michael Thomas created a one-and-a-half times life-size sculpture of Chris LeDoux during his 1976 World Championship ride on Stormy Weather. The statue, called \"Good Ride Cowboy\", is on display at the Chris LeDoux Memorial Park in his hometown of Kaycee, Wyoming.<ref name=\"ledouxstatue\">{{cite web |title= Chris LeDoux Immortalized in Bronze |publisher= ChicagoAtHome.Com |date= March 7, 2007 |url= http://www.chicagoathome.com/Detail.aspx?dct=62&id=96097&mid=1797 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120210161350/http://www.chicagoathome.com/Detail.aspx?dct=62&id=96097&mid=1797 |archive-date= February 10, 2012 |access-date= March 16, 2007 |url-status= live }}</ref>\n\nSon Beau LeDoux, himself a rodeo competitor, on July 24, 2007, spread his father's ashes over Frontier Park Arena during the annual [[Cheyenne Frontier Days]] rodeo.<ref>Johnke, Jeremiah. [https://archive.today/20120919191808/http://www.wyomingnews.com/articles/2007/07/25/sports/19sports_07-25-07.txt \"Remembrance: Singer's ashes spread on Frontier Park Arena\"] \u2013 ''[[Wyoming Tribune-Eagle]]'' \u2013 July 25, 2007</ref>\n\nThe city in which LeDoux attended college, Casper, Wyoming, celebrates LeDoux each November with the Chris LeDoux Memorial Rodeo, a weekend event that includes an art show featuring a number of LeDoux's works, a PRCA rodeo, and a country music concert.\n\nIn 2010, Robert Royston created ''One Ride'', a music and dance production that tells the story of the rodeo cowboy.\n\nIn 2010, country singer [[Luke Kaufman]] paid tribute to LeDoux in his song ''Broncin''' from the album ''Cowboy Baller, \"Soakin' up tapes of Chris LeDoux\".''\n\nIn 2011, country music artist Brantley Gilbert paid tribute to LeDoux in his single \"Country Must Be Countrywide\", with the line \"From his Wranglers to his boots \u2013 he reminded me of Chris LeDoux. With that Copenhagen smile, Country must be countrywide.\"<ref>{{cite web |title=Brantley Gilbert |url=http://brantleygilbert.com/ |website=Brantley Gilbert web site |access-date=August 7, 2021}}</ref>\n\nIn 2021, a bronze statue of LeDoux was placed at Cheyenne Frontier Days in Frontier Park in his honor. It is a large statue sculpted by Buffalo sculptor D. Michael Thomas. It is titled ''Just LeDoux It''. It was unveiled at the opening of Frontier Days, during the celebration of its 125th anniversary. The statue displays LeDoux on a bucking bronc, and also depicts a guitar.<ref>{{cite web |title=Wyoming Rodeo Hero Chris LeDoux Celebrated With Statue At Cheyenne Frontier Days |url=https://cowboystatedaily.com/2021/07/16/wyoming-rodeo-hero-chris-ledoux-celebrated-with-statue-at-frontier-park/ |website=Cowboy State Daily |access-date=August 7, 2021 |date=July 16, 2021}}</ref> Fellow musical artist Garth Brooks and Chris's son Ned LeDoux attended the unveiling.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Moore |first1=Bobby |title=Chris LeDoux Statue Unveiled For Cheyenne Frontier Days' 125th Anniversary |url=https://www.wideopencountry.com/chris-ledoux-statue/ |website=Wide Open Country |access-date=7 August 2021 |date=July 27, 2021}}</ref>\n\nSince 2011, the town of Kaycee, Wyoming has hosted Chris LeDoux Days, a festival held along Nolan Avenue featuring a rodeo and live music performances headlined by Chris's son, Ned.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Chris LeDoux Days {{!}} Travel Wyoming |url=https://travelwyoming.com/event/chris-ledoux-days/ |access-date=2024-06-17 |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==Rodeo honors==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Year\n! Honor\n|-\n| 2003\n| [[Cheyenne Frontier Days Old West Museum|Cheyenne Frontier Days and Old West Museum Hall of Fame]]<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.cfdrodeo.com/cfd-old-west-museum/our-story/history/cheyenne-frontier-days-hall-of-fame-inductees/ |title=Cheyenne Frontier Days and Old West Museum Hall of Fame |website=ww.cfdrodeo.com  |access-date=9 May 2017}}</ref>\n|-\n|2005\n|Inducted into the ProRodeo Hall of Fame as Bareback Bronc Rider and Notable<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.prorodeohalloffame.com/inductees/bareback-riding/chris-ledoux/ |title=Chris LeDoux - Pro Rodeo Hall of Fame |work=Pro Rodeo Hall of Fame |access-date=9 May 2017}}</ref>\n|-\n| 2006\n| [[Rodeo Hall of Fame]]<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://nationalcowboymuseum.org/rodeo-hall-of-fame/5320/\n |title=Chris LeDoux|publisher=Rodeo Hall of Fame Inductees |work=National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum |access-date=9 May 2017}}</ref> at the [[National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum]] in [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]]\n|-\n| 2007\n| [[Texas Trail of Fame]] historic [[Fort Worth Stockyards]] in [[Fort Worth, Texas]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://texastrailoffame.org/inductees/chris-ledoux/ |title=Chris LeDoux |date=June 11, 2013 |work=Western Heritage from the [[Texas Trail of Fame]] |access-date=11 May 2017 }}</ref>\n|-\n| 2009\n|Wyoming Sports Hall of Fame<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://archives.collegian.com/2009/02/12/fornstrom_named_to_wyoming_hall_of_fame/ |title=Fornstrom named to Wyoming Hall of Fame \u2013 Collegian Archives |website=archives.collegian.com |access-date=30 May 2017 |archive-date=November 27, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181127064713/http://archives.collegian.com/2009/02/12/fornstrom_named_to_wyoming_hall_of_fame/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n|-\n|2012\n|Cowboy Keeper<ref>{{cite web |title=Cowboy Keeper Hall of Fame |url=http://nationaldayofthecowboy.com/?page_id=83 |website=National Day of the Cowboy |access-date=April 30, 2019 |date=February 11, 2012}}</ref>\n|}\n\n==Rodeo career milestones==\n{| class=wikitable\n|-\n! Year\n! Event\n|-\n| 1964\n| ''[[National Little Britches Rodeo Association]]'' Bareback World Championship\n|-\n| 1967\n| ''Wyoming State High School'' Bareback Bronc Championship\n|-\n| 1969\n| ''[[National Intercollegiate Rodeo Association]]'' Bareback Riding Champion\n|-\n| 1976\n| ''[[Professional Rodeo Cowboys Association]]'' Bareback World Championship\n|-\n|1986\n|Officially retired from rodeo competition\n|}\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Chris LeDoux discography}}\n\n== Awards and nominations ==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n!Year\n!Organization\n!Award\n!Nominee/Work\n!Result\n|-\n|rowspan=2| 1993\n|[[35th Annual Grammy Awards|Grammy Awards]]\n|[[Grammy Award for Best Country Collaboration with Vocals|Best Country Collaboration with Vocals]]\n|\"[[Whatcha Gonna Do with a Cowboy (song)|Whatcha Gonna Do with a Cowboy]]\" <small>with [[Garth Brooks]]</small>\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n|[[Academy of Country Music Awards]]\n|Top Vocal Duo of the Year\n|Chris LeDoux and Garth Brooks\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n|2005\n|Academy of Country Music Awards\n|Cliffie Stone Pioneer Award\n|Chris LeDoux\n|{{won}}\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist|30em}}\n\n==Further reading==\n*Seemann, Charlie.
