Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Billy_Hill_(supergroup)","to":"Billy Hill (supergroup)"}],"pages":{"22900672":{"pageid":22900672,"ns":0,"title":"Billy Hill (supergroup)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"#REDIRECT [[Billy Hill (band)]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Hank_Williams_Jr.","to":"Hank Williams Jr."}],"pages":{"168285":{"pageid":168285,"ns":0,"title":"Hank Williams Jr.","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter and musician (born 1949)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2021}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Hank Williams Jr.\n| image             = Hank212.JPG\n| caption           = Williams in 2008\n| image_upright     = \n| birth_name        = Randall Hank Williams\n| alias             = {{hlist|Bocephus|Rockin' Randall|Wham Bam Sam|Luke the Drifter Jr.|Thunderhead Hawkins}}\n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1949|5|26}}\n| birth_place       = [[Shreveport, Louisiana]], U.S.\n| instrument        = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar|banjo|piano|keyboards|harmonica|fiddle|drums}}\n| genre             = {{Hlist|[[Country rock]]|[[southern rock]]|[[outlaw country]]|[[blues rock]]|[[rock and roll]]}}\n| occupation        = {{hlist|Singer-songwriter|musician}}\n| years_active      = 1963\u2013present\n| label             = {{hlist|[[MGM Records|MGM]]|[[Warner Records|Warner Bros.]]|[[Curb Records|Curb]]|Bocephus|NASH Icon}}\n| spouse            = {{marriage|Gwen Yeargin|1971|1977|reason=divorce}} {{marriage|Becky White|1977|1983|reason=divorce}} {{marriage|Mary Jane Thomas|1990|2022|reason=died}} {{marriage|Brandi Williams|2023}}{{efn|group=brandi|Brandi's last name is currently unknown.}}\n| website           = {{URL|hankjr.com}}\n| module            = {{Infobox person|child=yes\n| children = 5, including [[Hank Williams III]] and [[Holly Williams (musician)|Holly Williams]]\n}}\n}}\n\n'''Randall Hank Williams''' (born May 26, 1949), known professionally as '''Hank Williams Jr.''' or '''Bocephus''', is an American singer-songwriter and musician. His musical style has been described as a blend of [[rock music|rock]], [[blues]], and [[country music|country]]. He is the son of country musician [[Hank Williams]] and the father of musicians [[Holly Williams (musician)|Holly Williams]] and [[Hank Williams III]], and the grandfather of [[Coleman Williams]]. He is also the half brother of [[Jett Williams]].\n\nWilliams began his career following in his famed father's footsteps, covering his father's songs and imitating his father's style. Williams' first television appearance was in a December 1963 episode of ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'', in which at age fourteen he sang several songs associated with his father. Later that year, he was a guest star on ''[[Shindig!]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0929947/?ref_=ttfc_fc_cl_t130|title=Hank Williams, Jr.|publisher=[[IMDb]]|access-date=August 8, 2018}}</ref>\n\nAs Williams struggled to define his own voice and place within the [[country music]] genre, his style began slowly to evolve. His career was interrupted by a near-fatal fall while Williams was climbing [[List of mountains in Beaverhead County, Montana|Ajax Peak in Montana]] on August 8, 1975.<ref name=\"People\">{{cite journal|last=Buchalter|first=Gail|date=October 22, 1979|title=Hank Williams Jr. Fell Down a Mountain and Lived Now He's Climbing High on the C&w Charts|journal=[[People (magazine)|People]]|volume=12|issue=17|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20074883,00.html|access-date=August 3, 2013|archive-date=April 25, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160425141320/http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20074883,00.html|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=\"TheFall\">{{cite web|url=http://countrymusichalloffame.org/the-fall/|title=The Fall|publisher=[[Country Music Hall of Fame]]|access-date=August 3, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101104074223/http://countrymusichalloffame.org/the-fall/|archive-date=November 4, 2010|url-status=dead}}</ref> After an extended recovery, he rebuilt his career in the [[country rock]] scene.<ref name=Burns/> As a multi-instrumentalist, Williams' repertoire of musical instrument skills includes guitar, bass guitar, [[upright bass]], [[steel guitar]], [[banjo]], [[dobro]], piano, keyboards, saxophone, [[harmonica]], [[fiddle]], and drums.<ref name=\"autogenerated1\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hankjr.com/about/?id=2|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716224600/http://www.hankjr.com/about/?id=2|url-status=dead|title=Hank Williams Jr. \u2013 Official Website|archive-date=July 16, 2011|access-date=November 5, 2020}}</ref> In 2020, Williams Jr. was inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|Country Music Hall of Fame]].<ref name=\"Paulson\">{{Cite news|url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2020/08/12/hank-williams-jr-marty-stuart-dean-dillon-country-music-hall-fame/3352839001/|title=Hank Williams Jr., Marty Stuart, Dean Dillon to enter the Country Music Hall of Fame|first=Matthew Leimkuehler and Dave|last=Paulson|newspaper=[[The Tennessean]]|access-date=November 5, 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nWilliams was born Randall Hank Williams on May 26, 1949, in [[Shreveport, Louisiana]]. His [[Hank Williams|father]] nicknamed him Bocephus (after [[Grand Ole Opry]] comedian [[Rod Brasfield]]'s ventriloquist dummy).<ref>{{cite magazine|url =https://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/the-awkward-enduring-influence-of-hank-williams-jr|title =The Awkward, Enduring Influence of Hank Williams, Jr.|magazine =The New Yorker|first =David|last =Cantwell|date =March 24, 2016}}</ref> After his father's death in 1953, he was raised by his mother, [[Audrey Williams]].\n\nWhile he was a child, Williams was influenced by a <!--really? vast--> number of contemporary musicians who visited his family and taught him various musical instruments and styles. {{citation needed|date=June 2020}} Among these figures of influence were [[Merle Haggard]], [[Johnny Cash]], [[Fats Domino]], [[Earl Scruggs]], [[Lightnin' Hopkins]], and [[Jerry Lee Lewis]]. Williams first stepped onto the stage and sang his father's songs when he was eight years old.\n\nHe attended [[John Overton High School]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], where he would bring his guitar to music class and play for pep rallies and performances with the choir.\n\n== Career ==\nIn 1964, Williams made his recording debut with \"[[Long Gone Lonesome Blues]]\", one of his father's many classic songs.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Billboard Book Of Top 40 Country Hits: 1944\u20132006, Second edition |last=Whitburn |first=Joel |year=2004 |publisher=Record Research |page=388 |language=en |isbn=0823082911 }}</ref>\n\nHe provided the singing voice of his father<ref name=\"pc9\">{{Pop Chronicles |9 |4|Hank Williams Jr.}}</ref> in the 1964 film ''[[Your Cheatin' Heart (film)|Your Cheatin' Heart]].''<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0058765/ |title=Your Cheatin' Heart |date=December 1, 1964 |website=IMDb.com}}</ref> He also recorded an album of duets with recordings of his father.<ref name=\"pc9\" />\n\n===A change in appearance and musical direction===\nAlthough Williams' recordings earned him numerous country hits throughout the 1960s and early 1970s with his role as a \"Hank Williams impersonator\", he became disillusioned and severed ties with his mother.\n\nBy the mid-1970s Williams began to pursue a musical direction that would eventually make him a superstar. While recording a series of moderately successful songs, Williams began a pattern of heavy drug and alcohol abuse. Upon moving to [[Alabama]], in an attempt to refocus both his creative energy and his troubled personal life, Williams began playing music with [[Southern rock]] musicians including [[Waylon Jennings]], [[Toy Caldwell]], and [[Charlie Daniels]]. ''[[Hank Williams Jr. and Friends]]'' (1975), often considered his watershed album, was the product of these then-groundbreaking collaborations.\n\nOn August 8, 1975, Williams was nearly killed while mountain climbing in southwestern [[Montana]]. While climbing [[List of mountains in Beaverhead County, Montana|Ajax Peak]] on the [[Continental Divide of the Americas|continental divide]] ([[Idaho]] border) west of [[Jackson, Montana|Jackson]], the snow beneath Williams collapsed and he fell almost {{convert|500|ft}} onto rock, causing multiple severe skull and facial fractures.<ref name=singfll>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8R9OAAAAIBAJ&pg=1923%2C4536621 |work=Spokesman-Review |location=(Spokane, Washington) |agency=Associated Press |title=Singer injured in fall |date=August 11, 1975 |page=1}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2006-01-11-williams-miner-visit_x.htm?POE=LIFISVA | work=USA Today | title=Hank Williams visits W.Va. mine survivor | date=January 11, 2006}}</ref> Williams spent two years recovering, re-learning how to talk and sing, and undergoing 17 surgeries to repair his skull and reconstruct his face. The accident was chronicled in the semi-autobiographical, made-for-television film ''[[Living Proof: The Hank Williams Jr. Story]]''. To hide his scars and disfigurement from the accident, Williams grew a beard and began wearing sunglasses and a [[cowboy hat]]. The beard, hat, and sunglasses have since become Williams' [[trademark look|signature look]].{{citation needed|date=December 2022}}\n\nIn 1977, Williams recorded and released ''One Night Stands'' and ''The New South'', and worked closely with his old friend Waylon Jennings on the song \"Once and For All\".{{citation needed|date=December 2022}} In 1980, he appeared on the [[PBS]] show ''[[Austin City Limits]]'' during Season 5, along with the Shake Russell-[[Dana Cooper]] Band.{{citation needed|date=December 2022}}\n\n===Country music career===\n{{BLP sources section|date=October 2008}}\n[[File:HankWilliamsJrCollage-1000.jpg|thumb|upright=1.45|Williams performing at the Chumash Casino Resort in Santa Ynez, California, 2006]]\n\nIn 1976, ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' wrote that Williams' \"mainstream country material has always been among [[Nashville Tennessee|Nashville]]{{'}}s best\".<ref>{{Cite web| title = Hank Williams Jr.: Hank William Jr. and Friends. By John Morthland : Articles, reviews and interviews from Rock's Backpages.| access-date = June 25, 2018| url = https://www.rocksbackpages.com/Library/Article/hank-williams-jr-ihank-william-jr-and-friendsi|via=[[Rock's Backpages]] |url-access=subscription }}</ref>\n\nHe was prolific throughout the 1980s, sometimes recording and releasing two albums a year. ''[[Family Tradition (album)|Family Tradition]]'', ''[[Whiskey Bent and Hell Bound (album)|Whiskey Bent and Hell Bound]]'', ''[[Habits Old and New]]'', ''[[Rowdy (Hank Williams, Jr. album)|Rowdy]]'', ''[[The Pressure Is On]]'', ''[[High Notes]]'', ''[[Strong Stuff]]'', ''[[Man of Steel (album)|Man of Steel]]'', ''[[Major Moves (album)|Major Moves]]'', ''[[Five-O (album)|Five-O]]'', ''[[Montana Cafe]]'', and many others resulted in a long string of hits.\n\nBetween 1979 and 1992, Williams released 21 albums\u201418 studio albums and three compilations\u2014that were all certified at least [[Music recording certification|gold]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]]. Between 1979 and 1990, he enjoyed a string of 30 Top Ten singles on the Billboard Country charts, including eight No.&nbsp;1 singles, for a total of 44 Top Ten singles, including a total of 10 No.&nbsp;1 singles, during his career.\n\nIn 1982, he had nine albums simultaneously on the Billboard Top Country Albums chart, all of which were original works and not compilations. In 1987\u201388, Williams was named Entertainer of the Year by the [[Country Music Association]]. In 1987, 1988, and 1989, he won the same award from the [[Academy of Country Music]]. The pinnacle album of his acceptance and popularity was ''[[Born to Boogie (album)|Born to Boogie]]''.\n\nDuring the 1980s, Williams Jr. became a country music superstar known for catchy anthems and hard-edged, rock-influenced country. During the late 1970s and into the mid-1980s, Williams' songs constantly flew into the number one or number two spots, with songs such as \"Family Tradition\", \"Whiskey Bent and Hell Bound\", \"Old Habits\", \"Ain't Misbehavin{{'\"}}, \"[[Born to Boogie (song)|Born to Boogie]]\", and \"My Name Is Bocephus\".\n\nThe hit single \"[[Wild Streak]]\" (1987) was co-written by [[Houston]] native [[Terri Sharp]], for which Williams and Sharp both earned gold records. In 1988, he released a Southern pride song, \"[[If the South Woulda Won]]\". The reference is to a notional Southern victory in the [[American Civil War|Civil War]].\n\nHis 1989 hit \"[[There's a Tear in My Beer]]\" was a duet with his father created using electronic merging technology. The song was written by his father, and had been previously recorded with Hank Williams playing the guitar as the sole instrument. The music video for the song combined existing television footage of Hank Williams performing, onto which electronic merging technology impressed the recordings of Williams, which then made it appear as if he were actually playing with his father. The video was both a critical and commercial success. It was named ''Video of the Year'' by both the Country Music Association and the Academy of Country Music. Williams would go on to win a [[Grammy Award]] in 1990 for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Collaboration with Vocals|Best Country Vocal Collaboration]].\n\nHe is well known for his hit \"[[A Country Boy Can Survive]]\" and as the performer of the theme song for ''[[Monday Night Football]]'', based on his 1984 hit \"[[All My Rowdy Friends Are Coming Over Tonight]]\". In 1991, 1992, 1993, and 1994, Williams' opening themes for ''Monday Night Football'' earned him four [[Emmy Award]]s. \n[[File:Hank Williams, Jr. (2006).jpg|thumb|Williams in 2006]]\nIn 2000, he provided the voice of Injun Joe in ''[[Tom Sawyer (2000 film)|Tom Sawyer]]''. In 2001, Williams Jr. co-wrote his classic hit \"A Country Boy Can Survive\" after 9/11, renaming it \"America Can Survive\". In 2004, Williams was featured prominently on ''CMT Outlaws''. In 2006, he starred at the Summerfest concert.\n\nHe has also made a cameo appearance along with [[Larry the Cable Guy]], [[Kid Rock]], and [[Charlie Daniels]] in [[Gretchen Wilson]]'s music video for the song \"[[All Jacked Up (song)|All Jacked Up]]\". He and Kid Rock also appeared in Wilson's \"[[Redneck Woman]]\" video. Hank also had a small part of Kid Rock's video \"Only God Knows Why\", and \"Redneck Paradise\".\n\nIn April 2009, Williams released a new single, \"Red, White & Pink-Slip Blues\", which peaked at number 43 on the country charts. The song was the lead-off single to Williams' album ''[[127 Rose Avenue]]''. The album debuted and peaked at number 7 on the ''Billboard'' Top Country Albums chart. Also in July 2009, ''127 Rose Avenue'' was announced as his last album for Curb Records.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1616664/hank-williams-jr-says-new-album-is-his-last-for-curb-records.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090725202808/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1616664/hank-williams-jr-says-new-album-is-his-last-for-curb-records.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=July 25, 2009|title=Hank Williams Jr. says new album is his last for Curb Records|last=Morris|first=Edward|work=[[Country Music Television]]|date=July 21, 2009|access-date=July 24, 2009}}</ref>\n\n== Musical style ==\nAs a multi-instrumentalist, Williams' repertoire of skills includes guitar, bass guitar, [[upright bass]], [[steel guitar]], [[banjo]], [[Resonator guitar]], piano, keyboards, saxophone, [[harmonica]], [[fiddle]], and drums.<ref name=\"autogenerated1\"/> Williams began his recording career performing covers of his father's songs. Despite catering to the country music market, Williams preferred to listen to [[rhythm and blues]].<ref name=Dukes/> Williams also recorded singles under the name Luke the Drifter Jr.<ref name=Harrington>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1992/12/16/recordings/72741d15-828d-4c87-a3b0-1893e1a975af/ |title=Recordings |last=Harrington |first=Richard |date=December 16, 1992 |newspaper=The Washington Post |access-date=2022-04-22}}</ref> (a reference to his father's alias \"Luke the Drifter\"), [[rock and roll]] singles under the aliases Rockin' Randall<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/hank-williams-jr-mn0000117844/biography |title=Artist Biography |last=Erlewine |first=Stephen Thomas |publisher=AllMusic |access-date=2022-04-22}}</ref> and Bocephus<ref name=Harrington/> (a nickname given to him by his father), and [[blues]] under the name Thunderhead Hawkins.<ref name=Dukes>{{cite web |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/hank-williams-jr-rich-white-honky-blues-album-title-interview/ |title=Hank Williams Jr. Explains 'Rich White Honky Blues' Album Title |last=Dukes |first=Billy |date=June 17, 2022 |publisher=Taste of Country |access-date=2022-09-08}}</ref> Williams' music has been categorized as [[country rock]],<ref name=Burns>{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/kenburns/country-music/hank-williams-jr-biography|title=Hank Williams Jr. Biography |last=Burns|first=Ken |date= |work=PBS |access-date=2023-07-07 |quote=He began the slow rebuilding of his career, this time entirely in the Southern country-rock genre.}}</ref> [[blues rock]],<ref name=Webb>{{cite web |url=https://amp.oklahoman.com/amp/62781299007 |title=Hank Williams Jr. Rocks Norman Crowd |last=Webb |first=Todd |date=December 7, 1984 |publisher=Oklahoman |access-date=2023-07-07 |quote=Williams returned the welcome with an inspired set of country-style rock 'n' roll at its best. [...] a full-speed-ahead set of no-holds-barred rock, blues-rock, and rockabilly rock so intense that Williams himself was forced to partially disrobe near the end of the show. }}</ref> [[southern rock]],<ref name=Malone>{{cite book |editor-last=Malone |editor-first=Bill |date=February 2014 |title=The New Encyclopedia of Southern Culture|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AOynAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA383 |chapter=Williams, Hank Jr. |publisher=University of North Carolina Press |page=383 |isbn=978-1469616667}}</ref> [[outlaw country]],<ref name=Erlewine>{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/hank-williams-jr-mn0000117844/biography |title= Hank Williams, Jr. Biography |last=Erlewine|first=Stephen Thomas |work=AllMusic |access-date=2023-07-07}}</ref> [[rockabilly]]<ref name=Webb/> and [[rock and roll]].<ref name=Webb/>\n\n== Legacy ==\nArtists who have cited Hank Williams Jr. as an influence include Delta Generators,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://amp.telegram.com/amp/63214191007 |title=Country and blues on stage this Friday |last=Banner |first=Sandy Meindersma |date=July 31, 2008 |publisher=Telegram & Gazette |access-date=2022-04-22}}</ref> [[Walker Hayes]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/walker-hayes-hank-williams-jr-song-influence-interview/ |title=WALKER HAYES ON HIS LOVE OF HANK JR., DON WILLIAMS |last=Paul |first=Evan |date=January 27, 2022 |publisher=Taste of Country |access-date= |quote=}}</ref> [[Sam Hunt]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/country-radio-seminar-closes-with-sam-hunt-frankie-ballard-6487466/ |title=Country Radio Seminar Closes With Stellar Performances by Sam Hunt, Cole Swindell & More |last=Dauphin |first=Chuck |date=February 28, 2015 |website= |publisher=Billboard |access-date=2022-04-22}}</ref> Davin James,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/davin-james-mn0000230651/biography |title=Artist Biography |last=Hage |first=Erik |publisher=AllMusic |access-date=2022-04-22 }}</ref> [[Shooter Jennings]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/shooter-jennings-premieres-drunk-talks-hank-williams-jr-influence-8468362/ |title=Shooter Jennings Premieres 'D.R.U.N.K.,' Talks Hank Williams Jr. Influence |last=Dauphin |first=Chuck |date=August 3, 2018 |publisher=Billboard |access-date=2022-04-20}}</ref> [[Wayne Mills (singer)|Wayne Mills]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/2013/12/17/country-singer-killed/4049361/ |title=Bar owner charged in singer's death released from jail |last=Gonzalez |first=Tony |date=December 17, 2013 |publisher=USA Today |access-date= |quote=}}</ref> The Sickstring Outlaws<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2019/aug/01/live-five-electric-hoedown-hillbillies-steroids/ |title=Electric hoedown with hillbillies on steroids |last=Sanford |first=Jay Allen |date=August 1, 2019 |publisher=San Diego Reader |access-date=2022-04-22}}</ref> and [[Gretchen Wilson]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://gazettereview.com/gretchen-wilson-doing-now-update/ |title=What Happened To Gretchen Wilson \u2013 What's She Doing Now in 2022 |last=Rogers |first=Bridget |date=March 28, 2022 |publisher=Gazette Review |access-date=2022-04-22}}</ref>\n\nOn April 10, 2006, [[Country Music Television|CMT]] honored Williams with the [[Johnny Cash]] Visionary Award, presenting it to him at the 2006 [[CMT Music Awards]]. On November 11, 2008, Williams was honored as a [[Broadcast Music Incorporated|BMI]] Icon at the 56th annual BMI Country Awards. The artists and songwriters named BMI Icons have had \"a unique and indelible influence on generations of music makers\".<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.bmi.com/news/entry/537255 |title=Hank Williams, Jr. to be Honored as Icon at 56th Annual BMI Country Awards|website=Bmi.com|access-date=October 5, 2010|date=September 17, 2008}}</ref>\n\nIn 2015, Williams was inducted into the Louisiana Music Hall of Fame. On August 12, 2020, Williams was selected to be inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|Country Music Hall of Fame]].<ref name=\"Paulson\"/>\n\n==Personal life==\nHis daughter Katherine Williams-Dunning, the only one of his five children to not pursue a music career, died in a car crash on June 13, 2020, at age 27.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/hank-williams-jr-daughter-katherine-williams-dunning-killed-in-car-accident-tennessee/|title=Daughter of country music legend Hank Williams Jr. dies in car crash, authorities say|website=Cbsnews.com|date=June 14, 2020 |access-date=November 5, 2020}}</ref> His son Shelton performs as [[Hank Williams III]]; his other children include [[Holly Williams (musician)|Holly Williams]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.al.com/life/2021/06/hank-jrs-son-following-in-footsteps-of-legendary-grandpa-hank-williams.html |title=Hank Jr.'s son following in footsteps of legendary grandpa Hank Williams? |last=Colurso |first=Mary |website=al.com |date=June 8, 2021 |access-date=July 23, 2021 }}</ref> who is also a musician, as is his grandson [[Coleman Williams]] (Hank III's son), who performs under the sobriquet \"IV\".<ref name=hank3sonIV>{{cite web |last1=Trigger |title=The Hank Williams Lineage Continues with Hank3's Son \"IV\" |url=https://www.savingcountrymusic.com/the-hank-williams-linage-continues-with-hank3s-son-iv/ |website=Saving Country Music|date=March 7, 2021 }}</ref>  His wife Mary Jane Thomas died on March 22, 2022, aged 58, after complications from a medical procedure.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Avila |first1=Daniela |date=March 23, 2022 |first2=Sarah |last2=Michaud |title=Hank Williams Jr.'s Wife Mary Jane Thomas Has Died: 'A Beautiful Soul' |url=https://people.com/country/hank-williams-jr-wife-mary-jane-dead/ |access-date=2022-03-24 |website=PEOPLE.com |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Hank Williams Jr.'s Wife Mary Jane Thomas Dead at 58 |url=https://www.tmz.com/2022/03/23/hank-williams-jr-wife-dead-dies-mary-jane-thomas/ |access-date=2022-03-24 |website=TMZ|date=March 23, 2022 }}</ref> On September 9, 2023, Williams married his long-time friend since 2003, Brandi. The couple became engaged on Mother's Day of that same year.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Denis |first=Kyle |date=September 12, 2023 |title=Hank Williams Jr. Gets Married in Alabama |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/hank-williams-jr-wedding-married-brandi-1235411287/ |access-date=September 19, 2024 |work=Billboard}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Wilson |first=Angela |date=September 12, 2023 |title=Hank Williams Jr. Marries Fianc\u00e9e Brandi in Alabama Days After Announcing Engagement |url=https://people.com/hank-williams-jr-marries-brandi-in-front-of-a-small-group-of-family-and-friends-in-alabama-7968399 |access-date=September 19, 2024 |work=People}}</ref>\n\n==Politics==\nWilliams has been politically involved with the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]. For the [[2000 U.S. Presidential election|2000 U.S. presidential election]], he rerecorded his song \"We Are Young Country\" to \"This is Bush-Cheney Country\". On October 15, 2008, at a rally in [[Virginia Beach, Virginia|Virginia Beach]] for Republican presidential nominee [[John McCain]], he performed \"McCain-Palin Tradition\", a song in support of McCain and his running mate, [[Sarah Palin]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://marcambinder.theatlantic.com/archives/2008/10/the_mccainpalin_tradition.php|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206023625/http://marcambinder.theatlantic.com/archives/2008/10/the_mccainpalin_tradition.php|url-status=dead|title=\"McCain\u2013Palin Tradition\"|archive-date=February 6, 2009|access-date=November 5, 2020}}</ref> He has contributed to federal election campaigns, mostly to Republicans, including [[Michele Bachmann]]'s 2012 presidential campaign. However, he has donated to some Democrats in the past, most notably [[Jim Cooper]] and [[John S. Tanner]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsmeat.com/celebrity_political_donations/Hank_Williams_Jr.php|title=Hank Williams Jr.|publisher=Federal Campaign Contribution Report|access-date=November 27, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921054027/http://www.newsmeat.com/celebrity_political_donations/Hank_Williams_Jr.php|archive-date=September 21, 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nIn November 2008, Williams considered a run for the 2012 Republican nomination as a [[U.S. Senator]] from Tennessee for the seat held by GOP incumbent [[Bob Corker]], although his publicist said regarding Williams \"no announcement has been made\".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://realclearpolitics.blogs.time.com/2008/11/25/hank-williams-jr-for-senate |title=Hank Williams Jr. For Senate? - Real Clear Politics \u2013 TIME.com |publisher=Realclearpolitics.blogs.time.com |date=November 25, 2008 |access-date=November 27, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120128170506/http://realclearpolitics.blogs.time.com/2008/11/25/hank-williams-jr-for-senate/|archive-date=January 28, 2012 }}</ref> Williams ultimately did not run.\n\n===2011 ''Fox and Friends'' controversy===\nIn an October 3, 2011, interview with [[Fox News Channel]]'s ''[[Fox & Friends]]'', Williams discussed a June golf game where President [[Barack Obama]] and Republican House Speaker [[John Boehner]] had teamed against Vice President [[Joe Biden]] and Ohio Governor [[John Kasich]], saying the match was \"one of the biggest political mistakes ever\". When asked why the golf game troubled him, Williams stated, \"Come on. That'd be like Hitler playing golf with [[Benjamin Netanyahu|Netanyahu]]&nbsp;... in the shape this country is in?\" He also said that the President and Vice President were \"the enemy\" and compared them to \"the [[Three Stooges]]\". Later, anchor [[Gretchen Carlson]] said to him, \"You used the name of one of the most hated people in all of the world to describe, ''I think'', the president.\" Williams replied, \"Well, that is true. But I'm telling you like it is.\" As a result of his statements, [[ESPN]] dropped Williams' opening song from its ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' broadcast of the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] versus the [[Indianapolis Colts]] and replaced it with the [[The Star-Spangled Banner|national anthem]].{{citation needed|date=June 2020}}\n\nWilliams later said his analogy was \"extreme \u2013 but it was to make a point\", and \"some of us have strong opinions and are often misunderstood&nbsp;... I was simply trying to explain how stupid it seemed to me \u2013 how ludicrous that pairing was. They're polar opposites, and it made no sense. They don't see eye to eye and never will\". Additionally, Williams said he has \"always respected the office of the president ... Working-class people are hurting \u2013 and it doesn't seem like anybody cares. When both sides are high-fiving it on the ninth hole when everybody else is without a job \u2013 it makes a whole lot of us angry. Something has to change. The policies have to change\". ESPN later said it was \"extremely disappointed\" in Williams' comments, and pulled his opening from that night's broadcast.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2011/football/nfl/10/03/espn.williams.ap/index.html |title=ESPN pulls Hank Williams Jr. intro after singer links Obama with Hitler |publisher=Sportsillustrated.cnn.com |date=October 3, 2011 |access-date=November 27, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111113134647/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2011/football/nfl/10/03/espn.williams.ap/index.html |archive-date=November 13, 2011}}</ref>\n\nThree days later, ESPN announced Williams and his song would not return to ''Monday Night Football'', ending the use of the song that had been part of the broadcast on both ABC and ESPN since 1989.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/7066449/espn-hank-williams-jr-theme-song-return-monday-night-football|title=ESPN, Hank Williams Jr. part ways|date=October 6, 2010|work=ESPN.com}}</ref> Williams expressed defiance and indifference on his website, and said he was the one who had made the decision. \"After reading hundreds of e-mails, I have made MY decision,\" he wrote. \"By pulling my opening Oct 3rd, You (ESPN) stepped on the Toes of The First Amendment Freedom of Speech, so therefore Me, My Song, and All My Rowdy Friends are OUT OF HERE. It's been a great run.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/7066449/espn-hank-williams-jr-theme-song-return-monday-night-football |title=ESPN \u2013 Hank Williams Jr. theme song won't return to Monday Night Football \u2013 ESPN |publisher=ESPN |date=October 6, 2011 |access-date=November 27, 2011}}</ref> Williams' son, [[Hank Williams III]], stayed neutral in the debate, telling [[TMZ.com]] that most musicians, including his father, are \"not worthy\" of a political discussion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tmz.com/2011/10/04/hank-williams-jr-monday-night-football-son-politics-obama-hitler-fox-news-channel-jello-biafra-green-party-politics/ |title=Hank Williams Jr.'s Son \u2013 My Dad Should NOT Talk Politics |publisher=TMZ.com |date=November 22, 2011 |access-date=November 27, 2011}}</ref>\n\nAfter his song was pulled from ''Monday Night Football,'' Williams recorded a song criticizing Obama, ESPN and ''[[Fox & Friends]]'', titled \"[[Keep the Change (Hank Williams Jr. song)|Keep the Change]]\". He released the track on [[iTunes]] and via free download at his website.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/gameon/post/2011/10/hank-williams-jr-retaliates-with-song-that-slams-fox/1|title=Hank Williams Jr. retaliates with song that slams Fox|first=Tom|last=Weir|date=October 10, 2011|work=[[USA Today]]}}</ref> The song garnered over 180,000 downloads in two days.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1672429/hank-williams-jr-thrives-with-downloads-media-coverage-surrounding-controversy.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111014104416/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1672429/hank-williams-jr-thrives-with-downloads-media-coverage-surrounding-controversy.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 14, 2011|title=Hank Williams Jr. Thrives With Downloads, Media Coverage Surrounding Controversy|date=October 12, 2011|publisher=[[CMT News]]}}</ref>\n\nWilliams continued to make his opinions of Obama known and during a performance at the Iowa State Fair in August 2012, [[Barack Obama religion conspiracy theories|he called Obama a Muslim]] telling the crowd, \"We've got a Muslim president who hates farming, hates the military, hates the U.S. and we hate him!\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/OTUS/hank-williams-jr-tells-crowd-obama-muslim-hates/story?id=17042110|title=Country Star Calls Obama 'a Muslim'|date=August 20, 2012|publisher=ABC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Couch |first=Aaron |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/general-news/hank-williams-jr-songs-barack-obama-363946/ |title=Hank Williams Jr. Calls Obama 'Muslim' Who 'Hates The Military'|work=[[Hollywood Reporter]] |date=August 18, 2012 |access-date=July 5, 2023 |archive-date=July 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20230705214720/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/general-news/hank-williams-jr-songs-barack-obama-363946/}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Hank Williams Jr. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Ted_Russell_Kamp","to":"Ted Russell Kamp"}],"pages":{"27386414":{"pageid":27386414,"ns":0,"title":"Ted Russell Kamp","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| honorific_prefix =\n| name             = Ted Russell Kamp\n| honorific_suffix =\n| image            =\n| image_upright    =\n| image_size       =\n| landscape        = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank -->\n| alt              =\n| caption          =\n| native_name      =\n| native_name_lang =\n| birth_name       =\n| alias            =\n| birth_date       = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living people supply only the year unless the exact date is already WIDELY published, as per [[WP:DOB]] -->\n| birth_place      =\n| origin           =\n| death_date       = <!-- {{death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date 1st) -->\n| death_place      =\n| genre            = {{Hlist|[[Country rock]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.popmatters.com/142554-ted-russell-kamp-get-back-to-the-land-2496007914.html |title=TED RUSSELL KAMP: GET BACK TO THE LAND |last=Haag |first=Stephen |date=July 18, 2011 |publisher=PopMatters |access-date=2023-01-12 |quote=Don't let Ted Russell Kamp's Zappa-esque cookie duster fool you \u2014 he's no avant-garde prankster. Rather, he's an earnest country-rock/rockin\u2019-country singer-songwriter }}</ref>}}\n| occupation       = Composer<br />Arranger<br />Producer<br />Performer\n| instrument       = Guitar<br />Bass<br />Mandolin<br />Lap Steel Guitar<br />Keyboards\n| years_active     = 1995\u2013present\n| label            = PoMo<br />Kufala<br />[[Dualtone Records|Dualtone]]\n| associated_acts  = [[Shooter Jennings]]\n| website          = {{URL|tedrussellkamp.com}}\n| module           =\n| module2          =\n| module3          = \n}}\n\n'''Ted Russell Kamp''' is an American singer-songwriter. He is the bassist for [[Shooter Jennings]]' backing band. As a solo artist, Kamp has released 11 albums.\n\n==Biography==\nBorn in New York, Kamp grew up in the Northeast U.S. before moving to Seattle where he began his music career. He fronted a trio, Ponticello, which released four albums. During this time, Kamp released his first solo album, ''Dedications'' (1996). Kamp moved to Los Angeles in 2001 and started a new group, Union Pacific. He performed with other bands and worked as a session musician before being hired as the bassist for Shooter Jennings' band, the .357s.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ruhlmann|first=William|title=Artist Biography |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/ted-russell-kamp-mn0000053934/biography|website=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=May 30, 2017}}</ref>\n\nKamp also continued his solo career, with his album Divisadero<ref>{{cite web|title=Album Review: Ted Russell Kamp - Divisadero|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/divisadero-mw0000565354 |website=Allmusic|accessdate=May 30, 2017}}</ref><ref>\n{{cite journal | date=March\u2013April 2007| title=Album Review: Ted Russell Kamp - Divisadero | last = Berick | first = Michael | journal=[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]| volume=1| issue=68 | url=http://nodepression.com/album-review/ted-russell-kamp-divisadero| issn=1088-4971| accessdate=May 30, 2017}}</ref> ranked as #34 on the [[Americana Music Association]]'s 2007 chart.\n\nIn 2011, Kamp released Get Back to the Land,<ref>{{cite web|title=Album Review: Ted Russell Kamp - Get Back to the Land|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/get-back-to-the-land-mw0002092965 |website=Allmusic|accessdate=May 30, 2017}}</ref> which made the top 25 on the Americana Radio Chart and was #1 on the Euro Americana Chart.\n\nIn January 2013, Kamp released Night Owl,<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Music: Ted Russell Kamp - Night Owl|url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/170077-ted-russell-kamp-night-owl/ |magazine=[[PopMatters]]|accessdate=May 30, 2017}}</ref> which made the US Americana Radio Chart (#34) and the Euro Americana Chart (#15).\n\nKamp self-released ''The Low and Lonesome Sound'' in 2015, followed a year later by the acoustic album ''Flying Solo''.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Music: Ted Russell Kamp - The Low and Lonesome Sound|url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/ted-russell-kamp-the-low-and-lonesome-sound/ |magazine=PopMatters|accessdate=May 30, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Bassist Ted Russell Kamp, Flying Solo...|date=8 April 2016 |url=http://bassmusicianmagazine.com/2016/04/flying-solo-featuring-bassist-ted-russell-kamp/ |publisher=[[Bass Musician]]|accessdate=May 30, 2017}}</ref> He joined Ted Wulfers to record the classic song Tulsa Time to help support the Red Cross of Oklahoma. 100% of the proceeds were donated to The Oklahoma Red Cross.\n\nKamp is also an established producer in the music industry.\n\n==Discography==\n===Solo albums===\n* 1996: ''Dedications'' (Poetry Of The Moment [PoMo])\n* 2005: ''Northsouth'' (PoMo)\n* 2005: ''The Ponticello Years'' (Kufala)\n* 2006: ''Nashville Fineline'' (Kufala)\n* 2007: ''Divisadero'' (PoMo)\n* 2008: ''Poor Man's Paradise'' ([[Dualtone Records|Dualtone]] / PoMo)\n* 2010: ''California Country Soul, Vol. 2 : Ballads'' (PoMo)\n* 2011: ''Get Back To The Land'' ([[Dualtone Records|Dualtone]] / PoMo)\n* 2013: ''Night Owl'' (PoMo)\n* 2015: ''The Low and Lonesome Sound'' (self-released via [[CD Baby]])\n* 2016: ''Flying Solo'' [Audio & Video Labs, Inc.)\n* 2019: ''Walkin' Shoes'' (PoMo Records)\n\n===With [[Shooter Jennings]]===\n* 2005: ''[[Put the \"O\" Back in Country]]'' ([[Show Dog-Universal Music|Universal South]])\n* 2006: ''[[Electric Rodeo (Shooter Jennings album)|Electric Rodeo]]'' ([[Show Dog-Universal Music|Universal South]])\n* 2006: ''[[Live at Irving Plaza 4.18.06]]'' ([[Show Dog-Universal Music|Universal South]])\n* 2014: ''Don't Wait Up (For George)'' EP ([[Black Country Rock Media|Black Country Rock]])\n* 2016: ''[[Black Ribbons]]'' ([[Black Country Rock Media|Black Country Rock]])\n* 2016: ''[[Countach (For Giorgio)]]'' ([[Black Country Rock Media|Black Country Rock]])\n\n===As primary artist/song contributor===\n* 2009: various artists - ''A Bob Dylan Tribute: So Happy Just To See You Smile'' (Hanky Panky) - track 15, \"Dignity\"\n* 2010: various artists - ''I Like It Better Here - More Music From Home'' (Hemifr\u00e5n) - track 14, \"You Are My Home\"\n\n===As guest musician===\n* 2007: [[Gina Villalobos]] - ''Miles Away'' (Face West)\n* 2008: [[Waylon Jennings]] and the 357's - ''[[Waylon Forever]]'' ([[Vagrant Records|Vagrant]])\n* 2010: Shy Blakeman - ''Long Distance Man'' (Winding Road)\n* 2014: Calico the Band - ''Rancho California'' (California Country)\n* 2014: Creekwood - '2000 Miles West''\n* 2015: Alice Wallace - ''Memories Music & Pride'' (California Country)\n* 2015: Sam Morrow - ''There is No Map'' (Forty Below / Relativity)\n* 2016: [[Ry Bradley]] - ''You Me and the Music'' (self-released)\n* 2018: Dale Justice - ''Trouble Man'' (Hillbilly Highway)\n* 2021: Chris Armes - ''Ocotillo Rose'' (Yucca Thunder){{ }}\n* 2023: [[Diplo]], [[Sturgill Simpson]], and [[Dove Cameron]] ''Use Me (Brutal Hearts loop)''\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.tedrussellkamp.com/ Official Website]\n* {{AllMusic | id= ted-russell-kamp-mn0000053934 | label= Ted Russell Kamp}}\n* {{discogs artist|696115-Ted-Russell-Kamp|Ted Russell Kamp}}\n* [http://nodepression.com/album-review/ted-russell-kamp-divisadero Ted Russell Kamp - Divisadero Review] in ''[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]''\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Kamp, Ted Russell}}\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:American country rock singers]]\n[[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes.
