This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jason_Aldean","to":"Jason Aldean"}],"pages":{"2428577":{"pageid":2428577,"ns":0,"title":"Jason Aldean","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country singer (born 1977)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2023}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Jason Aldean\n| image             = Jason Aldean 2022 (cropped).jpg\n| caption           = Aldean in 2022\n| background        = solo_singer\n| birth_name        = Jason Aldine Williams\n| birth_date        = {{Birth date and age|1977|2|28}}\n| birth_place       = [[Macon, Georgia]], U.S.\n| origin            = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| instrument        = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar|piano}}\n| genre             = <!-- Do not add or remove genres without discussing on talk page first. -->{{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[country rock]]|{{nowrap|[[bro-country]]}}<ref name=\"vulture\">{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2013/08/rise-of-bro-country-florida-georgia-line.html|title=Jody Rosen on the Rise of Bro-Country|last=Rosen|first=Jody|date=August 11, 2013|work=Vulture.com|access-date=April 24, 2014}}</ref>}}\n| occupation        = {{flatlist| \n*Singer\n*musician\n<!-- not a songwriter -->\n}}\n| years_active      = 1998\u2013present\n| label             = [[BBR Music Group|Broken Bow]]\n| website           = {{URL|jasonaldean.com}}\n| spouse            = {{plainlist|\n* {{marriage|Jessica Ann Ussery|2001|2013|end=divorced}}\n* {{marriage|Brittany Kerr|2015}}\n}}\n}}\n\n'''Jason Aldine Williams''' (born February 28, 1977),<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc.|year=2008|page=21|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref> known professionally as '''Jason Aldean''', is an American [[country music]] singer. Since 2005, he has been signed to [[BBR Music Group|Broken Bow Records]], a record label for which he has released eleven albums and 40 singles. His 2010 album, ''[[My Kinda Party]]'', is certified quadruple-platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA). His 2012 album ''[[Night Train (Jason Aldean album)|Night Train]]'' is certified double-platinum, while his 2005 [[Jason Aldean (album)|self-titled]] debut, 2007 album ''[[Relentless (Jason Aldean album)|Relentless]]'', 2009 album ''[[Wide Open (Jason Aldean album)|Wide Open]]'', and 2014 album ''[[Old Boots, New Dirt]]'' are all certified platinum. Aldean has received five [[Grammy Award]] nominations throughout his career, twice for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]].\n\n27 of Aldean's 38 singles have reached #1 on either the [[Hot Country Songs]] or [[Country Airplay]] charts with \"[[Why (Jason Aldean song)|Why]]\", \"[[She's Country]]\", \"[[Big Green Tractor]]\", \"[[The Truth (Trent Willmon song)|The Truth]]\", \"[[Don't You Wanna Stay]]\" (a duet with [[Kelly Clarkson]]), \"[[Dirt Road Anthem]]\", \"[[Fly Over States]]\", \"[[Take a Little Ride]]\", \"[[The Only Way I Know]]\" (a collaboration with [[Luke Bryan]] and [[Eric Church]]), \"[[Night Train (Jason Aldean song)|Night Train]]\", \"[[When She Says Baby]]\", \"[[Burnin' It Down]]\", \"[[Just Gettin' Started]]\", \"[[Tonight Looks Good on You]]\", \"[[Lights Come On]]\", \"[[A Little More Summertime]]\", \"[[Any Ol' Barstool]]\", \"[[You Make It Easy]]\", \"[[Drowns the Whiskey]]\" (a duet with [[Miranda Lambert]]), \"[[Girl Like You (Jason Aldean song)|Girl Like You]]\", \"[[Rearview Town (song)|Rearview Town]]\", \"[[Got What I Got]]\", \"[[Blame It on You (Jason Aldean song)|Blame It on You]]\", \"[[If I Didn't Love You (Jason Aldean and Carrie Underwood song)|If I Didn't Love You]]\" (a duet with [[Carrie Underwood]]), and \"[[Trouble with a Heartbreak]]\". In 2023, he released \"[[Try That in a Small Town]]\", which was the subject of widespread media attention following the release of its music video, whilst becoming Aldean's first number-one hit on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].\n\n==Early life==\nJason Aldine Williams was born in [[Macon, Georgia]],<ref name=\"whitburn\" /><ref name=\"allmusic\" /> on February 28, 1977. His parents separated when he was three. He was raised by his mother in Macon, and during the summer he spent time with his father in [[Homestead, Florida]]. He attended [[Windsor Academy]], a private Christian school in [[Bibb County, Georgia]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Jason Aldean |url=https://waknights.com/our_team/jason-aldean/ |access-date=July 26, 2023 |website=Windsor Academy Knights}}</ref> Before his father went to his work, Aldean would map out guitar chords on notebook paper to show his son where to place his fingers to play the chords and Jason would sit and practice all day while his father was at work. When his father got home, he got out his own guitar and they played together. Soon he could play a song after hearing it only a few times. His early favorites included [[George Strait]]'s \"[[The Cowboy Rides Away (song)|The Cowboy Rides Away]]\", [[Hank Williams Jr.]]'s \"The Blues Man\", and [[Alabama (American band)|Alabama]]'s \"[[My Home's in Alabama (song)|My Home's in Alabama]]\".\n\nBoth of his parents encouraged young Aldean as he progressed musically. From age 14, after watching the country-music awards on television, he wanted to perform on stage. With his mother's help, he performed at the local VFW hall in Macon. He sang [[John Anderson (musician)|John Anderson]]'s song \"[[Seminole Wind (song)|Seminole Wind]]\" and [[Tracy Lawrence]]'s \"[[Sticks and Stones (Tracy Lawrence song)|Sticks and Stones]]\". He then began performing at area talent contests and local fairs. At 15, he joined the \"house band\" at Georgia nightspot Nashville South.\n\nIn order to stand out, Aldean changed the spelling of his middle name, Aldine, to come up with the name Aldean.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wycd.cbslocal.com/2015/01/20/10-country-stars-that-use-stage-names|title=10 Country Stars That Use Stage Names|date=January 20, 2015|access-date=June 28, 2015|archive-date=June 30, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150630221330/http://wycd.cbslocal.com/2015/01/20/10-country-stars-that-use-stage-names/|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\n===1998\u20132004: Career beginnings===\nAfter high school, with his father's help, Aldean and his band performed at clubs and festivals around the Southeast. With Justin Weaver (one of the band's members), Aldean began writing and recording original songs. In 1998, he performed songs from his first album at a showcase staged by [[Atlanta]] nightclub The Buckboard. He was approached by [[Michael Knox (record producer)|Michael Knox]], then of the [[Warner Chappell Music|Warner-Chappell]] song-publishing company.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p730273/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Jason Aldean Biography |access-date=December 23, 2010 |last=Leggett |first=Steve |work=[[AllMusic|Allmusic]]}}</ref> After signing with Warner-Chappell, Aldean moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] on November 1, 1998, at the age of 21.\n\nAldean was offered a recording contract but was subsequently dropped. He signed with another label but again was dropped in 2000 after his label postponed his recording sessions repeatedly. Various showcases failed to bring him a contract. The last straw was an attempt at the Wildhorse Saloon where the promised label talent scouts never showed up. Frustrated and discouraged with his struggling career, Aldean gave himself six months before planning to leave Nashville and return home to Georgia. Then five weeks later, he was offered a deal from [[BBR Music Group|Broken Bow Records]] in Nashville. Shortly after the release of [[Jason Aldean (album)|his self-titled debut album]], Aldean picked up his new (and current) agent Kevin Neal. While recording ''[[Relentless (Jason Aldean album)|Relentless]]'', Aldean moved to Clarence Spalding and Spalding Entertainment for management.\n\n===2005\u20132008: ''Jason Aldean'' and ''Relentless''===\nAldean's debut single, \"[[Hicktown]]\", was released in early 2005.<ref name=\"allmusic\" /> It served as the lead-off to his [[Jason Aldean (album)|self-titled debut album]] and reached number 10 on the US ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart.<ref name=\"Country Songs\">{{cite magazine|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=jason aldean|chart=Country Songs}}|title=Jason Aldean Album & Song Chart History \u2013 Country Songs|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|access-date=August 11, 2011}}</ref> The album contained his first number one hit with \"[[Why (Jason Aldean song)|Why]]\".<ref name=\"Country Songs\" /> This album contained the number 4 hit \"[[Amarillo Sky (song)|Amarillo Sky]]\",<ref name=\"Country Songs\" /> which had previously been a non-charting single in 2002 for [[McBride & the Ride]]. The song earned a 2006 ACM nomination for Song of the Year and Video of the Year. Aldean earned the title \"Top New Male Vocalist\" at the 2006 [[Academy of Country Music Awards|ACM Awards]]. Over 1,000,000 copies of the album were sold in the United States and it was certified platinum by the [[RIAA]] in 2007.\n\n[[File:Jasonaldean.jpg|thumb|Aldean performing in 2008]]\nAldean spent most of January 2007, in the studio with producer Michael Knox to finish his second album, ''[[Relentless (Jason Aldean album)|Relentless]]''.<ref name=\"allmusic\" /> The album was released on May 29, 2007, and at [[Wal-Mart]] locations was sold with a Limited Edition [[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] Pick DVD that included Aldean's performances. The album's lead-off single, \"[[Johnny Cash (Tracy Byrd song)|Johnny Cash]]\", was originally recorded by [[Tracy Byrd]], but Aldean's version of it peaked at No.&nbsp;6.<ref name=\"Country Songs\" /> Its followup \"[[Laughed Until We Cried]]\" became his 5th consecutive Top 10 hit.<ref name=\"Country Songs\" /> ''Relentless'' was also certified platinum by the [[RIAA]], and its [[Relentless (Jason Aldean song)|title track]] was released as its 3rd single. The song was Aldean's lowest-charting single both in the U.S. and Canada,<ref name=\"Country Songs\" /> failing to reach the Top 10 on the country charts.<ref name=\"Country Songs\" />\n\n===2009\u20132012: ''Wide Open'' and ''My Kinda Party''===\nAldean released his seventh single titled \"[[She's Country]]\" on December 1, 2008. This song serves as the lead-off single from his third album ''[[Wide Open (Jason Aldean album)|Wide Open]]'', which was released on April 7, 2009. The single debuted at No.&nbsp;51 on the [[Hot Country Songs]] chart<ref name=\"Country Songs\" /> in late-November 2008. Being his 7th consecutive Top 40 hit on the country charts,<ref name=\"Country Songs\" /> it is also his 1st Top 40 hit on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. It later became his second number-one hit,<ref name=\"Country Songs\" /> and his first since \"Why\" in May 2006.<ref name=\"Country Songs\" /> The next single, \"[[Big Green Tractor]]\", became Aldean's third number-one hit.<ref name=\"Country Songs\" /> ''Wide Open'' debuted at No.&nbsp;2 on the Top Country Albums chart. \"[[The Truth (Trent Willmon song)|The Truth]]\" became the album's third consecutive number-one hit in January 2010,<ref name=\"Country Songs\" /> with \"[[Crazy Town (song)|Crazy Town]]\" being the album's fourth single and peaking at No.&nbsp;2 on the country charts.<ref name=\"Country Songs\" />\n\nAldean performed with [[Bryan Adams]] on an episode of ''[[CMT Crossroads]]'' in the beginning of May, and the episode premiered on June 26, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicrow.com/category/artist/ |title=Artist |publisher=MusicRow |date=January 28, 2011 |access-date=February 3, 2011}}</ref> In an interview with [[Shave (magazine)|''Shave'' Magazine]], Aldean explained that working with Bryan on ''Crossroads'' \"was great\" and that \"[h]e was a lot of fun.\" But the real highlight for him was that he was working with Randy Owen. \"I am a big fan of [[Alabama (American band)|Alabama]] so I got a chance to work with [[Randy Owen]] on this album (it didn't make the album but it eventually made a bonus track). It was really cool. Alabama were like '[[The Beatles]]' for me so working with him was definitely one of the highlights,\" he said \"I mean, both of those guys were really cool moments, but if I had to pick one highlight, it would be working with Randy [Owen] this year.\"<ref name=\"shavemagazine\">{{cite magazine |url=http://www.shavemagazine.com/entertainment/091101 |title=Interview With Jason Aldean |magazine=Shave Magazine |first=Ziyah |last=Karmali |access-date=November 30, 2009 |date=November 1, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101213085509/http://www.shavemagazine.com/entertainment/091101 |archive-date=December 13, 2010}}</ref> A live DVD titled ''[[Wide Open Live & More]]'' was released on August 25, 2009.{{citation needed|date=December 2021}} At the 2010 CMT Music Awards, Aldean picked up 3 nominations in Video of the Year and Male Video of the Year for \"The Truth\", as well as Collaborative Video of the Year and CMT Performance of the Year for his performance of \"Heaven\" with Bryan Adams.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.cmt.com/2010-04-05/jason-aldean-lady-antebellum-sugarland-lead-2010-cmt-music-awards-nominees/#comment-137607 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100407001017/http://blog.cmt.com/2010-04-05/jason-aldean-lady-antebellum-sugarland-lead-2010-cmt-music-awards-nominees/#comment-137607 |url-status=dead |archive-date=April 7, 2010 |title=Jason Aldean, Lady Antebellum, Sugarland Lead 2010 CMT Music Awards Nominees |publisher=[[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] |date=April 5, 2010 |access-date=February 3, 2011}}</ref>\n\nIn August 2010, Aldean released the single \"[[My Kinda Party (song)|My Kinda Party]]\", which entered the Hot Country Songs chart at No.&nbsp;41.<ref name=\"Country Songs\" /> It is the lead-off single from his [[My Kinda Party|album of the same name]], which was released on November 2, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jasonaldean.com/story/news/jason_aldean_sets_release_of_fourth_studio_album__my_kinda_party_for_1122010/|title=Jason Aldean Sets Release of Fourth Studio Album \u2013 My Kinda Party for 11.2.2010|date=August 23, 2010|work=Jason Aldean|access-date=August 23, 2010}}</ref> It marks as Aldean's tenth top-10 country hit.<ref name=\"Country Songs\" /> Aldean also collaborated with [[Kelly Clarkson]] on the intimate duet \"[[Don't You Wanna Stay]]\". His and Clarkson's performance on November 10, 2010, at the CMA Awards received positive recognition, and debuted at No.&nbsp;59 on ''Billboard'''s Hot Country Songs chart<ref name=\"Country Songs\" /> from unsolicited airplay for the week of November 20, 2010. In March 2011, it became Aldean's fifth number-one hit.<ref name=\"Country Songs\" />\n\nIn early 2011, Aldean's version of \"[[Dirt Road Anthem]]\", which was recorded previously by both of its writers [[country rap]] artist [[Colt Ford]] and [[Brantley Gilbert]] (who also wrote \"My Kinda Party\"), debuted on the Hot Country Songs chart at No.&nbsp;57 as an album cut <ref name=\"Country Songs\" /> from an unsolicited airplay for the week of February 5, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1656874/kenny-chesneys-somewhere-with-you-remains-on-top.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110131130938/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1656874/kenny-chesneys-somewhere-with-you-remains-on-top.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 31, 2011|title=CMT: News: Kenny Chesney's \"Somewhere With You\" Remains on Top|date=January 29, 2011|work=CMT|access-date=February 5, 2011}}</ref> In March 2011, the song was chosen as the third single from ''My Kinda Party''. Aldean also collaborated with Ludacris for the song at the 2011 [[CMT Music Awards]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] on June 8, 2011. In addition to making #1 on the Hot Country Songs chart<ref name=\"Country Songs\" /> for the week of July 30, 2011, it also became Aldean's first Top 10 hit on the Hot 100 chart, peaking at #7.\n\nAldean performed \"My Kinda Party\" at the start of the [[2011 Major League Baseball Home Run Derby|2011 Home Run Derby]], which was broadcast on [[ESPN]].{{citation needed|date=December 2021}} Aldean won the CMA award for Album of the Year in 2011 as well as the Musical Event of the Year with \"Don't You Wanna Stay\", his duet with Kelly Clarkson. This was his first win.{{citation needed|date=December 2021}} On October 25, 2011, it was announced that Aldean would be performing on ''The Grammy Nominations Concert Live! \u2013 Countdown to Music's Biggest Night'', the 1-hour special which took place live on Wednesday, November 30, 2011, at the [[Nokia Theatre L.A. Live|Nokia Theatre]] in [[Los Angeles]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Aldean, Others Set To Perform For Grammys Nomination Party!|url=http://us99country.radio.com/2011/10/25/jason-aldean-to-perform-on-the-grammy-nominations-concert-live/|work=WUSN-FM US99.5}}</ref> \"Don't You Wanna Stay\" received a Grammy nomination for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Duo/Group Performance|Best Country Duo/Group Performance]], but lost to [[The Civil Wars]] at the [[54th Grammy Awards]] on February 12, 2012.{{citation needed|date=December 2021}} The fourth single from the album was \"[[Tattoos on This Town]]\", which peaked at No. 2,<ref name=\"Country Songs\" /> followed by yet another number one single, entitled \"[[Fly Over States]]\".<ref name=\"Country Songs\" />\n\n===2012\u20132016: ''Night Train'' and ''Old Boots, New Dirt''===\n\n[[File:Jason Aldean Night Train Tour 2014.jpg|thumb|right|Aldean performing on his [[2013 Night Train Tour|Night Train Tour]] in 2014]]\n\nThe first single from Aldean's fifth album was entitled \"[[Take a Little Ride (song)|Take a Little Ride]]\". It was released on July 16, 2012. Later, the album's title was announced as ''[[Night Train (Jason Aldean album)|Night Train]]''. This album was released on October 16, 2012. Its second single, \"[[The Only Way I Know]]\", is a collaboration among him, [[Luke Bryan]], and [[Eric Church]]. The album's third single, entitled \"[[1994 (song)|1994]]\", is a tribute to [[Joe Diffie]]. The album's fourth single, the [[Night Train (Jason Aldean song)|title track]], was released to country radio on June 24, 2013. The fifth single, \"[[When She Says Baby]]\", was released to country radio on November 18 of that same year. \"Take a Little Ride\", \"The Only Way I Know\", \"Night Train\", and \"When She Says Baby\" all peaked at number 1 on the [[Country Airplay]] chart respectively.<ref>{{cite magazine|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=jason aldean|chart=Country Airplay}}|title=Jason Aldean Album & Song Chart History \u2013 Country Airplay|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|access-date=November 8, 2012}}</ref>\n\nDuring a radio interview on May 18, Aldean hinted at another possible collaboration with [[Ludacris]]. He did state that it would not be on ''Night Train''. On December 16, 2014, Ludacris released an Extended Play titled ''[[Burning Bridges (EP)|Burning Bridges]]'', in which the title track featured him and Aldean as a duet.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jason Aldean to Collaborate with Ludacris Again |url=http://broadwayselectricbarnyard.com/2012/09/26/jason-aldean-to-collaborate-with-ludacris-again/ |publisher=Broadwayselectricbarnyard.com |access-date=October 6, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141007203643/http://broadwayselectricbarnyard.com/2012/09/26/jason-aldean-to-collaborate-with-ludacris-again/ |archive-date=October 7, 2014 }}</ref> Aldean performed \"My Kinda Party\" during the [[People's Choice Awards]] on January 9, 2013.{{citation needed|date=December 2021}} On June 5, 2013, Jason Aldean co-hosted the [[2013 CMT Music Awards]] with actress [[Kristen Bell]]. He and [[Lenny Kravitz]] opened the awards show singing \"[[American Woman (song)|American Woman]]\".<ref>{{cite web|title=Jason Aldean, Lenny Kravitz Open CMT Music Awards With \"American Woman\"|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1708543/jason-aldean-lenny-kravitz-open-cmt-music-awards-with-american-woman.jhtml/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130612052127/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1708543/jason-aldean-lenny-kravitz-open-cmt-music-awards-with-american-woman.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 12, 2013|publisher=Cmt.com|access-date=October 6, 2014}}</ref>\n\nOn July 22, 2014, Aldean released a new single \"[[Burnin' It Down]]\". This song would serve as the lead single off his sixth studio album ''[[Old Boots, New Dirt]]'', which was released on October 7, 2014. This song reached No. 1 both on the Hot Country Songs and Country Airplay charts.<ref name=\"Country Songs\" /> The album's second single, \"[[Just Gettin' Started (Jason Aldean song)|Just Gettin' Started]]\", was released to country radio on November 10, 2014. It reached No. 1 on the Country Airplay chart in March 2015. \"[[Tonight Looks Good on You]]\" was released as the third single on March 23, 2015. It reached No. 1 on the Country Airplay chart in July 2015. also performed ''[[CMT Crossroads]]'' with [[Bob Seger]] song called \"[[Turn the Page (Bob Seger song)|Turn the Page]]\". The album's fourth single, \"[[Gonna Know We Were Here]]\" released to country radio on August 17, 2015. It reached No. 2 on the Country Airplay chart in January 2016. Jason Aldean is one of only three artists to achieve RIAA platinum sales certification on an album released this year. His ''Old Boots, New Dirt'' album, which debuted at the top of Billboard's all-genre Top 200 chart in October, has now shipped more than one million units. This means that he is<ref name=\"auto\">{{Cite magazine|title = Jason Aldean Scores Only Platinum-Certified Country Album of 2014| magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date = December 8, 2014|url = https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/jason-aldean-has-only-platinum-selling-2014-country-album-20141208|access-date = October 5, 2015}}</ref> the only country star to release a platinum-seller in 2014, and joins only Taylor Swift and Ariana Grande in platinum album certifications for collections released this year.<ref name=\"auto\" />\n\nAt the conclusion of Aldean's Burn it Down Tour, he donated over $600,000 to [[Susan G. Komen for the Cure]] of South Florida.<ref>{{cite web|last1=McClellan|first1=Laura|title=Jason Aldean Wraps Tour, Donates $600K to Breast Cancer Research |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/jason-aldean-concert-for-a-cure-2015/|website=Taste of Country|date=October 27, 2015 |access-date=November 5, 2015}}</ref>\n\n===2016\u20132018: ''They Don't Know'' and ''Rearview Town''===\nIn July 2016 it was announced that the seventh regular studio album, ''[[They Don't Know (Jason Aldean album)|They Don't Know]]'', was set for release on September 9 of that year. Again produced by Michael Knox, the album was preceded by the single \"[[Lights Come On]]\", released to country radio on April 1, 2016.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/jason-aldean-unveils-new-album-they-dont-know-20160711|title=Jason Aldean Unveils New Album 'They Don't Know'|last=Betts|first=Stephen L.|date=July 11, 2016|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=July 14, 2016}}</ref> The album's second single, \"[[A Little More Summertime]]\", released to country radio on July 15, 2016. The album's third single, \"[[Any Ol' Barstool]]\", was released to country radio on December 5, 2016. The album's fourth and final single, the title track of the album, was released to country radio on May 8, 2017.{{citation needed|date=December 2021}} At the 2016 ACM Awards, Aldean was awarded Entertainer of the Year for the first time in his career. He would go on to win that award in 2017 and also 2018.{{citation needed|date=December 2021}}\n\nIn March 2017, Aldean announced that he is working on his eighth album,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/jason-aldean-eighth-studio-album/|title=Jason Aldean Is in the Studio, Working on Eighth Album|website=Taste of Country|date=March 14, 2017 |access-date=April 16, 2018}}</ref> titled ''[[Rearview Town]]'', which was released on April 13, 2018.<ref name=\"Rearview Town\">{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/jason-aldean-you-make-it-easy/|title=Jason Aldean Drops New Single 'You Make It Easy' [Listen]|work=Taste of Country|date=January 26, 2018|access-date=January 26, 2018}}</ref> The lead single, \"You Make It Easy\", was released on January 26, 2018.<ref name=\"Rearview Town\" /> Aldean also confirmed two other songs would appear on the album: \"Gettin' Warmed Up\" and \"Set It Off\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/jason-aldean-rearview-town-details/|title=Jason Aldean's Dropping 'Rearview Town' Secrets All Around Town|work=Taste of Country|last=Dukes|first=Billy|date=January 27, 2018|access-date=March 23, 2018}}</ref>\n\nOn October 1, 2017, Aldean had just begun performing \"[[When She Says Baby]]\" at the [[Route 91 Harvest]] music festival on the [[Las Vegas Strip]] in [[Paradise, Nevada]], when [[Stephen Paddock]] began [[2017 Las Vegas shooting|firing into the crowd]] from the 32nd floor of the [[Mandalay Bay Resort]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.foxnews.com/us/las-vegas-shooting-at-least-59-dead-in-massacre-trump-calls-act-of-pure-evil |title=Las Vegas shooting: At least 50 dead, more than 200 injured in massacre |first1=Adam |last1=Housley |first2=Jake |last2=Gibson |first3=Brooke |last3=Singman |date=October 2, 2017 |work=[[Fox News]] |access-date=October 2, 2017 |quote=Authorities first received calls about an active shooting at about 10:08 p.m. Country music star Jason Aldean was performing at the [[Route 91 Harvest]] Festival when the gunfire erupted as Aldean was almost shot in the head.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/jason-aldean-vegas-shooting-performance-11273115|title=Terrifying moment country music star Jason Aldean's Las Vegas performance is cut short by gunfire'|last=Sanders|first=Emmeline|date=October 2, 2017|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=October 2, 2017}}</ref> Aldean and his band managed to exit the stage unharmed, but 60 concertgoers died and 867 others were injured during the incident.<ref name=\"LVS\">{{cite news |url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2018/jan/19/sheriff-to-provide-update-about-strip-mass-shootin/ |title=Sheriff: Person of interest part of Strip shooting probe; Paddock had child porn |date=January 19, 2018 |work=[[Las Vegas Sun]] |access-date=January 19, 2018 |first1=Ricardo |last1=Torres-Cortez}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://apnews.com/90e2152a036a40a4a1083c2f058d4623/After-Vegas,-Jason-Aldean-carries-the-weight-of-tragedy |title=Jason Aldean Carries the weight of Tragedy|work=AP News|year=2017|access-date=April 9, 2018}}</ref><ref name=\"59th Victim\">{{cite news|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/crime/homicides/california-woman-declared-59th-victim-of-2017-massacre-in-las-vegas-2102779/|title=California woman declared 59th victim of 2017 massacre in Las Vegas|publisher=The Las Vegas Review-Journal|last=Lacanlale|first=Rio|date=August 24, 2020|access-date=August 27, 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"60th Victim\">{{cite news|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/crime/shootings/las-vegas-woman-becomes-60th-victim-of-october-2017-mass-shooting-2123456/|title=Las Vegas woman becomes 60th victim of October 2017 mass shooting|publisher=The Las Vegas Review-Journal|last=Lacanlale|first=Rio|date=September 17, 2020|access-date=September 17, 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"auto000\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.lvmpd.com/en-us/Documents/1-October-FIT-Criminal-Investigative-Report-FINAL_080318.pdf|title=LVMPD Criminal Investigative Report of the 1 October Mass Casualty Shooting|access-date=March 13, 2020|via=www.lvmpd.com}}</ref> On October 7, Aldean opened ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' with words of support for those hurting in the aftermath of the shooting, saying that \"we witnessed one of the worst tragedies in American history. Like everyone, I'm struggling to understand what happened that night (and why) and how to pick up the pieces and start to heal. But you can be sure that we're going to walk through these tough times together, every step of the way. Because when America is at its best, our bond and our spirit \u2014 it's unbreakable.\"<ref>Frank Pallotta. \"[https://money.cnn.com/2017/10/08/media/jason-aldean-saturday-night-live/index.html Jason Aldean opens 'SNL' playing Tom Petty's 'I Won't Back Down']\". [[CNN]], October 9, 2017. Accessed February 8, 2022.</ref> He then performed a cover of \"[[I Won't Back Down]]\" by [[Tom Petty]], who had died five days earlier.<ref>Lisa Respers France and Brandon Griggs. \"[https://www.cnn.com/2017/10/03/entertainment/tom-petty-obit/index.html Tom Petty dies at 66]\". [[CNN]], October 3, 2017. Accessed February 8, 2022.</ref>\n\n=== 2019\u20132023: ''9'' and ''Macon, Georgia'' ===\nAldean performed at the 2019 [[Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum]] Concert and Induction Ceremony.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://amp.tennessean.com/amp/4070180002|title= Musicians Hall of Fame inducts new class including Alabama, Steve Wariner, Don Everly, more|work=Tennessean|last=Watts|first=Cindy|date=October 23, 2019|access-date=April 4, 2022}}</ref> Aldean's ninth album, titled ''[[9 (Jason Aldean album)|9]]'', was released on November 22, 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/jason-aldean-9-album/|title=Jason Aldean Announces New '9' Album, Release Date|work=Taste of Country|last=Dukes|first=Billy|date=September 9, 2019|access-date=September 23, 2019}}</ref> The album's first single, \"[[We Back]]\" released to country radio on September 9, 2019. It peaked at number 6 on the Country Airplay in March 2020 and number 1 on the Canadian Country chart. The album's second single, \"[[Got What I Got]]\" released to country radio on April 6, 2020. \"[[Blame It on You (Jason Aldean song)|Blame It on You]]\" was released on October 26, 2020, as the album's third and final single.\n\nOn July 23, 2021, Aldean released the single \"[[If I Didn't Love You (Jason Aldean and Carrie Underwood song)|If I Didn't Love You]]\", featuring [[Carrie Underwood]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=px89HMy3M3o| archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211030/px89HMy3M3o| archive-date=October 30, 2021|title=Jason Aldean & Carrie Underwood - If I Didn't Love You (Lyric Video)|author=YouTube|date=July 23, 2021|via=YouTube|access-date=September 11, 2021}}{{cbignore}}</ref> It was the leadoff single to his tenth studio album, a [[double album]] project titled ''[[Macon, Georgia (album)|Macon, Georgia]]''. The first half, ''Macon'', was released on November 12, 2021. On January 14, 2022, \"[[Trouble with a Heartbreak]]\" was released as the album's second single<ref>{{cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qirstRKJ6S8|title=Jason Aldean - Trouble With a Heartbreak (Extended Version) (Official Music Video)|date=January 14, 2022|publisher=YouTube}}</ref> and was the leadoff single to the second half of the album, ''Georgia'', which was released on April 22, 2022.<ref name=\"auto1\">{{cite web|url=https://www.jasonaldean.com/news/805833/jason-aldean-announces-10th-studio-album-macon-georgia|title=Jason Aldean Announces 10th Studio Album, ''Macon, Georgia''|date=September 27, 2021 |access-date=October 1, 2021}}</ref> On March 25, 2022, Aldean and [[Brantley Gilbert]] released the single \"[[Rolex\u00ae on a Redneck]]\".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/brantley-gilbert-jason-aldean-rolex-on-a-redneck/|title= Brantley Gilbert and Jason Aldean Celebrate the Rewards of Hard Work in 'Rolex on a Redneck'|work=Taste of Country|date=March 25, 2022|access-date=April 1, 2022}}</ref> On July 18, 2022, Aldean released \"[[That's What Tequila Does]]\"<ref>{{Cite web |date=June 13, 2022 |title=Listen: Jason Aldean to Follow Multi-Week No. 1 Hit With New Single, 'That's What Tequila Does' |url=https://outsider.com/entertainment/music/country-music/listen-jason-aldean-follow-multi-week-no-1-hit-new-single-thats-what-tequila-does/ |access-date=June 14, 2022 |website=Outsider |language=en-US}}</ref> to [[country radio]] as the third and final single off ''Macon, Georgia''. In November 2022, Aldean released his version of [[Alabama (band)|Alabama]]'s \"[[Christmas in Dixie]]\".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Colurso|first1=Mary|title=Listen to Jason Aldean's cover of an Alabama classic, 'Christmas in Dixie'|url=https://www.al.com/life/2022/11/listen-to-jason-aldeans-cover-of-an-alabama-classic-christmas-in-dixie.html|website=AL.com|date=November 4, 2022|access-date=November 7, 2022}}</ref>\n\n===2023\u2013present: \"Try That in a Small Town\" and ''Highway Desperado''===\n{{main|Try That in a Small Town}}\nOn May 19, 2023, Aldean released \"Try That in a Small Town\" as the lead single from his eleventh album.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Dukes |first=Billy |date=May 19, 2023 |title=Jason Aldean's 'Try That in a Small Town' Lyrics Include a Subtle Gun Rights Message |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/jason-aldean-try-that-in-a-small-town-lyrics/ |access-date=August 3, 2023 |website=Taste of Country |language=en}}</ref> Its music video was released on July 14, generating controversy for invoking imagery related to the 2020 [[George Floyd protests]] while being filmed in front of the [[Maury County, Tennessee|Maury County]] courthouse, the site of a 1946 race riot and a 1927 [[Lynching of Henry Choate|lynching of a Black man]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Olson |first=Emily |date=July 20, 2023 |title=How Jason Aldean's 'Try That in a Small Town' became a political controversy |url=https://www.npr.org/2023/07/20/1188966935/jason-aldean-try-that-in-a-small-town-song-video |website=[[NPR]]}}</ref> Four days after its release, [[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] pulled the music video from air.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Newman |first=Melinda |date=July 18, 2023 |title=CMT Pulls Jason Aldean's Controversial 'Try That In a Small Town' Video: Exclusive |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/jason-aldean-try-that-in-a-small-town-video-pulled-cmt-1235373842/ |access-date=August 3, 2023 |magazine=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref> The song and video were denounced by fellow musicians including [[Sheryl Crow]], [[Jason Isbell]] and [[Margo Price]]<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Zemler |first=Emily |date=July 19, 2023 |title=Sheryl Crow Slams Jason Aldean's 'Try That in a Small Town': 'It's Just Lame' |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/sheryl-crow-jason-aldean-try-that-in-a-small-town-response-1234791267/ |access-date=August 3, 2023 |magazine=Rolling Stone |language=en-US}}</ref> while drawing support from country musicians [[Cody Johnson]] and [[Brantley Gilbert]] and former president [[Donald Trump]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newsweek.com/country-music-star-brantley-gilbert-lashes-out-jason-aldean-song-critics-1814810|title=Country Music Star Brantley Gilbert Lashes Out at Jason Aldean Song Critics|first=Jamie|last=Burton|date=July 24, 2023|work=[[Newsweek]]|access-date=August 2, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Sforza |first1=Lauren |date=July 20, 2023 |title=Trump defends Jason Aldean amid song controversy |url=https://thehill.com/blogs/in-the-know/4107561-trump-defends-jason-aldean-amid-song-controversy/ |access-date=July 24, 2023 |website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Nicholson |first=Jessica |date=July 23, 2023 |title=Cody Johnson Offers Support to Jason Aldean Amid 'Try That in a Small Town' Controversy |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/cody-johnson-supports-jason-aldean-try-that-in-a-small-town-controversy-1235376841/ |access-date=August 3, 2023 |magazine=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref> Amid the controversy, the song debuted at number two on the [[Billboard Hot 100]], Aldean's best chart performance of his career.<ref>{{Cite news |date=July 28, 2023 |title=Jason Aldean's Culture War Hit |work=The New York Times |language=en |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/07/28/arts/music/popcast-jason-aldean-small-town.html |access-date=August 3, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Trust |first1=Gary |date=July 24, 2023 |title=Jung Kook's 'Seven,' Featuring Latto, Blasts In at No. 1 on Billboard Hot 100, Followed by Jason Aldean |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/chart-beat/jung-kook-latto-seven-number-one-debut-hot-100-jason-aldean-1235377400/ |magazine=Billboard |access-date=July 24, 2023}}</ref> The next week, it rose to number one and became Aldean's first national chart-topper.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Trust |first1=Gary |date=July 31, 2023 |title=Jason Aldean's 'Try That in a Small Town' Tops Hot 100, As Country Hits Rank at Nos. 1, 2 & 3 for First Time |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/chart-beat/jason-aldean-try-that-in-a-small-town-number-one-hot-100-country-hits-top-three-1235382220/ |magazine=Billboard |access-date=July 31, 2023}}</ref>\n\nOn August 24, 2023, Aldean announced his eleventh album ''[[Highway Desperado]]'', which was released on November 3, 2023, and released the song \"Let Your Boys Be Country\" the following day, on August 25.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://countrynow.com/jason-aldean-announces-highway-desperado-album-and-shares-new-song-let-your-boys-be-country |title=Jason Aldean Announces 'Highway Desperado' Album and Shares New Song 'Let Your Boys Be Country' |author=Lauren Jo Black |publisher=Country Now |date=August 25, 2023 |access-date=September 2, 2023}}</ref> \"Let Your Boys Be Country\" was later released as the album's second single on November 27, 2023.\n\n==Personal life==\nAldean married Jessica Ann Ussery on August 4, 2001.<ref name=\"divorcefiling\">{{cite web | title = Jason Williams vs. Jessica Ann Ussery Williams Complaint for Divorce | url = http://tmz.vo.llnwd.net/o28/newsdesk/tmz_documents/0429_Jason%20Aldean_4_docs.pdf | date= April 26, 2013 | publisher = Chancery Court for Williamson County, Tennessee | access-date = April 29, 2013| archive-date= January 12, 2016| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160112113453/http://tmz.vo.llnwd.net/o28/newsdesk/tmz_documents/0429_Jason%20Aldean_4_docs.pdf| url-status=live}}</ref> Together, the couple have a daughter born in 2003, and another born in 2007.<ref name=\"divorcefiling\" /> On September 30, 2012, Aldean admitted to having \"acted inappropriately at a bar\"<ref>{{cite web| url = https://www.facebook.com/jasonaldean/posts/10151224234051539| first=Jason|last=Aldean| title=Hey Guys \u2013 I wanted to talk to you directly ...| publisher=Jason Aldean verified [[Facebook]] page| date=September 30, 2012| access-date= May 9, 2017| archive-date= May 9, 2017|archive-url=https://archive.today/20170509163520/https://www.facebook.com/jasonaldean/posts/10151224234051539%23| url-status=live}}</ref> with former ''[[American Idol]]'' contestant Brittany Kerr, responding to reports linking her and Aldean.  In a statement, Kerr said she had suffered \"a lapse in judgment\" and \"would like to sincerely apologize to everyone that has been affected by this.\"<ref>Statement given to multiple outlets including {{cite web| url= http://www.tmz.com/2012/10/02/brittany-kerr-apology-jason-aldean-hookup/| title=Brittany Kerr Apologizes for Jason Aldean Hookup -- 'Lapse in Judgment'|date= October 2, 2012| access-date= May 9, 2017|publisher=[[TMZ.com]]| archive-date= August 13, 2016| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160813042313/http://www.tmz.com/2012/10/02/brittany-kerr-apology-jason-aldean-hookup/ | url-status=live}}</ref> Aldean filed for divorce on April 26, 2013, citing irreconcilable differences and listing the filing date as the formal separation date.<ref name=\"divorcefiling\" />\n\nAldean and Kerr began dating and made their first public appearance as a couple at the 2014 CMT Awards.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hollywoodlife.com/2014/06/05/brittany-kerr-jason-aldean-cmt-music-awards-red-carpet-mistress-debut/|title = Jason Aldean Shows Off Former Mistress Brittany Kerr At CMTs | work = Hollywood Life|date = June 5, 2014|access-date = June 24, 2014|first=Sammi| last = Errico | archive-date = June 7, 2014 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140607210107/http://hollywoodlife.com/2014/06/05/brittany-kerr-jason-aldean-cmt-music-awards-red-carpet-mistress-debut/ | url-status = dead }}</ref> They announced their engagement in September 2014<ref>{{cite magazine | url = http://www.people.com/article/jason-aldean-brittany-kerr-engagement-ring |title=Brittany Kerr Flashes Engagement Ring from Jason Aldean: 'We've Been on Cloud Nine' | magazine = [[People (magazine)|People]] | date = September 26, 2014 | access-date = November 18, 2014 | first = Tim | last= Nudd}}</ref> and were married on March 21, 2015.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.people.com/article/jason-aldean-married-brittany-kerr|title=Jason Aldean Marries Brittany Kerr|last=Corriston|first=Michele|magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=March 21, 2015|access-date=May 9, 2017}}</ref> Their son Memphis was born on December 1, 2017.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8054967/jason-aldean-wife-baby-memphis|title=Jason Aldean and Wife Welcome Baby Boy|last=Iasimone|first=Ashley|magazine=Billboard|date=December 2, 2017}}</ref> Their daughter Navy was born in early 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/brittanyaldean/|title=Brittany Aldean Instagram|access-date=February 17, 2019}}</ref> In August 2022, Brittany Aldean posted an [[Instagram]] video in which she stated, \"I'd really like to thank my parents for not changing my gender when I went through my [[tomboy]] phase. I love this girly life\", followed by a longer post in which she stated an opposition to sex changes for minors.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/jason-aldean-wife-brittany-transphobic-post-reactions-1235131821/| title=Maren Morris and Cassadee Pope Call Out Jason Aldean's Wife Brittany Over Transphobic Comments | publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | date=August 27, 2022 | access-date=September 3, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/maren-morris-cassadee-pope-rip-045759920.html | title=Maren Morris, Cassadee Pope Rip Brittany Aldean Over Transphobic Post | publisher=Yahoo! Entertainment | date=August 27, 2022 | access-date=September 3, 2022}}</ref> In response, Aldean's [[public relations]] firm The GreenRoom dropped him after 17 years as a client on September 1.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://people.com/country/jason-aldean-publicity-firm-17-years-parts-ways-after-wife-brittany-transphobic-comments/ | title=Jason Aldean's Publicity Firm Parts Ways with Him Following Wife Brittany's Transphobic Comments | publisher=People | date=September 1, 2022 | access-date=September 3, 2022}}</ref>\n[[File:Jason Aldean's Kitchen + Rooftop Bar - October 2023 - Sarah Stierch.jpg|thumb|Jason Aldean's Kitchen + Rooftop Bar in Gatlinburg, Tennessee in 2023. ]]\nAldean owns part of a hunting company, Buck Commander, in partnership with former [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB) players [[Adam LaRoche]], [[Ryan Langerhans]], and [[Tom Martin (baseball)|Tom Martin]]; [[Willie Robertson]] of ''[[Duck Dynasty]]''; and fellow country singers [[Luke Bryan]] and [[Tyler Farr]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buckcommander.com/buckmen/ |title=Buckmen |publisher=Buck Commander |date=November 21, 2009 |access-date=June 24, 2013}}</ref> He also owns Jason Aldean's Kitchen + Rooftop Bar, which opened in Nashville in 2018.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Jason Aldean's Kitchen and Rooftop Bar is opening in Gatlinburg! What we know so far |url=https://www.knoxnews.com/story/entertainment/music/2023/04/21/jason-aldean-bar-kitchen-coming-gatlinburg-tennessee/70134849007/ |access-date=April 26, 2023 |website=Knoxville News Sentinel}}</ref> A second location in [[Gatlinburg]] opened in 2023, <ref>{{Cite web |date=July 13, 2023 |title=Jason Aldean's restaurant opens in Gatlinburg with city's largest rooftop patio |url=https://www.wate.com/news/sevier-county-news/jason-aldean-gatlinburg-restaurant-opening/ |access-date=July 23, 2023 |website=WATE 6 On Your Side }}</ref> and a third location in [[Pittsburgh]] opened in 2024.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.abc27.com/local-business/country-music-star-jason-aldean-opening-pennsylvania-restaurant-bar/ | title=Jason Aldean's new Pennsylvania restaurant & bar now open | date=March 22, 2024 }}</ref> He also is a co-owner of the E3 Chophouse in Nashville with Luke Bryan and Adam LaRoche.\n\nIn 2015, ''[[Forbes]]'' estimated Aldean's annual income at $43.5 million.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/jason-aldean/ |title=Jason Aldean|work=[[Forbes]]|year=2015 |access-date=April 28, 2016}}</ref> Aldean was the seventh highest-earning country musician making about 32.5 million dollars in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/pictures/595e6e654bbe6f269f7ef17f/the-worlds-highest-paid-c/|title=The World's Highest Paid Country Musicians 2017|website=Forbes|language=en|access-date=February 18, 2020}}</ref> In 2017, Aldean was on Forbes' Celebrity 100 list, being ranked at 98.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/jason-aldean/|title=Jason Aldean|last=Barton|first=ByMerrilee|website=Forbes|language=en|access-date=February 18, 2020}}</ref> Aldean became the sixth artist to receive the ACM Dick Clark Artist of the Decade Award in 2019. The award is given to artists who were consistently on top of the charts over the span of the decade.<ref name=\"billboard.com\">{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8501255/jason-aldean-artist-of-the-decade-award-acm-awards|title=Jason Aldean to Receive Artist of the Decade Award at 54th Academy of Country Music Awards: Exclusive|magazine=Billboard|access-date=February 18, 2020}}</ref>\n\nAldean survived the [[2017 Las Vegas shooting]]. While Aldean was performing at the [[Route 91 Harvest]], a gunman, later identified as [[Stephen Paddock]], began shooting into the crowd of concertgoers, killing 60 people and injuring approximately 800.\n\n===Charity work===\nAldean has supported raising awareness for breast cancer research since 2004, after losing a close friend to the disease. He has raised close to $4 million for cancer research through donating a portion of each ticket sale, special merchandise, VIP meet and greets, a donate button on his website, and his annual Concert for the Cure, most of which he has contributed to [[Susan G. Komen for the Cure]].<ref>{{cite web |title=#MoreThanPinkHero: Jason Aldean passes the $4 million mark raising money for breast cancer |url=http://sandhillsexpress.com/abc_music-co/morethanpinkhero-jason-aldean-passes-the-4-million-mark-raising-money-for-breast-cancer-abcid36116640/ |website=News Hill Nebraska |access-date=December 7, 2018 |archive-date=December 9, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181209165216/http://sandhillsexpress.com/abc_music-co/morethanpinkhero-jason-aldean-passes-the-4-million-mark-raising-money-for-breast-cancer-abcid36116640/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n==Band members==\n* Jason Aldean \u2013 lead vocals, guitar, piano\n* Tully Kennedy \u2013 bass guitar, backing vocals\n* Kurt Allison \u2013 lead guitar\n* Rich Redmond \u2013 drums, percussion \n* Carl Ray (Jay) Jackson \u2013 pedal steel guitar, banjo, backing vocals\n* Jack Sizemore \u2013 guitar, backing vocals\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Jason Aldean [[Tim McGraw]])\n*2010: Last Rodeo Tour (with [[Brooks & Dunn]])\n\n==Filmography==\n*''[[CMT Crossroads]]'' with [[Bryan Adams]] (2009), [[Bob Seger]] (2014)\n*''[[Sweetwater (2013 film)|Sweet Kelly]]\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n===Grammy Awards===\n<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/artists/jason-aldean/376|title=Jason Aldean - Artist|work=Grammy.com|access-date=May 13, Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_Flatlanders","to":"The Flatlanders"}],"pages":{"1980798":{"pageid":1980798,"ns":0,"title":"The Flatlanders","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use American English|date=July 2023}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2023}}\n{{Short description|American country band}}\n{{Refimprove|date=July 2015}}\n{{Infobox musical artist  <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n|name            = The Flatlanders\n|image           = Flatlanders.gif\n|caption         = The Flatlanders playing a concert in [[Lubbock, Texas]], on June 3, 2009\n|image_size      = \n|background      = group_or_band\n|origin          = [[Lubbock, Texas]], U.S.\n|genre           = [[Country rock]], [[alternative country]]\n|years_active    = 1972\u20131973, 1998\u2013present\n|label           = Charly, [[New West Records|New West]], [[Plantation Records|Plantation]], [[Rounder Records|Rounder]]\n|associated_acts = \n|website         =  \n|current_members = [[Jimmie Dale Gilmore]]<br /> [[Joe Ely]]<br /> [[Butch Hancock]]\n}}\n\n'''The Flatlanders''' are an American [[country music|country band]] from [[Lubbock, Texas]], founded in 1972 by [[Jimmie Dale Gilmore]], [[Joe Ely]] and [[Butch Hancock]].<ref>{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p1606/biography}}</ref> The group garnered little success during their brief original incarnation from 1972 to 1973, but when the individual members found success in their solo careers, interest in The Flatlanders was rekindled with the band reuniting several times since. An earlier incarnation of this band was known as The Double Mountain Fork Of The Brazos River Boys.\n\n==History==\nIn 1972, Gilmore, Ely and Hancock, formed The Flatlanders with each contributing vocals, guitar, and songwriting skills. Other key musicians were Steve Wesson on [[autoharp]] and [[musical saw]], Tony Pearson on [[mandolin]] and backup harmony, [[Tommy Hancock]] (no relation to Butch Hancock) on [[fiddle]] and Syl Rice on [[string bass]].\n\nOne of the band's first appearances was at the [[Kerrville Folk Festival]] in 1972, where they were named one of the winners of the inaugural Kerrville Folk Festival New Folk Singer/Songwriter Competition.\n\nThe band's first recording project was produced in 1972 by Shelby Singleton, the then-owner of [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis, Tennessee's]] famed [[Sun Studios]]. A promotional single, Gilmore's \"Dallas\", was a commercial failure, and the planned album, ''All American Music'', was all but scrapped, being released only in a limited run on [[Stereo 8|8-track tape]] in order to fulfill contractual obligations. \n\nThe Flatlanders performed through 1973 before disbanding. By the end of the decade, however, Gilmore, Ely and Hancock had all found success as solo performers, and rumors of their earlier obscure collaboration began to circulate. In 1990, [[Rounder Records]] issued the 1972 sessions as ''More a Legend Than a Band''.\n\nThe three musicians continued to reunite for occasional Flatlanders performances. In 1998 they contributed to the soundtrack of ''[[The Horse Whisperer (film)|The Horse Whisperer]]'', and then in 2002 released their follow-up album, ''Now Again,'' on [[New West Records]].  In 2004 this was followed with ''Wheels of Fortune'', again on New West. In 2004, New West released ''Live '72'' a live recording of the then-unknown country band performing at the One Knite [[honky-tonk]] in [[Austin, Texas]].\n\nIn 2009, The Flatlanders released the album, ''Hills & Valleys''. In promotion of the album, the group appeared as musical guests on the ''Late Show with David Letterman'' on July 21, 2009, and on Garrison Keillor's ''A Prairie Home Companion'' on April 27, 2013.\n\nIn 2012, The Flatlanders released ''The Odessa Tapes'', an album composed of unreleased recordings culled from 1972 recording sessions.<ref>{{cite web |title=Song Premiere: The Flatlanders, 'Shadow Of The Moon' |date=June 11, 2012 |url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2012/06/song-premiere-the-flatlanders-shadow-of-the-moon/ |publisher=America Songwriter |accessdate=June 14, 2012}}</ref>\n\nThe Flatlanders were voted into the Austin Music Awards Hall of Fame in March 2016. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailytexanonline.com/2016/03/16/country-band-the-flatlanders-inducted-into-austin-music-awards-hall-of-fame|title=Country band The Flatlanders inducted into Austin Music Awards Hall of Fame - The Daily Texan|website=Dailytexanonline.com}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n!rowspan=\"2\" Records\n|\u2014\n|\u2014\n|\u2014\n|\u2014\n|-\n|colspan=\"6\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|}\n\na. {{note|double}} All four albums feature different combinations of the same set of tracks recorded in 1972.\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.lubbock-lights.com ''Lubbock Lights'', a 2005 film starring The Flatlanders]\n*[https://web.archive.org/web/20060220031051/http://www.happenstance-music.com/KFF_History.asp Kerrville Folk Festival New Folk Finalist History from Happenstance and Doug Coppock]\n*{{cite news |first=Jon |last=Garelick |work=[[The Boston Phoenix]] |title=The three troubadours: Joe Ely, Jimmie Dale Gilmore, and Butch Hancock keep the Flatlanders alive |url=http://www.bostonphoenix.com/boston/music/other_stories/documents/03604723.asp |date=February 20, 2004}}\n*{{cite news |first=Carolyn Pennypacker |last=Riggs |work=[[L.A. Record]] |title=The Flatlanders: Knocks Your Brain Out Of Your Skull |url=http://larecord.com/interviews/2009/05/30/interview-the-flatlanders-joe-ely-knocks-your-brain-out-of-your-skull |date=May 30, 2009}}\n\n{{Jimmie Dale Gilmore}}\n{{Authority control}}\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Flatlanders}}\n[[Category:Country music groups from Texas|Flatlanders, The]]\n[[Category:Musical groups from Lubbock, Texas]]\n[[Category:New West Records artists]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 1972]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jill_Johnson","to":"Jill Johnson"}],"pages":{"5565547":{"pageid":5565547,"ns":0,"title":"Jill Johnson","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Distinguish|Jill Johnston}}\n{{Other people}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Jill Johnson\n| image            = Jill Johnson2.jpg\n| caption          = Johnson in 2009\n| image_size       = \n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = Jill Anna Maria Johnson\n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1973|5|24|df=yes}}\n| birth_place      = [[\u00c4ngelholm]], [[Sweden]]\n| instrument       = [[Vocals]]\n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]], [[country rock]], [[pop music|pop]], [[schlager]]\n| years_active     = 1996\u2013present\n| label            = [[Freebird Entertainment]]\n| website          = [http://www.jilljohnson.se/ www.jilljohnson.se]\n}}\n\n'''Jill Anna Maria Johnson''' (born 24 May 1973) is a Swedish [[country music|country]] and [[pop music|pop]] singer, songwriter<ref name=\"discogs\">{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/74167-Jill-Johnson|publisher=discogs.com|title=Jill Johnson Discography at Discogs|access-date=November 9, 2016}}</ref> and TV-host.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mynewsdesk.com/se/helenewigrenprbeyond/pressreleases/maja-francis-gaestar-jill-johnson-i-programmet-jill-i-lilla-hult-paa-svt-och-slaepper-singel-lyssna-haer-3022619|title=Maja Francis visits Jill Johnson in the program \"Jill i Lilla Hult\" on SVT and releases single. Listen to me!|date=23 July 2020|first=Helene|last=Wigren|website=PR&BEYOND|accessdate=4 August 2021}}</ref> She performed in the [[Melodifestivalen 1998]] contest, winning with the song \"[[K\u00e4rleken \u00e4r]]\" (\"Love Is\"), and represented Sweden at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1998]] with that song, which finished 10th with 53 points. In 2003 she entered [[Melodifestivalen 2003|Melodifestivalen]] for the second time with \"[[Crazy in Love (Jill Johnson song)|Crazy in Love]]\", which finished fourth in the final. She also hosted the final of [[Melodifestivalen 2005]]. Johnson is today one of the most successful artists in Sweden, with several Gold and Platinum records and since 2014 has hosted her own Swedish TV-show from [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], ''[[Jills veranda]]''.\n\n==Biography==\n[[Image:Jill johnson lida country festival sweden 2003.jpg|thumb|right|Johnson in 2003]]{{BLP sources|date=March 2023}}\nJohnson is from the small town of [[\u00c4ngelholm]] in the south western part of Sweden. By the age of four, she had decided she wanted to become an artist, an aspiration towards which she was highly encouraged by her local choir leader. As a 12-year-old, she started off as the vocalist in a Country & Western band, Tomboola Band, touring in Norway and Denmark. She signed eventually with EMI-Medley in Denmark and recorded an album, produced by producer Paul Bruun. The title-track, \"Sugar Tree\", became a hit in [[Denmark]]. In 1996, she had her first Swedish hit with \"[[Kommer tid, kommer v\u00e5r]]\", a [[duet]] with [[Jan Johansen (singer)|Jan Johansen]].\n\nIn 1998, she performed \"K\u00e4rleken \u00e4r\" (\"Love is\") at national contest [[Melodifestivalen]], winning the Swedish finals and going on to represent Sweden in the [[Eurovision Song Contest]]. The success was followed by the hit album ''N\u00e4r hela v\u00e4rlden ser p\u00e5'' and a successful tour.\n\nIn mid-1999, Johnson went to Los Angeles to look for material for her second album. At home, she worked with [[Andreas Carlsson]] (ASCAP Writer of the Year 2000), who is known for several hits, including [[Celine Dion]]'s \"That's the Way It Is\". She also tried out a few local newcomers and the album ''Daughter of Eve'' was released in early 2000. It was very well received and Johnson was compared with some of the world's best artists.\n\nIn 2000, she received a Platinum-record in Denmark for the sound-track \"Promise To Love\" from the Danish block-buster, ''Eneste Ene''. Later that year, Johnson started to collaborate with other songwriters such as Jenny Orenstein, Charlie Stefl, Mary Green [Biem Writer of the Year 2001]. This resulted in her receiving a publishing contract in Nashville, Tennessee. Consequently, in 2002 Johnson's album entitled ''Good Girl'' came to be with the help of producer Scott Baggett and some of Nashville's top musicians. This album secured Johnson's artistic sound and style and once again she was extremely well received by the press in their reviews where she was described as an artist of international calibre.\n\nIn the Swedish finals of the Eurovision Song Contest 2003 she qualified at fourth place (out of 32 entries) but and her song \"Crazy in Love\" became a hit and received a great deal of radio play and was followed by a successful tour.\n\nJohnson's collective ''Discography'' CD was released in late March 2003. It contains the 20 most popular songs since her debut in 1995. The CD went straight into the sales charts for best selling CDs in Sweden. The single \"Crazy in Love\" stayed at No 1 in the Swedish Top Charts (Svensktoppen) 12 weeks consecutively and No 2 for 15 weeks. ''Discography'' sold Gold in Sweden and Johnson also got a [[Grammis]] for this album.\n\nThe album ''Roots and Wings'' was released in November 2003, recorded and produced by Amir Aly in Sweden and by Scott Baggett in Nashville, Tennessee. ''Roots and Wings'' sold Gold in less than two weeks and Platinum a few months later.\n\nThe album ''Being who you are'' was released in Sweden in late March 2005 and sold Gold in only a few weeks.\n\nJohnson was the host of the 2005 Swedish finals of the Eurovision Song Contest in Stockholm. In 2014 she became the hostess of her own Swedish musical TV-series, ''[[Jills veranda]]'', where she brought together and performed with different Swedish and American music personalities in Nashville, the city where she also spends much time working with her own music. In 2014, she was awarded with the Swedish Kristallen-prize for \"Female host of the year\", due to [[Jills veranda]]. The show aired two following seasons in 2015 and 2017. In 2016 she participated in the popular musical TV-series ''[[S\u00e5 mycket b\u00e4ttre]]'', which was broadcast on [[TV4 (Sweden)|TV4]].\n\nIn 2019, Jill released the single \"Is It Hard Being A Man?\" among others which topped the Swedish radio charts. The same year, Jill went on a club tour, \"My Remedy Tour\", which visited fifteen citites and premiered on 8 March in Malm\u00f6. On 18 August 2019, Jill hosted her own episode in the popular Swedish radio show Sommar i P1. \n\nJohnson will play the role as Camilla in the Swedish TV-series \"Udda Veckor\", which airs on Discovery+ during the spring of 2021. Jill's participation in the show marks her debut as an actress in a fictional role.\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n'''Studio albums'''\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n!
