Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"James_Blundell_(singer)","to":"James Blundell (singer)"}],"pages":{"4442088":{"pageid":4442088,"ns":0,"title":"James Blundell (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Australian country singer}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=August 2013}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2023}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|name                = James Blundell\n|image               = James Blundell autographing.jpg\n|alt                 = Man signing autograph\n|caption             = Blundell in 2009\n|background          = solo_singer\n|birth_name          = \n|birth_date          = {{Birth date and age|1964|12|08|df=yes}}\n|death_date          = \n|origin              = [[Stanthorpe, Queensland]], Australia\n|instrument          = Vocals, guitar\n|genre               = [[Country music|Country]], [[country rock]]\n|occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n|years_active        = 1987\u2013present \n|label               = [[EMI Records|EMI]], ABC, Compass Brothers, Revenge, Red Rebel\n|website             = {{URL|jamesblundell.com.au}}\n}}\n\n'''James Blundell''' (born 8 December 1964) is an Australian [[country music]] singer. Born in [[Stanthorpe, Queensland]], Blundell first rose to prominence after being named \"best new talent\" at the 1987 [[Country Music Awards of Australia]]. Blundell has since released several albums in both Australia and the United States, with his most successful album ''[[This Road (album)|This Road]]'' (released in 1992) selling more than 145,000 copies in Australia. Blundell was an unsuccessful candidate for the [[Australian Senate|Senate]] in Queensland at the [[2013 Australian federal election|2013 federal election]], running for [[Katter's Australian Party]]. At the 2019 [[Country Music Awards of Australia]], Blundell was inducted into the Hall of Fame.\n\n==Early life==\nBlundell was born in [[Queensland]] town of [[Stanthorpe, Queensland|Stanthorpe]], and was brought up on a sheep and cattle station near the town. As an adult he worked as a station hand across various locations in northern Australia. After a back injury sustained while working on a farm in [[Papua New Guinea]] he turned to music.<ref name=\"countrystyle1\">{{cite web|url=http://countrystyle-cndsrc.texterity.com/countrystyle/200904/?pg=14|title=My Country Childhood - James Blundell Singer|last=Sweeney|first=Barbara|date=April 2009|publisher=Country Style|pages=32\u201334|access-date=1 February 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716212940/http://countrystyle-cndsrc.texterity.com/countrystyle/200904/?pg=14|archive-date=16 July 2011|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=dictionaryperformingarts1>{{cite book|last=Atkinson|first=Ann|author2=Linsay Knight|author3=Margaret McPhee|title=The Dictionary of Performing Arts in Australia|publisher=Allen & Unwin|year=1996|location=[[St Leonards, New South Wales|St Leonards]]|page=34|isbn=1-86373-898-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/the-boys-from-the-bush-are-back-in-town--james-blundell-plays-with-lee-kernaghan-in-canberra-on-may-5-20170426-gvsvbe.html|title=The boys from the bush are back in town - James Blundell plays with Lee Kernaghan in Canberra |work=The Canberra Times|date= 28 April 2017|access-date=21 February 2018}}</ref>\n\n==Music career==\n===1987\u20131991: Career beginnings===\n{{Main|James Blundell (album)|Hand It Down}}\nIn 1987, Blundell won the Australia's Starker Quest at the [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] (CMAA) and won a recording contract with RCA Victor Australia where he released \"Gidgee Bug Pub Song\".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/James-Blundell-The-Gidgee-Bug-Pub-Song/release/10851998|title=The Gidgee Bug Pub Song |publisher=Discogs|access-date=22 February 2018}}</ref> In 1988, Blundell won the [[Country Music Awards of Australia|Golden Guitar Award]] for the \"Best New Talent\".<ref name=\"age1\">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wmYRAAAAIBAJ&pg=4678,334073&dq=james-blundell+country&hl=en|title=What's on Music - Singles|last=Mangan|first=John|date=21 April 1989|work=The Age|pages=10|access-date=1 February 2010}}</ref><ref name=smh1>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WDsRAAAAIBAJ&pg=4880,8136322&dq=james-blundell+country&hl=en|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130124132450/http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WDsRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=aucDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4880,8136322&dq=james-blundell+country&hl=en|url-status=dead|archive-date=24 January 2013|title=Two golden guitars for singer|last=Jarvis|first=Sue|date=29 January 1989|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=1 February 2010}}</ref> Blundell signed with [[EMI]] released his [[eponymous]] debut studio album in 1989. The album spawned the singles \"Cloncurry Cattle Song\" and \"Kimberley Moon\"; both of which won him Male Vocalist of the Year awards at the CMAA in 1989 and 1990. In 1990, Blundell contributed \"Until the Next Big Dry\" for the 1990 compilation album ''[[Breaking Ground - New Directions in Country Music]]''. Late in 1990, Blundell released his second studio album ''[[Hand It Down]]'' which peaked at number 50 on the ARIA charts in 1991 and won him his first [[ARIA Award]] in [[ARIA Music Awards of 1991|1991]] for [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]]. The single \"Age of Grace\" won Blundell his third consecutive Male Vocalist of the Year awards at the CMAA in 1991.\n\n===1992\u20132002: Commercial Success with EMI===\n{{Main|This Road (album)|Touch of Water|Earth & Sea|I Shall Be Released: The Best of James Blundell}}\nIn March 1992, Blundell released a cover of [[The Dingoes]]' song \"[[Way Out West (The Dingoes song)|Way Out West]]\" with [[James Reyne]]. The song was a commercial success peaking at number 2 on the [[ARIA Charts]] and was certified gold.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ariacharts.com.au/annual-charts/1992/singles-chart|title=1992 ARIA SINGLES CHART|publisher=ARIA Charts|access-date=21 February 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171006163157/https://www.ariacharts.com.au/annual-charts/1992/singles-chart|archive-date=6 October 2017|url-status=dead}}</ref> It won Blundell his first [[APRA Awards (Australia)|APRA Award]] for Country Song of the Year. In April, Blundell released his third studio album ''[[This Road (album)|This Road]]'' which peaked at number 4 on the ARIA Charts, was certified platinum and has sold more than 145,000 copies in Australia.<ref name=PerthNow>{{cite web|url=https://www.perthnow.com.au/news/wa/bankrupt-james-blundell-back-with-his-folks-ng-d2f72398ac83efd21e265d879918c439|title= Bankrupt James Blundell back with his folks|publisher=Perth Now|date=30 May 2010 |access-date= 21 February 2018}}</ref> Additional singles \"This Road\" and \"Down on the Farm\" were released in 1992 and Blundell won two more Golden Guitar awards at the 1993 CMAA, including Top Selling album of the Year. In August 1993, Blundell released ''[[Touch of Water]]'' which peaked at number 11 on the ARIA Charts. Blundell continued to play regularly at folk and country music festivals around Australia. In April 1995, Blundell released his fifth studio album ''[[Earth & Sea]]'' which peaked at number 31. In 1996, disillusioned with the music industry, around Europe in a van, earning money by busking.<ref name=PerthNow/>\nIn 1997, Blundell featured in a [[Qantas]] commercial, singing \"[[I Still Call Australia Home]]\", and in the lead-up to the [[1999 Australian republic referendum]], Blundell recorded the official song for the \"No\" campaign, despite being in favour of a republic.<ref name=guardian1>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/1999/nov/03/australia.monarchy1|title=Digger's final push to keep the Queen|last=Campbell|first=Duncan|date=3 November 1999|work=The Guardian|access-date=1 February 2010}}</ref><ref name=abc1>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/am/stories/s58288.htm|title=Ad campaigns won't make referendum voting easier|date=11 October 1999|work=AM|publisher=ABC Radio|access-date=1 February 2010}}</ref><ref name=\"abc2\">{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/stories/s58363.htm|title='No' campaign accused of sexist advert |date=11 October 1999|work=The World Today|publisher=ABC Radio|access-date=1 February 2010}}</ref> In 1999, Blundell released his sixth studio album ''Amsterdam Breakfast'' which sold 8,000 copies.<ref name=PerthNow/> In August 2001, EMI released his first greatest hits album, ''[[I Shall Be Released: The Best of James Blundell]]'', which concluded his record deal.\n\n===2003\u20132012: Independent Artist, CMAA Hands of Fame and CMC Hall of Fame===\nAs an independent artist, Blundell garnered media attention for his 2003 song \"[[Postcards from Saigon]]\", speaking out against the [[war in Iraq]].<ref name=\"capitalnews1\">{{cite news|url=http://www.capitalnews.com.au/editorial.asp?editorial_id=696&issue=63|title=WEATHERING THE STORM|last=Jarvis|first=Susan|date=February 2005|publisher=Capital News|access-date=1 February 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091007043702/http://www.capitalnews.com.au/editorial.asp?editorial_id=696&issue=63|archive-date=7 October 2009|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=PerthNow/> In 2005, the song won Australian Independent Country Music Single of the Year and Independent Country Music Male Vocalist of the Year. In 2005, Blundell released ''Deluge'', followed by ''Ring Around the Moon'' in 2007 and ''Portrait of a Man'' in 2008.\n\nIn 2007, Blundell was inducted into the Australia Country Music Hands of Fame.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrymusichalloffame.com.au/Hands/1-Hands%20of%20F.htm |publisher=Country Music Hall of Fame|title= The Country Music Hands of Fame|access-date=21 February 2018}}</ref> In October 2010 Blundell was the narrator for [[Network Ten]]'s television show, [[Keeping up with the Joneses (TV series)|Keeping up with the Joneses]] and for four months from November 2010, Blundell performed in a musical theatre show, ''The Ultimate Rock 'n' Roll Jam Session'', with [[Nick Barker (Australian musician)|Nick Barker]], Dave Larkin, [[Ezra Lee (musician)|Ezra Lee]] and [[Doug Parkinson (entertainer)|Doug Parkinson]].<ref name=\"Fox Photo\">{{cite web|url=http://www.foxmediamarketing.com.au/gallery_385493.html|title=''The Ultimate Rock 'n' Roll Jam Session''|publisher=Fox Media Marketing (Clive Fox Photography)|access-date=16 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=\"Ultimate Rock\">{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2010/10/26/3048379.htm|title=Win Tweet Seats to the ''Ultimate Rock 'n' Roll Jam Sessions''|publisher=774 ABC Melbourne (Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC))|date=29 October 2010|access-date=16 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=\"Kary\">{{cite news|url=http://www.sydneyartsguide.com.au/the-ultimate-rock-n-roll-jam-session/|title=''The Ultimate Rock 'n' Roll Jam Session''|last=Kary|first=David|work=Sydney Arts Guide|date=22 February 2011|access-date=16 June 2015}}</ref> Blundell released his tenth studio album ''Woolshed Creek'' in April 2011. In March 2012, Blundell was the inaugural inductee into the [[Country Music Channel]]'s Hall of Fame.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/the-cmc-awards-winners|title=THE CMC Award Winners |publisher=Country Music Channel|date=March 2012 |access-date=21 February 2018}}</ref>\n\n===2013\u2013present: politics and music===\n{{Main|Campfire (James Blundell album)}}\nIn June 2013, Blundell became a candidate in the [[2013 Australian federal election]]. In August 2015, Blundell released ''Come on In'' and in February 2017, his twelfth studio album ''[[Campfire (James Blundell album)|Campfire]]'' which became his first charting album in over 20 years, peaking at number 58. In February 2018, a tribute album ''30 Years of Pride: A Tribute to James Blundell'' was released.\n\n==Politics==\nIn June 2013, Blundell was selected as [[Katter's Australian Party]]'s lead [[Australian Senate|Senate]] candidate<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/federal-election-2013/guide/sqld/|title=Federal Election 2013|publisher=ABC|date=30 August 2013|access-date=4 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kattersaustralianparty.com.au/our-people/james-blundell|title=Katter's Australia Party James Blundell|publisher=Katter's Australia Party|date=17 July 2013|access-date=30 August 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130819072825/http://www.kattersaustralianparty.com.au/our-people/james-blundell|archive-date=19 August 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref> for Queensland in the [[2013 Australian federal election|2013 federal election]].<ref name=signsup>{{cite web|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/country-music-star-james-blundell-signs-up-for-bob-katters-party/story-e6freoof-1226655052412|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130830203805/http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/country-music-star-james-blundell-signs-up-for-bob-katters-party/story-e6freoof-1226655052412|url-status=dead|archive-date=30 August 2013|title= Country music star James Blundell signs up for Bob Katter's party|publisher= [[The Courier-Mail]]|date= 2 June 2013|access-date= 30 August 2013}}</ref> This was largely at the urging of [[Bob Katter]], the party's founder and only federal member of parliament. Blundell had previously been approached to stand in elections by the [[Liberal National Party of Queensland|Liberal National Party]] (LNP), but declined.<ref name=\"somethingtosingabout\">Jamie Walker (2013). [http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/election-2013/country-star-gives-katter-something-to-sing-about/story-fn9qr68y-1226690482518 \"Country star gives Katter something to sing about\"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130804094342/http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/election-2013/country-star-gives-katter-something-to-sing-about/story-fn9qr68y-1226690482518 |date=4 August 2013 }} \u2013 ''The Australian''. Published 3 August 2013. Retrieved 30 August 2013.</ref> His selection was controversial within the party, in part because he had not been a party member before his candidacy was announced, and contributed to a former vice-president, Kevin Brown, resigning his membership.<ref>Jason Tin (2013). [http://www.news.com.au/national-news/queensland/katters-australian-party-members-slam-senate-preselection-of-country-star-james-blundell/story-fnii5v6w-1226655436169 \"Katter's Australian Party members slam Senate preselection of country star James Blundell\"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020145227/http://www.news.com.au/national-news/queensland/katters-australian-party-members-slam-senate-preselection-of-country-star-james-blundell/story-fnii5v6w-1226655436169 |date=20 October 2013 }} \u2013 ''The Courier-Mail''. Published 3 June 2013. Retrieved 30 August 2013.</ref> Some of Blundell's political positions have been controversial within the party, notably his support for [[Same-sex marriage in Australia|same-sex marriage]] and the abolition of [[Overtime|penalty rates]].<ref>[http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/election-2013/clive-palmer-bob-katter-discuss-all-things-great-and-small/story-fn9qr68y-1226704378810 \"Clive Palmer, Bob Katter discuss all things great and small\"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130826220941/http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/election-2013/clive-palmer-bob-katter-discuss-all-things-great-and-small/story-fn9qr68y-1226704378810 |date=26 August 2013 }} \u2013 ''[[The Australian]]''. Published 26 August 2013. Retrieved 30 August 2013.</ref><ref>Des Houghton (2013). [http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/opinion/bob-katter8217s-tolerance-of-star-senate-candidate-james-blundell8217s-views-on-gay-unions-sparks-member-exodus/story-fnihsr9v-1226693625846 \"Bob Katter's tolerance of star Senate candidate James Blundell's views on gay unions sparks member exodus\"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130811023522/http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/opinion/bob-katter8217s-tolerance-of-star-senate-candidate-james-blundell8217s-views-on-gay-unions-sparks-member-exodus/story-fnihsr9v-1226693625846 |date=11 August 2013 }} \u2013 ''The Courier-Mail''. Published 10 August 2013. Retrieved 30 August 2013.</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nBlundell has been married twice\u2014first to Louise, a former manager, and second to Lidia, with whom he had two sons.<ref name=\"telegraph2\">{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/adelaidenow/story/0,22606,22311096-5012985,00.html|title=Ex's pals hit back at James Blundell over Idol Jesse Curran|date=26 August 2007|work=The Daily Telegraph|location=Sydney|access-date=1 February 2010}}</ref> He left his second wife in August 2007 for Jesse Curran, a singer who he had met at one of his concerts and while she was a contestant on Australian Idol. He and Curran have since had two children together, Fian Blundell and Ria Blundell.<ref name=\"telegraph1\">{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/blundell-leaves-wife-for-idol-star/story-e6frfo60-1111114268538|title=James Blundell leaves wife for Jesse Curran |last=Reines|first=Ros|date=26 August 2007|work=The Daily Telegraph|location=Sydney|access-date=1 February 2010}}</ref><ref name=\"somethingtosingabout\"/>\n\nBlundell was engaged to Kristal Padget in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.canberratimes.com.au/story/6033676/the-boys-from-the-bush-are-back-in-town-james-blundell-plays-with-lee-kernaghan-in-canberra-on-may-5/|title = The boys from the bush are back in town - James Blundell plays with Lee Kernaghan in Canberra on May 5|date = 27 April 2017}}</ref> In March 2020 he announced his engagement to Rebecca Williams, 28 years after she inspired his 1992 hit \"Down on the Farm\".<ref>{{Cite web|title=James Blundell will marry \"Rebecca\" from his 1992 hit 'Down On The Farm'|url=https://tonedeaf.thebrag.com/country/james-blundell-will-marry-rebecca-from-his-1992-hit-down-on-the-farm/|access-date=2021-07-16|website=Tone Deaf|language=en-AU}}</ref>\n\nIn May 2010, Blundell filed for [[Bankruptcy#Australia|bankruptcy]], having gone into debt attempting to finance his albums, as well as having lost money on the sale of an investment property the previous year.<ref>[https://archive.today/20130830203825/http://www.news.com.au/breaking-news/james-blundell-caught-out-in-investment-property-slump/story-e6frfkp9-1225690988423 \"James Blundell caught out in investment property slump\"] \u2013 ''The Daily Telegraph''. Published 24 March 2009. Retrieved 30 August 2013.</ref> The bankruptcy was discharged in April 2013\u2014had it not been, he would have ineligible to stand as a candidate for election.<ref name=\"signsup\" />\n\nBlundell's brother, [[Peter Blundell (mayor)|Peter Blundell]], died on 24 December 2021. He was a former mayor of the [[Shire of Stanthorpe|Stanthorpe Shire]] and the [[Southern Downs Region]] as well as the [[Liberal National Party of Queensland|LNP]] candidate for [[Electoral district of Keppel|Keppel]] in the [[2017 Queensland state election]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Bowman|first=Trish|date=19 July 2017|title=LNP reveals shock candidate to take on Brittany Lauga|url=https://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/rockhampton/lnp-reveals-shock-candidate-to-take-on-brittany-lauga/news-story/d181fc40a4aa017c1ac4ed1cfafc03db|work=The Morning Bulletin|access-date=26 December 2021}}</ref><ref>[https://archive.today/20130830203810/http://www.afr.com/p/national/with_senate_in_sight_katter_man_Y8yJzToBCKw7tHgQZJCLgL \"With Senate in sight, Katter's man sings to small business\"] \u2013 ''[[The Australian Financial Review]]''. Published 17 June 2013. Retrieved 30 August 2013.</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Further|James Blundell discography}}\n*''[[James Blundell (album)|James Blundell]]'', 1989 \n*''[[Hand It Down]]'', 1990 \n*''[[This Road (album)|This Road]]'', 1992 \n*''[[Touch of Water]]'', 1993 \n*''[[Earth & Sea]]'', 1995 \n*''Amsterdam Breakfast'', 1999\n*''Deluge'', 2005\n*''Ring Around the Moon'', 2007<ref name=jamesblundell>{{cite web|url=http://www.jamesblundell.com.au/music.html|title=discography - albums |publisher=James Blundell Official Website|access-date=1 February 2010}}</ref>\n*''Portrait of a Man'', 2008<ref name=\"compass1\">{{cite web|url=http://www.compassbrothers.com.au/node/5|title=James Blundell|date=20 July 2008|publisher=Compass Brothers Records|access-date=1 February 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110227123659/http://www.compassbrothers.com.au/node/5|archive-date=27 February 2011|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n*''Woolshed Creek'', 2011<ref name=jamesblundell/>\n*''Come on In'', 2015<ref name=jamesblundell/>\n*''[[Campfire (James Blundell album)|Campfire]]'', 2017<ref name=jamesblundell/>\n*''World Don't Stop'', 2023\n\n==Awards==\n===AIR Awards===\nThe Australian Independent Record Awards (commonly known informally as [[AIR Awards]]) is an annual awards night to recognise, promote and celebrate the success of Australia's Independent Music sector.\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[AIR Awards of 2009|2009]]<ref name=\"09noms\">{{cite web|url=https://www.auspop.com.au/2009/10/air-nominees/|title=AIR Nominees|date=19 October 2009|access-date=19 August 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"AIRwins\">{{cite web|url=https://www.air.org.au/awards/history|title=History Wins|website=[[Australian Independent Record Labels Association]]|access-date=18 August 2020}}</ref>\n|''Portrait of a Man'' \n| Best Independent Country Album\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===ARIA Music Awards===\nThe [[ARIA Music Awards]] are a set of annual ceremonies presented by [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA), which recognise excellence, innovation, and achievement across all genres of the [[music of Australia]]. They commenced in 1987. Blundell had been nominated for five [[ARIA Music Awards]] and has won one.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ariaawards.com.au/search?term=James%20Blundell|title = Search - ARIA}}</ref><ref name=\"CountryAlbum\">ARIA Award previous winners. {{cite web|url=http://www.ariaawards.com.au/history/award/Best-Country-Album|title=ARIA Awards Best Country Album|publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA)|access-date=9 April 2022}}</ref>\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 1991|1991]] || ''Hand it Down'' || [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]] || {{won}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 1992|1992]] || \"Time on His Hands\" || Best Country Album || {{nominated}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 1993|1993]] || ''This Road'' || Best Country Album || {{nominated}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 1994|1994]] || ''Touch of Water'' || [[ARIA Award for Best Adult Contemporary Album|Best Adult Contemporary Album]] || {{nominated}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2007|2007]] || Ring Around the Moon || Best Country Album || {{nominated}} \n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===APRA Awards===\nThe [[APRA Awards (Australia)|APRA Awards]] are held in Australia and New Zealand by the [[Australasian Performing Right Association]] to recognise songwriting skills, sales and airplay performance by its members annually. Blundell has been nominated for three awards and has won one.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apraamcos.com.au/search |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210207235410/https://www.apraamcos.com.au/search |url-status=dead |archive-date=7 February 2021 |title=APRA search - James Blundell |work=APRA Awards |publisher=apraamcos.com.au |date=26 March 2015 }}</ref>\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| 1992\n| \"Way Out West\" <small> (with [[James Reyne]]) </small>\n| Country Song of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 1999\n| \"Goondiwindi Moon\" <small> (with [[Lee Kernaghan]] and [[Garth Porter]]) </small>\n| Most Performed Country Work\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Awards of 2008|2008]]\n| \"Higher Than Heavan\"\n| Country Work of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Country Music Awards (CMAA)===\nBlundell has won ten [[Golden Guitar|Golden guitar]] awards at the [[Tamworth, New South Wales|Tamworth]] [[Country Music Awards of Australia]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://country.com.au/golden-guitars/award-winners/1990s |title=1990\u2032s :: Country Music Australia |access-date=21 February 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140125225402/http://country.com.au/golden-guitars/award-winners/1990s/ |archive-date=25 January 2014 |url-status=dead }}</ref> \nIn 2019, Blundell was inducted into the [[Australian Roll of Renown]], which honours Australian and New Zealander musicians who have shaped the music industry by making a significant and lasting contribution to Country Music.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tcmf.com.au/roll-of-renown |title=Roll of Renown |publisher=Tamworth Country Music Festival |access-date=29 October 2020 }}{{Dead link|date=February 2023 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2019-01-27/golden-guitars-wolfe-brothers-win-top-country-music-awards/10753724|title= Wolfe Brothers, Andrew Swift, Beccy Cole and Travis Collins win Golden Guitars|publisher=ABC|date=27 January 2019|access-date=27 January 2019 }}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}} <small>(wins only)</small>\n|-\n| 1987 || himself || Star Maker || {{won}}\n|-\n| 1988 || \"Song for Louise\" || New Talent of the Year || {{won}}\n|-\n| 1989 || \"Cloncurry Cattle Song\" || Male Vocalist of the Year || {{won}}\n|-\n| 1990 || \"Kimberley Moon\" || APRA Song of the Year || {{won}}\n|-\n| 1990 || \"Kimberley Moon\" || Male Vocalist of the Year || {{won}}\n|-\n| 1991 || \"Blue Heeler\" || APRA Song of the Year || {{won}}\n|-\n| 1991 || \"Age of Grace\" || Male Vocalist of the Year || {{won}}\n|-\n| 1993 || ''This Road'' || Top Selling album of the Year || {{won}}\n|-\n| 1993 || \"Way Out West\" <small> (with James Reyne) </small> || Vocal Group or Duo of the Year || {{won}}\n|-\n| 1994 || ''Touch of Water'' || Top Selling album of the Year || {{won}}\n|-\n| 2007 || himself || Hands of Fame Inductee || {{yes2|imprint}}\n|-\n| 2019 || himself || [[Australian Roll of Renown]] || {{yes2|inducted}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Mo Awards===\nThe Australian Entertainment Mo Awards (commonly known informally as the [[Mo Awards]]), were annual Australian entertainment industry awards. They recognise achievements in live entertainment in Australia from 1975 to 2016. James Blundell won one award in that time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.moawards.com.au/awardwinners|title=MO Award Winners|website=Mo Awards|access-date=16 March 2022}}</ref>\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n| 1989\n| James Blundell\n| Male Country Entertainer of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Queensland Music Awards===\nThe [[Queensland Music Awards]] (previously known as Q Song Awards) are annual awards celebrating [[Queensland, Australia]]'s brightest emerging artists and established legends. They commenced in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.queenslandmusicawards.com.au/about|title= About the Queensland Music Awards|website=Queensland Music Awards|access-date=21 March 2021}}</ref>\n\n{{Awards table}} <small>(wins only)</small>\n|-\n| [[Queensland Music Awards#2011 Queensland Music Awards|2011]]<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.queenslandmusicawards.com.au/past-winners/2011|title=Past Winners 2011|website=Queensland Music Awards|access-date=25 March 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://musicfeeds.com.au/news/photos-queesland-music-awards-2011-winners/#/slide/1|title= Photos Queensland Music Awards 2011 Winners|website=Music Feeds|date=August 2011|access-date=25 March 2021}}</ref>\n| \"Move into the City\"\n| Country Song of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2024<ref>{{cite web|url=https://themusic.com.au/industry/cub-sport-jem-cassar-daley-joff-bush-win-big-at-2024-queensland-music-awards/WYznTUxPTnE/17-04-24|title= Cub Sport, Jem Cassar-Daley & Joff Bush Win Big At 2024 Queensland Music Awards|website=[[The Music (magazine)|The Music]]|date=17 April 2024|access-date=18 April 2024}}</ref>\n| James Blundell\n| Grant McLennan Lifetime Achievement Award\n| {{yes2|awarded}}\n|-\n|}\n\n===Tamworth Songwriters Awards===\nThe Tamworth Songwriters Association (TSA) is an annual songwriting contest for original country songs, awarded in January at the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]]. They commenced in 1986.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsaonline.com.au/song-competition/|title=Tamworth Songwriters Association|website=Tamworth Songwriters Association Online|access-date=23 March 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsaonline.com.au/past-winners/|title=Tamworth Songwriters Association Past Winners|website=Tamworth Songwriters Association Online|access-date=23 March 2022}}</ref>\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n| 1988\n| \"Gidgee Pub Song\" by James Blundell \n| Comedy/Novelty Song of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n{{James Blundell (singer)}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Blundell, James}}\n[[Category:1964 births]]\n[[Category:ARIA Award winners]]\n[[Category:Australian country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Australian republicans]]\n[[Category:Katter's Australian Party politicians]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:People from Stanthorpe, Queensland]]\n[[Category:People educated at the Southport School]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Confederate_Railroad","to":"Confederate Railroad"}],"pages":{"3212043":{"pageid":3212043,"ns":0,"title":"Confederate Railroad","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American Southern rock band}}\n{{distinguish|Confederate railroads in the American Civil War}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name             = Confederate Railroad\n| image            = Confederate Railroad2019.jpg\n| image_size       = \n| caption          = Confederate Railroad in 2019.\n| alias            = Confederate RR\n| origin           = [[Atlanta, Georgia]], U.S.\n| genre            = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country rock]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://ultimateclassicrock.com/confederate-flag-rock-music/ |title=ROCK'S COMPLICATED HISTORY WITH THE CONFEDERATE FLAG |last=Irwin |first=Corey |date=June 14, 2020 |publisher=Ultimate Classic Rock |access-date=September 20, 2021}}</ref>\n}}\n| years_active     = 1987\u2013present<!--All Music Guide says 1987-->\n| label            = {{flatlist|\n* [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]]\n* [[Audium Entertainment|Audium]]\n* [[Shanachie Records|Shanachie]]\n* [[Koch Entertainment|E1 Music]]\n* D&B Masterworks\n}}\n| website          = {{URL|confederaterailroad.net}}\n| current_members  = * [[Danny Shirley]]\n* Rusty Hendrix\n* Mark DuFresne\n* Mo Thaxton\n| past_members     = * Jimmy Dormire\n* Chris McDaniel\n* Michael Lamb\n* Warren \"Gates\" Nichols\n* Cody McCarver\n* Bobby Randall\n* Wayne Secrest\n* Joey Recker\n}}\n'''Confederate Railroad''' (originally known as \"Confederate RR\") is an American [[country rock]] band founded in 1987 in [[Marietta, Georgia]], by [[Danny Shirley]] (lead vocals), Michael Lamb (lead guitar), Mark Dufresne (drums), Chris McDaniel (keyboards), Warren \"Gates\" Nichols (steel guitar), and Wayne Secrest (bass guitar). After serving as a backing band for [[outlaw country]] acts [[David Allan Coe]] and [[Johnny Paycheck]], the band signed to a recording contract with [[Atlantic Records]], releasing their self-titled debut album that year. In the 1990s, they released four more albums for Atlantic.\n\nConfederate Railroad has released six studio albums. In addition, 18 of their singles have entered the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts.\n\nThe band's most recent studio album, ''Lucky to Be Alive'', was issued on the D&B Masterworks label on July 15, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timesfreepress.com/news/life/entertainment/story/2016/jul/15/not-ready-retire-work-just-keeps-coming-confe/375866/|title=Hixson's Danny Shirley and the Confederate Railroad still in demand 40 years after his professional debut|date=15 July 2016 |access-date=2016-08-05}}</ref> The band released their first live album, ''Confederate Railroad Live: Back to the Barrooms'', on the [[Koch Entertainment|E1 Music]] label on June 15, 2010.\n\n==History==\nConfederate Railroad was founded in 1987 by [[Danny Shirley]], Michael Lamb, Gates Nichols (May 26, 1944 \u2013 August 14, 2009),<ref name=obit1/> Chris McDaniel, Wayne Secrest (April 29, 1950 \u2013 June 2, 2018),<ref name=obit2/> and Mark Dufresne. The six members began playing at bars in and around [[Atlanta, Georgia]], and Augusta, Georgia.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p33597}}</ref> Over time, they also worked as a road band for [[David Allan Coe]] and [[Johnny Paycheck]]. Shirley had previously been signed to the Amor [[record label]] as a solo singer, charting five times on the country charts between 1984 and 1988.<ref name=\"whitburnshirley\">{{cite book|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|publisher=Record Research, Inc.|year=2008|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2|page=380}}<!--|access-date=2009-10-06--></ref>\n\nAfter several years in the Atlanta area, the band signed with [[Atlantic Records]] in 1992 and released its [[Confederate Railroad (album)|self-titled]] debut album. The album produced six hit singles and was certified 2\u00d7 Platinum in the U.S.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> In 1993, Confederate Railroad was awarded Best New Group at the [[Academy of Country Music|ACM]] awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://countrymusic.about.com/library/reviews/aaprunleashed.htm|title=Who Is Country Star David Allan Coe?|access-date=2007-03-02|archive-date=2011-09-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928045419/http://countrymusic.about.com/library/reviews/aaprunleashed.htm|url-status=dead}}</ref> In order of release, these singles were \"She Took It Like a Man,\" \"Jesus and Mama,\" \"[[Queen of Memphis]],\" (their highest chart peak, at no.&nbsp;2) \"When You Leave That Way You Can Never Go Back,\" \"[[Trashy Women]],\" and \"She Never Cried.\"\n\n''[[Notorious (Confederate Railroad album)|Notorious]]'' was the band's second album. Released in 1994, it was certified platinum as well. The album was led off by the no.&nbsp;9 \"[[Daddy Never Was the Cadillac Kind]],\" followed by the no.&nbsp;20 \"Elvis and Andy,\" and finally \"Summer in Dixie,\" which failed to make Top 40. Also in 1994, Shirley and [[Mark Collie]] co-wrote and sang guest vocals on [[Billy Ray Cyrus]]'s \"Redneck Heaven,\" an album cut from his 1994 disc ''[[Storm in the Heartland]]''.<ref>{{Cite AV media notes |title=Storm in the Heartland |others=Billy Ray Cyrus |year=1994 |type=CD booklet |publisher=Mercury Records |id=314-526 081-2}}</ref>\n\nOne year later, the band released its third album, 1995's ''[[When and Where]]''. This album failed to sell as well as its predecessors, and was less successful on the charts as well. Lead-off single \"When and Where\" reached No.&nbsp;24, while the other three singles \u2013 \"Bill's Laundromat, Bar and Grill,\" \"When He Was My Age,\" and \"See Ya\" all failed to reach Top 40. A ''[[Greatest Hits (Confederate Railroad album)|Greatest Hits]]'' package followed in 1996.\n\nIn 1998, the band released its fourth and final studio album for Atlantic, titled ''Keep on Rockin'''. Its only two singles were \"The Big One\" and \"Cowboy Cadillac,\" both of which failed to reach the Top 60 on the country singles charts. After another compilation titled ''Rockin' Country Party Pack'' (which produced another chart single in \"Toss a Little Bone,\" previously from ''When and Where''), the band exited Atlantic.\n\nOne year later, Confederate Railroad signed to Audium/Koch Records (now [[E1 Music]]) for its fifth studio album, ''Unleashed''. It was led off by the no.&nbsp;39 \"What Brothers Do.\" Although this was the band's first Top 40 country hit since \"When and Where\" in 1995, the other singles \u2013 \"She Treats Her Body Like a Temple\" and \"White Trash with Money\" \u2013 both failed to reach Top 40.\n\nThe band did not record again until 2007's ''Cheap Thrills'', an album of [[cover song]]s. This album was led off by a cover of \"[[Please Come to Boston]],\" which failed to chart.\n\nConfederate Railroad members signed a record deal with E1 Music in 2010 and released their first-ever live album called \"Confederate Railroad Live: Back to the Barrooms.\" Cody McCarver of Confederate Railroad also signed to the label and has recently had success{{vague|date=April 2020}} with Confederate Railroad's song \"White Trash with Money\" which was written by Confederate Railroad's Danny Shirley with songwriter Buck Moore. The video by Cody also featured Jimmy Dormire who left Confederate Railroad in 2008. Cody McCarver released a single and video called \"I'm America.\"\n\nSince 2019, the band has missed bookings and had concerts cancelled because of concerns over the band's name and their logo's inclusion of two [[Confederate flag]]s. In cancelling their planned performance at the [[Ulster County, New York#Recreation|Ulster County Fair]], organizers said the event must represent \"the values of all members of our community\" and that \"showcasing of a symbol of division and racism runs counter to that principle.\"\n\nCritics say that the Confederate flag is a racist symbol, representing a [[United States Civil War|war to continue slavery]] and [[racial segregation in the United States]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Kaur |first=Harmeet |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/08/01/entertainment/confederate-railroad-name-backlash-trnd/index.html |title=Confederate Railroad says it won't change its name |publisher=CNN |date=2019-08-01 |access-date=2020-04-04}}</ref> The band said the cancellation was \"very disappointing\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.confederaterailroad.com/press-release.htm |title=Press release |publisher=Confederate Railroad |access-date=2020-04-04}}</ref> Shirley says the flag represents history and Southern heritage.<ref>{{cite web|agency=Associated Press |url=https://www.sj-r.com/news/20190725/country-band-confederate-railroad-nixed-from-another-fair |title=Country band Confederate Railroad nixed from another fair - News - The State Journal-Register - Springfield, IL |publisher=Sj-r.com |date=2019-07-25 |access-date=2020-04-04}}</ref>\n\nShirley blamed [[J. B. Pritzker|Governor J. B. Pritzker]]'s cancellation of the band from the [[DuQuoin State Fair]] lineup on [[political correctness]], which he says is focused on the band's name. The governor's office said that state resources could not be used \"to promote symbols of racism,\" specifying the Confederate flag in the group's logo.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Hudak |first=Joseph |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/confederate-railroad-band-name-canceled-shows-875639/ |title=Confederate Railroad Singer Talks Band Name Controversy |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=2019-08-23 |access-date=2020-04-04}}</ref>\n\nShirley suffered a broken back on April 1, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/danny-shirley-confederate-railroad-lead-singer-broken-back/|title = Danny Shirley, Confederate Railroad Lead Singer, Suffers Broken Back| date=April 2021 }}</ref>\n\nIn 2022, the band toured the US as a 4-piece band with Shirley on lead vocals and guitar, Rusty Hendrix on lead guitar, Mo Thaxton on bass and occasional lead vocals, and Mark DuFresne on drums.\n\n==Musical stylings==\nDescribed vocally as a \"gruff, reliable twanger,\"<ref name=\"new2\">{{cite journal |last=Dickinson |first=Chris |date=August 1995 |title=Confederate Railroad - ''When and Where'' review |journal=New Country |volume=2 |issue=10 |page=62}}</ref> lead singer Danny Shirley cites [[outlaw country]] acts such as [[Waylon Jennings]] as his major influence.<ref name=\"new\">{{cite journal |last=Mansfield |first=Brian |date=April 1994 |title=When Good Things Happen to Rough People: Confederate Railroad Stays on the Country Side of the Tracks |journal=New Country |volume=1 |issue=3 |pages=36\u201339}}</ref> According to him, the band's music is \"straight-ahead outlaw country,\"<ref name=\"new\"/> although their image has also drawn comparisons to [[Southern rock]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\nConfederate Railroad's novelty numbers, such as \"Trashy Women,\" show a tongue-in-cheek sense of humor. A reviewer for ''New Country'' magazine wrote that they are \"one of the few bands who can pull off a song about how they prefer trashy women and sound like they really mean it.\"<ref name=\"new2\"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tntbooking.com/bios/confederate_railroad.htm|title=T&T Management and Booking Agency - Confederate Railroad|website=www.tntbooking.com|access-date=2007-03-02|archive-date=2006-11-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061109111752/http://www.tntbooking.com/bios/confederate_railroad.htm|url-status=dead}}</ref> A more serious side of the band is shown in their ballads. Those on ''Notorious'', for instance, were described by ''New Country'' magazine as \"show[ing] men left stunned and confused by a world that changed faster than they could follow.\"<ref name=\"new\"/>\n\n==Member changes==\nLead guitarist Michael Lamb, one of the group's original members, left in the mid 1990s and was replaced with Jimmy Dormire.\n\nChris McDaniel, the original keyboardist, left and was replaced with Cody McCarver.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> McCarver has released a solo album, although he continued to tour as a member of Confederate Railroad up until his last performance with them at the Putnam County Fair in [[Eleanor, West Virginia]], on July 16, 2010. To Date, Cody has released 2 Country Music Albums & 4 Gospel Albums. He's also worked on some Western Independent Films and his most recent work was with [[John Schneider (screen actor)|John Schneider]] working on his album and being a costar in his movie \"Stand on It\" as well as the sequel \"Poker Run.\" He is currently on the road touring with John Schneider in his band where he also opens the show with his own music.\n\nIn June 2008, Jimmy Dormire announced that he was leaving Confederate Railroad to continue his solo career, though he continues as a member of Cody McCarver's band. Dormire was subsequently replaced by Rusty Hendrix, former side man for Mark Wills and Sammy Kershaw. Jimmy was part of the Cody McCarver band, and became a regular in the John Schneider band before joining to Country Band [[BlackHawk (band)|BlackHawk]] and the [[Outlaws (band)|Outlaws]] as a Full time Member.\n\nGates Nichols retired from Confederate Railroad in December 2008, and in July of the following year, he was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. He died from the disease on the morning of August 14, 2009, at the age of 65.<ref name=obit1>{{cite news|url=https://www.samclarkfuneralhome.com/obituary/Warren-Nichols|title=Welcome to the memorial page for Warren Nichols May 26, 1944 ~ August 14, 2009 (age 65)|website=samclarkfuneralhome.com |access-date=May 6, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.confederaterailroad.net/news.htm|title=Confederate Railroad - News|website=www.confederaterailroad.net}}</ref> Nearly two years later, in January 2011, Bobby Randall joined Confederate Railroad, playing steel guitar and fiddle for 6 years until his departure in 2017.\n\nIn October 2014, Mo Thaxton joined the group on the baritone,{{vague|date=August 2019}} bass and vocals. Thaxton was a member of the group [[Dr. Hook & the Medicine Show|Dr. Hook]] for 12 years prior to joining Confederate Railroad.\n\nJoey Recker began playing piano with the group in January 2017 after 28 years in the Armed Forces. He continued on with Confederate Railroad until he decided to depart the band December 2021 to be closer to his family and focus on his faith. He fronts the Joey & Shug Duo that does local music and a Southern Gospel band called Antioch-Southern Gospel.\n\nBassist Wayne Secrest retired from the band in October 2017. He died on June 2, 2018, after a long illness, at the age of 68.<ref name=obit2>{{cite news|url=https://www.pricebrothersfh.com/obituary/Wayne-Secrest|title=Wayne Allen Secrest April 29, 1950 ~ June 2, 2018 (age 68)|website=pricebrothersfh.com |access-date=May 7, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/177213/confederate-railroad-founding-member-wayne-secrest|title=Confederate Railroad Founding Member Wayne Secrest Dies At Age 68}}</ref>\n\n==Solo work==\nIn addition to his work in the band, frontman [[Danny Shirley]] made a guest appearance alongside [[Mark Collie]] on the song \"Redneck Heaven\" from [[Billy Ray Cyrus]]' 1994 album ''[[Storm in the Heartland]]'', a song which Collie and Shirley co-wrote. Danny Shirley has released 3 albums prior to starting the Confederate Railroad Band. His first, \"Local Legend,\" was released in 1984 on Amor Records. His second, \"Far From Over,\" and third \"I Make the Living\" albums were released in 1990 also on Amor. Danny released a 2 CD album featuring several of the songs from those 3 albums called \"The Pyramid Collection\" in 2005.\n\nCody McCarver released a self-titled solo album for the Aspirion label in 2006, which produced the singles \"Red Flag\" and \"Through God's Eyes.\" He released another single, \"Look What You've Done,\" in 2009. His 2010 single \"White Trash With Money\" was written by fellow band member Shirley along with songwriter Buck Moore. \"White Trash With Money\" was followed by \"I'm America.\" Since recording two country albums, Cody went on to release four gospel albums and is currently acting in films along with [[John Schneider (screen actor)|John Schneider]] and playing in Schneider's band.\n\nIn 2022, Bassist Mo Thaxton recorded a Bluegrass album \"The Mo Show\" that was released in 2023. He recorded 2 Railroad songs \"Don't feel as young as I used to\" & \"Between the rainbows and the rain\". This CD is only available at their shows and sold exclusively by Mo himself.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:14em;\"| Title\n! <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Kevin_Costner_&_Modern_West","to":"Kevin Costner & Modern West"}],"pages":{"26339434":{"pageid":26339434,"ns":0,"title":"Kevin Costner & Modern West","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country rock band}}\n{{Infobox musical artist  <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name                = Kevin Costner & Modern West\n| image               = Costner and Modern West, 2010.jpg\n| caption             =\n| image_size          = 250\n| landscape           = yes\n| background          = group_or_band\n| origin              =\n| genre               = [[Country rock]], [[country music|country]]\n| years_active        = 2007\u2013present\n| label               = [[Show Dog-Universal Music|Universal South]]\n| associated_acts     =\n| website             = [(hacked) redirects somewhere else Official Website]\n| current_members     = [[Kevin Costner]]<br/> John Coinman<br/> Teddy Morgan<br/> Blair Forward<br/> Larry Cobb<br/> Park Chisolm<br/> Luke Bulla<br/> Bobby Yang<br/> Roddy Chong\n| past_members        =\n}}\n\n'''Kevin Costner & Modern West''' is an American [[country rock]] band founded and fronted by actor [[Kevin Costner]]. He began a worldwide tour with the band in October 2007, which included shows in Istanbul and Rome. It also performed at NASCAR Sprint Cup Series races at Daytona International Speedway and Lowe's Motor Speedway in [[Concord, North Carolina]].\n\nThe band released its first country album, ''[[Untold Truths]]'', on November 11, 2008, on Universal South Records. It peaked at No.&nbsp;61 on the ''Billboard'' Top Country Albums chart and No.&nbsp;35 on the Top Heatseekers chart. Three singles (\"Superman 14\", \"Long Hot Night\" and \"Backyard\") have been released to radio, although none have charted. Videos were made for the songs \"Superman 14\", \"Backyard\" and \"Hey Man What About You\".\n\nIn 2009, Costner went on tour with the band and special guests The Alternate Routes. In August, at the Big Valley Jamboree in Camrose, Alberta, Costner and the band were scheduled next on stage when a severe thunderstorm struck, causing the stage and stands on the main stage to collapse. One person was reported dead and forty wounded.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2009/08/02/world/AP-CN-Canada-Stage-Collapse.html?_r=1 |title=1 Dead, 40 Injured in Canada Stage Collapse |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=August 2, 2009 |accessdate=August 2, 2009}}{{dead link|date=February 2014}}</ref> Later, an auction was held to raise money for the two young sons of the woman killed. A dinner with Costner was auctioned for $41,000. Two guitars, one autographed by Costner, helped raise another $10,000 each.<ref>{{cite news |first=Nick |last=Lees |title=Katz likely culprit behind mystery $41,000 bid |url=https://www.pressreader.com/canada/edmonton-journal/20090812/281882999355295 |work=Edmonton Journal |date=August 12, 2009 |page=B3}}</ref>\n\nIn February 2010, Kevin Costner & Modern West released their second album, ''Turn It On'', only in Europe. To support the album the band toured Europe, with ''Turn It On'' reaching the album charts in Germany, Austria, Switzerland and Greece. The first single from the album, \"Let Me Be the One\", with special guest Sara Beck singing with Costner, was also made as a music video. A third album, ''From Where I Stand'', was released in 2011 and included vocals from the German pop singer [[Nena]]. In April 2012, the band played a benefit gala for the [[Adrienne Arsht Center for the Performing Arts]] in Miami, Florida.\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Craig_Wayne_Boyd","to":"Craig Wayne Boyd"}],"pages":{"44675141":{"pageid":44675141,"ns":0,"title":"Craig Wayne Boyd","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country singer and songwriter|bot=PearBOT 5}}\n{{BLP sources|date=December 2014}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Craig Wayne Boyd\n| image           = Craigwayneboyd.jpg\n| caption         = Craig Wayne Boyd in 2014\n| birth_name      = Craig Wayne Boyd<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.buddytv.com/info/craig-wayne-boyd-info.aspx |title=Craig Wayne Boyd Biography |publisher=Buddytv.com |access-date=2015-08-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924041607/http://www.buddytv.com/info/craig-wayne-boyd-info.aspx |archive-date=2015-09-24 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = {{Birth date and age|1978|12|31}}<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/style-blog/wp/2014/12/17/the-voice-finale-why-craig-wayne-boyd-was-never-an-underdog/|title=\u2018The Voice\u2019 finale: Why Craig Wayne Boyd was never an underdog|last=Yahr|first=Emily|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=December 17, 2014|access-date=December 17, 2014}}</ref><ref name=\"birthdate\">{{cite web|last=Carter|first=Brooke|url=https://gazettereview.com/2017/03/happened-craig-wayne-boyd-news-updates/|title=What Happened to Craig Wayne Boyd \u2013 Now in 2018|work=Gazette Review|date=March 23, 2017|access-date=April 29, 2019}}</ref>\n| birth_place     = [[Mesquite, Texas|Mesquite]], Texas, United States\n| origin          =\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar\n| genre           = {{Flat list|\n* [[Country music|Country]]\n* [[country rock]]}}\n| occupation      = Singer\n| years_active    = 2004\u2013present\n| label           = {{Flat list |\n* [[Dot Records|Dot]]\n* [[Universal Republic Records|Universal Republic]]\n}}\n| associated_acts = [[Blake Shelton]]\n| website         = http://www.craigwayneboyd.com/\n}}\n'''Craig Wayne Boyd''' (born December 31, 1978)<ref name=\"birthdate\"/> is an American [[Country music|country]] singer and songwriter. A native of [[Dallas]], Texas, Boyd is based in and resides in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], Tennessee. He is best known for winning [[The Voice (American TV series) season 7|Season 7]] of [[NBC]]'s reality TV singing competition ''[[The Voice (American TV series)|The Voice]]'' as a part of [[Blake Shelton]]'s team.\n\n==Early life==\nBoyd was born on December 31, 1978, and raised in the Dallas suburb of [[Mesquite, Texas|Mesquite]].<ref name=\"birthdate\"/> He grew up influenced by gospel and country music. He played many instruments in his youth. He was also his church's choir director.\n\n==Career==\n===Early years===\nBoyd moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] at the age of 25 in 2004 to pursue a career in [[country music]]. Boyd was signed to a publishing deal with EMI. He spent many years songwriting. Boyd began touring, opening for acts such as [[Jamey Johnson]], [[Randy Houser]], and [[Brantley Gilbert]].\n\n===''The Voice'' (2014)===\nOn Sept. 30, 2014, Boyd debuted on [[The Voice (American TV series) season 7|7th season]] of ''[[The Voice (American TV series)|The Voice]]''. During his Blind Audition, Boyd sang \"[[The Whiskey Ain't Workin']]\" by [[Travis Tritt]] and [[Marty Stuart]].  Two coaches ([[Blake Shelton]] and [[Pharrell Williams]]) turned around. Boyd chose [[Blake Shelton]] as his coach.  During the Battle Rounds, Boyd was paired with James David Carter to sing \"[[Wave on Wave (song)|Wave on Wave]]\" by [[Pat Green]].  Coach Shelton chose Carter over Boyd, but Boyd was stolen by Coach [[Gwen Stefani]].  In the Knockout Rounds, Boyd was paired with [[Anita Antoinette]].  Boyd sang \"[[Can't You See (The Marshall Tucker Band song)|Can't You See]]\" by [[The Marshall Tucker Band]].  Boyd lost the round, but was stolen back by Coach Shelton and advanced to the Live Playoffs.  During the Live Playoffs, Boyd sang \"[[Some Kind of Wonderful (Soul Brothers Six song)|Some Kind of Wonderful]]\" and was saved by the Public's votes to advance to the Top 12.\nFor the week of the Top 12, Boyd performed \"[[You Look So Good in Love]]\" by [[George Strait]]. Boyd was saved by the public's votes.\nFor the week of the Top 10, Boyd performed \"[[I Walk the Line]]\" by [[Johnny Cash]]. Boyd was saved by the public vote with his performance in the Top 10 of the iTunes Chart.\nFor the week of the Top Eight, Boyd performed \"[[Take It Easy]]\" by the [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]]. Boyd was saved by the public vote and advanced to the Top Five.\nFor the week of the Semi-finals, Coach Shelton picked \"[[Workin' Man Blues]]\" by [[Merle Haggard]] for Boyd to sing and Boyd also sang \"[[The Old Rugged Cross]]\" which was in the iTunes Top 10. Boyd advanced to the finals.\nFor the week of the Finals, Boyd performed three songs. He performed \"[[In Pictures (song)|In Pictures]]\" by [[Alabama (American band)|Alabama]] as his solo song. He performed \"[[Boots On]]\" by [[Randy Houser]] as a duet with his coach [[Blake Shelton]]. He also performed an original song called \"[[My Baby's Got a Smile on Her Face]]\". The song was written for Shelton, but he decided to give it to Boyd. The song is Boyd's debut single.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/craig-wayne-boyd-my-babys-got-a-smile-on-her-face/ |title=Craig Wayne Boyd, \u2018My Baby\u2019s Got a Smile on Her Face\u2019 |publisher=Tasteofcountry.com |access-date=2015-08-08}}</ref>\n\nBoyd was declared the winner on December 16, 2014, giving [[Blake Shelton]]'s team its fourth win out of the seven Seasons. He beat out [[Matt McAndrew]], [[Chris Jamison]], and Damien, all three of whom were from Team [[Adam Levine]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Ashley Lee |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/voice-season-7-winner-craig-758718 |title='The Voice' Season 7 Winner Craig Wayne Boyd Named: Recap |publisher=Hollywood Reporter |date=2014-12-16 |access-date=2015-08-08}}</ref>\n\nShortly after winning the show and signing with [[Universal Republic Records|Universal Republic]] and [[Dot Records]], Boyd played at the Grand Ole Opry and went on a 65 city tour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/the-voice-craig-wayne-boyd-grand-ole-opry-debut/ |title='The Voice' Winner Craig Wayne Boyd Set for Opry Debut |publisher=Tasteofcountry.com |access-date=2015-08-08}}</ref><ref name=\"postShowTour\">{{cite web | url=http://www.axs.com/craig-wayne-boyd-winner-of-the-voice-live-at-the-snoqualmie-casino-bal-40732 | title=Craig Wayne Boyd, winner of 'The Voice' live at the Snoqualmie Casino Ballroom | first=Sue | last=Gabel | date=February 14, 2015 | access-date=December 15, 2015 | website=axs.com }}</ref> In early May 2015, following 6 weeks of rumors, it was reported that Boyd parted ways with Dot. Boyd released one single under Dot records \"My Baby\u2019s Got A Smile On Her Face\", which debuted at No. 1 on the Billboard Hot Country Songs. His second single \"I'm Still Here\" was released to iTunes under his own imprint \u2013 Long Haul Records. The song peaked at No. 35 on the Billboard Digital charts.<ref name=\"DotDropped\">{{cite web | url=http://www.mjsbigblog.com/voice-7-winner-craig-wayne-boyd-no-longer-signed-to-dot-recordsbig-machine-label-group.htm | title=UPDATED: \u2018Voice\u2019 7 Winner Craig Wayne Boyd No Longer Signed To Dot Records/Big Machine Label Group | date=May 5, 2015 | first=Deb | last=B | access-date=December 15, 2015 | website=mjsbigblog.com}}</ref>\n\n:{{Color box|gold|border=darkgray}} \u2013 Studio version of performance reached the top 10 on iTunes\n{| class=\"wikitable\" style=\"text-align:center; font-size:90%; line-height:16px;\"\n|-\n!
